Citigroup (NYSE:C)

John Gerspach - Chief Financial Officer and Member of Executive Committee

Vikram Pandit - Chief Executive Officer
column11:
Director and Member of Executive Committee

Operator

"
column30: and welcome to Citi's Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Review with Chief Executive Officer
column31: Vikram Pandit; and Chief Financial Officer
column32: John's Gerspach. Today's call will be hosted by John Andrews
column33: Head of Citi Investor Relations. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Andrews
column38: and thank you everyone this morning for joining us. On the call today
column40: Vikram will take us through the presentation
column41: initially
column42: followed by John Gerspach
column43: our CFO
column44: who will take you through the detailed deck
column45: which available on our website. Afterwards
column46:
they will be happy to take your questions.

"
column47:
"

Before we get started
column48: I would like to remind you that today's presentation may concern forward-looking statements
column49: which are based on management's current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors
column50: including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today and those included in our SEC filings
column52: the Risk Factors section of our 2009 Form 10-K. With that said and out of the way
column53:
let me turn it over to Vikram. Vikram?

"
column57: and good morning
column58: everybody. Thank you for joining us today. 2010 was a very good year for Citi. We made excellent progress in executing our strategy in every major area and
column59: as a matter of fact
column60: if you had said a year ago that we would have accomplished what we have
column61: I'm not so sure too many people would have believed it. Yet
column62: we were profitable in each quarter
column63: earning $10.6 billion for the year. Revenues increased for the quarter and for the year in two of our three core businesses
column64: which are Transaction Services and Consumer Banking
column65:
and Securities and Banking had strong full year results.

"
column66:
"

Entering 2010
column67:
our primary goal was to become consistently profitable and we achieved it. Another goal was to continue to reduce assets in Citi Holdings and we did so by $128 billion. Remaining assets are now 19% of our balance sheet and that's down from almost 40% of the balance sheet at their peak.

"
column68:
"

We also have been building for the future from opening branches in Asia to making new investments in technology to attracting top-notch talent to our consumer and Institutional businesses. And we're building a position of strength that will allow us to harness the world's growth trends. And of course
column69: the capstone to the year was the sale of the government's remaining shares of common stock. To date
column70:
U.S. taxpayers have earned a profit of approximately $12 billion on their investment in Citigroup and we'll always be grateful for the investment they made in our company and for standing by us through this financial crisis.

"
column71:
"

Specifically for the fourth quarter
column72: our client business and flows were solid across the board and we saw a strong growth in our consumer franchise
column73: especially outside the U.S. On the Institutional side
column74: although Transaction Services and Banking performed well
column75: revenues in markets reflected weaker trading performance. And of course
column76: we're happy to see our credit spreads improve as much as they did. That is a good sign. Not only of our progress
column77: but also it'll reduce our cost of borrowing over time. But of course
column78:
it means that we had to take $1.1 billion charge due to CVA.

"
column79:
"

For 2011
column80: we will build on the foundation we put in place and accelerate our strategy for Citicorp. We'll make investments to increase our lead in the emerging markets. We will seek to become a leader in digital banking and mobile payments. And we'll continue to recruit top talent
column81: building on the key hires we made last year. And we'll do so despite a challenging economic backdrop. The effects of the financial crisis are still working their way through the system
column82: and I think that macro trends will dominate micro trends
column83: especially for the next few quarters. And although there are positive signs in the U.S. economy
column84: the housing market yet has to recover
column85:
job creation has been weak and internationally excessive government leverage is still hampering recovery in the euro zone.

"
column86:
"

We continue to build our capital base
column87: our Tier 1 common ratio now stands at 10.7%
column88: up from 9.6% at the beginning of the year. Through earnings and reductions in Citi Holdings
column89: we have built  robust loan loss reserves of $40.7 billion. We have participated in the stress test with the regulators and
column90: subject to their guidance
column91:
we still expect to be in a position to return capital to our shareholders in 2012.

"
column92:
"

Summing up
column93: I believe we have the right business model
column94: the right strategy for our company's present and future
column95:
and we are executing with discipline. The economic environment remains uncertain but our path for the future is clear. We've steadily built a foundation capable of producing consistent profitability and our focus now is on achieving sustained and responsible growth.

"
column96:
"

With that
column97:
I'd like to turn this over to John Gerspach and then we'll come back later and take some of your questions.

"
column98:
"

John Gerspach

"
column99:
"

Thank you
column100: Vikram
column101: and good morning
column102: everyone. Starting on Slide 2. On a full year basis
column103: Citigroup reported revenues of nearly $87 billion for 2010. Operating expenses totaled $47.4 billion. Credit costs were $26 billion
column104: down 50% from prior year levels on a comparable basis. And for the full year
column105: we earned $10.6 billion in net income or $0.35 per diluted share. We earned nearly $15 billion in our core Citicorp business
column106:
with earnings in Asia and Latin America contributing more than half of the total. Citi Holdings generated a loss of $4.2 billion.

"
column107:
"

Now turning to the quarter on Slide 3. Citigroup reported fourth quarter net income of $1.3 billion or $0.04 per diluted share. These results were significantly affected by three factors. First
column108: CVA was a negative $1.1 billion as Citi spreads tightened in the fourth quarter
column109: particularly following the U.S. Treasury sale of its remaining Citi shares in December. Second
column110: revenues in Securities and Banking were lower due to weaker trading performance in the Fixed Income and Equities businesses. And third
column111: expenses were $12.5 billion
column112:
up 8% from the last quarter and above our prior guidance.

"
column113:
"

Of the expense increase
column114: more than half was due to the combined impact of foreign exchange and higher legal and related costs
column115: while the remainder was attributable to severance
column116: volume-related growth in certain businesses and continued investments. On the positive side
column117: credit continued to improve in the quarter
column118:
with net credit losses declining 11% to $6.9 billion and we recorded a net loan loss reserve release of $2.3 billion.

"
column119:
"

Turning now to Citicorp and Citi Holdings on Slide 4. Our credit costs continued to decline in each segment
column120: driven by improvements in both consumer and corporate credit. Citicorp reported revenues of $14.3 billion and net income of $2.4 billion. The underlying business drivers for Citicorp continued to show momentum in the fourth quarter. As an example
column121: for the second consecutive quarter
column122: we grew both consumer and corporate loans in Citicorp
column123: primarily in the emerging markets. Sequentially
column124: end of period consumer loans were up 3% and corporate loans grew 4%. Citi Holdings reported revenues of $4 billion and a net loss of $1 billion. Citi Holdings ended the year with $359 billion of assets
column125: down $62 billion during the quarter and $128 billion for the year
column126:
including the sale of Student Loan Corporation.

"
column127:
"

On Slide 5
column128: we show a nine-quarter trend for Citicorp's results. CVA was negative $1 billion for Citicorp in the fourth quarter compared to a positive $99 million last quarter. Excluding CVA
column129: Citicorp's revenues were $15.3 billion
column130: down 6% versus the prior quarter due to lower revenues in Securities and Banking. Operating expenses of $9.4 billion were up 6% versus the prior quarter
column131: roughly a quarter of the increase was due to the impact of foreign exchange. The remainder was primarily due to higher legal and related costs
column132:
volume-related growth and continued investments in our core businesses.

"
column133:
"

Citicorp's net credit losses were $2.7 billion
column134: down 12% from the previous quarter
column135: driven by Citi-Branded Cards in North America and lower corporate net credit losses. We released $741 million in net loan loss reserves
column136: up from $426 million in the third quarter
column137: as higher net releases in Citi-Branded Cards and our corporate portfolio were partially offset by lower releases in our International Consumer businesses. Excluding CVA
column138:
earnings before taxes declined 16% to $3.9 billion.

"
column139:
"

Slide 6 highlights our North America Consumer Banking business. Revenues of $3.6 billion were down 5% sequentially. Lower revenue in cards reflects a charge for enhancements to our thank you rewards program
column140: as well as the continued impact of CARD Act. Lower retail revenue was mainly due to lower refinancing gains in the mortgage business. Expenses were up 7% to $1.6 billion
column141: reflecting a one-time benefit in the prior quarter
column142: as well as higher legal and related costs. Credit costs declined 29% to $1.4 billion. Net credit losses were down 10% to $1.8 billion
column143:
due to continued improvement in Citi-Branded Cards and we recorded a $348 million net loan loss reserve release.

"
column144:
"

Net credit margin increased 1% to $1.8 billion as the decline in net credit losses more than offset lower revenues. While average loans were flat to slightly down versus the prior quarter
column145: end of period card loans were up 1% sequentially and retail loans were up 4%. In cards
column146: open accounts were stable versus the prior quarter and purchase sales grew 4% sequentially. While overall purchase sales declined versus last year
column147: due to a lower account base
column148:
sales per active account grew year-over-year for the fourth consecutive quarter.

"
column149:
"

Turning to Slide 7. Our International Consumer Banking businesses had revenues of $4.6 billion
column150: up 4% sequentially
column151: with growth across all regions. This growth reflects strong momentum in underlying business drivers
column152: as well as the impact of foreign exchange. Underlying revenue drivers were positive again this quarter. However
column153: revenue growth was muted as spreads remained under pressure. We grew our average deposits in every region during the quarter
column154:
and average loans grew 5% sequentially in both Asia and Latin America.

"
column155:
"

Card purchase sales were up 14% sequentially and investment sales grew 11%
column156: as strong growth in Asia and EMEA was offset by a decline in Latin America as customers continued to shift to longer-term securities. Expenses were $2.8 billion
column157: up 10% from the prior quarter
column158:
reflecting the impact of foreign exchange and continued investments in the business.

"
column159:
"

Credit costs were up 70% to $593 million
column160: driven by a lower net loan loss reserve release during the quarter. NCL dollars were stable. These credit trends reflect these regions being substantially further along in their economic recovery and
column161: hence
column162: much closer to a normalized credit environment than North America. On a rate basis
column163: international net credit losses continued to improve and NCL dollars were flat against the growing loan balance. Net credit margin increased 5% sequentially to $3.8 billion in the fourth quarter
column164:
driven by revenue growth.

"
column165:
"

Slide 8 shows nine quarters of business drivers and financial performance for international Consumer Banking. Following a period of repositioning in 2009
column166: we returned to growth across every significant metric in 2010
column167: reflecting both economic recovery in these regions
column168: as well as our renewed investment spending. Year-over-year
column169: average loans and deposits were up 12% and 11%
column170: respectively. Trends in card purchase sales and investment sales were also up
column171: with full year 2010 results above 2008 levels. This growth in underlying business drivers is reflected in our financial results. On a full year basis
column172: net credit margin of $14.3 billion in 2010 was up 21% over the prior year. And net income more than doubled
column173:
reflecting the additional benefit of loan loss reserve releases.

"
column174:
"

Slide 9 shows our Securities and Banking business. Excluding CVA
column175: revenues of $4.6 billion were down 17% from the third quarter
column176: driven by weaker revenues in fixed income and Equity Markets
column177: partially offset by growth in Investment Banking and lending revenues. In Investment Banking
column178: revenues grew 25% to $1.2 billion as significantly higher equity underwriting revenues
column179: driven by Asia IPO activity
column180:
and stable debt underwriting revenue were partially offset by a decline in M&A fees.

"
column181:
"

x CVA
column182: equity market revenues were $808 million. The $254 million sequential decline primarily reflects weaker trading revenues linked to our derivatives business and principal positions. Fixed Income market revenues x CVA were down 32% to $2.3 billion. The decline was primarily attributable to weaker performance in market-making activities to facilitate client needs. Lending revenues were $185 million compared to a negative $18 million in the prior quarter
column183:
driven by smaller hedge losses on continued spread tightening for corporate credits.

"
column184:
"

Private Bank revenues
column185: excluding CVA
column186:
were up 3% to $506 million.

"
column187:
"

On a regional basis
column188: revenues excluding CVA grew 8% sequentially in Latin America and 3% in Asia. Total operating expenses were up 2% versus the prior quarter. Credit costs were a benefit in the fourth quarter as net credit losses declined 54% to $132 million
column189:
and we released $194 million in net loan loss reserves.

"
column190:
"

Moving to Transaction Services on Slide 10. Revenues of $2.6 billion were up 1% from the third quarter
column191: driven by growth in Asia and Latin America. Treasury and Trade Solutions was down 1%
column192: as higher trade revenues increased deposits and higher fees were more than offset by spread compression. Securities and Fund Services grew 6% sequentially
column193: driven by higher volumes. Overall
column194: transaction volumes and new mandates remain strong across both businesses during the quarter. Asset growth was driven by trade finance
column195:
with end of period trade assets up 14% sequentially and nearly double versus last year.

"
column196:
"

Average deposits grew 4% sequentially to $353 billion
column197: and assets under custody were up 2% to $12.6 trillion. Expenses of $1.3 billion were up 7% from last quarter
column198:
reflecting both higher volumes and continued investment to support the business.

"
column199:
"

Slide 11 shows Citi Holdings assets. We ended the quarter with $359 billion in Citi Holdings or 19% of total Citigroup assets. The $62 billion reduction in the fourth quarter was comprised of $48 billion of asset sales and business dispositions
column200: including $31 billion from Student Loan Corporation and $10 billion of sales from the Special Asset Pool
column201:
approximately $12 billion of net runoff and pay downs and $2 billion of net cost of credit and net asset marks.

"
column202:
"

On Slide 12
column203:
we show a nine quarter trend for Citi Holdings results. We narrowed the loss in Citi Holdings to $1 billion in the fourth quarter. Revenues were up 3% to $4 billion as higher revenues in Brokerage and Asset Management and the Special Asset Pool were offset by a decline in Local Consumer Lending. Expenses were up 7% to $2.4 billion and credit costs were down 13% to $2.9 billion.

"
column204:
"

Looking at Citi Holdings in more detail on Slide 13. Revenues in Brokerage and Asset Management were up sequentially to $136 million
column205: reflecting a higher contribution from the Morgan Stanley Smith Barney joint venture. In Local Consumer Lending
column206: revenues were down 4% sequentially to $3.4 billion
column207: as gains on asset sales were more than offset by lower revenues on a declining loan balance
column208: as well as the refund reserve build related to our consumer finance business in Japan. In the Special Asset Pool
column209: revenues were up 36% to $426 million in the fourth quarter
column210:
mainly due to higher gains on asset sales during the quarter.

"
column211:
"

Expenses were up 7% sequentially to $2.4 billion
column212: reflecting higher legal and related costs and severance. Credit costs were down 13% sequentially as credit trends continued to improve in both our consumer and corporate portfolios. Total net credit losses were down 10% to $4.2 billion and the net loan loss reserve release was down slightly to $1.5 billion. Local Consumer Lending continues to drive the earnings performance of Citi Holdings
column213:
with $1.1 billion net loss for the quarter.

"
column214:
"

Slide 14 shows the results for the Corporate/Other segment. Revenues declined by $450 million sequentially
column215: reflecting lower gains on sales of AFS Securities. Net income also reflects higher operating expenses during the quarter. Expenses were up by $286 million sequentially
column216: mainly due to legal and related costs. Assets of $272 billion include approximately $92 billion of cash and cash equivalents
column217:
and $124 billion of liquid available-for-sale Securities.

"
column218:
"

Slide 15 shows total Citigroup net credit losses and loan loss reserves. NCLs continued to improve
column219: down 11% sequentially to $6.9 billion and the net loan loss reserve release grew 14% to $2.3 billion. We ended the year with $40.7 billion of total loan loss reserves and our LLR ratio was 6.3%. Consumer NCLs declined 8% sequentially to $6.2 billion
column220:
and we released $1.3 billion in net loan loss reserves.

"
column221:
"

Corporate credit was a benefit of $256 million in the fourth quarter compared to a cost of $347 million last quarter. Corporate net credit losses declined 28% to $664 million and the net loan loss reserve release grew to $920 million. Corporate non-accrual loans of $8.6 billion were down 13% versus the prior quarter.

"
column222:
"

Moving to consumer credit trends on Slide 16. As I mentioned
column223: consumer net credit losses of $6.2 billion were down 8% sequentially
column224: with continued improvement in North America cards and real estate. Our net credit loss ratio declined again this quarter to 5.3% and our loan loss reserve ratio was 7.8%. In North America
column225: net credit losses declined 9% to $5.1 billion
column226:
while international net credit losses declined by 6% to $1.1 billion.

"
column227:
"

Slide 17 shows our International Consumer credit trends. In Citicorp
column228: NCL improvement on a dollar basis is slowing down as we grow our international loan portfolios. However
column229: on a rate basis
column230: we continued to see NCL improvement in both Asia and Latin America. In Asia
column231: India continued to show the most significant improvement in both NCLs and delinquencies. For the region
column232: 90-plus day delinquencies were relatively flat on a dollar basis and down as a percentage of loans. In Latin America
column233: NCLs improved on a rate basis
column234: driven by cards in Brazil and Mexico
column235:
and 90-plus day delinquencies also improved.

"
column236:
"

Now on Slide 18
column237:
we focus on North America cards.

"
column238:
"

Trends for both Citi branded and Retail Partner Cards continued to reflect the improving credit quality of these portfolios. In Citi-Branded Cards
column239:
NCLs declined for the third consecutive quarter. NCLs decreased by 11% to $1.7 billion and 90-plus day delinquencies were down 12% to $1.6 billion.

"
column240:
"

In Retail Partner Cards
column241: NCLs were down for the sixth consecutive quarter. NCLs decreased by 10% to $1.4 billion and 90-plus day delinquencies declined by 8% to $1.6 billion. For both portfolios
column242:
early-stage delinquencies also continued to show improvement.

"
column243:
"

Turning to the mortgage portfolio in Citi Holdings on Slide 19. NCLs and 90-plus day delinquencies in both first and second mortgages improved again this quarter. We continue to manage down these portfolios. Compared to the fourth quarter of last year
column244: we reduced our first mortgage portfolio by almost 20% to $80 billion and second mortgages were down 14% to $44 billion
column245: through a combination of sales
column246:
runoff and net credit losses. Our total loan loss reserve balance for mortgages in Citi Holdings currently represents over two years of NCL coverage.

"
column247:
"

Slide 20 provides more detail on the delinquency trends in first mortgages in Citi Holdings. 30-plus day delinquencies were down for the fifth consecutive quarter. Delinquencies declined by 15% to $9.9 billion
column248: with improvement across all buckets. Similar to last quarter
column249: the sequential decline in delinquencies was due entirely to asset sales and trial mods converting to permanent modifications
column250:
absent which delinquencies would be up slightly.

"
column251:
"

During the fourth quarter
column252: we sold $1.5 billion in delinquent mortgages
column253:
bringing our total sales of delinquent mortgages for the year to $4.8 billion. Mortgage sales served to reduce our overall delinquency inventory. They also eliminate any future risk of default as compared to modifications.

"
column254:
"

Through the end of the year
column255: we had converted a total of $4.8 billion of trial mods to permanent modifications
column256: more than three quarters of which were HAMP. We continue to believe that redefault rates for HAMP modified loans will be significantly lower versus non-HAMP programs. The first HAMP mods have now been on the books for about 12 months and
column257: to date
column258:
are exhibiting redefault rates of less than 15%.

"
column259:
"

On Slide 21
column260: we provide an update on rep and warranty issues. The chart on the left shows claims and repurchase activity on a unit basis. Over the past three years
column261: we have received claims on roughly 20
column262: 400 unindemnified loans. At year end
column263: nearly 4
column264: 600 of those claims remained pending
column265: which was slightly lower than our pending claim volume at the end of the third quarter. Of the roughly 15
column266: 800 claims which have been resolved
column267: approximately 7
column268:
600 or nearly 50% were actually repurchased or made whole.

"
column269:
"

Based on our current expectations
column270: we believe claims volumes should peak in the latter part of 2011. The right side of this slide shows a roll forward of the repurchase reserve for our Consumer Mortgage business. We began the fourth quarter with approximately $952 million of repurchase reserves. We added approximately $4 million of reserves
column271: arising from new mortgage sales in the fourth quarter
column272: and another $248 million related to changes in our estimate of average loss per claim. These additions to the reserve were charged to our P&L during the quarter as contra revenue. We realized approximately $235 million of losses during the quarter
column273: which were charged against the reserve. As a result
column274:
we ended the year with $969 million in mortgage repurchase reserves.

"
column275:
"

Slide 22 shows the trend in our key capital metrics. We ended the year with a Tier 1 ratio of 12.9% and a Tier 1 Common ratio of 10.7%. Our Tier 1 Common ratio grew approximately 40 basis points during the quarter
column276: reflecting a 1% increase in Tier 1 Common capital to $105 billion and a 2% reduction in risk-weighted assets
column277: due in part to the continued wind down of Citi Holdings. On a year-over-year basis
column278:
our GAAP assets grew 3% while we reduced our risk-weighted assets by 10%.

"
column279:
"

In summary
column280: our performance in 2010 creates a strong foundation for sustainable growth. Where 2009 was focused on recapitalizing the firm and putting into place our new strategy
column281: 2010 saw our return to profitability as we earned nearly $15 billion in our core Citicorp business while we cut losses in Citi Holdings by more than half. The strength of our international franchise was particularly apparent in 2010
column282: with Asia and Latin America earning over $8 billion
column283: a 14% increase versus 2009. And that growth and profitability was achieved while continuing to invest in these regions. We made significant progress in reducing Citi Holdings
column284: with assets declining $128 billion or 26% versus 2009. Today
column285:
Citi Holdings represents only 19% of total Citigroup assets.

"
column286:
"

Two consistent themes drove our performance in 2010. First
column287: global credit continued to recover
column288: with six consecutive quarters of sustained improvement in credit costs. And second
column289: we began increasing our investment spending in international businesses as the pace of economic recovery accelerated in these regions
column290:
resulting in strong growth in our underlying business drivers.

"
column291:
"

Finally
column292: our consistent profitability
column293: combined with the ongoing wind down of Citi Holdings
column294: contributed to our strong balance sheet. We ended 2010 with a Tier 1 Common ratio of 10.7%
column295: up approximately 110 basis points from last year
column296: making us one of the best capitalized large banks in the world. We remain confident
column297: based on what we know today
column298:
that we will be well above the Basel III capital requirements and above the 8% to 9% on a Tier 1 Common basis in 2012.

"
column299:
"

Now I'd like to discuss some factors which may affect our results in 2011. In Regional Consumer Banking
column300: we believe results will be driven by different trends in North America versus our international businesses. In North America
column301: if economic recovery is sustained
column302: revenues are expected to grow modestly as loan demand begins to recover
column303: particularly in the second half of the year. However
column304: net credit margin recovery will likely continue to be driven primarily by improvement in net credit losses. As always
column305:
loan loss reserve balances will continue to reflect the losses embedded in the portfolio.

"
column306:
"

Internationally
column307: we have seen the improvement in net credit losses slowing as the loan portfolios grow. Given continued economic expansion in these regions
column308: net credit margin is more likely to be driven by revenue growth
column309:
particularly in the second half of the year. As our investment spending should continue to generate volume growth to outpace spread compression.

"
column310:
"

International credit costs are likely to increase in 2011
column311: reflecting a growing loan portfolio. In Securities and Banking
column312: our continued investments served to build on an already strong foundation for future growth. The strength of our franchise should be evident in 2011
column313: as it was in our full 2010 results. Overall
column314:
Securities and Banking will continue to reflect trends in client activity and global market conditions.

"
column315:
"

In Local Consumer Lending in Citi Holdings
column316: revenue should continue to decline
column317: given a shrinking loan balance resulting from pay downs and continued asset sales. Based on current delinquency trends and ongoing loss mitigation actions
column318: we expect credit costs to continue to improve in Local Consumer Lending. Regarding expenses
column319: we expect 2011 expense levels to be in line with our 2010 guidance at $48 billion to $50 billion for the year
column320:
with some variability across quarters as we continue investing in Citicorp while rationalizing Citi Holdings.

"
column321:
"

That concludes our review of the quarter. And Vikram and I will now open up the line for questions.

"
column322:
"

Question-and-Answer Session

"
column323:
"

Operator

"
column324:
"

[Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Guy Moszkowski with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

"
column325:
"

Guy Moszkowski - BofA Merrill Lynch

"
column326:
"

I was hoping that maybe you could quantify how much of the linked quarter's increase in expenses actually was litigation
column327:
which was one of the primary factors you noted?

"
column328:
"

John Gerspach

"
column329:
"

If you think in terms of the way it breaks down
column330: about $150 million of the increase was due to foreign exchange
column331: about $400 million more or less was legal and related matters
column332:
$100 million was severance and restructuring and about $150 million each of investment and volume driven growth.

"
column333:
"

Guy Moszkowski - BofA Merrill Lynch

"
column334:
"

Within Securities and Banking
column335: did the expense increase in comp
column336: which I know you don't break out
column337: did that pretty much reflect -- well
column338: actually
column339:
I should phrase it differently. Did the comp reflect the decline in revenue or was it also up sequentially?

"
column340:
"

John Gerspach

"
column341:
"

Well
column342: as you said
column343: Guy
column344: we don't breakout comp for any of our individual businesses. But
column345: obviously
column346: our comp considerations reflect performance for the full year. Throughout the year
column347:
we do our best to estimate what we think we're going to be paying out. So we take all of that into consideration.

"
column348:
"

Guy Moszkowski - BofA Merrill Lynch

"
column349:
"

I guess what I'm trying to get at is whether there would've been a significant increase in litigation type expenses within S&B.

"
column350:
"

John Gerspach

"
column351:
"

There was some contribution in S&B of litigation
column352:
but I wouldn't say that S&B was the primary driver behind the $400 million that I talked about earlier.

"
column353:
"

Guy Moszkowski - BofA Merrill Lynch

"
column354:
"

column374: quite frankly

Bigger picture question. I mean
column716: we look at all the data we're getting on kind of the emerging markets in the international franchise and it seems loans are growing
column717: revenues are growing
column718: credit seems okay
column719:
but there's a lot of things going on in the world from currencies to what's going on in Europe. Can you give us any sense on what you're seeing kind of on the ground with some of the emerging markets as far as the kind of near-term continuation of growth prospects?

"
column720:
"

Vikram Pandit

"
column722: first of all
column724: that is a broad group. We know what's happening in certain areas. You see it in South Africa
column725: you see it in China
column726: which is the growth in inflation there. And especially those countries that don't have a flexible currency are seeing more of that and there is growth adjustment there
column727: as a resultl of these changes. But I would say that the underlying dynamics of the consumers in these markets and the growth models actually finding a real kind of a solid development model has not really changed. And so we expect to see a continued increase in loan demand. We expect to see continued increase in capital markets activities. We expect to see continued growth
column728: not only in the Asian markets
column729: but also in the Latin American and some of the African markets. Some of the Eastern European markets are still linked to Europe and that is a longer process. But we remain constructive on the emerging markets
column730: understanding that monetary tightening and other kind of breaks may have to be put on from time to time to manage the overheating that can occur and the inflation that occurs. I think the real question still keeps coming back to the U.S. economy
column731: in our view
column732: and what kind of growth you're going to see and what's going to happen to housing prices and it is still the largest economy in the world and that is going to be something the markets are going to have to watch over the next two
column733: three quarters. And that's why I think
column734: when I started
column735: I said that the macro still going to dominate the micro here for the next two
column736:
three quarters.

column1026: we comment on the fact that we were deliberately liquid at that point in time and we felt that it was prudent to remain liquid throughout 2010. That gives us a certain amount of flexibility for two things. One

column27: and welcome to Citi's First Quarter 2011 Earnings Review with Chief Executive Officer
column28: Vikram Pandit; and Chief Financial Officer
column29: John Gerspach. Today's call will be hosted by John Andrews
column30: Head of Citi Investor Relations. [Operator Instructions] Also
column31: as a reminder this conference call is being recorded today. If you have any objections

column39: for joining us today. On the call

column42: the CFO will take you through the earnings presentation
column43: which is available for download on our website
column44: citigroup.com. Afterwards
column45:
we'll be happy to take your questions.

column47: I would like to remind you that today's presentation may contain forward-looking statements
column48: which are based on management's current expectations and thus
column49: subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today and those included in our SEC filings
column50:
including without limitation the Risk Factor section of our 2010 Form 10-K.

column51:
"

With that out of the way
column52:
let me turn it over to Vikram.

column57: everyone. Thank you very much for joining us today. As you know
column58: last year was our first year of profitability since the financial crisis and we continue to make progress in 2011. We earned $3 billion this quarter
column59: more than double what we earned last quarter. Revenues were up 7% and expenses were down 1%. The environment has been challenging
column60: low interest rates are compressing spreads and we continue to carry large amounts of liquidity. But we believe this is a cyclical
column61: not a secular issue. Our core businesses performed well despite the environment
column62: with Citicorp earning $4.1 billion for the quarter and Citicorp Consumer and Corporate loans grew on a combined basis by 10% year-over-year
column63: and pretax earnings in Citicorp were almost evenly split between the emerging and developed markets
column64:
reflecting our deep roots in the 160 countries where we do business.

"

column66: our client business in Securities and Banking was strong
column67: although down from one year ago. Revenues in lending
column68: equities and Fixed Income rebounded strongly from the previous quarter. Client activity in our Global Transaction Services was also strong. We had higher transaction volumes
column69: deposits
column70:
trade finance loans and we have a strong pipeline going forward.

"
column71:
"

In both U.S. and international Consumer Banking
column72: net income was up from the last quarter and the first quarter of 2010. Net credit losses declined 31% from the first quarter last year. Internationally
column73: average deposits and loan increased 13% and 14%
column74: respectively
column75: from a year ago and credit trends continue to improve. Throughout our franchise
column76:
we are focused on adding high performance assets and we remain very selective about the assets we put on our books.

"
column77:
"

We continue to divest non-core assets in Citi Holdings
column78: with a $22 billion decrease in the first quarter
column79: total assets in Holdings stand at $337 billion
column80: down from 33% from one year ago. Citi Holdings assets are now at about 17% of our total balance sheet. And losses in Citi Holdings
column81: this quarter
column82: the loss was $608 million
column83:
down from 31% from the prior year.

column84:
"

These results helped improve our financial strength. Our Tier 1 Common ratio increased to 11.3% and our tangible book value increased to $4.69 per share
column85: up $0.24 per share from last quarter and up 15% from a year ago. We're also building for the future. We're making substantial investments in our businesses in Citicorp. In the first quarter
column86: investments exceeded $500 million
column87: including technology
column88: branches
column89: marketing and new corporate and investment banking hires. In addition
column90:
we're building our Commercial Banking business.

"
column91:
"

Lastly
column92: we announced a 1-for-10 reverse stock split
column93:
to be effective on the morning of May 9. We also announced our intention to reinstate a dividend of $0.01 per share in the second quarter. These are meaningful steps as we anticipate returning capital to our shareholders next year.

"
column94:
"

We will continue to execute on our strategy with discipline
column95:
reduce assets in Holdings and invest in key markets in our core businesses. I believe that we've demonstrated that we're consistently profitable and we're now focused on responsible growth.

column278: and our Tier 1 Common ratio grew over 50 basis points to 11.3%. We also have over $36 billion of loan loss reserves. Based upon what we know today
column279: we remain confident that we are on track to operate in the 8% to 9% Tier 1 Common range under Basel III in 2012. And assuming we have clarity on capital rules
column280: we still expect to be in a position to begin returning capital to shareholders next year. Now
column281:
I'd like to discuss some factors that may affect our results for the remainder of 2011.

In North America Consumer Banking

column284: we will further increase our investments in the business. In international Consumer Banking
column285: net credit margin is more likely to be driven by revenue growth

column288: reflecting a growing loan portfolio. In Local Consumer Lending in Citi Holdings

column290: as we've seen in the first quarter
column291: the pace of decline in Citi Holdings assets has moderated. Regarding expenses

column293: with some variability across quarters as we continue investing in Citicorp
column294: while rationalizing Citi Holdings. Certain expenses
column295:

There's a certain cycle that goes on in those economies and we're in one of those cycles right now.

column762: you're going to see reduced income from Citi Holdings assets. Now at the same point in time
column763: we are actively growing the earnings assets in Citicorp. Again
column764: loan growth in Citicorp
column765: 10% year-over-year. Loan growth in our consumer business
column766: in Latin America
column767: 17% year-over-year. Loan growth in Asia
column768: 16% year-over-year. So all of those are earning assets that you should start to see replacing the revenue
column769: the interest revenue that's being lost by Citi Holdings. It's a matter of pacing as far as the rate of decline in one and the rate of growth in the other. But we would actually think that over time
column770: the mix of our business is going to be more towards the model that Vikram laid out 2-plus years ago
column771: which is roughly 1/3 from Securities and Banking
column773: I guess
column774: call trading; 1/3 from a consumer business; and then 1/3 out of services
column775: we call services Transaction Services
column777:
et cetera. So that is the Citicorp that we are trying to grow. And I'm sorry if I confused you.

"
column778:
"

Richard Bove - Rochdale Securities LLC

"
column779:
"

No
column780: I understand. But right now
column781: almost 2/3 of the revenue are coming from one source and that's net interest income and from what I've heard
column782: I don't see how net interest margins are going to go up any time soon. And if you will
column783: reduction in the size of Citi Holdings
column784: is equal to or greater than the increase in the loans from emerging markets
column785: your earning assets are going to continue to decline. So you got a 16% year-over-year decline in net interest income. And at some point
column786:
that number is simply going to go up or your earnings are not going to go up.

"
column787:
"

John Gerspach

"
column788:
"

Let's talk about two separate concepts. Net interest revenue
column789: gross dollars and then net interest margin percentage. Net interest margin
column790: as I said before
column792: will stay under pressure for at least the next quarter due to some factors. Whether that's the continued spread compression that we're seeing and also
column793: then I've got the FDIC additional assessments. But then
column794: in answer to somebody else
column795: net interest margins should look to stabilize. That's the percentage. Net interest revenue
column796: and again
column797: I don't want to start forecasting net interest revenue. But net interest revenue as we grow those loan volumes in Citicorp
column798: at that growth
column799:
the absolute growth begins then to overtake the declines in the Citi Holdings assets. Then you should start to see some growth even on the net interest line.

"
column800:
"

Richard Bove - Rochdale Securities LLC

"
column801:
"

Okay. Thank you.

"
column802:
"

Operator

"
column803:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Mike Mayo with CLSA.

"
column804:
"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (USA) Inc.

"
column805:
"

Just some clarification on the OCI
column806:
it went up a lot this quarter and that helped tangible book value. What's the key driver there and should we expect similar volatility in OCI in the future?

"
column808:
"

Yes
column809: Mike
column810: two big drivers on OCI. One is the asset transfer that I mentioned earlier. That was $1.1 billion favorable impact to OCI. And then the other significant impact on OCI would be cumulative translation adjustments
column811:
FAS 52 adjustments. And that benefited us about $0.04 in tangible book value.

"
column812:
"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (USA) Inc.

"
column813:
"

And then a separate question
column814: why are you guys doing the reverse stock split? We all have our reasons why you might be doing it
column815:
but I'm not sure we heard directly from you.

"
column816:
"

Vikram Pandit

"
column817:
"

I think
column818: Mike
column819: we're pretty clear in our public press releases and other communications. We've got a couple of reasons and one of them is that -- and you've got to talk about not only the stock split
column820: but also our intention in the second quarter to reinstate a
column821: albeit a nominal
column822: dividend . And there are some clientele reasons
column823: one
column824: there are a number of clients who can't buy stocks at either $5 or $10 per share or below those. And then there are some who can't buy a stock without some dividend
column825: those are some of the obvious ones. In addition to that
column826: we do think that it could have an impact using volatility of the stock as the stock prices at a different level. I would also tell you that post the reverse split
column827:
both the number of shares outstanding and the stock price are closer to our peers.

"
column828:
"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (USA) Inc.

"
column829:
"

And then lastly
column830: S&P put on negative watch
column831:
U.S. Government debt. How do you think about the potential implications of that change and that would go to maybe the securities you have in your balance sheet or some other activities. How do you think about protecting yourself?

"
column832:
"

Vikram Pandit

"
column834: we're glad we're in 100-plus countries to start with because there is a level of diversification that goes with that. And in line with what our clients need because what that says is
column835: that we really look at our entire balance sheet
column836: that's the first point. The second point is that I haven't really looked at what S&P said this morning
column837: so I don't really have any deeper insight against what we said. But I'd also tell you
column838:
I have full confidence in our administrative and our legislative policies to get our country to the right place.

"
column839:
"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (USA) Inc.

"
column840:
"

All right. Thank you.

"
column842:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Carole Berger with Soleil Securities.

"
column843:
"

Carole Berger - Soleil Securities Group
column845:
"

Bank of America took a charge on their MSRs [Mortgage Servicing Rights] this quarter
column846: citing of the settlement with the regulators and the higher costs going forward for servicing. I know you didn't discuss it
column847: but how do you view higher servicing costs
column848:
was there an embedded charge that was material or immaterial in the quarter?

"
column849:
"

John Gerspach

"
column850:
"

Yes
column851: Carole
column852: we've taken a look at the consent order
column853: and frankly
column854: we identified improvements that needed to be made in our mortgage servicing operation back in 2009. And so we're actively working on improving servicing dating back to the fourth quarter of that year. As a matter of fact
column855: we had most of the improvements in place by February 2010. Now the consent order does contain some additional things that we'll have to address. But as we've looked at the impact of the consent order
column856:
we've estimated that it'll have about a $25 million to $30 million annual increase in expenses for us. So really not that much and we don't expect it to have much of an impact on our MSR asset.

"
column857:
"

Carole Berger - Soleil Securities Group
column858:
Inc.

"
column859:
"

And what are you carrying your MSRs at now?

"
column860:
"

John Gerspach

"
column864: so we've got a mortgage servicing book of about $440 billion
column865:
so it's like $4.7 billion.

"
column866:
"

Carole Berger - Soleil Securities Group
column867:
Inc.

"
column868:
"

Thank you.

"
column869:
"

Operator

"
column870:
"

And you have no further questions at this time.

"
column871:
"

John Andrews

"
column872:
"

Great. Thank you
column873: everyone

column875:
thanks.

{"Citigroup's CEO Discusses Q2 2011 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Citigroup (NYSE:C)

"
column6:
"

Vikram Pandit - Chief Executive Officer and Director

"
column7:
"

John Gerspach - Chief Financial Officer

"
column13:
"

Ed Najarian - ISI Group Inc.

"
column15:
"

John McDonald - Sanford C. Bernstein & Co.
column18:

Guy Moszkowski - BofA Merrill Lynch

James Mitchell - Buckingham Research Group
column21:
"

Moshe Orenbuch - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse AG

"
column22:

Gerard Cassidy - RBC Capital Markets
column24:
"

Glenn Schorr - Nomura Securities Co. Ltd.

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (NYSE:USA) Inc.

Matthew O'Connor - Deutsche Bank AG

Operator

column29:
"

Hello and welcome to the Citi Second Quarter 2011 Earnings Review with Chief Executive Officer Vikram Pandit and Chief Financial Officer John Gerspach. Today's call will be hosted by John Andrews
column30: Head of Citi Investor Relations. [Operator Instructions] Also as a reminder
column31: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column32: please disconnect at this time. Mr. Andrews
column37: and good morning to everybody. Thank you for joining us this morning. On the call today
column40: who will give you an overview of the quarter. And then John Gerspach
column41: our CFO
column42: will take you through the earnings presentation
column43: which is available for download on our website
column44: www.citigroup.com. Afterwards
column45:
we will be happy to take your questions.

"
column46:
"

Before we get started
column47: I would like to remind you that today's presentation may contain forward-looking statements which are based on management's current expectation and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results and capital and other financial condition may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors
column48: including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today and those included in our SEC filings and including
column49: without limitation
column50:
the Risk Factors section of our 2010 Form 10-K.

"
column51:
"

With that out of the way
column52:
now let me turn it over to Vikram.

"
column56: everybody. Thank you for joining us today. We announced earnings of $3.3 billion for the second quarter
column57:
which brings our total net income for the first half to $6.3 billion. This was another solid quarter of operating performance as we continue to execute our strategy and invest in our franchise.

"
column58:
"

Loans grew throughout our core businesses in the second quarter at a level that more than offset the reduction in Citi Holdings. The revenues from our International Consumer Banking operations increased from the previous quarter and year
column59:
as did the net income from the North American Consumer Bank.

"
column60:
"

In our Institutional Businesses
column61: Investment
column62: Corporate and Private Banking revenues improved. Global Transaction Services performed very well
column63: as net income increased from the previous quarter
column64: despite continued low interest rates. However
column65:
our Markets business was clearly impacted by the trading environment.

"
column66:
"

In Citi Holdings
column67: we continued the reduction of assets in an economically rational manner. Our Holdings assets were reduced by $29 billion during the quarter
column68: from $337 billion to $308 billion
column69:
and now make up less than 16% of Citigroup's balance sheet.

"
column70:
"

We remain on track to meet the Basel III capital requirements through both the optimization of our assets and the generation of capital. We continue to expect that Citi will be in a position to return capital to shareholders in 2012 and still have an 8% to 9% Basel III Tier 1 common capital ratio at the end of that year.

"
column71:
"

As we'll show later in the presentation
column72: and John Gerspach will take you through this
column73: our earnings and utilization of deferred tax assets create a multiplier effect on regulatory capital formation. In the first half of this year
column74:
this generated $9 billion of Basel III regulatory capital on $6.3 billion of earnings and $1.5 billion of DTA utilization.

"
column75:
"

Looking forward
column76: while we are comfortable with the broader macro economic trends that underpin our strategy
column77: we are concerned with the impact the near-term economic environment will have on the industry for the second half of the year. But that said
column78:
we are consistently profitable and remain focused on growing responsibly.

"
column79:
"

Let me turn it over to John
column80: who will take you through our presentation
column81:
then we'll come back to the Q&A later.

"
column82:
"

John Gerspach

"
column83:
"

Thank you
column84: Vikram
column85: and good morning
column86: everyone. Starting on Slide 2
column87: Citigroup reported second quarter net income of $3.3 billion or $1.09 per diluted share versus $0.90 per share in the second quarter of 2010. Revenues of $20.6 billion were down 7% versus the prior year
column88: as strong growth in International Consumer Banking and Transaction Services was more than offset by lower revenues in Citi Holdings
column89:
Securities and Banking and North America Consumer Banking.

"
column90:
"

Expenses were up 9% year-over-year to $12.9 billion. But excluding the U.K. bonus tax of roughly $400 million in the second quarter of 2010
column91: expenses were up nearly 13%. Approximately 1/3 of this 13% increase resulted from the impact of foreign exchange
column92: and another 1/3 was related to higher legal and related costs. The remaining 1/3 was driven by the net impact of investment spending
column93: partially offset by ongoing productivity savings. All other expense increases
column94: such as higher volume-related costs in Citicorp
column95:
were largely offset by a reduction in Citi Holdings expenses.

"
column96:
"

Net credit losses declined again in the second quarter to $5.1 billion
column97: 35% lower than the second quarter of 2010. We also released $2 billion of net loan loss reserves compared to a $1.5 billion net release last year and a $3.3 billion in the first quarter. On a sequential basis
column98: end-of-period loans grew 2% for Citigroup
column99:
as strong loan growth in Citicorp more than offset the decline in Citi Holdings.

"
column100:
"

Turning now to Citicorp and Citi Holdings on Slide 3. Citicorp reported revenues of $16.3 billion and net income of $3.7 billion in the second quarter is down slightly versus last year. Sequentially
column101: we grew end-of-period loans in every business in every region in Citicorp
column102: and the same holds true year-over-year with the exception of North America branded cards. Versus last year
column103: Citicorp loans grew 16%
column104:
including 11% growth in consumer and 22% growth in corporate loans.

"
column105:
"

Citi Holdings reported revenues of $4 billion and a net loss of $218 million
column106: which included over $0.5 billion of pretax realized gains on the sale of assets transferred out of held-to-maturity in the Special Asset Pool in the first quarter. Citi Holdings ended the quarter with $308 billion of assets
column107:
down $29 billion during the quarter and $157 billion year-over-year.

"
column108:
"

Now on Slide 4
column109: we show a 9-quarter trend for Citicorp's results. Excluding CVA
column110: Citicorp's revenues of $16.2 billion in the second quarter were flat versus the prior year. Sequentially
column111: revenues were down 3% as growth in Regional Consumer Banking and Transaction Services was more than offset by lower revenues in Securities and Banking. Operating expenses of $10.1 billion were up 10% versus the prior year
column112: but again excluding the U.K. bonus tax in the second quarter of 2010
column113: expenses were up 14%. Over 1/4 of this 14% increase resulted from the impact of foreign exchange. The remainder was primarily driven by investment spending. All other expense increases
column114: such as higher volume-related costs
column115:
were largely offset by ongoing productivity savings.

"
column116:
"

Citicorp's net credit losses were $2.2 billion
column117: down 27% from the prior year
column118: driven by Citi-branded cards in North America. We released $914 million in net loan loss reserves
column119: up from $665 million last year
column120: due to higher net releases in Citi-branded cards
column121: partially offset by lower releases in International Consumer Banking and the corporate portfolio. Excluding CVA
column122:
earnings before taxes of $4.9 billion were up 3% year-over-year as lower credit costs more than offset higher operating expenses.

"
column123:
"

Emerging markets continue to be a significant driver of Citicorp results
column124: as shown on Slide 5. Excluding CVA
column125: emerging markets contributed nearly half of Citicorp's revenues and over 60% of earnings before taxes in the second quarter. Emerging markets revenues have grown year-over-year for 5 consecutive quarters
column126: driven by both our consumer and institutional businesses. This growth reflects consistent strength in underlying business drivers
column127:
with average deposits up 13% year-over-year and loans up 27%.

"
column128:
"

Slide 6 shows results for our North America Consumer Banking business. Revenues of $3.4 billion were down 9% versus last year
column129: mainly due to a decline in average card loans
column130: lower mortgage revenues and the impact of CARD Act. Sequentially
column131: revenues were up 1%. Expenses of $1.8 billion were up 17% year-over-year and 5% sequentially as we continued to increase investments largely through higher marketing and technology spending. Credit costs declined 74% from last year to $552 million. Net credit losses were down 39% to $1.3 billion
column132: driven by Citi-branded cards. And the reserve release was $757 million this quarter. Net credit margin grew by 32% year-over-year to $2.1 billion. Sequentially
column133: we grew both end-of-period retail and card loans
column134: although average card loans declined modestly. On a year-over-year basis
column135:
purchase sales grew 2% while card accounts were roughly flat.

"
column136:
"

Turning to our International Consumer Banking businesses on Slide 7. International revenues were $4.8 billion in the second quarter
column137: up 12% year-over-year with growth in all regions. Revenue growth reflects continued improvement in underlying drivers as well as the benefit from foreign exchange
column138:
partially offset by spread compression.

"
column139:
"

Year-over-year
column140: average deposits and loans grew by 17% and 20% respectively. Investment sales were up 5% versus last year and card purchases grew 28%. Expenses were $3 billion in the second quarter
column141: up 19% versus last year
column142:
with over 1/3 of the increase due to the impact of foreign exchange. The remainder primarily reflects higher investment spending and volume-related costs partially offset by continued productivity savings.

"
column143:
"

A lower net reserve release resulted in an increase in credit costs
column144: up 52% year-over-year to $629 million. Net credit losses declined 12% to $697 million
column145: while the net loan loss reserve release was $90 million this quarter versus $403 million in the prior year. Higher revenues and lower net credit losses resulted in net credit margin expansion
column146:
up 17% year-over-year to $4.1 billion.

"
column147:
"

On Slide 8
column148: we show growth trends for International Consumer Banking in more detail. International growth reflects both the economic environment in these markets as well as the results of our investment spending. Sequentially
column149: we have grown average loans and deposits every quarter for over 2 years
column150: and card purchase sales have increased year-over-year for 7 quarters. We have also increased our net credit margin and our earnings before taxes
column151: excluding the impact of loan loss reserves
column152:
year-over-year for 7 consecutive quarters.

"
column153:
"

Slide 9 shows our Securities and Banking business. Excluding CVA
column154: revenues of $5.3 billion were down 7% from last year and down 15% versus the prior quarter. In investment banking
column155: revenues of $1.1 billion were up 27% sequentially with strength in both advisory and underwriting activities. x CVA
column156: equity market revenues of $776 million were down 30% sequentially
column157: mainly due to lower market volumes and a challenging trading environment
column158: particularly in derivatives. Fixed income market revenues x CVA were down 27% sequentially to $2.9 billion
column159:
driven by credit-related and securitized products.

"
column160:
"

Our rates and currencies business showed a much smaller revenue decline as lower G10 revenues were partially offset by growth in emerging markets. Lending revenues were $346 million
column161:
up from $244 million last quarter due to lower hedge losses. Private Bank revenues excluding CVA were up 7% sequentially to $555 million.

"
column162:
"

Total operating expenses of $3.9 billion were down 1% from the second quarter of 2010. Excluding the impact of the U.K. bonus tax last year
column163: expenses were up 9%
column164: mainly due to investment spending
column165:
partially offset by productivity savings. Credit costs were $59 million in the second quarter compared to a benefit in the prior year period.

"
column166:
"

Now moving to Transaction Services on Slide 10. Revenues of $2.7 billion were up 6% from the second quarter of last year
column167: driven by growth in the emerging markets. Treasury and trade solutions was up 6%
column168: primarily due to higher trade revenues and increased deposits
column169: partially offset by spread compression. Securities and fund services grew 6% year-over-year
column170:
driven by strong growth in custody and securities lending on new credit -- on new client mandates as well as market activity.

"
column171:
"

Transaction volumes and new mandates continue to show momentum in both businesses. Asset growth was driven by trade loans
column172: with average trade assets up 70% from last year. Average deposits grew 14% year-over-year to $365 billion with a favorable shift towards core operating balances. Assets under custody were up 19% to $13.5 trillion as a result of market and client activity. Expenses of $1.4 billion were up 18% versus last year
column173: reflecting higher volumes and continued investments
column174:
partially offset by productivity savings.

"
column175:
"

On Slide 11
column176: we show a 9-quarter trend for Citi Holdings. The loss in Citi Holdings narrowed to $218 million in the second quarter
column177:
which included over $0.5 billion of realized pretax gains on the sale of assets transferred out of held-to-maturity in the Special Asset Pool in the first quarter. Revenues were down 18% year-over-year to $4 billion due primarily to lower assets.

"
column178:
"

While expenses of $2.2 billion were down 9% versus last year
column179: sequentially
column180:
costs were up $185 million primarily due to higher legal and related costs. Total credit costs were down by more than half to $2.1 billion.

"
column181:
"

Looking at Citi Holdings in more detail on Slide 12. Revenues in Brokerage and Asset Management were $47 million this quarter
column182: down from the second quarter of 2010
column183: reflecting a lower contribution from the Morgan Stanley Smith Barney JV. In Local Consumer Lending
column184: revenues were down 30% versus last year to $2.9 billion
column185: driven by declining loan balances. In the Special Asset Pool
column186: revenues were $1 billion in the second quarter
column187: reflecting the previously mentioned realized gains on the sale of assets transferred out of held-to-maturity last quarter
column188: as well as realized gains on other asset dispositions. Credit costs were down by more than half year-over-year to $2.1 billion as credit trends continued to improve in both the consumer and corporate portfolios. Total net credit losses were down 40% to $3 billion
column189:
and we released $1.1 billion of net loan loss reserves in Citi Holdings.

"
column190:
"

Slide 13 shows the Citi Holdings assets. We ended the quarter with $308 billion in Citi Holdings or 16% of total Citigroup assets. The $29 billion reduction in the second quarter was comprised of nearly $21 billion of asset sales and business dispositions
column191:
over $7 billion of net runoff and paydowns and roughly $1 billion of net cost of credit and net asset marks.

"
column192:
"

On Slide 4
column193: we show -- on Slide 14
column194: pardon me
column195: we show the drivers of Citi Holdings' wind-down over the past 10 quarters. Net credit cost and net asset marks are down dramatically since early 2009
column196: representing only $2 billion of net decline in the first half of 2011. The next largest component is net runoff and paydowns
column197: which have gradually declined as the remaining portfolio has gotten smaller. Finally
column198: the most significant driver has been asset sales and business dispositions. As we have discussed previously
column199: there is a smaller pool of assets available for sale today than in prior periods. Additionally
column200: there are only a few remaining businesses of significant size
column201:
and future sales activity would depend on both attractive terms and a favorable funding environment.

"
column202:
"

Moving to Slide 15
column203: we take a closer look at the remaining assets in Citi Holdings. Brokerage and Asset Management is mostly related to the Morgan Stanley Smith Barney JV. Morgan Stanley has calls to purchase our stake in the JV in 3 tranches beginning in 2012
column204: and either party has the right to cause an IPO after 2015. We have also roughly $12 billion of margin loans and other assets
column205:
the majority of which should transfer to the JV by the end of 2012.

"
column206:
"

Local Consumer Lending is a mix of operating businesses and runoff portfolios. Two sizable operating businesses remain. First is retail partner cards with $45 billion of assets. Second is Citi Financial with $32 billion of assets
column207: including both the one main business and Citi Financial servicing. On Slide 15
column208:
these assets are included in both mortgages and personal loans. The majority of assets in Local Consumer Lending will either run off or be reduced by smaller sales. Over half of the assets are mortgages with a roughly 6-year expected average life.

"
column209:
"

The Special Asset Pool consists of securities
column210: loans and other assets. Roughly $19 billion are trading assets or available-for-sale. $13 billion are held-to-maturity securities with an expected average life of 7 years. $7 billion are loans and leases which we currently expect to reduce significantly by the end of next year. And the remainder is other assets
column211: including private equity positions
column212:
targeted for sale.

"
column213:
"

Slide 16 shows the results of the Corporate/Other segment. Here
column214: revenues declined by $400 million versus last year
column215: reflecting lower investment yields and the impact of hedging activities
column216: partially offset by the gain on sale of a portion of our stake in HDFC this quarter. Net income also reflects higher operating expenses during the quarter. Expenses were up by $415 million versus last year
column217:
mainly due to legal and related costs. Assets of $269 billion include approximately $78 billion of cash and cash equivalents and $130 billion of liquid available-for-sale securities.

"
column218:
"

Slide 17 shows total Citigroup net credit losses and loan loss reserves. NCLs continued to improve in the second quarter
column219: down 18% sequentially to $5.1 billion. And the net LLR release was $2 billion versus $3.3 billion in the prior quarter. We ended the quarter with $34.4 billion of total loan loss reserves and our LLR ratio was 5.4%. Consumer NCLs declined 11% sequentially to $4.8 billion
column220:
and we released $1.5 billion in net loan loss reserves.

"
column221:
"

Corporate credit was a benefit of $107 million in the second quarter compared to $520 million last quarter. Corporate net credit losses were down 59% sequentially to $349 million
column222: driven in part by lower cost of loan sales. We released $456 million of net corporate loan loss reserves
column223:
down from $1.4 billion in the first quarter. Corporate nonaccrual loans of $4.8 billion were down 12% versus the prior quarter.

"
column224:
"

Slide 18 shows our international consumer credit trends. In Citicorp
column225: as our loan portfolios grew
column226: dollar NCLs were up modestly from the first quarter in Asia and Latin America
column227: but remain stable to improving on a rate basis. 90-plus-day delinquencies also increased sequentially in dollar terms in Asia and Latin America
column228:
but remain fairly stable as a percentage of loans. We also saw a continued improvement in international consumer credit in Citi Holdings.

"
column229:
"

On Slide 19
column230: we show North America Citi-branded cards in Citicorp and retail partner cards in Citi Holdings. Credit trends for both portfolios continue to improve. In Citi-branded card
column231: NCLs decreased by 9% sequentially to $1.2 billion
column232: and 90-plus-day delinquencies were down 16% to $1.2 billion. In retail partner cards
column233: NCLs decreased by 14% sequentially to $956 million
column234: and 90-plus-day delinquencies declined by 18% to $1.1 billion. For both portfolios
column235:
early stage delinquencies also showed improvement on both a dollar and a rate basis.

"
column236:
"

On Slide 20
column237: we show the North America mortgage portfolio in Citi Holdings
column238: split between residential first mortgages and home equity loans. NCLs and 90-plus-day delinquencies improved in both portfolios in the second quarter. In residential first mortgages
column239: we ended the second quarter with $73 billion of loans
column240: down 19% from a year ago. Sequentially
column241: 90-plus-day delinquencies declined by 13% to $3.9 billion and were down more than 50% from last year. Net credit losses were down 17% sequentially to $461 million. The sequential decline in first mortgage delinquencies again was primarily due to continued asset sales
column242:
as we sold nearly $800 million in delinquent mortgages in the quarter.

"
column243:
"

Regarding modification activity. Over the past 9 quarters
column244: we have converted $5.7 billion of trial mods to permanent modifications. More than 3/4 of these modifications were HAMP
column245: and we continue to experience re-default rates on HAMP-modified loans of less than 15%. The remainder were modified under other Citi programs
column246: and to date
column247:
the re-default rate on these modifications has been less than 25%.

"
column248:
"

In recent quarters
column249: the pace of our modification activity has slowed. Going forward
column250: we expect fewer new modifications
column251: while some portion of our previous modifications will re-default. As a result
column252: delinquency trends may deteriorate. However
column253:
this is already factored into our net loan loss reserve balances.

"
column254:
"

In the second quarter
column255: we recorded a modest increase in our net loan loss reserves primarily related to home equity loans. We ended the quarter with roughly $10 billion of our total loan loss reserves allocated to North America real estate lending in Citi Holdings
column256: or over 27 months of coincident NCL coverage. Now for our total North America consumer mortgage portfolio
column257: including Citi Holdings as well as $27 billion of residential first mortgage and home equity loans in Citicorp
column258:
our reserves also cover over 27 months of NCLs.

"
column259:
"

Slide 21 shows the trend in our key capital metrics. We ended the quarter with a Tier 1 capital ratio of 13.6% and a Tier 1 common ratio of 11.6%. Our total risk-weighted assets were $992 million -- $992 billion
column260:
with roughly 28% attributable to Citi Holdings.

"
column261:
"

Looking at risk-weighted assets in more detail on Slide 22. Over the past few quarters
column262: Citigroup's risk-weighted assets
column263: as reported under Basel I
column264: have been fairly constant
column265: as growth in Citicorp has been offset by a significant reduction in Citi Holdings. We currently expect risk-weighted assets under Basel I to grow slightly by low single digits as of the end of 2012. Based on our initial analysis
column266: last year we estimated that Basel III would result in an increase in risk-weighted assets in Citicorp of approximately 30% to 35%. Today
column267: we believe the increase in risk-weighted assets for total Citigroup will be in the range of 35%
column268: with Citicorp's risk-weighted assets increasing in the range of 20%. The refinement in our estimate of the risk-weighted asset impact is based on several factors
column269:
including greater experience with Basel III risk models and key drivers and more clarity on the impact of mitigating actions. We believe our businesses in Citicorp are inherently Basel III-friendly.

"
column270:
"

For Regional Consumer Banking and Transaction Services
column271: we expect only a slight increase in risk-weighted assets under Basel III. In Regional Consumer Banking
column272: we serve a customer base with generally higher credit quality
column273: which positively affects our risk weightings. Transaction Services is an asset-light business with relatively little credit risk. As expected
column274: the greatest impact of Basel III will be on our risk-weighted assets in Securities and Banking. Of course
column275:
we will continue to refine our estimates of risk-weighted assets under Basel III as additional clarity and guidance becomes available.

"
column276:
"

Turning to capital generation on Slide 23. In the first half of 2011
column277: Citigroup earned a total of $6.3 billion in net income. We also utilized $1.5 billion of DTA. Under Basel III
column278: we deduct a significant portion of our DTA from our equity when calculating Tier 1 common capital. Therefore
column279: utilizing DTA generates regulatory capital by reducing the size of the DTA and hence
column281:
"

In addition
column282: both earnings and the DTA usage also create a \"multiplier effect\" on the growth of regulatory capital. Under Basel III
column283: the inclusion of DTA
column284: mortgage servicing rights and unconsolidated investments and financial subsidiaries is subject to limitation based on a percentage of Tier 1 common capital. Therefore
column285: any growth in Tier 1 common capital results in a larger portion of these assets being included in Basel III regulatory capital. The combined impact of earnings
column286: DTA usage and the \"multiplier effect\" generated $9 billion of Basel III Tier 1 common capital in the first half of 2011. Additionally over time
column287: we expect to continue to generate capital from the wind-down of Citi Holdings as well as other mitigating actions. We expect to end 2012 with an 8% to 9% Tier 1 common ratio under Basel III as fully implemented
column288:
including the impact of returning capital to shareholders during the year.

"
column289:
"

Now in summary
column290: we continue to execute our strategy in the second quarter. Now I'd like to discuss some factors which may affect our results in the second half of 2011. In North America Consumer Banking
column291: we expect revenues to continue to stabilize in the second half of the year
column292: while net credit losses should continue to improve. We will also continue to invest in the business. In International Consumer Banking
column293: our investment spending should continue to generate revenue growth. We currently expect both Asia and Latin America consumer banking to achieve positive operating leverage in the fourth quarter of this year. International credit costs are likely to continue to increase in the second half of the year
column294:
reflecting a growing loan portfolio.

"
column295:
"

In our Institutional businesses
column296: Securities and Banking results will continue to reflect trends and client activity
column297: global market conditions and seasonal factors. Transaction Services should continue to benefit from increased volumes and the globalization of trade and capital flows
column298: partially offset by continued spread compression. Corporate credit costs are expected to increase
column299:
reflecting growth in corporate loans.

"
column300:
"

In Local Consumer Lending in Citi Holdings
column301: revenues should continue to decline
column302:
given a shrinking loan balance resulting from paydowns and continued asset sales.

"
column303:
"

Regarding operating expenses. The impact of the weakening U.S. dollar
column304: as well as higher legal and related costs
column305: total roughly $1.6 billion out of the $1.9 billion increase in our expense base in the first half of 2011 as compared to the first half of last year. These factors will likely continue to affect our expenses in the second half of this year and will remain difficult to predict. Therefore
column306: we expect operating expenses to remain elevated for the remainder of the year. As a result
column307:
our full year operating expenses will likely exceed the $48 billion to $50 billion guidance that we had communicated previously.

"
column308:
"

That concludes our review of the quarter. And Vikram and I will now open up the line for questions.

column603: we don't like the idea that our expenses are going to be above the guidance anymore than anybody else does. When you're faced with $700 million impact in the first half due to foreign exchange and say
column604: roughly $900 million due to the increase in legal and related expenses
column605: you've got 2 decisions to make: You can either manage back down to the guidance by cutting your investment programs; or you can agree that you're going to press on
column606: but as we've always said
column607: continue to find reductions in your base. And don't forget
column608: we've targeted
column609: we -- our basic operating mantra is that every business should be able to find approximately 3% to 5% of productivity saves every year. And that's actually the way that we have been operating and we will continue to operate. So if you think about the first half of the year
column610: we talked about $1.6 billion worth of impact due to foreign exchange and legal and related. During that time
column611: the impact of investments is a little bit north of $1.5 billion. So we've made about $1.5 billion of investments
column612: and we've had roughly 50% of those investment dollars covered by productivity saves in the business. And so we're continuing to actively manage our expense base. Again
column613: we're very conscious of -- you guys are very focused on expenses. I got to tell you
column614: so are we. But we're also trying to make sure that we're putting the right expense dollars into the businesses to grow operating margin. We think that
column615: that's what you want us to do

column617: you've got roughly a 12- to 18-month lead time before you really begin to see something positive in operating leverage coming out of those investments. And in both of those geographies

column625: it's going to be a second half of 2012 story as far as gaining positive operating leverage out of the North America Consumer Bank. In similar fashion
column626: we are taking -- we're making investments
column627: continuing to make investments in Transaction Services this year. That's a business that you can starve in investments for a very short period of time
