Okay. Let's start with this quarter. So we had about a 6 basis point decline in NIM quarter-on-quarter. And there's roughly say
column713: 5 factors that drove NIM decline first quarter to second quarter. Number one would have to be the FDIC assessment. The increase in the FDIC tax cost us about 4 basis points of NIM in the quarter. The second factor would be loans. The combination of those higher-yielding loans running off in Citi Holdings combined with the lower
column714: somewhat lower yielding net loan growth in Citicorp
column715: that had about a 9-basis-point impact
column716: a negative impact
column717: on our NIM. The third factor
column718: we had some additional borrowing costs in some of our trading businesses to fund some client positions that was a little bit higher than the first quarter. That was 3 basis points. So those are the bad guys. And then on the good guy side
column720: we had -- we didn't have the reserve build in Citi Financial in Japan that we had in the first quarter. So that was 7 basis points to the good. And then as we begin to roll that--run down our long-term debt
column721: that added about a 3-basis-point positive to our NIM. So I think I've got the math right. That should net out to roughly 6 basis points. So as you think going forward
column722: it's going to be -- the FDIC now should be behind us. That's kind of baked in. And it's going to be that combination of what happens with the runoff in loans in holdings
column724: the impact of the continued runoff in the long-term debt. And so I'd say over the next 2 quarters
column725: absent some significant portfolio sale coming out of holdings

Moshe Orenbuch - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse AG

column944:
"

I mean I understand caution
column945: but obviously
column946: it's -- given that the trends are improving
column947: in other words
column948: that should tell you that all other things being equal
column949: you would need less reserves as opposed to more
column950: right? I mean
column951:
isn't that correct?

column952:

John Gerspach

column953:
"

That's absolutely right. Now the one thing though
column954: and I don't want to get preachy about this
column955: but mortgages are really different than credit cards. Your risk on mortgages
column956: it just hangs around for a long time because those mortgages sit in inventory once they get past the 180 days. And so you still have a great deal of severity risk that can impact you as -- until housing prices begin to rise and until you can start clearing out some of your foreclosure and process inventory
column957: you've got an elongated period of time where you're going to have elevated credit losses. That's one of the reasons why we have been such active sellers of delinquent mortgages
column958:
because we just don't want to start building up a lot of mortgages that are sitting on our books that are more than 180 days past due.

"
column959:
"

Moshe Orenbuch - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse AG

column960:
"

Right. And to the extent that you have extra severity risk

you're saying essentially that's partially mitigated by the fact that your delinquency trends have been better.

column965:
"

Delinquency trends certainly help. But once those mortgages get past that 180 days
column967: that's why we manage that very
column968:
very closely. That's when your severity risk really kicks in.

"
column969:
"

Moshe Orenbuch - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse AG

"
column970:
"

Right. Kind of on the comment that you made of running the capital levels at 8% to 9%
column971: I mean I think that's very helpful kind of guidance for us. One of your competitors
column974: and they mentioned they're planning to run at 7.5%. Is the 8% to 9% kind of a basically kind of an internal classification? I mean
column975:
how should we think about how you arrived at that?

"
column979: and I think we tried to describe the thought process in the
column980: I think it was the third quarter of last year. And we just believe that given our mix of business and where we are
column982: that -- and recognizing interconnectiveness and everything else
column983: we think that's the right level of capital for us to operate. I think others at that point in time were saying that they were at 7%. And they thought that 7% was it
column984:
and they weren't going to run it $1 more than 7%. We've always been targeted at this 8% to 9% level. We try to be very consistent with that. And that's the way we've have been managing the place now for going on a year.

"
column985:
"

Moshe Orenbuch - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse AG

"
column987: great. Very last quick one. In terms of the partner card business
column988: and you've talked about that a lot. But it's not really just one kind of block of business
column990: there's different partners. And is it probable or possible that some of those partners would be more consistent with your customer franchise
column993:
"

That is certainly a possibility. I certainly would not deny that.

"
column995:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Peter Ganucheau with Carlson Capital.

"
column997:
"

There's been a lot of discussion on the FX issue. I just want to get a conclusion. You're basically saying that most of the P&L impact would be hedged naturally or explicitly. So I'm trying to get comfort with thinking that the FX volatility won't move the needle in the bottom line on the P&L. Is that fair?

"
column1000: it's self-hedged. When you take a look at the impact on our revenue and our expense and the cost of credit
column1001: we basically -- the business is basically self-hedged against FX exposure. So we'll get
column1002: depending upon how the dollar moves
column1003: we'll get either a very small impact
column1005: on the bottom line. But it does have an impact on the individual lines
column1006: and that's why when people look at expenses
column1007: just separate out just their view on expenses
column1008:
that's going to color your view on expenses.

"
column1010:
"

So maybe just think about expense as FX? I mean
column1012:
and then the second one is a mathematical...

"
column1014:
"

That would clearly be a way to look at it.

"
column1016:
"

Okay. And the second point I have is the question on some math. I've got $992 billion of risk-weighted assets
column1017: 72% you said is Citicorp. That's $714 billion. Now your old guidance on the risk-weighted asset inflation would have been 35%. The new guidance is 20%. Do a little math
column1018: I won't take you through it
column1019: but the delta is $108 billion in risk-weighted assets. At 9.5% Tier 1 common
column1020: let's say it's a 7 plus to 250 [ph]
column1021:
that's $11.3 billion in incremental excess capital that's freed up. And that's 10% of your market cap and the stock is flat. So I must be doing my math wrong. So what am I doing wrong?

"
column1023:
"

The only thing that struck me as you went through that is by the end of 2012
column1024:
we would certainly expect to have some growth in our Citicorp assets because we are growing that business.

"
column1026:
"

Okay. Fair enough. Holdings is there
column1028: right? But even if you include the increased inflation at Holdings
column1030: it would cut that effect in half

"

Your next question comes from the line of Mike Mayo with CLSA.

"

"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (USA) Inc.

"
column1035:
"

I know we've been through expenses a lot
column1036:
and you said the net effect is the positive $100 million on income. But what is the revenue number? You said the weaker dollar contributed $1.6 billion or $1.9 billion increase in the first half versus the prior year. How much did the weaker dollar add to the revenue line item?

"
column1038:
"

I don't have that for you
column1039: Michael. I'm sorry. As I said
column1040:
the net impact for the full firm is roughly $100 million pretax.

"
column1041:
"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (USA) Inc.

"
column1043: your revenues were down $0.5 billion and your expenses were up $0.5 billion. FX is going to impact both. You said legal hurts that some
column1044: but it still looks like it's going to be negative operating leverage. But of what you can control in expenses
column1045:
where do you think you need to do better than you've been doing? Or is it that just the way it's going to be because you're in an investment mode?

"
column1048: we are clearly in an investment mode and we -- look
column1049:
I think you can always do things better. But we're definitely focused on driving those productivity saves. And so we're very focused on managing the business as we go forward.

"
column1050:
"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (USA) Inc.

"
column1051:
"

You gave us an isolation where each segment should turn to a positive operating leverage mode. When do you think the overall firm would be in a positive operating leverage status? Is that the end of this year
column1056: Michael. But when you consider with holdings and everything else
column1057:
I'm not prepared to pick a time frame.

"
column1058:
"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (USA) Inc.

"
column1059:
"

Sure. Let me shift gears. The net $13 billion of exposure to the European countries identified
column1060:
what is the gross number and what's the difference between the gross and the net?

"
column1062:
"

I don't think that the gross number is relevant. I mean again
column1063:
we're taking a look at the net exposure after hedges and appropriate risk management approaches.

"
column1064:
"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (USA) Inc.

"
column1066:
and what else would be included in risk management?

"
column1071:
I'm just trying to kind of run through an inventory.

"
column1072:
"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (USA) Inc.

"
column1073:
"

Okay. And having gone through the crisis and having seen a lot of outside guarantees and hedges not working
column1074:
how comfortable are you that you have the right hedges and risk management in place?

"
column1077: it's reported. And if we report it as net exposure
column1078: it's based on our confidence that we are -- we consider these to be true hedges. By the way
column1079: just the only thing I'd add is John Gerspach talked about collateral
column1080: its net of collateral. It's -- there are types of collateral that don't get netted. Suppose you had a -- if you had a loan in one of these countries and the collateral was a lot of
column1083:
that's not a qualified hedge necessarily. It doesn't come through the numbers. So we do have collateral of that sort too in some of these financial institutions numbers.

"
column1084:
"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (USA) Inc.

"
column1085:
"

Okay. And then lastly I saw that Jerry Grundhofer stepped off the board 3 weeks ago after having pretty recently been renominated. Can you add any color to what was said in some of the public statements? He was in charge of the Risk Committee as I understand it. Who's the new head of the Risk Committee? Why did he leave?

"
column1087:
"

We will make those announcements in terms of changes post our board meeting that's coming up. So that's in process. We are delighted with the board that we have. We have enormous amount of depth
column1088: both on the financial services side and the risk side. And Jerry was very clear
column1089: and our press releases were very clear in terms of his reasons for choosing what he wanted to do. And we really think that we all have come a very long way. He made substantial contributions
column1090:
and the board is in good shape going forward.

"
column1092:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Meredith Whitney from Meredith Whitney Advisors.

"
column1094:
"

This is John Dunn [ph] actually. Just one last question on expenses. Can you give us a breakout of the comp versus noncomp in the investment bank
column1095: and just a sense of how that compares to last quarter
column1098:
"

No. We don't disclose comp versus noncomp in the investment bank.

"
column1100:
"

Okay. Just wanted to take a chance.

"
column1102:
"

Your last question comes from the line of Mike Holson [ph] with The Boston [ph] Company.

"
column1105:
I'm going use that opportunity to ask 2 quick ones. The first one's really easy. You mentioned there's a gain from the sale of HDFC. Approximately how much was that?

"
column1110:
"

Okay. And then I'm just going to follow up on Mike Mayo's question about the gross PIIGS exposure. I understand the reasons why you guys don't want to disclose it
column1112: if Europe turns into a real problem
column1113:
the net exposure guidance or disclosure you gave isn't going to give investors any comfort whatsoever. So I would encourage you guys to give the gross exposure at some point if you're not going to do it today.

"
column1118:
"

There are no further questions at this time. Presenters
column1119:
do you have any closing remarks?

"

Yes. It's John Andrews. Thank you for those of you who just managed to stay on for this lengthy call. The replay will be available later this afternoon on the website. And we'll all talk to you later

column1:
{"Citigroup's CEO Discusses Q3 2011 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Citigroup (NYSE:C)

"
column8:
"

John C. Gerspach - Chief Financial Officer

"
column9:
"

Vikram S. Pandit - Chief Executive Officer and Director

"
column11:
"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (NYSE:USA) Inc.
column13:
"

Vivek Juneja - JP Morgan Chase & Co
column15:
"

Matthew O'Connor - Deutsche Bank AG
column18:
"

Jason M. Goldberg - Barclays Capital
column20:
"

Christoph M. Kotowski - Oppenheimer & Co. Inc.
column22:
"

John E. McDonald - Sanford C. Bernstein & Co.
column26:
"

James F. Mitchell - Buckingham Research Group
column28:
"

Glenn Schorr - Nomura Securities Co. Ltd.
column30:
"

Moshe Orenbuch - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse AG
column34:
"

Todd L. Hagerman - Sterne Agee & Leach Inc.
column36:
"

Adam G. Hurwich - Ulysses Management LLC

"
column37:
"

Ed Najarian - ISI Group Inc.
column41: and welcome to Citi's Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Review with Chief Executive Officer
column42: Vikram Pandit; and Chief Financial Officer
column43: John Gerspach. The call will be hosted by John Andrews
column44: Head of Citi Investor Relations. [Operator Instructions] Also
column45: as a reminder
column46: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column47: please disconnect at this time. Mr. Andrews
column48:
you may begin.

"
column49:
"

John Andrews

"
column50:
"

Rachel
column51: thank you. And good morning to everybody
column52: and thank you for joining us today. On the call today our CEO
column57: will take you through the earnings presentation
column58: which is available for download on our website
column59: citigroup.com. After which
column60:
we'd be happy to take your questions.

"
column61:
"

Before we get started
column62: I would like to remind you that today's presentation may contain forward-looking statements
column63: which are based on management's current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results and capital and other financial condition may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors
column64: including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today and those included in our SEC filings
column65: including
column66: without limitation
column67: the Risk Factors section of our form -- 2010 Form 10-K. With that out of the way
column68:
let me turn it over to Vikram.

"
column69:
"

Vikram S. Pandit

"
column70:
"

John
column71: thank you
column72: and good morning
column73:
everybody. Thank you for joining us today.

"
column74:
"

Earlier today
column75: we announced net income of $3.8 billion or $1.23 per share for the third quarter. When you exclude CVA and focus on our operating results
column76: we earned $2.6 billion or $0.84 per share. These are solid results
column77:
particularly in a macro environment in which economic and political uncertainty created a lot of market volatility.

"
column78:
"

As always
column79: we're managing through short-term challenges while steadily executing our long-term strategy. Over the past few years
column80: we have methodically positioned Citi for the trends and opportunities we see in the world. We've built substantial financial strength
column81: de-risked our balance sheet and reoriented our business back to what we do best and what's in Citi's DNA
column82: being a uniquely global bank focused on capital flows and global trade
column83:
with a particular focus on the emerging markets.

"
column84:
"

I want to start by focusing on 4 areas: first
column85: our risk as it pertains to Europe
column86: the emerging markets and the U.S. mortgages; second
column87: our decision to move retail partner cards out of Citi Holdings and into Citicorp; third
column88: our financial strength; fourth
column89:
I want to provide you some detail on our ongoing efforts to manage expenses; and I will close with a few comments on the economic environment.

"
column90:
"

I believe that Citi's performance during this quarter shows the significant progress we have made in improving our risk management
column91: one of my top priorities when I became CEO. We've completely revamped our risk profile
column92: risk approach and most importantly
column93:
our risk culture. We've put in place robust practices in the businesses and regions to integrate risk analysis into decision-making.

"
column94:
"

Today
column95: you have another example of this improved risk management in the update on our European exposure. More than 18 months ago
column96: we recognized the potential for Greece's sovereign debt issues to impact other countries in the Eurozone. Since then
column97: we have reduced our exposures where needed
column98: while continuing to serve our clients diligently. As you will see
column99: we have continued to closely manage our trading and AFS portfolios in the GIIPS
column100: France and Belgium and currently
column101:
have no material net exposure to sovereign debt securities.

"
column102:
"

In terms of funded exposures
column103: we have net lending exposures to the GIIPS sovereign entities of $1.5 billion
column104: and we currently don't have any France and Belgium net sovereign lending exposure. Our GIIPS financial institution net lending exposure is $2.1 billion
column105: and our France and Belgium financial institution net lending exposure is $2.3 billion. Our exposures include lending to foreign subsidiaries where applicable. Margin may be held against some exposures
column106: reducing our net exposure
column107: while other exposures are collateralized. We are providing that margin and collateral information as well. Lastly
column108: our exposures to corporates are partly driven by global banking
column109:
and a large amount of these exposures are to large multinationals that participate in global trade [ph] and capital flows.

"
column110:
"

Today
column111: we are also including a good amount of information regarding our consumer banking businesses in the emerging markets. Our deep roots in these markets give us sufficient advantages in growing and managing these businesses and managing our credit risk. These businesses continue to produce strong growth in revenues
column112:
loans and deposits.

"
column113:
"

Our credit portfolio in the emerging markets is diversified by country and by product. The credit quality in these portfolios is not only good
column114: in fact
column115: in most of the countries where we do business
column116:
it's even better than the U.S. And the credit margins we earn in these markets are substantially better than the margins the industry earns in the U.S.

"
column117:
"

One sign of our success on these markets is that our investment spending in Asia is paying off. We achieved positive operating leverage in our Asian consumer business this quarter
column118:
one quarter ahead of when we expected it. We expect our Latin American consumer business to follow next quarter.

"
column119:
"

I did say last year that it was unlikely for the emerging markets to continue at their current pace. That said
column120: we still expect them to grow faster than the developed markets. And also
column121: the individual markets are not monolithic
column122:
each country faces its own opportunities and trends.

"
column123:
"

We continue to be very transparent about our U.S. mortgage exposure. We have a smaller owned mortgage portfolio than any peer. Because of our aggressive risk mitigation efforts
column124: which includes selling mortgages
column125:
our portfolio has shrunk faster than any peer.

"
column126:
"

And in a period of uncertainty
column127: we believe that we hold the largest reserves against that portfolio. We have the smallest servicing portfolio and the smallest securitization portfolio of any peer. While we continue to focus on the risk of mortgage portfolio
column128: particularly if the economy were to weaken
column129:
I feel very good about all the steps we have taken and how we are positioned today.

"
column130:
"

Regarding Citi Holdings
column131: we've decided to move the vast majority of our retail partner cards business to Citicorp. We have made a lot of progress in strengthening this portfolio
column132:
including shedding some assets and re-underwriting the portfolio to much higher credit standards.

"
column133:
"

The portfolio is now 2/3 of its size at its peak
column134: with an average balance weighted FICO of more than 700. In addition
column135: so far this year
column136:
this business has earned a $2.2 billion profit before taxes and is a powerful source of ongoing profits.

"
column137:
"

As importantly
column138: the credit card business and the availability of credit have changed since the enactment of the CARD Act
column139: consumer behavior has also changed
column140:
as branded cards carry smaller open lines and consumers would rather use retail cards to preserve and protect their open lines of credit with banks.

"
column141:
"

With this transfer
column142: pro forma holdings assets will total about $250 billion or 13% of Citi's balance sheet. Although we continue to analyze the holdings portfolio
column143: we don't expect any other transfers of this magnitude
column144:
and our goal is to get holdings below 10% of the balance sheet in the near future.

"
column145:
"

Next
column146: Citi has built unquestionable financial strength over the past several years. At the end of the third quarter
column147: our Tier 1 common ratio was 11.7%
column148: and we had approximately $145 billion in tangible common equity. Almost 25% of our balance sheet is cash or liquid securities. We have enough liquidity that we could operate without issuing long-term debt for a couple of years
column149:
although we still plan to participate in the debt markets.

"
column150:
"

We still expect to end 2012 with the 8% to 9% Basel III Tier 1 common ratio and meet the Basel III capital requirements ahead of schedule. Subject to regulatory approval
column151: we still plan to begin returning capital to shareholders next year
column152: and we believe the pace of return can increase in 2013 and beyond
column153:
as economic conditions improve and we continue to reduce holdings assets and monetize our deferred tax assets.

"
column154:
"

Let me spend a minute on expenses. Third quarter expenses were $12.5 billion in total
column155: down 4% from the second quarter. After the big reductions in headcount and cost over the last couple of years
column156:
we continued to actively manage our expense base. We are constantly assessing our performance and will continue to resize our businesses when necessary.

"
column157:
"

Looking forward
column158: we expect our fourth quarter expenses to be roughly flat
column159: although the impact from episodic items such as FX and legal costs are not predictable. Also
column160:
compensation will continue to hinge on performance.

"
column161:
"

Finally
column162: as I have said before
column163: the macro will dominate the micro
column164: but we are encouraged by the results driven by the methodical execution of our strategy. Regardless of any cyclical slowdowns in the emerging markets
column165: we think the secular trends
column166: such as trade and rising consumption in the emerging markets
column167: will persevere
column168:
and we will pace our investments accordingly.

"
column169:
"

In the developed markets
column170: growth is likely to be slow for years. We remain concerned about the U.S. housing market
column171: and the U.S. residential mortgage portfolios of most banks remain the greatest risk. John will now take you through the presentation
column172: and as John Andrews said before
column173:
we'll come back to answer your questions.

"
column174:
"

John C. Gerspach

"
column175:
"

Thank you
column176: Vikram
column177: and good morning
column178: everyone. Starting on Slide 2. Citigroup reported third quarter net income of $3.8 billion or $1.23 per diluted share. This quarter's results included significant CVA of $1.9 billion
column179: driven by Citi's credit spreads widening. Excluding CVA
column180:
earnings were $2.6 billion or $0.84 per share in the third quarter.

"
column181:
"

Revenues of $20.8 billion were roughly flat versus the prior year on a reported basis. Excluding CVA from both periods
column182: revenues were down 8%
column183: as continued strong growth in international consumer banking and Transaction Services was more than offset by lower revenues in Citi Holdings
column184: Securities and Banking
column185:
and North America Consumer Banking. Expenses of $12.5 billion were up 8% year-over-year and down 4% from last quarter.

"
column186:
"

Year-over-year
column187: roughly 3 quarters of the increase was driven by the impact of foreign exchange
column188: higher legal and related costs and the absence of one-time benefits in the prior period. Excluding these items
column189: operating expenses grew 2% year-over-year in the third quarter
column190: driven by higher investments
column191:
partially offset by productivity savings and other expense reductions. I'll discuss year-to-date expenses in more detail later.

"
column192:
"

Cost of credit continued to improve year-over-year
column193: down 43% to $3.4 billion. Sequentially
column194: end of period loans declined 2% for Citigroup. However
column195: reported loans included a net negative impact from foreign exchange in the third quarter. On a constant dollar basis
column196: total Citigroup loans were up 1% sequentially
column197:
as loan growth in Citicorp more than offset the decline in Citi Holdings.

"
column198:
"

On Slide 3
column199: we highlight significant items affecting the third quarter and comparable periods. As I mentioned earlier
column200: CVA was a significant factor this quarter
column201:
at $1.9 billion pretax compared to $164 million in the second quarter and $115 million in the third quarter of last year. The $1.9 billion of CVA this quarter included $1.6 billion of CVA on Citi's fair value option debt and roughly $300 million of derivative CVA net of hedges.

"
column202:
"

In the second quarter of 2011
column203: we also recorded over $0.5 billion of realized gains on the sale of assets transferred out of held to maturity in the Special Asset Pool. And in the third quarter of last year
column204: we had a net loss on the announced sale of Student Loan Corporation of $800 million. Finally
column205: turning to loan loss reserves
column206: we recorded a significantly lower net reserve release in the third quarter of 2011
column207:
at $1.4 billion versus $2 billion both last quarter and in the prior year.

"
column208:
"

Turning now to Citicorp and Citi Holdings on Slide 4. Citicorp reported revenues of $17.7 billion and net income of $4.6 billion in the third quarter. Versus last year
column209: Citicorp loans grew 13% on a reported basis
column210:
including 6% growth in consumer and 21% growth in corporate loans.

"
column211:
"

As I mentioned earlier
column212: in the third quarter
column213: international loan growth reflects a negative impact from foreign exchange. Loans originated in foreign currencies are translated back to U.S. dollars for reporting purposes
column214: and therefore
column215: as the U.S. dollar appreciates
column216:
our reported loan balances are reduced.

"
column217:
"

Excluding the impact of FX
column218: we grew loans in every business in Citicorp in the third quarter
column219: both year-over-year and sequentially. Citi Holdings reported revenues of $2.8 billion and a net loss of $802 million. Citi Holdings ended the quarter with $289 billion of assets
column220:
down $19 billion during the quarter and $132 billion year-over-year.

"
column221:
"

On Slide 5
column222: we show a 9-quarter trend for Citicorp's results. Excluding CVA
column223: Citicorp's revenues of $15.8 billion in the third quarter were down 2% versus the prior quarter and prior year
column224:
as growth in Regional Consumer Banking and Transaction Services was more than offset by lower revenues in Securities and Banking.

"
column225:
"

Operating expenses of $9.8 billion were up 9% versus the prior year and down 3% from last quarter. Year-over-year
column226: roughly 1/4 of the increase resulted from the impact of foreign exchange. The remainder was primarily driven by investment spending
column227:
offset by productivity savings and other expense reductions.

"
column228:
"

Citicorp's net credit losses were $1.9 billion
column229: down 36% from the prior year
column230: driven by Citi-branded cards in North America. We released $585 million in net loan loss reserves
column231: up from $426 million last year

column574:
"

Curious
column575: John
column576: your comments on reshaping the investment bank for the opportunities that you see
column577: obviously
column578: in a tougher revenue environment now. But expenses have been elevated there. I'm just curious. What drives the decision
column580:
if you go there and you shrink a little? Is it Basel III? Is it Volcker's? Is it the derivatives rules? What are the main drivers that's going to bring rethinking on the IB or Securities and Banking?

"
column581:
"

Vikram S. Pandit

"
column582:
"

Glenn
column583: let me answer that. It's a Vikram. And I think
column584: yes
column585: it's all of the above. You've got to start right there
column586: which is Basel III
column587: Volcker are definitely going to have an impact on the kind of business you're in
column588: the credit business like securitization
column589: some of the derivatives business. Those that are non-clearinghouse
column590: counterparty business are going to be affected by that. You've got to scale for that. That's important. On the other hand
column591: the expenses are going to be higher because if you want to be in clearinghouses
column592: you got to make sure the systems are set up. So on one hand
column593: you reduce the business. On the other hand
column594: on a getting-ready-for-it basis
column595: the expenses are higher. And none of us truly know where the Volcker rules are going to come out. They are going to have an impact. We need to watch that
column598: we've been getting ready for that
column599: making sure that we can comply with the definitions of proprietary trading and other activities. So those are clearly the cases. The bigger issue is whether we all are going to see a secular change in the level of activity in those businesses. You and I know that's really hard to predict
column600: and we all are living in an environment where the interest rates are 2%. And on the other hand
column601: we're expecting some of these businesses to return some very good rates of return. Now how that all squares
column602: we're going to have to see. And that's probably the most uncertain part. The part that we're more certain about is that capital markets activities
column603: albeit slowly and albeit in a smaller volume to date are moving to the emerging markets. It's the emerging market companies that are doing the IPOs. It's the emerging market companies that are going to need issuance of debt and all of the M&A that goes with that
column604: and that's one of those businesses that we are investing against as a company. So you can see it sort of a picture with a lot of factors that are changing
column605: which means that you got to be right on top of the business
column606:
making sure you're sizing the business correctly and optimizing it to where we think activity is going to come from and taking some guesses as to what the secular level of activity is going to be.

column739: you would have expected our risk-weighted assets to have dropped by about $30 billion this quarter. And in fact
column740: they only dropped by about $11 billion. So we had growth on our risk-weighted assets. And that comes from 3 basic factors. About 1/3 of that increase comes from loan growth
column741: again
column742: x FX. Risk-weighted assets associated with loans grew by about $7 billion in the quarter. Another $6 billion or $7 billion was risk-weighted asset growth in our trading book
column743: that was driven by factoring in market volatility into the various models. And then the other 1/3 was a combination of repositioning some of our AFS securities and some of our reverses out of 0 risk-weighted assets into 20% or 50% risk-weighted assets. So those 3 factors kind of add up to the $20 billion worth of risk-weighted asset growth. And if you think about it
column744: each -- as I think we put in the Q
column745: each $10 billion of risk-weighted asset growth impacts our Tier 1 ratio by about 12 basis points. So that $20 billion generally would be somewhere around 24 basis points and I think the way the roundings work
column746:
you probably get an extra 3/10 increase in our published Tier 1 ratio.

column779: improved the credit quality
column780: and it's fully funded by our deposit base. Why now is also a result of understanding all the changes that came out of the CARD Act
column781: and I think that one of the biggest changes coming out of the CARD Act is that bank open lines on branded cards had been rationalized
column782: total amount of credit outstanding has been rationalized and that retail credit at point of sale is an important source of financing for people who are buying large items
column783: such as those that are private label partners' supply. And so basically
column784: consumer behavior has changed
column785: and we think that this form of white label or private label credit is going to be important part of what drives consumer sales

column789: and looked at sort of the credit requirements in the U.S. marketplace. And we generally feel that it is
column790: therefore

column1325: we wouldn't have moved it unless we went through
column1328: strategic view as to what was happening to credit in the U.S. and the customer base in the U.S. and what's happening to funding and all of that. And the fact is that there is a closer relation between the private label card business and customers being able to get credit today than prior to the CARD Act being passed and prior to Basel III rules. And so it was on the basis of all of that. We also see a trend
column1330: where it's going to be quite likely that not all banks are going to be able to own the last mile in terms of the customer. And therefore
column1331: having these capabilities to serve our corporate clients customers are an important part of the services we have to offer them as well. So it was in relation to that. It was in relation to the fact that we're going to manage that portfolio as tightly as we are managing today in terms of making sure it's high credit quality. And so this was not based on any one quarter or any one month in terms of assessment. It was based on what we think it means to us longer term
column1332: and what it's going to contribute to our earnings base

We do not target a growth rate. We target a clientele that we believe we can help and a lot depends upon what our clients need. And that
column1343: our clientele in some of these markets is different than some of the local banks might have or who much more penetration. They are much more mass-market than we are. column1344: they will have an impact. But the second part is

and we are still underpenetrated in terms of serving some of these clients that we may have a structural growth rate that may turn out to be different than the broader GDP growth rate of other countries. That's what's going to drive our growth. But it is not driven by saying we need to make an x amount of target in terms of loan growth. It's based on serving our clients and the credit quality we're comfortable with.

John
column75: thank you
column76: and good morning
column77: everybody. Thank you for joining us today. As you know
column78: earlier today
column79: we reported earnings of $1.2 billion in net income for the fourth quarter of 2011. This increased our net income for the year to $11.3 billion
column81:
"

The fourth quarter was dominated by the macro environment
column82: and our earnings clearly suffered as a result. Market activity was down significantly and our clients reduced their risk. Any of our businesses geared to the capital markets
column83: such as sales and trading
column84:
Securities and Fund Services and GTS and even investment sales and consumer banking were impacted.

"
column85:
"

Investor activity was particularly weak in December as reflected in the volumes we experienced. In light of the macro environment
column86: we have been quite cautious. The situation in Europe is being driven by politics as much as anything else. And given its inherent unpredictability
column87: we have prudently derisked and hedged our exposures
column88:
actions which have further impacted our revenues.

"
column89:
"

However
column90: our consumer and nonmarkets-related businesses continue to perform well as we executed our strategy. Throughout Citicorp
column91: we grew our loans by 14% from 2010
column92: including a 24% increase in corporate loans. And GTS continued to show positive momentum with the full year revenue of 5% from 2010. Revenue from International Consumer Banking grew by 6%
column93: x FX for the year as we opened 3 million new accounts while increasing average loans and deposits on a constant dollar basis by $15 billion and $9 billion
column94:
respectively.

"
column95:
"

During the quarter
column96: we achieved positive operating leverage in Latin America and again in Asia during the quarter. In the U.S.
column97: customer accounts
column98: deposits
column99: loans and revenue each grew from the previous quarter. We continue to make progress in winding down Citi Holdings. We reduced Holdings' assets by $90 billion during the year. And after considering the impact of the transfer of Retail Partner Cards into Citicorp
column100:
Holdings comprised only 12% of Citigroup's balance sheet.

"
column101:
"

And as I indicated in December
column102: we took a $400 million severance charge in the fourth quarter due to the reduction of approximately 5
column103: 000 positions. There were also other macro and episodic charges that John will go over in his presentation
column104: including FX
column105: a Japan DTA write-down and increased legal and related expenses. We also didn't have the CVA/DVA benefit
column106:
which had substantially increased our revenue in the third quarter.

"
column107:
"

As we know
column108: the situation in Europe is having a global impact. We believe it will impact U.S. GDB -- GDP by somewhere within 0.5% to 1.5%
column109: and the emerging markets are being affected as well. The European banks have $40 trillion in total assets and they are deleveraging as a result. And from what we understand
column110:
these banks hold 65% of an emerging market debt and finance 80% of global trade finance. So the global banking system will need to step up and fill the void that comes from the deleveraging.

"
column111:
"

As usual
column112: the future isn't easy to predict
column113: but we believe we are prepared. Despite the improved tone of the market so far this month and the positive signs coming from Europe
column114:
we will continue to maintain a cautious posture until the political aspects of the current situation are clear.

"
column115:
"

In 2011
column116: our expenses were impacted by several factors. Most significantly
column117: a weakened dollar added $800 million in FX
column118: while legal and related expenses were $1.3 billion higher than in 2010. These drove an increase in total expenses of just under 7%. But as you will see
column119: our core operating expenses rose by 2.1%. This includes $3.9 billion in investments
column120:
$1.9 billion of which were funded through our ongoing expense reduction initiatives.

"
column121:
"

The $3.9 billion in investments included approximately $1 billion to meet regulatory requirements. We also upgraded talent in both our institutional and consumer businesses. Other investments from modernizing our branches to increased marketing are necessary to attract and serve our clients better.

"
column122:
"

A few years ago
column123: the company had substantially reduced its spending on consumer marketing. And in 2011
column124: we increased that spending to competitive levels. These are longer-cycle investments
column125:
but they are starting to pay off through increases in our new account acquisitions in the U.S. and the attaining of positive operating leverage in key EM consumer markets.

"
column126:
"

That being said
column127: I believe these increases in expense levels are behind us. We have a robust reengineering program and our goal is to self-fund new investments going forward. As a result of this and other actions
column128: we currently expect to reduce our expenses by $2.5 billion to $3 billion in 2012 compared to the reported full year 2011 level
column129: of course
column130: excluding changes in FX or unanticipated legal costs or significant one-timers. We also continue to right-size our business for the opportunities we see
column131:
particularly in Securities and Banking. So we're prepared whether the current environment proves to be a result of cyclical or secular trends.

Now let me close with some comments about 2012. Clearly
column366: the operating environment continues to be extraordinarily challenging in a number of businesses
column367: none more so than Securities and Banking. While we have seen some pickup in activity in the first weeks of January
column368:
the macro uncertainty that has dominated the securities market still remains unresolved. And that largely reflects the ongoing overhang of the Eurozone crisis.

"
column369:
"

As Vikram noted
column370: we reduced our risk in the fourth quarter and we saw both institutional and retail clients do likewise
column371: which contributed to meaningfully lower levels of activity across markets and regions. While we firmly believe that Europe has the financial wherewithal to solve the sovereign crisis
column372: any resolution will be a political process
column373: which continues to be uncertain and unpredictable. So until the markets believe that an achievable
column374: comprehensive resolution to the European sovereign debt crisis has been structured
column375:
the macro uncertainty that has dominated investor activity will likely remain an issue.

"
column376:
"

Now the challenges in Europe are not all bad news for us. The significant deleveraging of the European banks is creating meaningful competitive opportunities in a number of businesses
column377: particularly in Transaction Services
column378: as European banks are pulling back from serving many clients in key businesses they historically dominate
column379: like trade finance. And we are pursuing those opportunities
column380:
but doing so in a cautious manner as we continue to support our clients while maintaining a tight risk profile.

"
column381:
"

Given the ongoing headwinds in Securities and Banking
column382: we remain very focused on expenses and
column383: as Vikram mentioned
column384: also on ensuring our capacity is aligned with the opportunities that we see. For 2012
column385: we currently expect Citigroup's full year operating expenses
column386: excluding the impact of foreign exchange and any significant episodic items
column387:
will be between $2.5 billion and $3 billion lower than the reported 2011 expenses of $50.7 billion.

"
column388:
"

Turning to our other businesses. In Transaction Services
column389: we expect revenues to continue to grow at a moderate pace despite the low interest rate environment
column390:
and we are reaffirming our expectation that Transaction Services will achieve positive operating leverage by the second or third quarter of this year.

"
column391:
"

In North America Consumer Banking
column392: we expect consumer credit to continue improving but at a slowing pace in 2012. We are seeing positive trends in this business as we have completed much of the portfolio derisking undertaken following the crisis. We are beginning to see the benefit of our investment spending as card accounts
column393:
purchase sales and loans have all stabilized and are now beginning to grow. We believe this will drive positive operating leverage by the end of 2012.

"
column394:
"

In International Consumer Banking
column395: we had positive operating leverage overall this quarter as both Latin America and Asia generated positive operating leverage
column396: building on the momentum started by Asia in the third quarter. While we are seeing some slowing in certain drivers
column397: like investment sales in Asia
column398: reflecting again the cautious sentiment of even retail investors
column399: broadly speaking
column400: we continue to see growth in loans
column401: deposits
column402:
purchase sales and accounts in virtually every region.

"
column404: the transfer of Retail Partner Cards business will result in approximately $45 billion of assets
column405: including $41 billion of loans moving to Citicorp. As a result of this transfer
column406: earnings in Citi Holdings will be lower going forward as the cards business was the single source of meaningful profitability in Local Consumer Lending segment in Citi Holdings. Nonetheless
column407:
we are reaffirming our prior guidance that existing reserves plus expected pre-provision net revenue in the Local Consumer Lending business remain sufficient to cover expected lifetime losses in the remaining LCL portfolio.

"
column408:
"

We continue to believe mortgage-related issues are the single largest source of risk facing the U.S. banking industry. While we expect our overall delinquencies to rise slightly in coming quarters as some previously modified mortgages start re-defaulting
column409: to date
column410: those re-default rates remain below our expectations. Despite the expected delinquency increase
column411: we saw some positive signs in early bucket mortgage delinquencies this quarter that we will continue to watch carefully. In the meantime
column412:
litigation and regulatory risk in the mortgage business will remain high and we continue to focus on further reducing our portfolio.

"
column413:
"

So
column414: in summary
column415: the uncertain macro environment will continue to be a meaningful headwind for our Securities and Banking business
column416: but our consumer businesses and Transaction Services should continue to exhibit growth
column417:
and we will continue to wind-down Citi Holdings in an economically rational manner.

"

Vikram and I would be more than happy to take your questions.

column994: let me talk about it this way. The biggest broad-based repositioning is towards less resources in some of the more developed markets and more resources in the emerging markets. That's a very big
column995: broad piece. I think that works through all our businesses
column998: et cetera. But that's one big piece. The second big piece of restructuring is still towards those businesses that are more services-oriented
column1000: those kind of -- restructuring towards the kind of activities that allow us to serve our clients by providing them services and loans. That's the second type of restructuring. Third type of restructuring is in reaction to our view as to what volumes are going to be in the different product areas. I think it is clear to us that some of the credit markets
column1002: some of the other derivative markets are going to have different kind of volumes than what we've been used to. We've been restructuring towards that. We've been restructuring towards volumes that may be lower as a result of Basel III charges in certain areas as well. So that's the third big round of restructuring. And I guess
column1006: is our general view is that with more companies
column1007: that will over time go public and more credit markets in the emerging markets that we're skewing our resources a little bit more in that area. So that's the big picture kind of perspective which -- John

Hello

column46: Vikram Pandit; and Chief Financial Officer
column47: John Gerspach. Today's call will be hosted by John Andrews

you may begin.

"
column57: and thank you for joining us this morning. As usual
column58: on our call today
column59: our CEO
column60: Vikram Pandit
column61: will speak first. Then
column62: John Gerspach
column63: our CFO
column64: will take you through the earnings presentation in some detail
