column66: citigroup.com. Afterwards
column67:
we will be happy to take your questions.

"
column68:
"

Before we get started
column69: I would like to remind you that today's presentation may contain forward-looking statements
column70: which are based on management's current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results and capital and other financial condition may differ materially from those statements due to a variety of factors
column71: including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today and those included in our SEC filings and including
column72: without limitation
column73:
the Risk Factors section of our 2011 Form 10-K.

"
column74:
"

With that said
column75:
let me turn it over to Vikram.

"
column76:
"

Vikram S. Pandit

"
column77:
"

John
column78: thank you
column79: and good morning
column80: everybody. Thanks for joining us today. As you know
column81: earlier today
column82: we reported net income of $2.9 billion for the first quarter of 2012. x CVA and excluding the net gain from minority stakes
column83:
we earned $3.4 billion in net income or $1.11 per share. This is a significant increase both from the first and fourth quarters of 2011.

"
column84:
"

While our business has operated in an improved environment
column85: we also saw the benefit of our investments. We generated revenue growth and had positive operating leverage across all 3 of Citi's core businesses
column86: that is
column87: Global Consumer Banking
column88: Securities and Banking and Transaction Services. Key drivers
column89: such as loans in Citicorp
column90: grew by 12% from the prior year
column91:
while we deepened client relationships and improved market share in several businesses.

"
column92:
"

Global Consumer Banking generated $10 billion in revenues in the quarter
column93: up 5% from the previous year. Securities and Banking revenues rebounded
column94: driven by particularly strong performances in Fixed Income. In Transaction Services
column95: revenues were a record $2.7 billion
column96: reflecting strong growth
column97: particularly in trade finance
column98:
where our unique global footprint gives us a meaningful competitive edge.

"
column99:
"

Overall
column100: net income x CVA for our institutional businesses increased 12% compared to first quarter of 2011 and was 4.5x larger when compared to the fourth quarter of 2011. We reduced our legacy assets in Citi Holdings by 7% during the quarter
column101:
and Citi Holdings assets are now at $209 billion or just 11% of our total assets.

"
column102:
"

While the operating environment improved in the first quarter
column103: there is still much macro uncertainty
column104:
and we'll continue to manage our risk carefully.

"
column105:
"

Let me now turn to capital and liquidity. First
column106: let me share with you some numbers since we further added to our capital base during the first quarter. We ended the quarter with $122 billion of Tier 1 common capital and a ratio of 12.4% under Basel I
column107: up from 11.8% at the end of fourth quarter. And for the first time
column108: we're sharing our Tier 1 common ratio on a Basel III basis
column109: which stood at an estimated 7.2% at the end of the quarter. Keep in mind that Basel III requires the deductions of certain minority holdings on a dollar-for-dollar basis from an institutions capital base
column110:
and the 7.2% figure reflects that.

"
column111:
"

In aggregate
column112: our minority investments in unconsolidated financial institutions
column113: such as Akbank and Morgan Stanley Smith Barney
column114: amount to 120 basis points of deduction. As you know
column115:
we expect to reduce certain of these stakes over time.

"
column116:
"

While we're at 7.2% now
column117: we still expect to exceed 8% by the end of this year and have various paths to do so. In fact
column118: based on our current analyst estimates of our earnings for the remainder of 2012 and anticipated actions
column119: including the reduction of our stake in Akbank
column120:
we expect to be above 8% even if Morgan Stanley doesn't exercise its option to buy 14% of the MSSB joint venture this year.

"
column121:
"

On liquidity
column122: more than 1/4 of our balance sheet is in cash or liquid securities. And even though the Basel III liquidity coverage ratio doesn't come into effect until 2015
column123: we are at an estimated LCR ratio in excess of 125%. We have already exceeded the proposed requirements. As you can see
column124:
our capital and liquidity numbers are amongst the strongest in our industry globally.

"
column125:
"

That leads me now to the CCAR process. While several capital actions were approved
column126: such as redeeming certain series of outstanding trust preferred securities
column127: we have to resubmit our capital plan to the Fed. However
column128: we do understand that new factors may need to be taken into account in the resubmission
column129: and that
column130: in any event
column131: we need to understand the process going forward in order to make a determination on what to include in our resubmission. At this point
column132: we expect to receive additional information from the Fed this month
column133: and we're required to submit our revised plan by mid-June. The Fed
column134: then
column135: has 75 days to review the plans
column136:
and that time frame stretches almost to the end of the third quarter.

"
column137:
"

As we consider our resubmission for this year
column138: we also have to keep in mind that we will be resubmitting the 2013 capital plan to the Fed a short time later. We're having the conversations with the Fed
column139: which will inform what we submit and what we ask for. And obviously
column140: for all of us on the phone
column141: that could range from resubmitting exactly what we asked for before all the way to waiting until the 2013 submission. We
column142: that is the management and the board
column143: will make a decision
column144: which takes all of these factors in account
column145: and of course
column146: we'll have more to say later in the process. In the meantime
column147: what I can promise you is that we expect to keep building our capital. We'll keep executing our strategy
column148:
and we'll take every step we can to generate strong returns for our shareholders.

"
column149:
"

Finally
column150: as many of you know
column151: we're commemorating our 200th anniversary this year. The central mission of our bank throughout has been to support economic progress. Our historic strengths: facilitating international trade flows
column152: maintaining a strong presence in the world\u2019s largest cities and focusing on the emerging markets are well suited for today's connected world. We see positive signs throughout our businesses
column153:
and we're going to serve our clients by putting our unique capabilities to work for them.

"
column154:
"

Now let me turn this over to John who will review our results in detail
column155: and then
column156: of course
column157:
we'd be happy to take your questions at the end of that.

"
column158:
"

John C. Gerspach

"
column159:
"

Okay
column160: thank you
column161: Vikram
column162: and good morning
column163: everyone. Before I go into more detail on the quarter
column164:
I'd like to highlight a few significant items affecting our results.

"
column165:
"

First
column166: on the revenue slide -- on the revenue side
column167: CVA and DVA were negative $1.3 billion in the first quarter as Citi's credit spreads tightened. We also benefited from a pretax gain of nearly $500 million related to minority investments. On the expense side
column168: legal and related expenses remained elevated at over $500 million. However
column169:
repositioning charges declined to $66 million from over $400 million in the prior quarter.

"
column170:
"

Now on Slide 4
column171: we show first quarter results. Citigroup reported net income of $2.9 billion or $0.95 per diluted share. Excluding CVA/DVA and the minority investment gain
column172: earnings were $3.4 billion or $1.11 per diluted share. Revenues of $19.4 billion were down 2% versus the prior year on a reported basis. However
column173: excluding CVA/DVA and the minority investment gain
column174:
revenues were up 1% from last year as revenue growth in Citicorp outpaced the decline in Citi Holdings.

"
column175:
"

Expenses of $12.3 billion were roughly flat year-over-year on a reported basis. Excluding the impact of foreign exchange translation and the significant expense items I just mentioned
column176: operating expenses were up less than 1%. Incremental investment spending was more than offset by efficiency savings. Credit costs of $3 billion were down 5% versus last year. Net credit losses of $4 billion were down 37% year-over-year
column177: including incremental charge-offs of approximately $370 million in the first quarter related to previously deferred principal balances on modified mortgages
column178:
which I'll discuss later.

"
column179:
"

Excluding these incremental charge-offs
column180: NCLs would have been down 43% from last year. Virtually all of the incremental $370 million of charge-offs was offset by a reserve release specific to the deferred principal amounts
column181: and so the net impact was essentially earnings neutral. Excluding this specific release
column182: the net reserve release in the first quarter would have been roughly $800 million
column183:
down from $3.3 billion in the prior year. Citigroup end-of-period loans were up 2% from last year to nearly $650 billion as strong loan growth in Citicorp continued to outpace the wind down of Citi Holdings and deposits grew 5% to over $900 billion.

"
column184:
"

On Slide 5
column185: we show results for Citicorp and Citi Holdings
column186: excluding the impact of CVA/DVA. Citicorp generated first quarter revenues of $19.4 billion and net income of $5.2 billion. Year-over-year
column187: Citicorp's revenues and expenses grew by 6% and 1%
column188: respectively
column189: with positive operating leverage in every business. Pre-provision net revenues in Citicorp were over $9 billion for the quarter
column190: up 12% from last year. And for the fifth consecutive quarter
column191: we grew loans year-over-year in every business in Citicorp. Citicorp's loans grew 12%
column192:
with consumer up 6% and corporate loans up 23%.

"
column193:
"

Citi Holdings had revenues of $786 million and a net loss of $1.1 billion. Citi Holdings ended the quarter with $209 billion of assets
column194: down $16 billion during the quarter and $86 billion or nearly 30% year-over-year. At quarter end
column195:
Citi Holdings accounted for just under 11% of total Citigroup assets.

"
column196:
"

On Slide 6
column197: we show a 9-quarter trend for Citicorp's results. Excluding CVA/DVA
column198: Citicorp's revenues of $19.4 billion in the first quarter were up 6% from the prior year and up 23% from the prior quarter
column199: driven by growth in each of our core businesses. Operating expenses of $10.3 billion were up slightly versus the prior year on a reported basis. Excluding the impact of FX and the significant expense items I noted earlier
column200:
expenses were up 2% on higher volumes in Consumer Banking and Transaction Services. Incremental investment spending was more than offset by efficiency savings.

"
column201:
"

Citicorp's net credit losses were $2.2 billion
column202: down over 30% from the prior year
column203: driven by improvement in North America cards. The net loan loss reserve release in Citicorp was significantly lower this quarter
column204: at $588 million compared to $1.8 billion last year. This reflects lower net releases in North America cards
column205: as well as reserve builds in international Consumer Banking and the corporate portfolio
column206: primarily driven by loan growth. Excluding CVA/DVA
column207: earnings before taxes of $7.4 billion were up 12% versus last year and more than double from the prior quarter
column208: driven by higher revenues and lower net credit losses
column209:
partially offset by a lower net reserve release.

"
column210:
"

On Slide 7
column211: we show results for our global consumer bank. In the first quarter
column212: we generated $10 billion in revenues
column213: up 6% year-over-year on a constant dollar basis. International revenue growth has accelerated in recent quarters
column214: reflecting our investments
column215: while in North America
column216: the turnaround continued. Excluding loan loss reserves
column217: we have steadily grown our pretax earnings each quarter for over 2 years
column218:
with strong recent growth in North America.

"
column219:
"

Slide 8 shows the results for North America Consumer Banking
column220: which now includes retail partner cards and Citi retail services. Total revenues of $5.2 billion were up 5% versus last year
column221: largely driven by higher gains on sales of mortgage loans. Card revenues declined year-over-year
column222: reflecting spread compression in branded cards due to the continued impact of the look-back provisions of CARD Act and higher promotional balances
column223:
as well as lower average card loans.

"
column224:
"

Expenses of $2.3 billion were up 3% year-over-year as incremental investments were partially offset by efficiency savings and the absence of a litigation reserve in the prior year. Credit costs declined by nearly 1/3 from last year to $802 million. Net credit losses were down 31% to $1.6 billion
column225: driven by cards
column226:
and the net reserve release was $841 million this quarter compared to $1.2 billion in the prior year.

"
column227:
"

Earnings before tax
column228: excluding the impact of loan loss reserves
column229: grew to $1.2 billion from less than $300 million last year. Overall
column230: we continue to see progress in our North America consumer franchise. Average deposits grew for the fourth consecutive quarter
column231: up 4% year-over-year
column232: including double-digit growth in checking account balances. In branded cards
column233: accounts also grew for the fourth consecutive quarter
column234: up 5% year-over-year
column235: and purchase sales grew 3%. And in retail services
column236:
purchase sales were up 2%.

"
column237:
"

Turning to international Consumer Banking on Slide 9. In total
column238: the international consumer businesses achieved positive operating leverage for the second consecutive quarter
column239: with reported revenue and expense growth of 4% and 2%
column240: respectively. On a constant dollar basis
column241: revenues grew 7% and expenses were up 5%. Revenue growth continued to reflect improvement in most underlying drivers
column242:
offset by spread compression due in part to the continued migration to higher quality borrowers.

"
column243:
"

Accounts grew 6% year-over-year
column244: and on a constant dollar basis
column245: we grew average deposits
column246: average loans and purchase sales in every region in the first quarter. Investment sales remained lower than the prior year. However
column247: we saw a rebound from the fourth quarter as retail investors sentiment improved. As I noted
column248: expenses of $2.9 billion were up 5% on a constant dollar basis
column249:
driven by volume-related costs as modest incremental investment spending was more than offset by efficiency savings.

"
column250:
"

Credit costs were $799 million in the first quarter as compared to $490 million last year. While net credit losses declined modestly to $649 million
column251: we recorded a net reserve build of $106 million in the first quarter
column252: principally due to portfolio growth versus a net release in the prior year. Earnings before tax
column253: excluding the impact of loan loss reserves
column254:
grew 15% year-over-year to $1.3 billion.

"
column255:
"

On Slide 10
column256: we show growth trends for international Consumer Banking in more detail. On a constant dollar basis
column257: average loans grew 12% over the prior year; average deposits were up 3%; and purchase sales grew 13%. As reported
column258: on a trailing 12-month basis
column259: we have grown both net credit margin and pretax earnings
column260: excluding the impact of loan loss reserves
column261:
each quarter for over 2 years.

"
column262:
"

Slide 11 shows our Securities and Banking business. Excluding CVA/DVA
column263: revenues of $6.7 billion were up 6% from last year and more than double the revenues of the prior quarter. Investment banking revenues of $865 million were up 2% from the prior year on strong debt underwriting activity and up 36% sequentially as both equity and debt underwriting rebounded from fourth quarter levels. While M&A activity remains under pressure in the current environment
column264: Citi has gained share in announced M&A year-to-date. x CVA/DVA
column265: equity market revenues of $902 million were down 18% from the prior year on lower market volumes. However
column266: sequentially
column267:
revenues were up significantly on improved trading performance in derivatives and higher cash equities revenues.

"
column268:
"

Fixed income market revenues
column269: x CVA/DVA
column270: of $4.7 billion were up 19% year-over-year and more than double from fourth quarter levels
column271: driven by strong performance in G10 Rates and local markets foreign exchange. Lending revenues of $56 million were down significantly versus prior periods as strong growth in net interest revenues was more than offset by over $500 million of losses on lending hedges in the first quarter
column272:
driven by spread tightening.

"
column273:
"

Private bank revenues
column274: excluding CVA/DVA
column275: were $576 million
column276: up 11% versus each of the prior periods on growth in deposit and loan volumes
column277: as well as stronger capital markets activity. Total operating expenses of $3.7 billion were down 2% from last year
column278: driven by efficiency savings
column279:
and credit costs were $58 million in the first quarter versus a benefit of $187 million last year.

"
column280:
"

Moving to Transaction Services on Slide 12. Revenues of $2.7 billion were up 7% from last year as strong growth in Treasury and Trade Solutions more than offset a decline in Securities and Fund Services. Treasury and Trade Solutions was up 11%
column281: driven by strong growth in deposits and trade loans. Securities and Fund Services was down 4% year-over-year. However
column282:
revenues grew 5% sequentially as activity levels began to rebound from the fourth quarter.

"
column283:
"

The underlying drivers for Transaction Services continue to show strong momentum. End of period trade loans were up nearly 60% from the first quarter of last year
column284: and average deposits were up 6%. Assets under custody were flat year-over-year
column285: but up 4% from the prior quarter. Expenses of $1.4 billion were up 3% versus last year on higher volumes
column286: as incremental investment spending was more than offset by efficiency savings. Importantly
column287: we achieved positive operating leverage in Transaction Services in the first quarter
column288: and this should be sustainable going forward. Strong revenues
column289: combined with a modest increase in expenses
column290:
drove 10% earnings growth year-over-year to over $900 million.

"
column291:
"

On Slide 13
column292: we show a 9-quarter trend for Citi Holdings. The reported loss in Citi Holdings was $1 billion in the first quarter
column293: slightly higher versus last year but improved from the prior quarter. Revenues
column294: excluding CVA/DVA
column295: were down over 50% year-over-year to $786 million
column296: due primarily to lower assets
column297: as well as the absence of positive private equity marks in the prior period. Operating expenses of $1.2 billion were down 16% versus last year
column298:
and total credit costs were down 21% to $1.3 billion.

"
column299:
"

Looking at Citi Holdings in more detail on Slide 14. Revenues in Brokerage and Asset Management were negative $46 million this quarter
column300: down from last year due to a lower contribution from the Morgan Stanley Smith Barney joint venture
column301: as well as higher funding costs. In Local Consumer Lending
column302: revenues were down 13% versus last year to $1.3 billion
column303: driven by declining loan balances. In the Special Asset Pool
column304: revenues
column305: x CVA/DVA
column306:
were negative $494 million in the first quarter.

"
column307:
"

Net interest revenue was negative $102 million as interest-earning assets continued to represent a smaller portion of the Special Asset Pool
column308: while we continued to incur funding costs on the total portfolio. Noninterest revenue
column309: excluding CVA/DVA
column310: was negative $392 million
column311: down $353 million from prior year
column312: driven by the absence of positive private equity marks in the prior year period
column313:
as well as a reserve build of $150 million related to private-label mortgage securitizations.

"
column314:
"

Citi Holdings operating expenses were down 16% year-over-year to $1.2 billion
column315: mainly due to declining assets
column316: partially offset by higher legal and related costs. Credit costs were down 21% year-over-year to $1.3 billion. Total net credit losses were down 43% to $1.7 billion
column317: reflecting a significant reduction in loans in the Special Asset Pool
column318:
as well as a declining loan balance and improved credit trends in Local Consumer Lending.

"
column319:
"

On a sequential basis
column320: net credit losses were up $222 million
column321: driven by an increase in North America mortgages. As I noted earlier
column322: in the first quarter
column323: we recorded roughly $370 million of incremental charge-offs related to previously deferred principal balances on modified mortgages
column324: virtually all of which was offset by a specific reserve release. These charge-offs were related to anticipated forgiveness of principal
column325: largely in connection with the national mortgage settlement. Excluding the incremental charge-offs
column326: net credit losses in Citi Holdings would have declined 10% sequentially. In total
column327:
we released $576 million of net loan loss reserves in Citi Holdings compared to $1.5 billion in the prior year.

"
column328:
"

Slide 15 shows Citi Holdings' assets. We ended the quarter with $209 billion in Citi Holdings or just under 11% of total Citigroup assets. The $16 billion reduction in the first quarter was comprised of roughly $4 billion of asset sales and business dispositions
column329:
approximately $11 billion of net runoff and paydowns and $1 billion of net cost of credit and net asset marks.

"
column330:
"

Slide 16 shows the results for the Corporate/Other segment. Revenues of $500 million were up significantly from last year
column331: mainly driven by the $477 million net gain related to minority investments
column332: which I described earlier. Expenses were up $148 million versus last year
column333:
driven by higher legal and related costs. Assets of $312 billion included approximately $121 billion of cash and cash equivalents and $135 billion of liquid available-for-sale securities.

"
column334:
"

Turning to total Citigroup expenses on Slide 17. First quarter expenses of $12.3 billion were roughly flat to the prior year
column335: with both periods including a similar combined level of legal and related costs and repositioning charges of around $600 million. Adjusting for these items
column336: as well as the impact of foreign exchange
column337:
core operating expenses grew less than 1% in the first quarter. Incremental investment spending of $400 million was more than offset by nearly $600 million of efficiency savings. We continue to be highly focused on managing our core operating expenses.

"
column338:
"

Slide 18 shows total Citigroup net credit losses and loan loss reserves. NCLs continued to improve in the first quarter
column339: down 4% sequentially to $4 billion
column340: and the net loan loss reserve release was $1.2 billion
column341: down from $1.5 billion in the fourth quarter. Excluding the incremental mortgage charge-offs I mentioned earlier of roughly $370 million
column342: NCLs would have been down 13% sequentially and the net reserve release would have been roughly $800 million. We ended the quarter with $29 billion of total loan loss reserves
column343:
and our loan loss reserve ratio was 4.5%.

"
column344:
"

Consumer NCLs were stable versus the fourth quarter at $4 billion even with the incremental mortgage charge-offs
column345:
and we released $1.3 billion in consumer loan loss reserves. Corporate credit costs were $29 million in the first quarter compared to a net benefit of $158 million last quarter as we recorded a net build in reserves this quarter versus a release in the prior period.

"
column346:
"

Slide 19 shows our international consumer credit trends
column347: which generally remained stable to improving in Citicorp in the first quarter as loans continued to grow. In Asia
column348: the NCL rate continued to improve in the first quarter and 90-plus-day delinquencies were fairly flat at around 50 basis points. In Latin America
column349: the sequential decline in NCL rate reflects
column350: in part
column351: the absence of adjustments in Central America
column352: which resulted in higher credit losses in the fourth quarter. However
column353: even excluding these adjustments from the prior period
column354:
the NCL rate would have been improved sequentially.

"
column355:
"

In Local Consumer Lending in Citi Holdings
column356: net credit losses were down quarter-over-quarter on a dollar basis. However
column357:
the NCL rate increased on a lower average loan balance. The increase in the 90-plus-day delinquency rate was also primarily driven by the decline in loans.

"
column358:
"

On Slide 20
column359: we show the North America mortgage portfolio in Citi Holdings split between residential first mortgages and home equity loans. Regarding the incremental charge-offs of about $370 million in North America real estate
column360: approximately $315 million was attributable to residential first mortgages
column361: with the remainder in home equity loans. Excluding this action
column362:
total net credit losses for North America real estate in Citi Holdings would have been down slightly versus the prior quarter.

"
column363:
"

In residential first mortgages
column364: we ended the quarter with $65 billion of loans
column365: down 14% from a year ago. Excluding the incremental charge-offs in the first quarter
column366: net credit losses would have increased by 4% from the fourth quarter. 90-plus-day delinquencies remained stable in the first quarter at just over $4 billion. However
column367: we continue to watch these trends closely. In home equity loans
column368: we ended the quarter with nearly $39 billion of loans
column369: down 13% from a year ago. Excluding the incremental charge-offs in the first quarter
column370: net credit losses would have been down 5% sequentially
column371: and 90-plus-day delinquencies were also down versus the prior quarter at roughly $900 million. In total
column372: we continue to allocate nearly $10 billion of our total loan loss reserves to North America real estate lending in Citi Holdings. And excluding the incremental NCL action this quarter
column373:
we maintained over 30 months of coincident NCL coverage.

"
column374:
"

On Slide 21
column375: we show our key capital metrics. Our total Tier 1 capital ratio was 14.2% as of the first quarter
column376: and our Tier 1 common ratio was 12.4%
column377: up 60 basis points from year end. We also grew our tangible book value to $50.90 per share. As Vikram noted
column378: at the end of the first quarter
column379: our estimated Tier 1 common ratio under Basel III was 7.2%
column380: and this included approximately 120 basis points of impact from our nonconsolidated minority investments in financial companies
column381:
including the Morgan Stanley Smith Barney joint venture and Akbank. We continue to expect to be above 8% Basel III -- above our 8% Basel III target even if Morgan Stanley does not exercise its option to buy 14% of the JV this year.

"
column382:
"

Now let me close with some comments about the outlook. First
column383: Global Consumer Banking
column384: our largest business
column385: continues to produce good growth in revenues and earnings
column386: as well as in key drivers like loans and deposits. Credit quality remains good in Asia and Latin America and continues to improve in the U.S. We produced positive operating leverage across all major regions in consumer banking in the first quarter
column387:
although we do not expect to see sustained positive operating leverage in North America until the end of the year.

"
column388:
"

Transaction Services also continues to produce strong revenue and earnings growth and had positive operating leverage a quarter earlier than we had previously expected. Treasury and Trade Solutions is driving the growth in Transaction Services
column389: reflecting our ongoing expansion in trade finance
column390:
where our unique and large global footprint gives us an unmatched competitive advantage. We are optimistic that Transaction Services will have sustained growth and positive operating leverage in the coming quarters.

"
column391:
"

In Securities and Banking
column392: there were a few key takeaways this quarter. First
column393: we believe our underperformance in equities in the second half of last year is behind us. Our proprietary trading business is gone
column394: and our equity derivatives business recovered well
column395: which
column396: we believe
column397: reflects changes we made to that business
column398: including new leadership. Second
column399: our investment banking franchise is beginning to see market share gains in M&A and equity underwriting
column400: while our strong debt underwriting business continues to perform. We think those gains could be an early sign that the investments we made in investment banking resources are beginning to pay off. And finally
column401:
our fixed income business continues to perform well and had a particularly strong first quarter.

"
column402:
"

Overall
column403: we continue to remain highly focused on managing expenses while still investing in key areas. Expenses were relatively flat year-over-year
column404: and we are still targeting 2012 expenses to be $2.5 billion to $3 billion lower than the 2011 reported numbers
column406: of course
column407:
any large impact resulting from foreign exchange or any significant unanticipated items.

"
column408:
"

In Holdings
column409: the wind-down of assets will continue and our primary focus remains the mortgage portfolio. While our portfolio is smaller than our peers\u2019
column410: we continue to believe that mortgages represent the greatest risk to any major bank balance sheet and a number of headwinds remain. More broadly
column411: while the macro environment has improved compared to the second half of last year
column412: there is still much uncertainty
column413: which has been underscored by the recent spate of mixed economic data and rekindled eurozone fears
column414: so we will continue to manage risk carefully and to maintain a strong balance sheet. We remain very optimistic about our prospects given our client franchise
column415:
our unique mix of businesses and our unparalleled footprint.

"
column416:
"

Vikram and I will now be happy to answer your questions.

"

[Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Glenn Schorr of Nomura.

"
column420:
"

Glenn Schorr - Nomura Securities Co. Ltd.
column422:
"

Curious in the whole CCAR process. I'm curious what you've learned now that you've gotten some qualitative impact detail back from the Fed and what you learned on the international loss rates
column423:
how the Fed feels about them and if you've made any -- have any thoughts on the way you manage the business differently going forward as a result of the CCAR process.

"
column424:
"

Vikram S. Pandit

"
column426: let me address that
column427: Glenn. First
column428: the one comment I'd make is if you take a look at CCAR and the stress test and kind of understanding
column429: as you know well
column430: stress tests are tail-risk events and tail-risk events implicitly tell you what kind of capital you should have against businesses. If you think about it that way
column431: the weightings coming out of the CCAR process are very different than the weightings that come out of the Basel III risk-weighted asset process. That's a significant learning for all of us in the industry. Another way of saying that is risk-weighted assets in Basel III overweight risk in trading businesses
column432: while the CCAR is much more in line with what true risk might be. And on the consumer side
column433: the CCAR weightings are higher than the risk weightings on the Basel III process. So for all of us
column435: the questions are around
column436: well
column437: how do you dovetail the 2? And we've always been of the point of view at Citi that our capital charges should be higher our risk capital or risk-weighted assets. And frankly
column438: risk capital's shape
column439: not the magnitude
column440: but the shape of risk capital is much more in line with where the CCAR comes out than where the Basel III numbers are. And I think that's probably the single biggest determinant of where you'd want to put capital to some extent. Although it's early
column441: I can also tell you
column442: you can't necessarily take one year CCAR as given because as we've all learned
column443: these stress tests can keep changing. Scenarios will change
column444: but it is an indication that when you think about capital allocation in your businesses
column445: you need to think about not only Basel
column446: but risk capital
column447: CCAR being one of the measures. That's the big picture kind of issue. On the narrower issues
column448: Glenn
column449: we continue to talk to the Fed
column450: and we're going to continue to do that. We stand by our numbers
column451: our stress test numbers
column452: and we stand by our submission
column453: and there's a lot more we need to do to get closer to understanding exactly how the next part of the process is going to work. And stay tuned
column454:
we'll have more to say later.

"

column1:
{"Citigroup Management Discusses Q1 2012 Results - Fixed Income Call Transcript": ["

Citigroup (NYSE:C)

"
column7:
"

John C. Gerspach - Chief Financial Officer

"
column11:
"

Robert Smalley - UBS Investment Bank
column14:
"

Matthew H. Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities
column23: and welcome to Citi's Fixed Income Investor Review with Chief Financial Officer
column25: Eric Aboaf. Today's call will be hosted by Ilene Fiszel Bieler
column26: Head of Fixed Income Investor Relations. [Operator Instructions] Also as a reminder
column27: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column28: please disconnect at this time. Ms. Fiszel Bieler
column30:
"

Ilene Fiszel Bieler

"
column33: and thank you all for joining us. On our call today
column35: John Gerspach will speak first. Then
column38: will take you through the Fixed Income investor presentation
column39: which is available for download on our website
column41:
we'll be happy to take questions.

"
column42:
"

Before we get started
column43: I would like to remind you that today's presentation may contain forward-looking statements
column44: which are based on management's current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results and capital and other financial conditions may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors
column45: including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today and those included in our SEC filings including
column46: without limitation
column47: the Risk Factors section of our 2011 Form 10-K. With that said
column48:
let me turn it over to John.

"
column49:
"

John C. Gerspach

"
column50:
"

Thank you
column52: and good morning
column53: everyone. We're very pleased to be hosting our Fixed Income investor review this quarter. Today
column54: we're going to update you on our continued execution and progress in several areas including our liquidity and balance sheet management. Eric Aboaf
column56: is going to take you through some specifics on our balance sheet progress
column57: our liquidity profile and our capital position
column58: as well as review our recent issuance activity and current funding plans for the coming year. Many of you may have joined us for last Monday's earnings call
column59:
and there are some key points from that call that I would like to highlight to start us off here on Slide 1.

"
column60:
"

This quarter
column61: we reported net income of $2.9 billion for the first quarter of 2012. x CVA and excluding the net gain from minority investments
column62: we earned $3.4 billion in net income or $1.11 per share. This is a significant increase both from the first and fourth quarters of 2011. While our businesses operated in an improved environment in the first quarter
column63: we also saw the benefit of our investments. We generated revenue growth and had positive operating leverage across Citi's core businesses: Global Consumer Banking
column64: Transaction Services and Securities & Banking. Key drivers such as loans in Citicorp grew by 12% from the prior year
column65:
while we deepened client relationships and improved market share in several businesses.

"
column66:
"

Global Consumer Banking generated $10 billion in revenues in the quarter
column67: up 5% from the previous year. Securities & Banking revenues rebounded
column68:
driven by particularly strong performances in Fixed Income.

"
column69:
"

In Transaction Services
column70: revenues were a record $2.7 billion
column71: reflecting strong growth
column72: particularly in trade finance
column73:
where our unique global footprint gives us a meaningful competitive advantage.

"
column74:
"

Overall
column75: net income x CVA for our institutional businesses increased 12% compared to the first quarter of 2011
column76:
and was 4.5x larger when compared to the fourth quarter of 2011.

"
column77:
"

We reduced our legacy assets in Citi Holdings by 7% during the quarter
column78: and Citi Holdings assets are now at $209 billion or just 11% of our total assets. While the operating environment improved in the first quarter
column79: there is still much macro uncertainty
column80:
and we'll continue to manage risk carefully.

"
column81:
"

Now
column82: let me turn to capital and liquidity. First
column83: let me share with you some numbers since we further added to our capital base during the first quarter. We ended the quarter with $122 billion of Tier 1 common capital
column84: and a ratio of 12.4% under Basel I
column85: up from 11.8% at the end of the fourth quarter. And for the first time
column86: we shared our Tier 1 common ratio on a Basel III basis
column87:
which stood at an estimated 7.2% at the end of the quarter.

"
column88:
"

Now keep in mind that Basel III requires the deductions of certain minority holdings on a dollar-for-dollar basis from an institution's capital base
column89:
and the 7.2% figure reflects that.

"
column90:
"

In aggregate
column91: our minority investments in unconsolidated financial institutions such as Akbank and Morgan Stanley Smith Barney amount to 120 basis points of deduction. As you know
column92: we expect to reduce certain of these stakes over time. While we're at 7.2% now
column93: we still expect to exceed 8% by the end of this year and have various paths to do so. In fact
column94: based on current analyst consensus estimates of our earnings for the remainder of 2012 and our anticipated actions
column95: including the reduction of our stake in Akbank
column96:
we expect to be above 8% even if Morgan Stanley doesn't exercise its option to buy 14% of the MSSB joint venture this year.

"
column97:
"

On liquidity
column98: more than 1/4 of our balance sheet is in cash or liquid securities
column99: and even though the Basel III liquidity coverage ratio doesn't come into effect until 2015
column100: we are at an estimated LCR ratio in excess of 125% at quarter end. As a result
column101: we have already exceeded the proposed requirement. As you can see
column102:
our capital and liquidity numbers are amongst the strongest in our industry globally.

"
column103:
"

Turning to Slide 2. I'd like to reemphasize some of our key earnings results from the first quarter. There are a few significant items I'd like to mention that affected our results. First on the revenue side
column104: CVA and DVA were negative $1.3 billion in the first quarter as Citi's credit spreads tightened. And we also benefited from a pretax gain of nearly $500 million related to minority investments. And on the expense side
column105: legal and related expenses remained elevated at over $500 million. However
column106:
repositioning charges declined to $66 million from over $400 million in the prior quarter.

"
column107:
"

Citigroup reported net income of $2.9 billion or $0.95 per diluted share. Excluding CVA/DVA and the minority investment gain
column108: earnings were $3.4 billion or $1.11 per diluted share. Revenues of $19.4 billion were down 2% versus the prior year on a reported basis. However
column109: excluding CVA/DVA and the minority investment gain
column110: revenues were up 1% from last year
column111:
as revenue growth in Citicorp outpaced the decline in Citi Holdings.

"
column112:
"

Expenses of $12.3 billion were roughly flat year-over-year on a reported basis. Excluding the impact of foreign exchange translation and the significant expense items I just mentioned
column113:
operating expenses were up less than 1%. Incremental investment spending was more than offset by efficiency savings.

"
column114:
"

Credit costs of $3 billion were down 5% versus last year. Net credit losses of $4 billion were down 37% year-over-year
column115: including incremental charge-offs of approximately $370 million in the first quarter related to previously deferred principal balances on modified mortgages. As we discussed in more detail on last week's earnings call
column116: these charge-offs were related to the national mortgage settlement. Excluding these incremental charge-offs
column117: NCLs would have been down 43% from last year. Virtually all of this incremental $370 million of charge-offs was offset by a reserve release specific to the deferred principal amounts. And so the net impact was essentially earnings-neutral. Excluding this specific release
column118: the net reserve release in the first quarter would have been roughly $800 million
column119:
down from $3.3 billion in the prior year.

"
column120:
"

Citigroup end-of-period loans were up 2% from last year
column121: to nearly $650 billion. A strong loan growth in Citicorp continued to outpace the wind-down of Citi Holdings
column122: and deposits grew 5% to over $900 billion. And now
column123:
let me turn it over to Eric.

"
column124:
"

Eric W. Aboaf

"
column125:
"

Thank you
column126: John. While the operating environment improved in the first quarter
column127: we've continued to manage our business and our balance sheet carefully
column128: given the macroeconomic uncertainty. Both our capital and liquidity are robust no matter which measure you use. We have a Basel I Tier 1 common ratio of 12.4%
column129: and a Basel III Tier 1 common estimate of 7.2%
column130: which includes 120 basis point impact from minority investments
column131:
certain of which we intend to divest.

"
column132:
"

We have ample liquidity with $421 billion in aggregate liquidity resources
column133:
and our current Basel III LCR estimate up above 125% is comfortably in excess of the 100% proposed minimum.

"
column134:
"

We continue to make progress in reshaping the balance sheet
column135: which provides us with additional capital and liquidity to strategically deploy in our Citicorp businesses. Year-over-year
column136:
our lending growth is up a healthy 12% in Citicorp and 2% in total after taking into account the Holdings wind-down. Our total deposits are up 5%.

"
column137:
"

We are seeing continued improvement in credit trends
column138: with net credit losses down 37% from a year ago
column139: and we are well reserved with loan loss reserves of $29 billion
column140:
or 4.5% of loans.

"
column141:
"

And net loan loss reserve releases are down approximately 65% year-over-year
column142:
which demonstrates significant improvement in the quality of our earnings this quarter.

"
column143:
"

With this strong balance sheet
column144:
we have the resources and the capabilities to continue to grow as we help our global clientele navigate the current environment.

"
column145:
"

Please turn to Slide 4. Let me describe how we are managing our balance sheet for the current environment and investing to grow the Citicorp businesses. On the left
column146: you see assets for Citicorp and Corp/Other
column147: which are up 5% year-over-year as we continue to reinvest in the franchise. Here
column148:
you can see how we have deployed our balance sheet to support our customers over the past year in Citicorp.

"
column149:
"

For example
column150: net loans
column151: which is our largest asset category
column152: is up approximately $61 billion year-over-year and approximately $8 billion quarter-over-quarter as we continue to lend to both consumer and corporate clients in a disciplined manner. Similarly
column153:
we've increased our trading assets by $18 billion quarter-over-quarter and in line with the prior year period in response to customer demand during the improved operating environment we saw in the first quarter.

"
column154:
"

On the right
column155: you see Citi Holdings assets
column156: which are down 29% year-over-year as the wind-down continues to free up capital. Our Citicorp
column157: Citi Holdings strategy continues to provide us the flexibility to redeploy that capital and take advantage of growth opportunities
column158: particularly in our lending businesses
column159:
while also giving us the ability to size our market-making balance sheet to the current economic environment.

"
column160:
"

Turning to Slide 5. Given our healthier balance sheet
column161: we have been deploying our capital in the Citicorp lending businesses in a disciplined manner
column162: as I just mentioned. So let me describe what we are seeing in loan volumes. In Citicorp
column163: loans grew $514 billion
column164: up 12% year-over-year
column165:
including 6% growth in Consumer and 23% growth in Corporate Loans. This quarter's results represented the seventh consecutive quarter of Citicorp loan growth.

"
column166:
"

In our institutional businesses
column167: lending increased 45% in Transaction Services from the prior year
column168: driven by trade finance lending in Asia
column169: Latin America and Europe. And we saw a 15% growth in our Securities & Banking corporate loan book
column170: which increased borrowing -- with increased borrowing across all client segments and geographies. International Consumer Banking loan volumes increased 8% year-over-year overall
column171: led by growth in Asia and Latin America. These trends reflect the underlying economic growth in these regions
column172: as well as the results of our investment spending
column173:
which are driving growth in both cards and retail loans.

"
column174:
"

North America consumer loan volumes were up modestly at 4%
column175: driven by retail banking loans as the cards market continues to reflect consumer deleveraging
column176:
as well as CARD Act and other regulatory changes. Our overall increase in Citicorp loan volume provides a powerful engine of year-on-year growth in net interest income and accrual earnings.

"
column177:
"

Turning to Slide 6. Having just discussed our loan trends
column178: let's turn to deposits. This page shows how our deposit base is continuing to grow. Deposits around the world are our primary source of funding in the bank
column179: which I will discuss with you further in a moment. Company-wide
column180: deposits increased 5% or $40 billion year-over-year
column181: and increased to a robust 7% in Citicorp. As I've said before
column182: deposits are one of our lowest cost sources of funds. And you can see that while deposits have grown
column183: the overall cost of funds on deposits is down year-over-year and significantly more from prior periods. This reflects both the low rate environment and our ability to lower price points
column184: which widens our margins given abundant customer liquidity
column185: while still remaining competitive and attracting deposits. We would
column186: however
column187: expect to see some pressure on deposit rates due to competitive pricing in certain regions or when interest rates increase. This quarter
column188: in keeping with our client-focused model
column189: we saw healthy deposit growth across all our deposit-taking businesses
column190: including Consumer Banking
column191:
the Private Bank in our Securities & Banking business and in Transaction Services.

"
column192:
"

Turning to Slide 7. This page shows how we continue to improve the quality of our deposit base. You can see on the page that we have been actively changing the composition of our deposits within both Global Consumer Banking and our institutional businesses
column193: meaning Transaction Services and Securities & Banking. Time deposits
column194: where rates are fixed for the term of the deposit and which have lower margins
column195: are becoming a smaller proportion of our base in both businesses
column196:
whereas operating balances are becoming a larger proportion of our deposits. These checking and savings accounts for individuals and cash management accounts for corporations are providing wider margins and have exhibited stickier behavior.

"
column197:
"

Year-over-year
column198: our deposit mix has shifted positively within each business. Operating balances are now 76% and 73% of the total for the global consumer and our institutional businesses
column199: respectively. On a firm-wide basis
column200: operating balances now represent 74% of our overall Citicorp deposit base
column201: whereas last year
column202: they represented approximately 71%
column203: and 2 years ago
column204:
they were at 62%.

"
column205:
"

On Slide 8
column206: I want to show you how the balance sheet activity that we just reviewed is contributing to our net interest margin. This quarter
column207: we saw NIM remain flat
column208: which is largely due to a few offsetting factors. As I mentioned
column209: we rebuilt our trading book after the fourth quarter decline
column210: and those assets came at lower yields. That offset the NIM tailwind that typically comes as loans become a larger proportion of our asset base. At the same time
column211: as you have heard me say before
column212: we have been focused on reducing our borrowing costs. In the bank
column213: we have been substituting maturing long-term debt
column214: which is a more expensive source of funding
column215: with deposits
column216: our lowest-cost source of funds. This has a positive impact on NIM. And finally
column217: we had a reserve release in Japan consumer finance
column218:
which had a positive impact on NIM this quarter.

"
column219:
"

Looking forward
column220: absent any other significant changes
column221: our NIM will likely continue to reflect the pressure of a low interest rate environment and subsequent changes in our portfolio. As such
column222: we expect we'll probably see a NIM ratio closer to approximately 2.85% next quarter. And after that
column223:
we would expect that NIM should be stable or perhaps grow slightly.

"
column224:
"

Turning to Slide 9. Looking at Citi Holdings
column225: let me describe our progress in reducing the amount of our higher-risk assets in general. Holdings assets have declined by 74% from their peak in 2008 to $209 billion and now stand at just 11% of our balance sheet. The $16 billion reduction in the first quarter was comprised of roughly $4 billion of asset sales and business dispositions
column226: approximately $11 billion of net runoff and paydowns and $1 billion of net cost to credit and net asset marks. This slide shows you the key businesses within Citi Holdings where those reductions occurred. Importantly
column227: the 2 largest components of Citi Holdings
column228: the Special Asset Pool and Local Consumer Lending
column229: are down 51% and 24%
column230: respectively
column231: from the first quarter of 2011. And as I've said before
column232:
our Local Consumer Lending U.S. Mortgage business is a fraction of the size of that of our large U.S. bank peers.

"
column233:
"

Clearly
column234: we are continuing to make significant progress executing on our Citi Holdings asset reduction strategy. And as we have stated
column235:
we believe the pace of reductions will continue at approximately this rate.

"
column236:
"

Given the interest in GIIPS countries
column237: we wanted to update you on our exposures on Page 10. At the end of the first quarter
column238: Citi's gross funded credit exposure to GIIPS was $20.5 billion
column239: roughly flat to last quarter. Netted against our gross funded credit exposure
column240: we have margin posted under legally enforceable margin agreements
column241: collateral pledged under bankruptcy-remote structures and purchased credit protection from financial institutions predominantly outside of these 5 countries. These amounts totaled $14.5 billion. So net of this margin
column242: collateral and purchase credit protection
column243: our net current funded exposure to GIIPS at the end of the first quarter was $9.1 billion. This was up a bit from the $7.7 billion last quarter due primarily to normal fluctuations in the trading book
column244: while the banking book itself was down slightly. You can also see that the majority of our exposure in these countries is to corporate
column245: not to the sovereign itself. We continue to carefully manage these exposures while serving our important clients in these countries. Importantly
column246: since the end of the second quarter of 2011
column247: we have decreased our net current funded GIIPS credit exposure by 1/2
column248:
down 50% from $11.9 billion to $6 billion.

"
column249:
"

Now moving to Slide 11. Having discussed balance sheet trends in some detail
column250: now let's review Citi's liquidity and funding strategy
column251: which has been a cornerstone of strength. Our current strategy is designed to provide ample high-quality liquidity to make sure that we are well positioned to grow our core business and navigate various market conditions. In both the bank and nonbank
column252: we carry a healthy liquidity buffer
column253: which is generally held in cash and highly liquid securities
column254: such has treasuries and agencies and other G7 instruments. We execute on this funding strategy in both our bank and nonbank businesses by accessing a spectrum of funding sources. In our bank businesses
column255: our funding is primarily in the form of stable
column256: diversified deposits from around the world
column257: which I discussed earlier. In our nonbank businesses
column258:
we use a modest amount of short-term funding such as repo to finance liquid assets. We then use a range of long-term debt instruments to cover our broader business needs.

"
column259:
"

Our funding strategy has served us well over the last few years and has prepared us easily to meet the proposed Basel III liquidity requirements as we show on Slide 12. The Basel III liquidity coverage ratio or LCR is designed to ensure banks maintain adequate level of unencumbered cash and highly liquid securities that can be converted to cash to meet liquidity needs under an acute 30-day stress scenario. As you are aware
column260: the proposed minimum requirement for the LCR is 100%. The Basel committee recently disclosed results from its quantitative impact study exercise
column261: which was conducted in the second quarter of 2011. The average LCR for all large Group 1 banks was 90%
column262: while the European large bank average was 71%. While we are still awaiting final guidance on the Basel III liquidity coverage ratio
column263: we believe that we are already comfortably in compliance given the current rules as we understand them
column264:
and we are running an estimated LCR ratio above 125%.

"
column265:
"

Given that the industry average is below the proposed minimum requirement
column266: it appears certain banks will need to reposition themselves in order to achieve compliance with the LCR minimum. In this repositioning will likely take the form of issuing more long-term debt to close liquidity gaps
column267: selling less liquid securities inventory and replacing them with government and agency securities
column268: and in raising additional customer deposits or reducing customer lending. Since Citi's current LCR estimate is more than 25% above the proposed minimum
column269:
we believe we will be able to avoid any potential repositioning costs I just outlined.

"
column270:
"

Part of the reason we scored well on the Basel III LCR is the size of our liquidity buffer
column271: which is defined as cash and highly liquid securities on Slide 13. It stood at approximately $421 billion at the end of the first quarter. This quarter
column272: our high-level bank liquidity is up as deposits have increased. At the same time
column273: our nonbank liquidity to support our parent and broker-dealer activities decreased slightly. We continue to believe that this range is proportionally calibrated to the size of our balance sheet and current market conditions. In addition
column274: as of the first quarter
column275: we currently estimate that other entities and subsidiaries held approximately $93 billion of cash and unencumbered liquid securities. When you include this additional liquidity
column276:
our total liquidity buffer is approximately $421 billion.

"
column277:
"

And finally
column278: it is also worth mentioning that we only include our on-balance sheet liquidity buffer here. As such
column279:
we don't include borrowing capacity at the Fed discount window or international central banks or with the FHLB as part of our aggregate liquidity resources. That capacity is over and above what you see on this page.

"
column281: let me describe for you the current status of our ratings
column282: a topic we have discussed quite a bit over the last 1.5 years. As you are aware
column283: S&P and Fitch resolved their industry-wide reviews in the fourth quarter of 2011 and announced their rating changes at that time. You may recall that during this previous rating action
column284: we estimated that less than 1% of our funding could be impacted
column285: and the actual impact was far less and was not material. We are rated A
column286: A-1 with S&P at our key operating entities
column287: Citibank
column288: N.A.; CGMI and CGML ; and A-
column289: A-2 at the Citigroup holding company. Also
column290: we are rated A
column291:
F1 with Fitch at both the operating and holding company levels.

"
column292:
"

As you are also aware
column293: on February 15 of this year
column294: Moody's announced an industry-wide review and placed 17 global banks and securities firms on review for downgrade
column295: along with many more local banks around the world. As you can imagine
column296: we have been in active dialogue with Moody's during the review time period and have been discussing Citi's strong capital and liquidity position
column297:
ever-improving asset quality and overall franchise strength. We have also discussed our relative standing and strength as compared with the other U.S. and European banks on review.

"
column298:
"

Now given this potential action
column299: we have carefully thought through the potential impacts. In this context
column300: we are often asked about funding requirements related to derivatives. As we have disclosed in our filings previously
column301: in the event of a downgrade
column302: Citi may have to post additional funding in the form of cash obligations and collateral. Specifically
column303: in the event of a 2-notch downgrade by Moody's
column304: Citi could be required to post additional funding in the form of cash obligations and collateral of up to approximately $2 billion. This is a subset of what we shared with you in the 10-K
column305:
which represented a 2-notch downgrade across all 3 agencies at once.

"
column306:
"

Further
column307: in terms of the derivatives business
column308: that activity is predominantly conducted on the bank today
column309:
and we do not believe that a downgrade to the A3 level will have a material impact as this remains above the counterparty threshold for the vast majority of our clients.

"
column310:
"

In general
column311: these are very small numbers in the context of our $1.9 trillion balance sheet
column312: as well as when compared to our liquidity buffer
column313:
which as we just discussed is more than $420 billion.

"
column314:
"

Turning to Slide 15
column315: I wanted to take a moment to talk about what we have been hearing and seeing from our clients and investors regarding credit assessments and how that's changed over the years. In the past
column316: when information was limited and infrequent
column317: ratings often served as the only available measure of creditworthiness. This suited an era of smaller
column318: simpler banks with limited disclosures
column319: as well as a nascent investor marketplace. Today
column320: investors and clients have become increasingly sophisticated and are typically assessing banks in multiple indicators rather than solely relying on ratings from 2 agencies
column321: no less a single agency. In fact
column322:
investors and clients are looking for an investing edge and have effectively built internal teams to take on the credit-assessment process.

"
column323:
"

In contrast to the past
column324: clients and counterparties today are looking at a variety of metrics to assess bank creditworthiness. These measures include financial metrics
column325: which is a bank's equity base
column326: regulatory capital levels
column327: liquidity profile and loan loss reserve. Market metrics
column328: which are available in realtime
column329: such as bonds and CDS spreads and stock prices
column330: are also being included in valuations. And finally
column331: business metrics
column332: such as business strategy
column333: geographic diversification and risk concentrations
column334:
are also key drivers of the assessment process for today's complex multinational banks.

"
column335:
"

We believe this shift to a more integrated approach to credit evaluations is appropriate in an increasingly complex market environment and have expanded our disclosures accordingly.

"
column336:
"

In keeping with our discussion of the changing market environment
column337: Citi has significantly shifted its funding mix over the last 2 years away from short-term sources to deposits and long-term debt and equity. Slide 16 shows the funding composition that we have for the bank and nonbank. Within our bank
column338: we believe our deposit base is one of the most stable and lowest-cost funding source. And you can see that approximately 80% of our bank is funded by deposits compared to 72% in the first quarter of 2010. In the nonbank businesses
column339: long-term debt represents the most significant component of our liability mix. The vast majority of this funding is comprised of senior term debt along with subordinate instruments and trust-preferred securities. As of the first quarter
column340: long-term debt comprised 35% of the funding in the nonbank. While long-term debt was lower over the course of the past year
column341: so is the levels of assets
column342: especially illiquid assets it is meant to support. Approximately 30% of our nonbank liabilities are secured financings
column343: often referred to as repos
column344: which provide funding in a carefully calibrated manner for liquid securities at modest haircut. And finally
column345:
our large base of book equity supports both the bank and nonbank entities.

"
column346:
"

On Slide 17
column347: let me turn to long-term funding and our liability management initiatives. The top half of the page shows our long-term debt outstanding by category over time
column348: including senior debt
column349: TLGP and credit card securitizations. The bottom half of the page segments the amount of long-term debt in the bank and nonbank entities. So the bottom is just another cut of the top to provide you with some further texture. As you can see here
column350: our long-term debt outstanding has decreased year-over-year in most long-term debt categories as we have deleveraged the balance sheet
column351: especially in the bank. In the bank
column352: we have consciously reduced debt funding as we have grown our deposit base. Looking at the nonbank at the bottom half of the page
column353: longer-term debt has decreased as we have led TLGP roll off
column354: while keeping a healthy amount of funding for our broker-dealer. In the nonbank
column355: assets have been reduced at a corresponding pace
column356: especially as we wound down holdings and took actions to reduce higher-risk and less-liquid Basel III assets in the dealer. As you can see here with our current estimate for the fourth quarter of 2012
column357: we believe that this trend will continue
column358: and expect a decline in the amount of long-term debt that we have outstanding
column361: let me review with you the liability management strategy that we have been executing over the course of the last few years. As we have discussed on past calls
column362: we have successfully derisked our balance sheet and reduced Holdings assets
column363: thereby creating ample liquidity. Through selective public tender offers and open market purchases
column364: we have reduced outstanding debt
column365: both short and long term
column366: with either excess cash or by replacing it with new issued debt at lower spreads. The chart on the left-hand side of this page shows our quarterly liability management activity in the nonbank. As you can see
column367: we've been consistently active in the senior benchmark and structured space. This quarter
column368:
our buybacks at structured and benchmark paper allowed us to lower our overall funding costs.

"
column369:
"

On the right-hand side of this page
column370: you can see that we carefully managed the weighted average maturity of our long-term debt. Over the last year
column371: WAM increased to approximately 7 years from 6.2 years in 2010. On the bank
column372: we have consciously allowed TLGP to run off as we have replaced it with stable deposit funding. You can see at the end of last year
column373: with TLGP rolling down
column374: we no longer have unsecured benchmark debt with maturity greater than one year in the bank. On the dealer nonbank
column375: we've used our liability management efforts
column376: coupled with our issuance strategy
column377:
to consciously maintain the maturity of our debt.

"
column378:
"

Moving onto Slide 19
column379: you can see our expected maturities for the full year 2012 and also our expected maturities of long-term debt over the next 2 years. This chart fully shows how maturities peak in 2012 and come down in 2013. As we see in light blue at the top of the first column
column380: TLGP debt represents the bulk of the maturities in 2012. Many observers have noted that this wave of maturities is an industry-wide situation which came about as many banks issued TLGP and other government-guaranteed debt in 2008 and 2009. As I've said before
column381: for us at Citi
column382:
we do not expect to replace TLGP maturities.

"
column383:
"

As we have demonstrated and reviewed on prior slides
column384: the reason is clear. As we continue to reduce our Citi Holdings balance sheet in both our bank and nonbank entities
column385:
our need for long-term debt is coming down.

"
column386:
"

During the first quarter
column387: we issued approximately $7 billion in long-term structured -- structural debt. We issued across multiple tenders in both benchmark and structured notes. As we stated last quarter
column388: we continue to expect to issue approximately $15 billion to $20 billion of long-term debt during 2012
column389: although this number may change based on market conditions or other factors. At this time
column390: we believe we will be at the low end of this range
column391:
and the balance of our issuance program will be a mix of benchmark and structured debt.

"
column392:
"

Moving onto Slide 20. As many of you know
column393: as part of the CCAR process
column394: Citi received approval to redeem certain series of outstanding trust preferred securities. Let's take a moment to review the securities that we have outstanding. You can see on the bar charts below that we have grouped our outstanding trust preferreds into 2 categories based on their call features
column395: those that are currently callable and those that are not currently callable but we believe would be callable under a regulatory capital event. These securities are ordered in each category by coupon
column396:
and the smaller bar shows the notional amount of bridge security as well.

"
column397:
"

Many of you have asked about our current strategy with regard to our trust preferred securities given the regulatory changes pending under Dodd-Frank and Basel III. For the issues that are not callable now
column398: we would be at -- but would be at the time of regulatory capital event
column399: we
column400: along with many others in the industry
column401:
are awaiting the expected forthcoming NPR from the regulators.

"
column402:
"

In general
column403: we will consider various factors when evaluating each of our trust preferred and enhanced trust preferred securities
column404: including aspects such as coupon
column405:
currency and the optional and regulatory call features of the securities I've just reviewed and the timing of such options. You can expect that Citi will make the appropriate economic decision.

"
column406:
"

So turning to Slide 21
column407: let me talk about capital
column408: which continues to be an area of significant strength for us and supports the lending growth that I described. Our Basel I Tier 1 common capital stands at $122 billion
column409: and our Basel I total capital is $172 billion. At the end of the first quarter
column410: our Basel I Tier 1 common ratio was 12.4%
column411: significantly up from a year ago and also up from the fourth quarter. Our risk-weighted assets stand at $978 billion and Citi Holdings risk-weighted assets now represent approximately 19% of the total. And as I mentioned earlier
column412: our Basel III Tier 1 common estimate was 7.2% at the end of the first quarter
column413:
and we still expect to exceed 8% Tier 1 common under Basel III by the end of this year.

"
column414:
"

As you can see
column415: our capital base is one of the strongest in the industry
column416:
both as compared to U.S. and international banking peers.

"
column417:
"

Moving to our last slide. Let me summarize 4 major points. First
column419: our capital base continues to be one of the strongest in the industry
column420: and this is reflected across every one of our significant capital ratios. Second
column421: we have significantly improved our structural liquidity by increasing our capital base and deposits
column422: and reducing Citi Holdings assets. We believe that we have ample liquidity and our estimated Basel III LCR is over 125%
column423: which is significantly above the estimated industry average and the proposed required minimum. Third
column424: we will have a significantly lower proportion of wholesale funding going forward. We currently have modest long-term debt issuance plans over the next year. We will not be replacing the maturing TLGP debt. Thus
column425: we expect that our long-term debt outstanding will continue to decline. And fourth
column426: while the environment remains uncertain
column427: we saw continued strength in our core lending and deposit-taking businesses
column428: as well as in our market businesses this quarter. As we stated earlier
column429: we achieved positive operating leverage again in our Asian and Latin American Consumer Banking businesses this quarter
column430:
and Transaction Services achieved positive operating leverage as well. That concludes our Fixed Income review. John and I will be happy to take your questions.
