"
column30: and welcome to Citi\u2019s Second Quarter 2012 Earnings Review with Chief Executive Officer
column31: Vikram Pandit; and Chief Financial Officer
column32: John Gerspach. Today\u2019s call will be hosted by John Andrews
column34:
"

We ask that you please hold all questions until the completion of the formal remarks
column35: at which time you will be given instructions for the question-and-answer session. Also as a reminder
column36: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column41:
"

Great
column42: thank you very much. Good morning everybody
column43: and thank you for joining us this morning. On the call today
column44: our CEO Vikram Pandit will speak first
column45: then John Gerspach
column46: our CFO will take you through the earnings presentation
column47: which is available for download on our website
column48: citigroup.com. Afterwards
column49:
we will be happy to take your questions.

"
column50:
"

Before we get started
column51: I would like to remind you that today\u2019s presentation may contain forward-looking statements
column52: which are based on management\u2019s current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results and capital and other financial condition may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors
column53: including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today
column54: and those included in our SEC filings
column55:
including without limitation the risk factors section of our 2011 Form 10-K.

"
column57:
let me turn it over to Vikram.

"
column58:
"

Vikram S. Pandit

"
column59:
"

John
column60: thank you
column61: and good morning everybody and thank you for joining us today. As you know
column62: we reported earnings of $2.9 billion for the second quarter of 2012
column63: and excluding CVA and the loss from the partial sale of our stake in Akbank
column64: net income were $3.1 billion. That amounts to $1 per share. Overall
column65:
I\u2019m pleased with our performance in light of the economic environment we faced during the quarter.

"
column66:
"

The investments we\u2019ve made continue to show encouraging results. Loans and deposits in Citicorp had solid growth. Our market businesses were resilient despite volatility and we increased market share in investment banking.

"
column67:
"

Revenue in transaction services set another record as we leveraged a unique global footprint
column68: especially in trade finance. While our consumer businesses were impacted by the slower economies
column69: we still saw positive operating leverage in both Latin America and Asia
column70:
excluding Japan.

"
column71:
"

We\u2019re managing our expenses closely
column72: and making sure we\u2019re right sized for the environment we anticipate
column73: expenses decrease from both the first quarter of this year
column74:
and second quarter of last year.

"
column75:
"

For the first half of the year
column76: we had positive operating leverages in each of our core businesses. In Securities and Banking
column77: revenues excluding CVA and DVA
column78: increased 2% and expenses decreased 5%. In Transaction Services
column79: revenues increased 6% and expenses increased 2%; and in Global Consumer Banking
column80:
revenues increased 2% and expenses increased 1%.

"
column81:
"

More broadly
column82: we\u2019ve been managing our risk very tightly throughout the organization
column83: Citi Holdings assets are now $191 billion or approximately 10% of our total assets
column84:
as we reduced our legacy assets in Citi Holdings by 9% during the quarter.

"
column85:
"

Citi remains highly liquid with over $400 billion in cash and government securities
column86: and our capital levels continue to be among the strongest in the industry. As of the end of the second quarter
column87: our Tier 1 common ratio was 12.7% under Basel I
column88:
and was an estimated 7.9% under Basel III. We still expect to exceed 8% under Basel III this year.

"
column89:
"

When you put it all together
column90: we\u2019re generating solid returns in our core businesses. For the combined Citicorp and Corporate/Other
column91:
our return on tangible common equity was 14.7% excluding CVA/DVA and Akbank.

"
column92:
"

On the same basis for Citigroup
column93: our return on tangible common equity for the quarter was 8.2%. And given the amount of disallowed DTA
column94: the return on Basel III becomes an important measure of capital. On the fully implemented 9.5% basis
column95: our return on Basel III capital in Citigroup was an estimated 10.3%. And our return on Basel III capital on the combined Citicorp Corporate/Other was 18.4% excluding CVA/DVA and Akbank. And while the environment is uncertain
column96: and we continue to optimize our portfolio
column97:
we have the capacity to earn similar returns on Basel III going forward.

"
column98:
"

On a macro level
column99: we believe the euro zone overhang will continue. Our on the ground sense of the emerging markets leaves us more positive than we were a few months ago
column100:
and maybe even better than some market perceptions.

"
column101:
"

In the U.S. consumer demand and Basel loan demand remain low
column102: as consumers continue to deleverage. And as Federal banks have lowered interest rates
column103: the margin from lending has decreased
column104:
and it is expected rates will stay low for the near future.

"
column105:
"

That said
column106: our strategy is showing results
column107: and we are executing it diligently. Our focus on capital flows between the world\u2019s top 150 cities on serving multinationals globally
column108: as only we can
column109: and on the faster growing emerging markets are right for the times and the capabilities of our bank. We are diversified and while the negatives will pop-up here and there
column110: our footprint and strategy will serve us well overtime. In short
column111:
we\u2019re on top of the things we can control.

"
column112:
"

John will now take you through our slides
column113: and then we\u2019ll come back at the end
column114:
and take questions together. John?

"
column115:
"

John C. Gerspach

"
column116:
"

Hey
column117: thank you Vikram
column118: and good morning everyone. This part
column119: I\u2019d like to highlight a few significant items affecting our results on slide three. First on the revenue side
column120: CVA and DVA were a positive $219 million in the second quarter. We also recorded a pre-tax loss of $424 million related to the partial sale of our investment in Akbank
column121:
compared to a gain on sales of nearly $200 million on HDFC last year.

"
column122:
"

On the expense side
column123: legal and related expenses remained elevated at $480 million
column124: and repositioning charges were $186 million
column125: roughly half of which was related to securities and banking. In addition to these items
column126: our reported results were affected by foreign exchange translation
column127: as the U.S. dollar generally strengthened in the second quarter
column128:
against local currencies in which we generate revenues and incur expenses and credit costs.

"
column129:
"

While FX translation had no material impact on our earnings or regulatory capital ratios
column130: it did affect individual line items
column131: and recorded business drivers
column132:
which is why \u2013 I\u2019ll discuss more as we\u2019ll go through the presentation.

"
column133:
"

On slide four
column134: we show second quarter results. Citigroup reported net income of $2.9 billion or $0.95 per diluted share. Excluding CVA/DVA and the loss on Akbank
column135: earnings were $3.1 billion
column136:
or $1 per diluted share. Revenues of $18.6 billion were down 10% versus the prior year on a reported basis.

"
column137:
"

Excluding CVA/DVA and the impact of minority investments
column138: revenues were down 7% from last year
column139:
as revenue growth in Citicorp was offset by the impact of foreign exchange and the continued decline in Citi Holdings revenues. Expenses of $12.1 billion were 6% lower than the prior year on a reported basis.

"
column140:
"

Excluding the impact of foreign exchange and significant expense items
column141: I just mentioned
column142:
core operating expenses declined nearly 3%. Credit costs of $2.8 billion were down 17% versus last year. Net credit losses of $3.6 billion were 31% lower than the prior year. And the net reserve release was $984 million down 50% from last year.

"
column143:
"

Citigroup end-of-period loans grew 1% year-over-year to $655 billion as continued loan growth in Citicorp outpaced the wind-down of Citi Holdings
column144:
and deposits grew 6% to $914 billion.

"
column145:
"

On slide 5
column146: we show results for Citicorp and Citi Holdings excluding the impact of CVA/DVA. Citicorp generated second quarter revenues of $17.8 billion and net income of $4.2 billion. Year-over-year
column147: Citicorp's reported revenues were flat
column148:
and expenses declined 3% and we maintained positive operating leverage in each of our three core businesses.

"
column149:
"

Excluding FX
column150: Citicorp revenues were 5% higher than last year
column151: and expenses were roughly flat. Pre-provision net revenues in Citicorp were $7.4 billion for the quarter up 5% from last year and for the sixth consecutive quarter
column152: we grew loans year-over-year in every business in Citicorp. Total Citicorp loans grew 10%
column153: with consumer up 2% and corporate loans up 22%. Excluding FX
column154:
Citicorp loans grew 13% with consumer up 5%.

"
column155:
"

Citi Holdings had revenues of $903 million and a net loss of $933 million. Citi Holdings ended the quarter with a $191 billion of assets
column156: down $18 billion during the quarter and $74 billion or 28% year-over-year. At quarter end
column157:
Citi Holdings accounted for approximately 10% of totaled Citigroup assets.

"
column158:
"

On slide 6
column159: we show a nine quarter trend for Citicorp\u2019s result. Excluding CVA/DVA
column160: Citicorp\u2019s revenues of $17.8 billion were flat to the prior year
column161:
and down 8% from last quarter on a reported basis.

"
column162:
"

Operating expenses of $10.3 billion was 3% lower than the prior year. Citicorp\u2019s net credit losses of $2.2 billion
column163: declined 25% from last year
column164: driven by improvement in North America cards and the net loan loss reserve release in Citicorp was $715 million
column165: down nearly 50% from last year
column166: this reflected lower net releases in North America cards
column167: as well as a net reserve build in international consumer banking
column168:
primarily driven by loan growth.

"
column169:
"

Excluding CVA/DVA
column170: earnings before taxes of $5.9 billion
column171: grew 7% versus last year
column172: driven by lower operating expenses and lower credit losses
column173:
partially offset by a lower net reserve release.

"
column174:
"

On slide seven
column175: we show Citicorp\u2019s pre-tax earnings by business excluding CVA/DVA and the impact of loan loss reserves. As you can see from this chart
column176: our earnings excluding loan loss reserves are increasingly steady and are diversified across the franchise with a growing contribution from consumer and transaction services. On a trailing 12-month basis through the second quarter
column177: consumer banking generated 46% of Citicorp\u2019s earnings
column178:
and together with transaction services these businesses represented nearly three quarters of pre-tax profit.

"
column179:
"

column182:
as well as an improved operating margin.

column183:
"

Slide nine
column184:
shows the results for Citi for North America Consumer Banking. Total revenues of $5.1 billion were up 4% versus last year largely driven by higher gains on sales of mortgage loans. Total card revenues declined 6% year-over-year. In branded cards average loans declined reflecting an increase in the payment rate and spreads remained under pressure due to the continued impact of the look-back provisions of CARD Act and higher promotional balances.

"
column185:
"

In retail services
column186:
net interest revenues were stable while non-interest revenues declined driven by improving credit and its impact on contractual partner payments.

"
column187:
"

Total operating expenses of $2.5 billion were up 5% year-over-year driven entirely by an increase in legal reserves related to interchange litigation. Credit costs declined by over 20% to $760 million. Net credit losses were down 29% to $1.5 billion driven by improvement in cards
column188: and the net reserve release was $814 million this quarter
column189:
compared to $1.2 billion in the prior year.

"
column190:
"

Earnings before tax and excluding the impact of loan loss reserves grew to $1.2 billion from $468 million last year. Overall
column191: we continue to see progress in our North America consumer franchise. Average deposits grew for the fifth consecutive quarter
column192: up 5% year-over-year
column193: including double-digit growth in checking account balance. In Branded Cards
column194: accounts also grew for the fifth consecutive quarter
column195: up 5% year-over-year. And for both card portfolios
column196:
net credit margin continued to expand year-over-year.

column197:

Turning to international consumer banking on slide ten; in total

column199: with declines in reported revenues and expenses
column200:
up 4% and 5% respectively.

"
column201:
"

In constant dollars
column202:
revenues grew 4% and expenses were up 3%.

"
column203:
"

Latin America achieved positive operating leverage for the third consecutive quarter
column204: with revenues up 8% and expenses up 3% in constant dollars. Asia
column205: however
column206: had negative operating leverage with revenues roughly flat and expenses up 2% in constant dollars. Most of revenue pressure in Asia was due to lower investment sales
column207:
given continued weak investor sentiment.

"
column208:
"

Cards revenues continued to grow on higher average loans and strong purchase sales. And lending and deposit revenues were flat versus last year as growth in certain market was offset by pressure in Korea and Japan. Korea in particular is being affected by consumer regulatory changes. We show more information on these trends in the appendix.

"
column209:
"

Despite these headwinds
column210: most drivers for international consumer banking continue to grow in the second quarter. Accounts grew 6% year-over-year
column211: and on a constant dollar basis
column212: we grew average deposits
column213:
average loans and purchase sales in every region.

"
column214:
"

Credit costs were $730 million in the second quarter

column216: net credit losses continue to decline
column217: down 12% to $613 million. However
column218: we recorded a net reserve build of $86 million in the second quarter
column219: principally due to portfolio growth versus a net release in the prior year. Earnings before tax
column220:
excluding the impact of loan loss reserves grew 3% year-over-year to $1.1 billion.

column221:
"

On slide 11

column223: average loans grew 10% over the prior year
column224: and average deposits were up 1%
column225: including 7% growth in checking account balances. Card purchase sales grew 10%. As reported
column226: on a trailing 12-month basis
column227:
we have grown pre-tax earnings excluding the impact of loan loss reserve each quarter for well over two years.

Slide 12 shows our securities and banking business

column231:
and down 22% versus the prior quarter.

"

column234: our wallet share in investment banking has improved year-to-date in all major products. Ex-CVA/DVA

column236:
and 39% sequentially on lower market activity in both cash and derivatives.

column238: and down 41% sequentially from a strong first quarter. Year-over-year
column239: revenues in rates and currencies grew at a double-digit pace
column240:
driven by particularly strong performance in our foreign exchange and local market businesses.

Credit and securitized products were down year-over-year due to weaker market conditions. Lending revenues of $608 million were up significantly versus prior periods. Year-over-year
column242: loan growth and improved spread drove higher net interest revenues
column243:
and we have $42 million of gains on lending hedges this quarter compared to a loss of $85 million last year.

"
column244:
"

Total operating expenses of $3.6 billion were down 8% from last year driven by efficiency savings and lower incentive compensation
column245: partially offset by nearly $100 million of repositioning cost. Net income
column246: excluding CVA/DVA
column247:
grew 16% year-over-year to $1.3 billion.

"

"

Moving to Transaction Services on slide 13; revenues of $2.8 billion were up 5% from last year
column249: as growth in Treasury and Trade Solutions more than offset the decline in Securities and Fund Services. Treasury and Trade Solutions was up 9%
column250: driven by strong growth in deposits and trade loans. Securities and Fund Services was down 6% year-over-year on lower market volumes. However
column251:

column254: and incremental investment spending was of offset by efficiency savings. We achieved positive operating leverage in Transaction Services for the second consecutive quarter
column255:
driving 6% earnings growth year-over-year.

column258:
due primarily to overall lower assets as well as the absence of gains on the sale of held-to-maturity securities and other assets in the second quarter of last year. Operating expenses of $1.2 billion were down 25% versus last year. And total credit costs were down 31% to $1.2 billion.

"
column259:
"

Looking at Citi Holdings in more detail on slide 15

revenues in brokerage and asset management were $87 million this quarter versus $47 million last year driven by our higher contribution from the Morgan Stanley Smith Barney joint venture.

column265:
"

Non-interest revenue excluding CVA/DVA was negative $38 million compared to a positive $1.1 billion last year
column266:
which included the significant gains on the sale of held-to-maturity securities and other assets. We also booked $85 million of reverses related to private label mortgage securitizations in the second quarter.

"
column267:
"

Citi Holdings operating expenses were down 25% year-over-year to $1.2 billion mainly due to declining assets as well as lower legal and related costs. Credit costs were down 31% year-over-year to $1.2 billion. Total net credit losses were down 39% to $1.3 billion reflecting a significant reduction in loans and the special asset pool as well as a declining loan balance and improved credit trends in local consumer lending. We released $269 million of net loan loss reserves in Citi Holding compared to $583 million last year.

"
column268:
"

Slide 16 shows Citi Holdings Assets. We ended the quarter with a $191 billion in Citi Holdings were roughly 10% of total Citigroup assets. The $18 billion reduction in the second quarter included roughly a $11 billion of sales approximately $6 billion of net runoff and pay-downs and $1 billion of net credit and net asset marks.

"
column269:
"

column270: driven by the $424 million pre-tax loss on the partial sale of Akbank compared to a gain of nearly $200 million on the partial sale of HDFC last year. Expenses of $597 million were down 3% versus last year
column271: mainly due to lower
column272:
legal and related expenses. Assets of $289 billion included approximately a $101 billion of cash and cash equivalents and $135 billion of liquid available for sale securities.

"
column273:
"

Turning to total Citigroup expenses on Slide 18. Total operating expenses up $12.1 billion in the second quarter were 6% lower than last year. While core operating expenses
column274:
excluding legal and related costs and repositioning charges decline nearly 3% in constant dollars to a $11.5 billion.

"
column275:
"

As I mentioned earlier
column276: legal and related costs remained elevated through the second quarter
column277: and we also incurred nearly $200 million of repositioning costs. However
column278:
we also benefited from FX translation as the U.S. dollar strengthened in many markets.

"
column279:
"

In total

column282:
we currently believe that our core operating expenses should be roughly at or below the $11.5 billion we incurred in the second quarter.

"

Additionally
column284: however

column286: which on a combined basis have exceeded what we would otherwise consider to be a normalized level of roughly $250 million per quarter. Obviously
column287:
these charges have been running at an elevated level and will continue to be difficult to predict particularly in this environment.

"

"

Slide 19

column290:
down 10% sequentially to $3.6 billion and the net loan loss reserve release was $984 million. We ended the quarter with $27.6 billion of total loan loss reserves and our LLR ratio was 4.3%.

"

column307: we ended the quarter with $37 billion of loan

In total

column312:

On slide 22
column313: we show our key capital metrics. As of the second quarter
column314: our Basel I Tier 1 Common Ratio was 12.7%
column315: adjusting for the final market risk rules recently adopted by the U.S. regulators that would be effective in January 2013. Our Basel I Tier 1 Common Ratio would be approximately 11.3%. Under Basel III
column316: our estimated Tier 1 Common Ratio as of the second quarter was 7.9%
column317:
up from 7.2% in the first quarter. These estimates both include the impact of the final market risk rules and are based on the proposed advanced approach for calculating risk-weighted assets under the recent NPR.

"
column318:
"

As you maybe aware
column319: the regulatory proposals also requires Citi and other banks to calculate its risk-weighted assets under a newly defined standardized approach
column320: and to use the lower of the two resulting ratios for our reported Basel III Tier 1 Common Ratio. We continue to review the implications of that standardized approach
column321: but based on preliminary data
column322:
and I want to stress that this is preliminary.

"
column323:
"

Our estimated Basel III Tier 1 Common Ratio for the second quarter as calculated under this standardized approach approximates the ratio under the advanced calculation. However
column324:
the risk-weighted asset components are somewhat different. We continue to expect to be above an 8% Basel III Tier 1 Common Ratio later this year.

"
column325:
"

Slide 23 shows the components of our Basel I and estimated Basel III Capital Ratio. As of the second quarter
column326: our Tier 1 common capital under Basel I was $124 billion
column327: compared to an estimated $99 billion under Basel III. Over half of the difference reflects that this allowance of our minority investments in unconsolidated financial institutions
column328:
with the remainder driven by pension liabilities within other comprehensive income and deferred tax assets.

"
column329:
"

Turning to the denominator
column330:
our total risk-weighted assets under Basel III as calculated using the proposed advanced approach were an estimated $1.25 trillion or 28% higher versus Basel I.

"
column331:
"

Looking at Citicorp and Corp/Other
column332: our risk-weighted assets increased by only 15% reflecting the strong credit quality of our loan portfolio
column333:
the low asset intensity of our service businesses and our focus on flow facilitation in capital markets. The impact of Citi Holdings on our total risk-weighted assets will decrease over time as we continue to wind down those assets.

"
column334:
"

On slide 24

column337: the return on tangible common equity for Citicorp plus Corp/Other for the first half of 2012 was an estimated 15.9%
column338: and including Citi Holdings
column339:
Citigroup generated return of nearly 9%.

"
column340:
"

On slide 25
column341: we highlight our returns under Basel III; again using risk-weighted asset as calculated using the proposed advanced approach. Citigroup\u2019s return on Basel III assets for the first half of the year was an estimated 1%
column342: including a 1.8% return for Citicorp plus Corp/Other. And if we assume Tier 1 common capital level of 9.5% of Basel III risk-weighted assets across each business
column343: the return on Basel III capital for Citigroup would have been an estimated 10.6% for the first half of 2012
column344: including a 19.3% return for our core businesses in Citicorp
column345:
plus Corp/Other.

column346:
"

Let me close with some comments about the outlook. First
column347: Global Consumer Banking
column348: overall credit quality remains good
column349:
with continued improvement in North America and stable credit in Asia and Latin America. We expect these trends to continue for the remainder of the year assuming no meaningful downturn in the global economy.

"
column350:
"

Latin America
column351: despite the noise this quarter from FX was the fastest growing of our regions in consumer. And we expect that to continue particularly in Mexico
column352:
given both market growth and the strength of our franchise.

"
column353:
"

Asia consumer revenue growth has slowed
column354: reflecting the two principal issues that I mentioned. First
column355: investment sales remain weak
column356: as retail investors in Asia have de-risked giving the same global macro concerns that have slowed institutional activity. And second
column357: specific country slowdowns
column358: most notably in Korea where policy actions by the government have trimmed the availability of consumer credit in that market. We see these trends continuing in the near-term
column359: which would imply some revenue headwinds for Asia
column360:
into the third and fourth quarters.

"
column361:
"

North America consumer benefited from another quarter of strong mortgage activity
column362: which we currently expect will continue into the third quarter. However
column363: in cards
column364: high payment rates from consumers reflecting ongoing economic uncertainty and deleveraging
column365:
and our shift to higher credit quality borrowers continues to weigh on loan growth. This trend will likely remain into the third quarter as into meaningful improvement in the U.S. economy.

"
column366:
"

Transaction Services continue to produce strong revenue and earnings growth
column367:
and had a second consecutive quarter of positive operating leverage that we expect will be sustainable going forward.

"
column368:
"

In Securities and Banking there were a few key takeaways this quarter. First
column369: the biggest challenge we and the industry face is the ongoing macro uncertainty
column370: reflected in low levels of client activity. Without meaningful signs of accelerating economic growth or incredible resolution as perceived by the market to the European issues
column371: the reduced activity is likely to persist into the third quarter. Having said that
column372: the strength and breadth of our fixed-income franchise
column373: particularly our rates and currencies business was evidenced in the second quarter
column374:
and first half of the year.

"
column375:
"

Turning to equities; we believe our business has passed the problems of the second half of last year
column376: and we continue to execute well
column377: although low levels of client activity remain a substantial challenge
column378: and that will likely continue into the third quarter. Our investment banking franchise continue to see momentum with wallet share gains in every major products
column379: although overall market activity remained muted. Based on that
column380:
we are cautiously optimistic that our investments in our banking franchise are showing results.

"
column381:
"

Given the current operating environment
column382:
we remain very focused on rightsizing our businesses in securities and banking to the opportunity we see. And we are keeping a tight ring on expenses as the positive operating leverage we produced in the second quarter and the first half of 2012 demonstrates.

"
column383:
"

In Holdings
column384: the wind down of assets will continue
column385: and our primary focus remains the mortgage portfolio. Mortgages continue to face a number of challenges including the substantial foreclosure backlog
column386: ongoing political headwind
column387:
and the risk from any weakening of the U.S. economy.

"
column388:
"

As such
column389: we have not released any general loan loss reserves against our mortgage portfolio to-date
column390:
and have maintained robust coverage ratios.

"
column391:
"

In summary
column392: one of the biggest issues we face remains the uncertain macro environment
column393: and in particular the European sovereign debt issues. As such
column394: we will continue to run our risk exposures very tightly
column395:
while serving our clients.

"
column396:
"

Basically
column397: we will continue to manage what we can control
column398: and limit our exposure to what we cannot control. Nonetheless
column399: we remain optimistic about our prospects given our client franchise
column400: our unique mix of businesses
column401:
and our unparalleled footprint.

column1:
{"Citigroup's CEO Discusses Q3 2012 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Citigroup Inc. (NYSE:C)

"
column22:
"

Erica Penala - Bank of America Merrill Lynch

"
column27:
"

Hello and welcome to Citi\u2019s Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Review with Chief Executive Officer
column28: Vikram Pandit and Chief Financial Officer
column29: John Gerspach. Today\u2019s call will be hosted by Susan Kendall
column30: Head of Citi Investor Relations. We ask that you please hold all questions until the completion of the formal remarks at which time you will be given instructions for the question-and-answer session. Also
column32: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column38: operator. Good morning and thank you all for joining us. On our call today are CEO
column39: Vikram Pandit will speak first. Then John Gerspach
column41: will take you through the earnings presentation
column42: which is available for download on our website citigroup.com. Afterwards
column43:
we\u2019ll be happy to take questions.

"
column44:
"

Before we get started
column45: I would like to remind you that today\u2019s presentation may contain forward-looking statements which are based on management\u2019s current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results in capital and other financial condition may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors
column46:
including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today and those included in our SEC filings including without limitation the Risk Factors section of our 2011 Form 10-K.

"
column47:
"

With that said
column48:
let me turn it over to Vikram.

"
column49:
"

Vikram Pandit

"
column50:
"

Susan
column51: thank you and good morning everyone. Thank you for joining us today. As you know
column52: we reported earnings of $468 million for the third quarter of 2012. Excluding non-operating item such as the mark on MSSB
column54:
net income was $3.3 billion and that amounts to $1.06 per share.

"
column55:
"

Our businesses gained momentum during the quarter while the impact of Citi Holdings lessened. Loans and deposits increased and in all three of our operating businesses
column56:
we had positive operating leverage for the third straight quarter. We also had positive operating leverage in Citigroup as a whole.

"
column57:
"

We gained wallet share again in Investment Banking
column58: while our markets businesses performed very well. Although
column59: Transaction Services has been impacted by spread compression
column60:
both trade loans and deposits continued to grow and the pipeline appears to be strong.

"
column61:
"

Our Institutional businesses showed growth and resilience in the emerging markets
column62: where we have our unique
column63: where our unique footprint gives us a meaningful competitive advantage as we can see by several noteworthy transactions whether they are in China
column64: India
column65: Russia
column66:
Mexico or Brazil. Transactions ranging from the Cnooc-Nexen deal to the Santander IPO in Mexico are a reflection of our broad and deep capabilities.

"
column67:
"

Net income increased in Global Consumer Banking
column68: as the drivers for the business remained strong internationally
column69: especially in emerging markets such as Latin America. North America benefited from increased mortgage refinancing. Overall
column70:
these earnings highlight the continued execution of our strategy and show the strength of our core businesses and our diversification both by product and geography.

"
column71:
"

We also made progress winding down Citi Holdings. Last month\u2019s price agreement on MSSB has given us more certainty on our exit. Citi Holdings assets were reduced by $20 billion in the quarter and now total $171 billion or 9% of our balance sheet. Holdings assets are down 31% from the end of third quarter of 2011.

"
column72:
"

Citi continues to maintain significant liquidity with roughly $400 billion in highly liquid unencumbered assets
column73:
primarily cash and government securities. Our Basel III Tier 1 Common Ratio increased to an estimated 8.6% and is among the highest in the industry.

"
column74:
"

We continue to generate solid returns for Citicorp and Corp/Other
column75: excluding CVA/DVA and the sale of minority interest. Our year-to-date return on allocated tangible common equity is 17.2% and return on Basel III Tier 1 Common on a fully implemented 9.5% basis is 18.7%. For Citigroup as a whole
column76:
the year-to-date return on tangible common equity supporting the businesses is 11.8% and return on Basel III on a fully implemented basis is 10.7%.

"
column77:
"

Regarding the macro picture
column78: market sentiment improved during the quarter as a result of the moves made by the ECB and Fed. However
column79: GDP growth remains uneven globally and interest rates remain low. In the U.S.
column80: there are promising signs that more robust economic growth is within reach assuming the resolution of the fiscal cliff. Lack of a resolution of the cliff situation will be highly disruptive. The housing market has shown improvement
column81: while capital
column82: labor
column83:
energy and technology are all very affordable and in healthy supply.

"
column84:
"

In Europe the actions by policy makers appear to have set a path for preserving the Europe
column85:
but more needs to be done to create deeper market confidence for a better GDP picture.

"
column86:
"

In the emerging markets
column87: policy makers have been quick to act and we expect growth there to substantially keep outpacing the developed markets. In light of these factors
column88:
we\u2019ll continue to manage our risk carefully using the deep knowledge we have of the markets where we do business.

"
column89:
"

John Gerspach will go over the slides now and then both of us will come back and we\u2019ll be happy to take your questions. John?

"
column90:
"

John Gerspach

"
column91:
"

Yeah
column92: thank you Vikram and good morning everyone. To start
column93:
I would like to highlight some significant items affecting our results this quarter. This will be on slide three.

"
column94:
"

First CVA and DVA were negative $776 million pretax and $485 million after tax in the third quarter for a negative impact on EPS of $0.16 per share. Secondly
column95: the loss on Morgan Stanley Smith Barney was $4.7 billion pretax and $2.9 billion after tax for a negative impact on earnings per share of $0.94. And finally
column96: we recorded a tax benefit of $582 million related to the resolution of certain tax audit items which had a positive impact on EPS of $0.19. Adjusting for these items
column97: we earned $3.3 billion in the third quarter or $1.06 per share. Throughout today\u2019s earnings presentation
column98:
I will be discussing our results on this basis to provide comparability to prior periods.

"
column99:
"

In addition
column100: as shown on slide four
column101: there are a few other significant items which are included in our third quarter results. First on the revenue side: In Securities and Banking
column102: we recorded losses on hedges related to accrual loans of $252 million this quarter
column103:
driven by credit spread tightening and our lending portfolio compared to gains of $156 million last quarter and over $700 million in the third quarter of last year.

"
column104:
"

On the expense
column105:
legal and related expenses remained elevated at over $500 million in the third quarter and repositioning charges were nearly $100 million.

"
column106:
"

On slide five
column107: we showed total Citigroup results. Revenues of $19.4 billion were up 3% from last year while operating expenses of $12.2 billion declined 2%
column108:
resulting in positive operating leverage for Citigroup in total.

"
column109:
"

Credit costs of $2.7 billion were down 20% versus last year. Net credit losses of $4 billion were 12% lower than the prior year including incremental mortgage charge-offs of approximately $635 million in Citi Holdings in the third quarter of this year. These incremental charge-offs were related to new OCC guidance regarding the treatment of mortgage loans where the borrower has gone through chapter 7 bankruptcy.

"
column110:
"

The vast majority of these charge-offs were related to loans which were current. Substantially all of the incremental $635 million of charge-offs were offset by a related reserve release of approximately $600 million this quarter and so the net impact on earnings was minimal.

"
column111:
"

Excluding these incremental charge-offs
column112: net credit losses would have been down 26% from last year and the net reserve release in the third quarter would have been roughly $900 million
column113:
down from $1.4 billion in the prior year.

"
column114:
"

We earned $3.3 billion of net income in the third quarter or a $1.06 per share
column115: up from $0.84 per share last year on a comparable basis
column116: driven by revenue growth and a decline in both expenses and credit cost. Citigroup
column117:
end of period loans grew 3% year-over-year to $658 billion. As loan growth in Citicorp continued to outpace the wind down of Citi Holdings. And deposits grew 11% to $945 billion.

"
column118:
"

On slide six
column119: we show results for Citicorp and Citi Holdings. Citicorp generated third quarter revenues of $18.4 billion and net income of $4.6 billion. Year-over-year
column120:
Citicorp revenues grew 5% and expenses and we maintained positive operating leverage in each of our 3 core businesses. Pre provision net revenues in Citicorp were $8.1 billion for the quarter up 15% from last year. And for the seventh consecutive quarter we grew loans year-over-year in every business in Citicorp.

"
column121:
"

Total Citicorp loans grew 11% with consumer loans up 5% and corporate loans up 19% Citi Holdings had revenues of $971 million and a net loss of $679 million. Citi Holdings ended the quarter with a $171 billion of assets down $20 billion during the quarter and $76 billion or $31% year-over-year. At quarter end Citi Holdings accounted for 9% of total Citigroup assets.

"
column122:
"

On slide seven we show a nine quarter trend for Citicorp\u2019s results. As I noted Citicorp's revenues of $18.4 billion were 5% higher than last year and expenses of $10.3 billion were 2% lower year-over-year. Citicorp's net credit losses of $2.2 billion declined 17% from last year driven by improvement in North America cards and the net loan loss reserve release in Citicorp was $696 million down from $887 million last year. This reflected a significant decline in the net reserve release in North America cards
column123:
partially offset by a reserve release in the corporate portfolio. Earnings before taxes of $6.6 billion grew 25% versus last year driven by higher revenues lower operating expenses and lower credit losses partially offset by a lower net reserve release.

"
column124:
"

On slide eight
column125:
we show Citicorp's pretax earnings by business excluding the impact of loan loss reserves. On a trailing 12 month basis earnings grew to $20.2 billion in the third quarter driven by strong results in Consumer Banking and Securities and Banking.

"
column126:
"

On slide nine
column127: we show Citicorp's results for the first nine months of the year. Revenues of $55.6 billion grew 4% from the prior year
column128: while expenses declined 1% generating double digit growth in operating margin. At the same time net credit losses improved significantly. Pretax earnings before the impact of loan loss reserves were $17.9 billion in the first nine months of the year or 34% higher than last year
column129:
reflecting the combination of positive operating leverage in each of our businesses as well as improved credit.

"
column130:
"

Slide 10
column131:
shows the results for North America Consumer Banking. Total revenues of $5.4 billion were up 6% versus last year largely driven by higher gains on sales of mortgage loans total card revenues declined 4% year-over-year. In branded cards both average loans and spreads declined year-over-year reflecting consumer deleveraging and the continued impact of the look back provisions of the Card Act.

"
column132:
"

In Retail Services
column133:
net interest revenues were stable year-over-year while non-interest revenues declined driven by improving credit and its impact on contractual partner payments. On a sequential basis however card revenues grew 5% as average loan stabilized and spreads improved in both portfolios.

"
column134:
"

Total operating expenses of $2.5 billion were up 2% year-over-year primarily due to higher retail channel mortgage volumes. Credit cost of $852 million declined modestly year-over-year and were up 19% sequentially.

"
column135:
"

Net credit losses continued to decline by 27% year-over-year to $1.4 billion driven by improvement in cards however the net loan loss reserve release was significantly lower than prior periods at $518 million this quarter compared to $956 million in the prior year and $814 million last quarter.

"
column136:
"

Earnings before tax excluding the impact of loan loss reserves nearly doubled from last year to $1.6 billion. Overall
column137: we continued to see progress in our North America consumer franchise. Average deposits grew for the sixth consecutive quarter; up 6% year-over-year
column138: including double digit growth in checking account balances. In branded cards
column139: accounts also grew for the sixth consecutive quarter
column140: up 4% year-over-year and for both card portfolios
column141:
net credit margins continue to expand year-over-year.

"
column142:
"

On slide 11
column143: we show results for international consumer banking in constant dollars. On this basis
column144: both revenues and expenses grew 3% year-over-year in the third quarter. Latin America achieved positive operating leverage for the fourth consecutive quarter with revenue growth of 7% and flat expenses versus last year and EMEA achieved positive operating leverage as well. Asia however
column145: had negative operating leverage for the quarter with revenues down 2% and expenses up 8% in constant dollars
column146:
which I\u2019ll discuss more in a minute.

"
column147:
"

Despite some headwinds
column148: most drivers for International Consumer Banking continued to grow in the third quarter
column149: both year-over-year and sequentially. Average loans grew 10% from last year and 2% sequentially. Average deposits grew 4% year-over-year and 1% sequentially
column150:
and both card purchase sales and investment sales also grew versus the prior period.

"
column151:
"

Credit costs were $722 million in the third quarter
column152: up 8% from last year as net credit losses grew 6% due to loan growth and there was no material loan loss reserve release this quarter. Earnings before tax
column153:
excluding the impact of loan loss reserves were nearly flat year-over-year at $1.1 billion.

"
column154:
"

On slide 12
column155: we show our Asia Consumer results in more detail. First on revenues: Investment sales revenues recovered from the second quarter. However
column156:
they remain modestly lower than last year and our total deposit and lending revenues including cards are down modestly from both periods.

"
column157:
"

Similar to last quarter
column158: most of the pressure on our Retail Banking Business continued to be seen in Korea and Japan. Korea
column159: in particular
column160: reflects the continued impact of regulatory changes
column161:
including the rate caps and other initiatives intended to slow the growth of consumer credit in that market.

"
column162:
"

At the same time
column163: spreads in several countries have compressed
column164: reflecting a decline in market interest rates. Despite these headwinds
column165: our franchise in Asia remained strong and we continue to grow volumes in the third quarter
column166: including average deposits
column167:
average retail loans and average card loans.

"
column168:
"

The cost associated with sustaining this volume growth drove a significant portion of the expense increase in the business
column169: both year-over-year and versus last quarter. Third quarter expenses also included nearly $20 million of repositioning charges in Korea as we began to rationalize our distribution network and refocus our client segmentation. While these changes were prompted by the new regulatory environment in Korea
column170:
they also simplify the business and align our Korea franchise more closely with the urban-based global strategy we employ in most other markets. We expect to incur additional repositioning charges in the fourth quarter to complete this effort.

"
column171:
"

Importantly
column172:
our overall outlook for Asia remains positive and we currently believe that in this environment we can grow revenues from our third quarter base at an annual rate of 4% to 6% with a return to positive operating leverage in 2013.

"
column173:
"

Slide 13 shows our International Consumer Credit trends
column174: which generally remained stable in the third quarter. For total International Consumer Banking
column175:
the NCL rate remained below 2% and 90 plus day delinquencies were stable at just above 90 basis points.

"
column176:
"

In Asia
column177: the NCL rate increased slightly from the first and second quarters each of which benefited from higher recoveries while delinquencies improved slightly. In Latin America
column178: both the NCL rate and delinquencies remained fairly stable. And in EMEA
column179:
the sequential increase in the NCL rate in the third quarter reflects the impact of a recovery in the prior quarter.

"
column180:
"

Slide 14 shows our Securities and Banking business. Revenues of $5.6 billion grew 15% versus last year and were up 7% from the prior quarter. Investment banking revenues of $926 billion grew 26% from the prior year on stronger debt and equity underwriting activity and higher M&A revenues
column181: while the sequential growth of 8% was driven by debt underwriting. Overall
column182: our wallet share in Investment Banking
column183:
continue to improve year-to-date in all major products.

"
column184:
"

Equity market revenues of $510 million grew 76% from last year driven by the absence of proprietary trading losses in the prior year as well as better derivatives performance. Sequentially
column185:
equity market revenues were down 7% on lower market volumes.

"
column186:
"

Fixed income market revenues of $3.7 billion grew 63% from last year driven by significantly higher revenues in credit related and securitized products
column187: as well as strong performance in rates and currencies. Sequentially
column188:
fixed income revenues were up 31% on strong results across all major products.

"
column189:
"

Lending revenues
column190: excluding the impact of gains and losses on hedges related to the accrual loans were $445 million in the third quarter
column191: up 35% from last year
column192:
on higher loan volumes and improved spreads and down slightly sequentially as higher volumes were offset by the absence of gains of asset sales in the prior quarter.

"
column193:
"

Total operating expenses of $3.5 billion were down 3% from last year driven by efficiency savings. Credit costs were a benefit of $73 million in the third quarter and net income grew 67% year-over-year to $1.6 billion.

"
column194:
"

Moving to Transaction Services on slide by 15; revenues of $2.7 billion were down 2% from last year on a reported basis and up 1% in constant dollars as continued growth in Treasury and Trade Solutions was mostly offset by a decline in Securities and Fund Services.

"
column195:
"

Treasury and Trade solutions was up 4% year-over-year in constant dollars driven by continued growth in deposits and trade loans partially offset by ongoing spread compression.

"
column196:
"

Securities and Fund Services revenues declined 8% in constant dollars on lower settlement volumes. The drivers for Transaction Services continue to show strong momentum. End of period trade loans were up over 30% from the prior year and average deposits were up 17% both in constant dollars. Expenses of $1.4 billion were down 5% versus last year driven by efficiency savings.

"
column197:
"

Slide 16 shows Citi Holdings assets. We ended the quarter with $171 billion in Citi Holdings assets or roughly 9% of total Citigroup assets. The $20 billion reduction in third quarter reflected a $12 billion decline in assets related to Morgan Stanley Smith Barney
column198: $4 billion of other assets sales
column199:
$3 billion of net pay downs and roughly $1 billion of cost of credit.

"
column200:
"

On slide 17
column201:
we showed Citi Holding's financial results for the quarter. Revenues in brokerage and asset management were negative $120 million this quarter versus $55 million last year due to a lower equity contribution from Morgan Stanley Smith Barney and lower private equity marks.

"
column202:
"

In Local Consumer Lending
column203: revenues were down 15% versus last year to $1.1 billion
column204: primarily due to declining loan balances. In the special asset pool
column205: revenues were negative 13 million in third quarter compared to negative $277 million last year
column206:
driven in part by lower funding cost as well as an improvement in asset marks.

"
column207:
"

Citi Holdings expenses were down 21% year-over-year to $1.2 billion
column208: mainly due to declining assets. Credit costs were down 26% year-over-year to $1.2 billion. Total net credit losses were $1.8 billion
column209: including the $635 million of the incremental mortgage charge-offs I described earlier. Excluding these incremental charge-offs
column210:
net credit losses in Citi Holding would have declined 38% year-over-year.

"
column211:
"

As I mentioned
column212: substantially all of the incremental charge-offs were offset by a reserve release of approximately $600 million
column213: so the impact on earnings was minimal. In total
column214:
we released $830 million of net loan loss reserves in Citi Holdings.

"
column215:
"

The net loss in Citi Holdings improved to $679 million in the third quarter however
column216:
this included a tax benefit of nearly $200 million related to the sale of certain assets in the special asset pool.

"
column217:
"

Looking at the past five quarters of Citi Holdings results on slide 18
column218:
Rep & Warranty reserve bills and legal and related costs continue to weigh on Citi Holdings in the third quarter. These costs have been difficult to predict and we continue to work to put these issues behind us.

"
column219:
"

On an operating basis however
column220: excluding these items
column221:
we maintained a modest positive operating margin in the third quarter and our goal is to continue to generate positive margin although there may be quarter-to-quarter fluctuations arising from periodic gains or losses as we continue to wind down the assets.

"
column222:
"

Credit trends also remained favorable this quarter
column223: with adjusted net credit losses of $1.2 billion
column224:
declining 12% quarter-over-quarter and mortgage losses comprising over [17%] of the total. We ended the quarter with $8.5 billion of loan loss reserves allocated to North America mortgage loans in Citi Holdings or 30 months or coverage.

"
column225:
"

The decline in North America mortgage reserves from $9.4 billion last quarter to $8.5 billion reflected the $600 million reserve release related to the incremental charge-offs as well as asset sales during the quarter. We continue to watch the housing market carefully and have taken note of some recent indications that the market may be stabilizing.

"
column226:
"

On slide 19 we show mortgage loan and adjusted net credit loss trends over the past two years. Since the third quarter of 2010 we have reduced the North America mortgage loans in Citi holdings by nearly 30% driven by $20 billion of pay-downs
column227:
$9 billion of assets sales and $9 billion of net losses.

"
column228:
"

Of the $9 billion of asset sales over the past two year
column229: approximately 6 billion have been delinquent loans
column230: including the sale of nearly $750 million in delinquent loans in the third quarter. We have also significantly reduced the quarterly net credit losses
column231: on the portfolio
column232:
down nearly 40% to $850 million in the third quarter even while $40 million to $45 million of losses were accelerated into each of the second and third quarters of this year as a result of actions we are taking to fulfill our commitments onto the national mortgage settlement.

"
column233:
"

Delinquency trends remained favorable through the third quarter with 90 plus day delinquencies improving in both residential first mortgages and home equity loans. Assuming no material deterioration of the economic environment here in the U.S.
column234:
the net credit losses on these portfolios should generally decline overtime as the portfolio continues to shrink.

"
column235:
"

Slide 20
column236:
shows the results for Corporate/Other. Revenues of $33 million were down from the prior year driven by the impact of hedging activities and lower investment yields. Expenses of $764 million were 47% higher versus last year mainly due to higher legal and related expenses as well as incremental firm wide marketing expenses in the third quarter. Assets of $302 billion included approximately $116 billion of cash and cash equivalents and $130 billion of liquid available for sales securities.

"
column237:
"

Turning to totaled Citigroup expenses on slide 21 total operating expenses of $12.2 billion in the third quarter were 2% lower than last year while core operating expenses excluding legal and related cost and repositioning charges declined 1% in constant dollars to $11.6 billion this core operating expense number is marginally higher than our expectation of a $11.5 billion for the quarter
column238:
driven by greater than expected volumes in Consumer Banking.

"
column239:
"

As we look to the fourth quarter
column240: we currently believe our core operating expenses should remain roughly in line with the third quarter levels. Additionally
column241:
we expect to continue to incur elevated legal and related expenses and repositioning cost in the fourth quarter.

"
column242:
"

On slide 22
column243: we show our key capital metrics under Basel III our estimated Tier I common ratio as of the third quarter was 8.6% up from 7.9% in the second quarter. More than half of the increase was driven by operating earnings. Roughly 15 basis points came from the Morgan Stanley Smith Barney transaction
column244:
roughly 8 basis points was due to lower risk weighted assets and the remainder was driven by changes in other comprehensive income and other items.

"
column245:
"

On Basel I
column246: Tier 1 common ratio remained flat as of the third quarter at 12.7% adjusting for the final market risk ruled that will be effective in January 2013. Our Basel I Tier 1 common ratio would be approximately 11.5% slide 23 shows the components of our Basel I and estimated Basel III capital ratios. As of the third quarter
column247:
our Tier 1 Common Capital under Basel I was $124 billion compared to an estimated $106 billion under Basel III.

"
column248:
"

Turning to the denominator
column249:
our total risk weighted assets under Basel III were an estimated $1.2 trillion or 27% higher versus Basel I. The increase from Basel I to Basel III remained very favorable for Citicorp and Corp/Other with an increase of only 15%.

"
column250:
"

Slide 24 shows our returns on capital for the first nine months of 2012. On the lower left
column251: we show our average tangible common equity for the period
column252: split between the amount of TCE
column253:
which supports our deferred tax assets and that which is employed by our businesses.

"
column254:
"

A significant amount of our deferred tax asset is deducted from regulatory capital under Basel III and therefore
column255:
we are required to have a higher absolute level of TCE then would otherwise be needed to support our income generating businesses.

"
column256:
"

The $40 billion of TCE that must be retained to support the DTA earns a return through the utilization of this specific asset rather than from the income produced by our businesses. In other words
column257: only a $110 billion of our TCE is employed in our income producing operations. On this basis
column258:
Citigroup earned nearly a 12% return on the tangible common equity supporting our operating businesses in the first nine months of the year.

"
column259:
"

Turning to regulatory capital
column260: if we assume Tier 1 common capital levels of 9.5% of Basel III risk weighted assets across each business. The return on Basel III capital for Citigroup would have been an estimated 10.7% in the first nine months of the year
column261:
including an 18.7% return for our core businesses in Citicorp plus Corporate/Other.

"
column262:
"

Now
column263: let me close with a few comments about the outlook. First Global Consumer Banking; in North America
column264: revenues continue to benefit from strong mortgage refinancing activity which we currently expect will continue into at least the early part of next year. However
column265:
card revenues remain under pressure with declining average loan balances driven by continued consumer deleveraging.

"
column266:
"

Additionally
column267: while net credit losses are likely to improve modestly from current levels
column268:
we expect loan loss reserve releases to continue to decline in North America as delinquency trends have stabilized in the card business.

"
column269:
"

In Latin America
column270: we continue to see strong growth in revenues and volumes driven by market growth and the strength of our franchise in Mexico. Overall
column271:
credit quality remained stable in the third quarter and we believe this trend will continue.

"
column272:
"

In Asia
column273: as we discussed earlier
column274: consumer revenue growth has slowed
column275: primarily reflecting headwinds in Korea and Japan. In response to regulatory changes in Korea
column276: we are repositioning that business. We took nearly $20 million of related charges in the third quarter and we expect to incur additional repositioning costs in the fourth quarter to complete the effort. Our overall outlook remains positive in Asia however
column277: as volumes continued to grow in the third quarter. As I noted
column278:
we currently believe that in this environment we can grow revenues from our third quarter base at an annual rate of 4% to 6% with a return to positive operating leverage in 2013.

"
column279:
"

Transaction Services continue to show positive operating leverage in the third quarter
column280: although overall revenues were down slightly year-over-year reflecting ongoing spread compression
column281: lower settlement volumes and the impact of FX. We continue to believe we can absorb the headwind of a low interest rate environment with additional volumes and new mandates and while our growth in trade assets slowed in the third quarter reflecting the market environment
column282:
we continue to be well positioned to gain market share in that business.

"
column283:
"

Securities and Banking results were very strong in the third quarter
column284:
as a more favorable market environment offset the impact of seasonally slower volumes for many businesses. The strength of our fixed income franchise in particular was evident this quarter with momentum across all products.

"
column285:
"

In Equities
column286: our performance continues to demonstrate that the issues of the second half of 2011 are behind us
column287:
although we will likely continue to experience low levels of client activity in this macro environment.

"
column288:
"

And finally
column289: we continue to see momentum in Investment Banking with wallet share gains in every major product. Importantly
column290:
we remain disciplined on expenses in securities and banking with a continued focus on operating at the right size for the opportunities we see in the market.

"
column291:
"

In Holdings
column292: the wind down of assets will continue
column293: although likely at a slower pace than the third quarter and our primary focus remains the mortgage portfolio. We continue to watch the mortgage market closely and while we have noted signs that the housing market may have stabilized
column294: we would like more clarity on economic trends in the U.S. before we can conclude that the housing recovery is sustainable. In the meantime
column295: we are focused on reducing the loan portfolio
column296:
mitigating risk and working through the rep and warranty and other issues associated with that business.

"
column297:
"

Overall
column298: while market sentiment improved in the third quarter benefiting certain of our businesses
column299:
the overall macro environment including slowing GDP growth in certain countries and a persistent low rate environment remains an overhang for now. We continue to make progress however in the third quarter and we remain optimistic about our prospects given our client franchise and unique mix of businesses.

"

Well
column427: I would say that all mortgage charge-off activity has got an element of HPI sensitivity built into it
column428: just based upon the mechanics of what you go through in order to recognize the losses. So you know
column429: when a loan gets to 188 days past due
column430: you take your initial write-down
column431:
which of course is influenced by what you think the realizable value of that property is going to be. So there is an HPI component in that charge-off.

"
column432:
"

Then as the loan stays on your books and with the extension of the foreclosure timeline
column433: this is becoming an increasingly longer period of time
column435: you know
column436:
two or three times a year and reassess where you have that property marked against what your new estimates as far as realize-ability would be and of course that is heavily influenced by the expectation of HPI.

"
column437:
"

So when it comes to those severity type of losses
column438: especially I\u2019ll call it the secondary
column439: you know the catch up severity losses they are on the subsequent writedowns
column440: there we\u2019ve seen some real improvement
column441: the overall volume of subsequent writedowns last year was probably running in the $60 million a quarter
column442: this quarter it dropped down closer to $50 million
column443: a lot of that being driven by volume related
column444: we just have more inventory in our book
column445: but importantly you know at least what I\u2019m seeing is that
column446:
the average subsequent writedown for severity factors year-over-year has probably dropped by a third for each of the properties. So you\u2019re starting to see some level of that recovery of HPI enter into the numbers.

Good afternoon. Just a couple of quick questions John you mentioned some of the trends in the securities businesses and in the third quarter and I realized it's very early in Q4. But I'm curious if you're seeing any reduction in activity levels from clients who might be a little more cautious heading into the election in the fiscal cliff?

"
column1040:
"

I don't think I'm going to give a comment on the early stages of the fourth quarter market.

"

"

Now but having said that
column1043:
there's no question uncertainties are good for the economy. It's never good for the markets and at some point it's not about what happens to the cliff. It is leading up to cliff that can have an impact as well. All of those are uncertainties still ahead of us.

"

"

And then just a quick administrative question
column1046: John you targeted our estimated debt effective tax rate going forward last quarter moving forward would be about 22%
column1050: I would up it probably to 24% right now
column1051: you take a look at our tax rate this quarter
column1052: it's certainly very noisy given some of the things that have happened. If you strip out the Morgan Stanley Smith Barney loss and the $580 million tax reserve release. That gives you a rate that's more in line with what you would normally see. And you strip out those two and our rate becomes
column1056:
"

So that's just a shade over the guidance that I gave last quarter
column1057:
about 22% and I would expect the fourth quarter to be more in line with that 23% to 24% range that you see in the third quarter.

"
column1068:
thank you all for joining us today.

"

"

Thank you all very much.

"
