column1:
{"Citigroup's CEO Discusses Q4 2012 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Citigroup (NYSE:C)

"
column16:
"

Erika Penala - Bank of America

"
column24:
"

Hello and welcome to Citi\u2019s Fourth Quarter 2012 Earnings Review with Chief Executive Officer Mike Corbat and Chief Financial Officer John Gerspach. Today\u2019s call will be hosted by Susan Kendall
column25: Head of Citi Investor Relations. We ask that you please hold all questions until the completion of the formal remarks
column26: at which time you will be given instructions for the question-and-answer session. Also
column28: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column30:
"

Ms. Kendall
column34: operator. Good morning and thank you all for joining us. On our call today
column37: will speak first. Then John Gerspach
column39: will take you through the earnings presentation
column40: which is available for download on our website citigroup.com. Afterwards
column41:
we\u2019ll be happy to take questions.

"
column42:
"

Before we get started
column43: I would like to remind you that today\u2019s presentation may contain forward-looking statements which are based on management\u2019s current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results in capital and other financial condition may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors
column44: including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today and those included in our SEC filings
column45: including
column46: without limitation
column47:
the Risk Factors section of our 2011 Form 10-K.

"
column48:
"

With that said
column49:
let me turn it over to Mike.

"
column50:
"

Mike Corbat

"
column52: thank you and good morning everyone
column54: we reported earnings of $1.2 billion for the fourth quarter of 2012. Excluding DVA and our repositioning charge
column57:
"

These earnings were below expectations
column58: reflecting the high level of legacy costs
column59:
most notably in legal and related expenses. We also had a reserve release which was significantly smaller than in previous quarters as our credit trends are normalizing and we\u2019ve not yet begun to release mortgage reserves.

"
column60:
"

To be clear
column61: we\u2019re not satisfied with these bottom line earnings
column62: and our focus is not only on putting the drag of legacy issues behind us
column63:
but also on optimizing the efficiency and returns of our business as a whole.

"
column64:
"

Despite the disappointing bottom line
column65: our businesses generally performed well during the quarter. Investment banking increased its wallet share
column66: loans grew in our core businesses
column67: such as Latin American consumer
column68: where we saw double digit growth. In addition
column69: we decreased Citi Holdings assets by 9% during the quarter for a 31% reduction for the year. Our capital strength improved during the quarter
column70:
with the tier 1 common ratio increasing to an estimated 8.7% on a Basel III basis.

"
column71:
"

Although the environment has shown signs of improvement
column72: we believe it\u2019s likely to remain challenging
column73: with continued spread compression
column74: the introduction and implementation of new or evolving regulation
column75: as well as the costs associated with putting legacy issues behind us. This puts even greater importance on getting our operating efficiency to a level we\u2019re satisfied with
column76:
and on allocating our resources to opportunities with the greatest risk-adjusted return.

"
column77:
"

Regardless of the environment
column78: Citi needs to be recognized globally as an indisputably strong and stable bank. We believe the proper essentials are the combination of a strong balance sheet
column79: made up of high-quality assets
column80:
supported by the appropriate levels of capital and liquidity.

"
column81:
"

Along with our risk profile
column82: our necessary levels of capital and liquidity are a function of the consistency of the quantity and quality of our earnings
column83: and as a company
column84:
we need to deliver on our commitments.

"
column85:
"

When I became CEO in October
column86: I stated three main objectives to accomplish by early in the New Year. First
column87: conduct business reviews and prepare the 2013 budget
column88: which drove our repositioning charge in the fourth quarter. Second was to structure my management team
column89: which was announced on January 7
column90: and third was to finalize and submit our CCAR
column91:
which was submitted on the same day.

"
column92:
"

Throughout this period
column93: I spent a good amount of time meeting with stakeholders
column94: our clients
column95: investors
column96: regulators
column97: and of course our people. Let me make a few points based on those conversations. First
column98: our strategy is to focus on our core banking businesses by trying to provide best in class products and services to people and institutions leveraging our global footprint
column99:
which includes the world\u2019s growing fastest markets and cities. We believe our strategy is aligned with the dominant secular trends.

Second
column100: we\u2019ll continue to seek ways to refine and optimize the execution of our strategy and focus on operating efficiency. As a company
column101: we need to show expense discipline and we can be smart allocators of our resources
column102: driving them where they can catalyze strong
column103:
risk-adjusted returns.

For example
column104: the $900 million in expense reductions we expect to realize in 2013 from the repositioning actions we announced in December
column105: was driven by a bottoms-up review of where and how we\u2019re going to allocate our expense dollars. That said
column106: improving our operating efficiency needs to be BAU
column107:
not just an annual event.

Third
column108: we\u2019re very focused on Citi Holdings
column109: considering the disproportionate  drag at places on net income and returns. In 2002
column110: we reduced the size of Citi Holdings by 31% and it now makes up 8% of our balance sheet. That being said
column111:
there is no silver bullet which will immediately resolve Holdings.

We\u2019ll continue to manage these assets and our associated expenses in an economically rational way while taking advantage of any reasonable opportunities to reduce them more expeditiously.

And as you know
column112:
our North American mortgage portfolio makes up the majority of Holdings\u2019 assets. Trends in that portfolio were favorable in the recent quarter and we continue to watch the US economy and housing market very closely.

But before I turn it over to John
column113:
I\u2019d like to emphasize that we recognize our net income today doesn\u2019t yet reflect either the amount or caliber of earnings our shareholders expect and that our franchise is capable of. It\u2019ll take some time to work through the challenges of the current environment to realize the potential.

Improving our operating efficiency
column114:
returns on assets and tangible equity in a risk-balanced manner and returning capital to our shareholders are critical goals going forward.

I\u2019m a believer in you are what you measure and I intend to set clear goals and hold my management team accountable for them. Similarly
column115:
we\u2019ll share key metrics with you in the coming months so you can hold me accountable as well.

Now
column116:
John will go over the slides and then we\u2019d be happy to answer any of your questions. Thank you.

John Gerspach

Thank you
column117: Mike
column118: and good morning
column119: everyone. To start
column120:
I\u2019d like to highlight some significant items affecting our results this quarter. First CVA and DVA were negative $485 million pre-tax and $301 million after tax in the fourth quarter for a negative impact on EPS of $0.10.

In addition
column121: as previously announced
column122: we recorded a $1 billion pre-tax repositioning charge in the fourth quarter
column123: or $653 million after tax
column124:
for a negative impact on EPS of $0.21.

For comparison purposes
column125: in the fourth quarter of 2011
column126:
CVA and DVA had a minimal impact at negative $40 million pre-tax and repositioning costs were $428 million pre-tax or $275 million after tax for a total negative impact of $0.10 per share.

Adjusting for these items we earned $2.2 billion in the fourth quarter of 2012 or $0.69 per share as compared to $0.41 per share in the fourth quarter of 2011. Throughout today\u2019s earnings presentation
column127:
I will be discussing our result excluding both CVA and DVA as well as the higher than normal repositioning costs in the fourth quarters of 2011 and 2012 to provide comparability to prior periods.

I will also discuss prior quarters excluding the impact of gains and losses on minority investments as well as the tax benefit in the third quarter of 2012. A full schedule of repositioning charges by business is included in the appendix.

In addition
column128: as shown on Slide 4
column129:
there are a few other significant items which are included in our results.

First
column130: operating expenses in the fourth quarter included legal and related costs of nearly $1.3 billion compared to $529 million last quarter and $832 million in the prior year. Legal and related costs in Citicorp including Corp other
column131: increased significantly from prior periods to $735 million driven primarily by U.S. consumer-related matters. And
column132: Citi Holdings legal expenses were roughly $550 million
column133: including the previously announced $305 million charge related to the foreclosure review settlement. Second
column134: the net loan loss reserve release of $86 million this quarter
column135:
was significantly lower than prior periods.

"
column136:
"

Year over year
column137: about half of the decline in the reserve release was driven by Citicorp
column138: mostly in North America cards
column139: and about half was driven by Citi Holdings
column140: reflecting declining loan and reserve balances versus last year. In Citi Holdings
column141:
we recorded a net reserve build in the fourth quarter as a significantly lower net reserve release was more than offset by the impact of losses on loan sales. This compared to a reserve release of $663 million last year.

"
column142:
"

On slide five
column143: we show total Citigroup results for the quarter. Revenues of $18.7 billion were up 8% from last year
column144:
while operating expenses of $12.8 billion were roughly flat as higher legal and related costs were offset by a 3% decline in core operating expenses.

"
column145:
"

Credit costs of $3.2 billion increased 11% versus last year. Net credit losses of $3.1 billion declined by 25%. However
column146: as I just discussed
column147:
the net reserve release of $86 million was down significantly from $1.5 billion last year.

"
column148:
"

We earned $2.2 billion of net income in the fourth quarter
column149: or $0.69 per share
column150: up from $0.41 per share last year on a comparable basis. This was driven by loan growth
column151: lower core operating expenses
column152: and lower net credit losses
column153:
partially offset by the increase in legal and related expenses and a lower net loan loss reserve release.

"
column154:
"

Citigroup end of period loans grew 1% year over year to $655 billion
column155: as loan growth in Citicorp continued to outpace the wind-down of Citi Holdings and deposits grew 7% to $931 billion. We saw an expected decline in deposits during the fourth quarter
column156: reflecting the runoff of episodic deposits which came in at the end of the third quarter
column157: as well as the expiration of the transaction account guarantee
column158:
or TAG program. This decline was partially offset by continued growth in core operating account balances.

"
column159:
"

On slide six
column160: we show full year results
column161: including the split between Citicorp and Citi Holdings. Throughout today\u2019s earnings presentation
column162: I will be discussing Citicorp results including our operating businesses: Global Consumer Banking
column163: Securities and Banking
column164: and Transaction Services
column165:
as well as the Corporate Other segment.

"
column166:
"

Full year 2012 revenues for Citigroup were $77 billion
column167: up slightly from 2011
column168:
with less than 5% of revenues coming from Citi Holdings. Operating expenses were down 2% and credit costs also declined as a significant reduction in net credit losses was offset by a smaller loan loss reserve release in 2012 versus the prior year.

"
column169:
"

For the full year
column170: Citigroup earned nearly $12 billion in net income
column171: up 18% from last year. On slide 7
column172:
we show quarterly results for Citicorp and Citi Holdings. Citicorp generated fourth quarter revenues of $17.6 billion and net income of $3.2 billion.

"
column173:
"

Year over year
column174: revenues grew 9% and expenses were up 3% as higher legal and related costs were partially offset by a 2% decline in core operating expenses. And
column175: for the eighth consecutive quarter
column176: we grew loans year over year in every business in Citicorp. Total Citicorp loans grew 7%
column177:
with consumer loans up 3% and corporate loans up 11%.

"
column178:
"

Citi Holdings had revenues of $1 billion
column179: and a net loss of $1 billion. Citi Holdings ended the quarter with $156 billion of assets
column180: down 15% during the quarter and $69 billion
column181: or 31%
column182: year over year. At quarter end
column183:
Citi Holdings accounted for 8% of total Citigroup assets.

"
column184:
"

On slide eight
column185: we show a nine-quarter trend for Citicorp\u2019s results. As I noted
column186: Citicorp\u2019s revenues of $17.6 billion were 9% higher year over year
column187: and down 4% sequentially
column188:
mostly reflecting seasonally lower capital markets revenues.

"
column189:
"

Expenses of $11.3 billion were up 3% from last year and 2% sequentially due to the higher legal and related costs.

Citicorp\u2019s net credit losses of $2.1 billion continued to decline in the fourth quarter
column190: down 19% from last year
column191: driven by improvement in North America cards and the net loan loss reserve release in Citicorp was $137 million
column192: down significantly from the prior quarter and prior year
column193: mostly reflecting a decline in the net reserve release in North America cards. Year-over-year
column194:
we grew Citicorp\u2019s earnings in every quarter of 2012.

On Slide 9
column195: we show Citicorp\u2019s pre-tax earnings by business excluding the impact of loan loss reserves. For the full year 2012
column196: earnings grew to just over $20 billion
column197: up 40% from 2011
column198:
driven by consumer banking and securities and banking.

Slide 10 shows the results for North America consumer banking. Total revenues of $5.3 billion in the fourth quarter were up 3% year-over-year
column199: largely driven by higher gains on sales of mortgage loans
column200:
partially offset by a decline in cards revenues. Total card revenues were down 3% from last year as lower average loans were partially offset by an improvement in spreads.

Lower retail services revenues also reflected improving credit and its impact on contractual partner payments. Total operating expenses of $2.6 billion were down 3% year-over-year primarily due to efficiency savings.

On a sequential basis
column201:
the increase in expenses was primarily driven by higher legal and related costs. Credit costs of $1.1 billion increased 10% year-over-year and were up 25% sequentially.

Net credit losses declined by 27% year-over-year to $1.3 billion driven by improvement in cars. However
column202:
the net loan loss reserve release was significantly lower than prior periods at $215 million this quarter compared to $784 million in the prior year and $518 million last quarter.

Looking ahead to 2013
column203: assuming a continuation of the current economic environment here in the US
column204:
we expect the average quarterly net reserve releases in cards to roughly approximately the fourth quarter level.

Earnings before tax
column205: excluding the impact of loan loss reserves
column206: nearly doubled from last year to $1.5 billion. Overall
column207: we continue to see progress in our North America consumer franchise. Average deposits grew for the seventh consecutive quarter
column208: up 9% year-over-year
column209:
including double-digit growth in checking account balances.

In branded cards
column210: accounts also grew for the seventh consecutive quarter
column211: up 3% year-over-year and for both card portfolios
column212:
net credit margins continued to expand year-over-year.

On Slide 11
column213: we show results for international consumer banking in constant dollars. On this basis
column214: both revenues and expenses grew 4% year-over-year. In Latin America
column215: both revenues and expenses grew 7% from last year and in AMEA
column216:
we generated positive operating leverage with revenue growth of 11% and expense growth of 5% year-over-year.

In Asia
column217: revenues were down 2% from last year while expenses were up 1%. However
column218: on a sequential basis
column219:
revenues were flat as we began to move past the headwinds in both Korea and Japan. I\u2019ll talk more about Asia in a minute.

Most drivers for international consumer banking continued to grow in the fourth quarter. Total average loans grew 5% from last year. Card purchase sales were up 10% and investment sales grew 36% year-over-year.

Credit costs of $869 million in the fourth quarter were up 12% from last year
column220:
driven by a 12% growth in net credit losses due mostly to loan growth as well as some specific commercial loan charge-offs in Latin American.

On Slide 12
column221: we show our Asian consumer results in a bit more detail. Total revenues remained under pressure in the fourth quarter due to the continued low rate environment and the impact of regulatory headwinds in certain markets
column222: most notably
column223:
Korea.

Our underlying business volumes
column224: however
column225: reflected continued franchise strength and importantly
column226: credit performance remained very good
column227: reflecting the high quality of our portfolio. We also maintained expense discipline across the region
column228:
while still investing in important markets such as China.

"
column229:
"

Looking first at the cards business
column230: revenues grew 2% year over year with significant growth in card purchases. In total
column231: purchase sales grew 8% from last year and
column232: excluding Korea
column233:
purchase sales were up 9% versus prior periods.

"
column234:
"

Investment sales revenue showed strong performance
column235: up 14% year over year and down moderately from a particularly good third quarter
column236: as retail investor sentiment improved
column237:
and we continued to attract high-quality customers.

"
column238:
"

Revenue pressure was most evident in our retail lending and deposit businesses
column239: down 10% year over year as spread compression offset volume growth. Volumes were muted in Korea in particular. Excluding this market
column240:
average retail loans grew 8% year over year.

"
column241:
"

Our overall outlook for Asia remains positive
column242: and we continue to believe we can grow 2013 revenues at an annual rate of 4-6% from current levels. We also believe that longer-term
column243: as customers become less risk-averse and interest rates normalize
column244: revenue growth in Asia will converge with the existing driver growth and that should feed through the earnings
column245: given our efficiency
column246: portfolio quality
column247:
and strong market position.

"
column248:
"

Slide 13 shows our international consumer credit trends. Credit quality in our international consumer portfolio remains strong in the fourth quarter. For total international consumer banking
column249: the NCL rate increased 17 basis points from last quarter to 215 basis points
column250: driven by Latin America
column251:
while 90-plus day delinquencies were fairly stable at just above 90 basis points.

"
column252:
"

In Latin America
column253: the increase in the NCL rate reflected a $50 million sequential increase in retail net credit losses. Roughly a third of this increase was related to two specific commercial loan charge offs in Mexico and the remainder primarily reflected seasoning of the portfolio
column254: mainly personal loans in Mexico
column255: Colombia
column256:
and Brazil.

"
column257:
"

In Latin America
column258: we expect retail banking NCL rates should normalize in the range of 2.5% by the second half of 2013. The card NCL rate in Latin America remains stable in the fourth quarter at 7.7%. However
column259:
we would expect this portfolio to normalize to a level of around 8.5% in 2013 as the portfolio seasons.

"
column260:
"

On a combined basis
column261: therefore
column262: we expect the NCL rate in Latin America to normalize in the range of 4.5% by the second half of 2013
column263: based on what we see today. In Asia
column264: both the NCL and delinquency rates remained fairly stable at 1% and 50 basis points
column265:
respectively.

"
column266:
"

Slide 14 shows our Securities and Banking business. Revenues of $4.8 billion grew 47% from last year
column267: and were down 14% from the prior quarter
column268: on seasonally lower capital markets revenues. Investment banking revenues of $996 million grew 56% from the prior year and 8% sequentially
column269:
with higher revenues in all major products.

"
column270:
"

Overall
column271: our wallet share in investment banking improved this year in most products and regions. Equity market revenues of $455 million nearly doubled from last year
column272: driven by improved derivatives performance as well as the absence of the prior period\u2019s proprietary trading losses. However
column273: sequentially
column274:
equity market revenues were down 11% on lower derivatives revenues.

"
column275:
"

Fixed income market revenues of $2.7 billion grew 58% from last year
column276: driven by significant improvement in credit and securitized products as well as higher revenues in rates and currencies. Sequentially
column277:
fixed income revenues declined 27% from a strong third quarter.

"
column278:
"

Lending revenues
column279: excluding the impact of gains and losses on hedges related to accrual loans
column280: were $397 million in the fourth quarter
column281: up 17% from last year
column282: on higher loan balances and improved spreads
column283:
and down 11% sequentially on loan sale activity.

"
column284:
"

Total operating expenses of of $3.4 billion were down 2% from last year driven by efficiency savings.

Credit costs were $78 million in the fourth quarter and net income grew substantially year-over-year to $1.1 billion.

Moving now to transaction services on Slide 15
column285:
revenues of $2.6 billion were up 1% from last year. Treasury and trade solutions was up 1% year-over-year driven by continued growth in deposits and trade loans partially offset by ongoing spread compression and securities and fund services revenues were flat to last year as growth in fee revenues was also offset by continued spread compression.

The drivers for transaction services continued to show strong momentum. End of period trade loans were up 24% from the prior year. Average deposits were up 16% and assets under custody grew by 10%.

Expenses of $1.5 billion were up 2% from last year due mostly to higher legal and related costs as well as certain episodic items
column286:
which also drove part of the increase from the prior quarter.

We experienced negative operating leverage in transaction services in the fourth quarter
column287: reflecting both spread compression in revenues and the increase in expenses. While we currently expect client volumes to continue to grow
column288:
revenue pressure from spread compression is likely to persist in the near term.

Quarterly expenses
column289: however
column290: should be somewhat lower than fourth quarter 2012 levels as we go forward. As such
column291:
we expect to return to positive operating leverage in transaction services on a full-year basis in 2013.

Slide 16 shows the results for corporate other. Revenues of negative $76 million were down from the prior year driven by the absence of last year\u2019s hedging gains and lower investment yields.

Expenses of $805 million were significantly higher versus last year
column292:
mainly due to higher legal and related expenses. Assets of $249 billion included approximately $46 billion of cash and cash equivalents and $144 billion of liquid available for sale securities.

Slide 17 shows Citi Holdings\u2019 assets. We ended the quarter with assets of $156 billion in Citi Holdings or roughly 8% of total Citigroup assets. The $15 billion reduction in the fourth quarter reflected $4 billion of asset sales
column293:
$10 billion of net paydowns and roughly $1 billion of cost of credit.

On Slide 18
column294: we show Citi Holdings\u2019 financial results for the quarter. Total revenues of $1 billion were down 2% year-over-year
column295:
as declines in local consumer lending were largely offset by higher revenues in the special asset pool reflecting an improvement in asset marks.

Citi Holdings\u2019 expenses were down 15% year-over-year to $1.5 billion mostly due to the reduction in assets and on a sequential basis the increase mostly reflects the $305 million charge related to the foreclosure review settlement.

Credit costs increased 14% year-over-year to $1.2 billion. Total net credit losses of $972 million were down 36% year-over-year. However
column296:
we recorded a net loan loss reserve build in the fourth quarter as a significantly lower net reserve release was more than offset by the impact of losses on loans sets. This compared to a net reserve release of $663 million last year.

Looking at the past five quarters of Citi Holdings\u2019 results on Slide 19
column297: rep and warranty reserve builds
column298:
legal and related costs and repositioning charges continued to weigh on Citi Holdings in the fourth quarter.

On an operating basis
column299: however
column300: excluding these items
column301: we maintained a modest positive operating margin again in the fourth quarter and our goal is to continue to generate positive margins
column302:
although there may be quarter-to-quarter fluctuations arising from periodic gains or losses as we continue to wind down the assets.

Credit trends remain favorable this quarter with North America mortgages comprising 75% of total net credit losses. We ended the quarter with $8.4 billion of loan loss reserves allocated to North America mortgage loans in Citi Holdings
column303: or 33 months of loss coverage. On slide 20
column304: we show mortgage loan and adjusted net credit loss trends over the past two years. Since the fourth quarter of 2010
column305: we have reduced the North America mortgage loans in Citi Holdings by 27%
column306: driven by $19 billion of paydowns
column307: $6 billion of asset sales
column308:
and $9 billion of net losses.

"
column309:
"

In the recent fourth quarter
column310: we sold nearly $600 million of delinquent loans. We have also significantly reduced the quarterly net credit losses on the portfolio
column311: down 40% since the fourth quarter of 2010 to $762 million
column312: even while roughly $60 million of losses were accelerated into the recent quarter as a result of the continued actions we are taking to fulfill our commitments under the National Mortgage Settlement
column313:
or NMS. We currently expect NMS to continue to have an impact on net credit losses through the second quarter of 2013.

"
column314:
"

Delinquency trends improved as well through the fourth quarter
column315: in both residential first mortgages and home equity loans. Assuming the continuation of the current economic environment here in the U.S.
column316: the net credit losses on these portfolios should generally decline over time
column317:
as the portfolio continues to shrink.

"
column318:
"

On slide 21
column319: we show our net interest margin and revenue trends. Our net interest margin expanded in the fourth quarter by 7 basis points to 2.93%
column320: with about half of the improvement driven by our trading book and the remainder reflecting lower funding costs
column321: partially offset by lower loan yields. Net interest revenue also increased from last quarter
column322:
as growth in Citicorp net interest revenue offset the ongoing wind-down of Citi Holdings.

"
column323:
"

On a full year basis
column324: our net interest margin remained relatively stable versus last year at 288 basis points. And
column325: we currently believe we can maintain our net interest margin at roughly this level for 2013
column326:
with some quarterly fluctuations.

"
column327:
"

Turning to total Citigroup expenses
column328: on slide 22
column329: while reported operating expenses of $13.8 billion in the fourth quarter were 5% higher than last year
column330: core operating expenses
column331: excluding legal and related costs and repositioning charges
column332:
declined 3% in constant dollars to $11.5 billion.

"
column333:
"

We currently believe $11.5 billion is an indicative base for quarterly operating expenses going into 2013. From this level
column334: Citi Holdings expenses should decline over time with the ongoing reduction in assets. We will continue to pursue ongoing reengineering opportunities and we continue to expect to achieve $900 million of expense savings in 2013
column335: related to our announced repositioning actions
column336:
with full year expense savings of $1.2 billion beginning in 2014.

"
column337:
"

These total expense savings will likely be offset in part by volume-related costs
column338: particularly as we seek to grow client volumes in the low interest rate environment. Overall
column339: however
column340: we expect core operating expenses in 2013 to be lower than full year 2012. Of course
column341: legal and related costs will likely continue to be elevated and somewhat volatile
column342:
although we would not expect our fourth quarter levels to be the new norm.

"
column343:
"

On slide 23
column344: we show our key capital metrics through the fourth quarter. Under Basel III
column345: our estimated tier 1 common ratio increased to 8.7% versus 8.6% in the third quarter. And
column346: our Basel I tier 1 common ratio remained flat at 12.7%. Adjusting for the final market risk rules that became effective this month
column347:
our Basel I tier 1 common ratio would have been approximately 11.2%.

"
column348:
"

In summary
column349: our results in the fourth quarter reflected the challenging operating environment as we faced elevated legal and related costs and continued spread compression
column350: particularly in the U.S. and Asia. In consumer banking
column351: we continued to see strong loan growth in Latin America
column352:
and in Asia we began to move past some of the regulatory headwinds which slowed volumes in the second half of the year.

"
column353:
"

Importantly
column354: the credit trends in our global consumer portfolio remained favorable with net credit losses and delinquencies at historically low levels. In securities and banking
column355:
we demonstrated our ability to grow revenues while maintaining expense disciplines and our investment banking franchise showed good progress.

And finally
column357:
we faced a continued low interest rate environment in many local markets but we showed positive operating leverage for the year as higher volumes offset spread compression.

We continued to reduce Citi Holdings
column358:
which represented only 8% of total assets at year-end. We also ended the year with demonstrated strength in both capital and liquidity.

As we go into 2013
column359:
we are keenly aware of the challenging rate environment but remain positive in our ability to grow volumes to offset this headwind given our unique global footprint.

We are also highly focused on efficiency and optimizing our core businesses in order to drive improved returns. With that
column360:
Mike and I are happy to take any questions.

John Gerspach

"
column941:
"

The answer to that is
column942: I\u2019m not going to say in business by business
column943: because spread compression is going to hit you differently in different businesses
column944: and I think we\u2019ve seen that. Certainly in Transaction Services
column945: if you\u2019re not able to offset spread compression
column946: but the volume
column947: you can have the impact of spread compression
column948: you know
column949:
it will take away revenues without impacting your level of volume.

"
column950:
"

And so therefore
column951: you\u2019re really running the same stuff through your shop. So your ability to take expense out is then just limited to your ability to generate reengineering savings
column952:
which may or may not be enough to offset the impact of the spread compression.

"
column953:
"

So in general
column954: you know
column955: you\u2019re thinking about it the right way
column956: but it is somewhat dependent business by business
column957:
and it\u2019s also dependent upon the magnitude of the spread compression that is impacting each business.

"
column958:
"


Eric Wasserstrom - SunTrust

And then just to follow up on that
column960: which is obviously something that you [unintelligible]
column963:
the other big risk factors that would disrupt the realization of positive operating leverage across the various businesses?

"
column966: general economics. If our customers aren\u2019t growing their businesses
column967: if our customers have a change in sentiment as far as how they view the general economy and cut back on either savings or borrowing or any of that
column968:
that certainly is a risk factor.

"
column969:
"


Eric Wasserstrom - SunTrust

So it sounds like outside of deterioration in the broader macro-environment
column970: what you\u2019re suggesting is the spread issue remains a serious one to look at
column972:
we should probably be thinking about continued low single digit operating leverage expansion.

"
column974:
"

Although I probably will be directing you to make sure that you do a thorough reading of every risk factor that we publish in the 400-page 10-K that we\u2019ll be delivering to you at some point in time in the next 45 days or so.

"
column978:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Andrew Marquardt with Evercore Partners.

"
column980:
"

Just following on that line of questioning
column982: can you talk about the areas that you\u2019re most focused on investing? You talked about
column984: cost saves and there\u2019s more to come
column987: but the investment spend that you need to focus on to drive the volume and the revenue
column988:
can you talk a little bit about where you\u2019re most focused?

"
column991: so we\u2019re focused in a few areas. One is in the operations and technology area in terms of continuing to combine
column994: and roll out common systems around our global network. I think that would be one significant area where we\u2019ve made investment. We\u2019re going to need the continue to make investment. We\u2019re always investing in our people
column995: in terms of wanting to continue to retain and attract talent
column996: and in particular in our institutional parts of our business
column997:
we\u2019ll be continuing to invest in the build-out of our commodities businesses around the world. We\u2019ll continue to be investing in digital and digitization around our consumer banking. I\u2019d say those are probably a few of the more significant investments.

"
column1000: if we were just to focus on the global consumer bank
column1001:
it sounds like you\u2019re turning the corner in terms of revenue in Asia and Lat-Am remains very strong. How should we think about revenue in North America?

"
column1003:
"

I think from a North American \u2013 in particular
column1004: I would say US consumer perspective
column1006: while John spoke to some of the positive attributes
column1007:
I think that needs to be balanced with some of the realities of the low interest rate environment.

I think that as others have forecasted and I think that we see is a slowing in terms of the mortgage refinance boom and the economics that have been associated with that. I think those are two reasonable headwinds that we\u2019re going to have to overcome in 2013 in North America consumer.

Andrew Marquardt - Evercore Partners

Outside of mortgage
column1008:
can the cards business \u2013 should we think about that actually growing this year or still needed?

Mike Corbat

I think we\u2019ve done a lot of work. We\u2019ve made fresh and we\u2019ve stabilized the portfolio. We\u2019ve got to get growth back into it and that\u2019s going to be a focus.

Andrew Marquardt - Evercore Partners

And then just lastly
column1009: as you\u2019re going through your ongoing business reviews and work on operational efficiencies
column1010: have you had a chance to get a sense of longer term
column1011:
the all-in earnings power of the franchise? Will you also be updating us on your views on that longer term?

I guess historically you guys have talked about it an ROA 125
column1012:
150. Is that still applicable or should we wait for an update?

Mike Corbat

I think \u2013 addressing those questions in reverse order \u2013 I think that the ROA 125 to 150 in this environment is not a practical goal to set out there in the short term. So we\u2019ll be resetting that.

I think we\u2019ll be coming out over the next coming months
column1014:
with some things that we\u2019re going to be measured against and we\u2019ll try and lay that out and show you best we can the path for the company going forward.

Operator

And you have no further questions. Do you have any closing remarks?

Susan Kendall

Hi
column1019: for joining us today. If you have any follow-up questions
column1020:
please call the investor relations team here. Thanks.

column1:
{"Citigroup's CEO Discusses Q1 2013 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Citigroup (NYSE:C)

"
column18:
"

Matt Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column19:
"

Erika Penala - Bank of America Merrill Lynch

"
column25:
"

Hello and welcome to Citi\u2019s first quarter 2013 earnings review with Chief Executive Officer Mike Corbat and Chief Financial Officer John Gerspach. Today\u2019s call will be hosted by Susan Kendall
column27:
"

We ask that you please hold all questions until the completion of the formal remarks
column28: at which time you will be given instructions for the question-and-answer session. Also
column30: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column36: operator. Good morning and thank you all for joining us. On our call today
column39: will speak first. Then John Gerspach
column41: will take you through the earnings presentation
column42: which is available for download on our website
column43: citigroup.com. Afterwards
column44:
we\u2019ll be happy to take questions.

"
column45:
"

Before we get started
column46: I would like to remind you that today\u2019s presentation may contain forward-looking statements which are based on management\u2019s current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results in capital and other financial condition may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors
column47: including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today and those included in our SEC filings
column48: including
column49: without limitation
column50:
the Risk Factors section of our 2011 Form 10-K.

"
column52:
let me turn it over to Mike.

"
column55: Susan.  Good morning everyone.  This morning we reported earnings of $3.8 billion for the first quarter of 2013.  Excluding CVA and DVA
column57:
or $1.29 per share.

"
column58:
"

During the quarter
column59: we benefited from seasonally strong results in our markets businesses
column60: sustained momentum in investment banking
column61: and continued year over year growth in loans and deposits in Citicorp
column62:
in a more favorable credit environment.

"
column63:
"

As I\u2019ve said
column64: achieving consistent high quality earnings is one of my top priorities
column65: and these first quarter results are encouraging.  However
column66: although this was a good start for 2013
column67: the environment remains challenging
column68:
and we\u2019re sure to be tested as we go through the year ahead.

"
column69:
"

In addition to our performance across business lines
column70: there were several other areas that I\u2019d want to point out.  First
column71: our capital strength again improved during the quarter with the tier one common ratio increasing to an estimated 9.3% on a Basel III basis
column72:
and we now expect the ratio to reach at least 10% by the end of this year.

"
column73:
"

After a very thorough process
column74: we were pleased that our regulators did not object to the capital plan we submitted
column75: and although the requested returns were modest
column76: the permission to do so
column77: which was based on both quantitative and qualitative analysis
column78: is meaningful.  As I said on my first earnings call
column79:
it\u2019s critical that Citi be viewed as an indisputably strong and stable institution and we made progress toward that goal during the first quarter.

"
column80:
"

Next
column81: as I\u2019ve highlighted
column82: we have two areas of intense focus for our company: to reduce the drag on earnings caused by Citi Holdings
column83: and to utilize our deferred tax assets.  We made progress on both fronts.  We reduced our assets in Citi Holdings by $7 billion.  Holdings assets now total just under $150 billion
column84:
or 8% of our balance sheet.

"
column85:
"

And more importantly
column86: the loss in holdings was reduced to less than $800 million
column87: driven by improvement in credit costs
column88: including a $375 million reserve release related to North American mortgages.  And we began utilizing reserves as the mortgage portfolio continues to shrink
column89: credit performance continues to improve
column90: and we become more comfortable that the housing recovery is sustainable.  As a result
column91:
we will continue to analyze this portfolio and adjust our reserve levels accordingly.

"
column92:
"

We also did consume a small amount of our DTA during the first quarter. $700 million of DTA was utilized
column93:
and we\u2019re focused on generating sustainable U.S. taxable earnings which are the primary driver of DTA consumption.

"
column94:
"

Lastly
column95: I said on my first earnings presentation that I would soon announce the metrics by which you can measure our progress.  Last month I presented three targets we aim to reach by the end of 2015.  First is achieving an efficiency ratio in Citicorp in the mid-50% range.  Second
column96: we want to generate a return on Citigroup\u2019s tangible common equity of over 10%
column97:
and third is reaching a return on Citigroup\u2019s assets of between 90 and 110 basis points in a risk-balanced manner.

"
column98:
"

These goals will not be easily reached on a full year basis
column99: but they\u2019re the right ones for our company
column100: given the environment.  And as I\u2019ve said
column101: you are what you measure
column102:
and we will hold ourselves accountable.

"
column103:
"

We\u2019re executing the repositioning plan we announced in December
column104: but as I\u2019ve said
column105: driving efficiency needs to be business as usual
column106:
and we\u2019re working hard to ingrain that into the organization.

"
column107:
"

To that end
column108: as you may have heard last week
column109:
we\u2019ll remove a layer of management in our institutional clients group so that our six principal lines of business will report directly to Jamie Forese. This simplification preserves the businesses which are core to our unparalleled global network and will lead to better integration in service of our institutional clients.

"
column110:
"

Looking ahead
column111: I believe the environment is going to remain challenging.  Europe\u2019s issues
column112: as the situation in Cypress shows
column113: still have the potential to rattle the markets and impact investor confidence.  At best
column114: the Euro Zone is in a period of austerity instead of growth
column115: and the ongoing low rate environment
column116: new regulation
column117:
and cost of putting certain legacy issues behind us will continue to put pressure on our earnings.

"
column118:
"

But I am confident we\u2019re on the right course
column119: and I look forward to sharing our progress with you in the coming quarters.  Now John will go over the slides
column120:
and then we\u2019d be happy to answer any of your questions. John?

"
column121:
"

John Gerspach

"
column122:
"

Thank you
column123: Mike
column124: and good morning everyone.  To start
column125: I\u2019d like to highlight some significant items affecting our results this quarter.  First
column126: CVA and DVA were negative $319 million pretax
column127: and $198 million after tax
column128: in the first quarter
column129: for a negative impact on EPS of $0.06.  For comparison purposes
column130: in the first quarter of 2012 CVA and DVA were negative $1.3 billion pretax
column131: or $800 million after tax
column132:
for a negative impact of $0.27 per share.

"
column133:
"

In addition
column134: in the first quarter of 2012
column135: we recorded a pretax gain of roughly $475 million related to the sale of minority investments
column136: which had a positive impact on EPS of $0.10 per share in that quarter.  Adjusting for CVA/DVA
column137: we earned $4 billion in the first quarter of 2013
column138: or $1.29 per share
column139:
as compared to $1.11 per share on an adjusted basis in the first quarter of 2012.

"
column140:
"

Throughout today\u2019s earnings presentation
column141: I will be discussing our results excluding CVA/DVA
column142:
and gains or losses on the sale of minority investments to provide comparability to prior periods.

"
column143:
"

In addition
column144: as shown on slide four
column145: there are a few other significant items which are included in our results.  First
column146: operating expenses in the first quarter included legal and related costs of over $700 million
column147:
compared to nearly $1.3 billion last quarter and $545 million in the prior year.

"
column148:
"

Legal and related costs in Citicorp were down significantly in the first quarter
column149: to $66 million.  However
column150: Citi Holdings\u2019 legal expenses increased to over $600 million
column151: primarily reflecting higher legacy legal expenses in the special asset pool.  Legal and related costs will likely continue to be elevated
column152: and volatile
column153:
as we continue to put our legacy issues behind us.

"
column154:
"

Second
column155: repositioning costs were $148 million in the first quarter
column156: compared to $1 billion in the fourth quarter of 2012 and $66 million in the first quarter of last year.  Given the higher than normal repositioning costs in the fourth quarter
column157:
today I\u2019ll be discussing our results excluding the charges in that quarter to provide comparability.

"
column158:
"

And finally
column159: the loan loss reserve release in the first quarter was $652 million
column160: including a release of roughly $375 million related to the North America mortgage portfolio in Citi Holdings.  In total
column161: the net reserve release was $86 million in the prior quarter
column162:
and nearly $1.2 billion in the first quarter of last year.

"
column163:
"

On slide five
column164: we show total Citigroup results for the quarter.  Revenues of $20.8 billion grew 3% from last year
column165: while operating expenses of $12.4 billion increased 1%
column166:
driven by the higher legal and related costs in Citi Holdings.

"
column167:
"

Excluding legal and related costs and repositioning charges
column168: core operating expenses were $11.5 billion in the first quarter
column169: down slightly from the prior year.  Looking forward
column170:
core operating expenses should decline as we begin to see the benefits of the repositioning actions announced last December.

"
column171:
"

Credit costs of $2.5 billion declined 16% versus last year. Net credit losses of $3 billion were down 25%. However
column172: the loan loss reserve release also declined by nearly half
column173:
to $652 million.

"
column174:
"

We earned $4 billion of net income in the first quarter
column175: or $1.29 per share
column176: up from $1.11 per share last year on a comparable basis
column177: driven by revenue growth and lower net credit losses
column178:
partially offset by the increase in legal and related expenses and a lower net loan loss reserve release.

"
column179:
"

Our effective tax rate was also higher in the first quarter
column180: at 29% versus 27% last year.  We expect our full year tax rate to be in the range of 30% in 2013
column181:
as a result of both higher expected earnings in North America as well as a higher tax rate on international operations.

"
column182:
"

The increased rate on earnings outside North America is due to a change in our assertion that earnings in certain entities would be permanently reinvested outside the U.S. As we have built up capital in these entities that is adequate to support future investments
column183:
we now believe that current and future earnings in these entities could be repatriated at some point.

"
column184:
"

Citigroup end of period loans were flat year over year at $646 billion in the first quarter
column185:
as growth in Citicorp was offset by the [line] down of Citi Holdings. And deposits grew 3% to $934 billion.

"
column186:
"

On slide six
column187: we show the split between Citicorp and Citi Holdings.  Citicorp generated first quarter revenues of $19.9 billion
column188: and net income of $4.8 billion.  Year over year
column189: revenues grew 2% and expenses declined by 2%
column190:
driven by lower legal and related expenses in Citicorp.

"
column191:
"

Credit costs increased modestly year over year
column192: as a decline in net credit losses was more than offset by lower reserve releases.  And we continue to grow loans year over year in each core business.  Total Citicorp loans grew 5%
column193:
with consumer loans up 1% and corporate loans up 9%.

"
column194:
"

Citi Holdings had revenues of $910 million
column195: and a net loss of $788 million
column196: a significant improvement from prior periods
column197: driven by lower credit costs.  Citi Holdings ended the quarter with $149 billion of assets
column198: down $60 billion
column199: or 29%
column200: year over year.  At quarter end
column201:
Citi Holdings accounted for just under 8% of total Citigroup assets.

"
column202:
"

Turning now to Citicorp
column203: on slide seven we show Citicorp\u2019s pretax earnings by business
column204: excluding the impact of loan loss reserves
column205: on a trailing 12-month basis.  Through the first quarter
column206: pretax earnings grew to $21 billion
column207: an increase of nearly 30% over the prior year 12 months
column208:
driven by consumer banking and securities and banking.

"
column209:
"

Slide eight shows the results for North America consumer banking. Total revenues of $5.1 billion in the first quarter were down 1% year over year. In retail banking
column210: revenues were down 3%
column211:
as loan and deposit growth was more than offset by spread compression in this low rate environment.

"
column212:
"

Cards revenues
column213: on the other hand
column214: were flat versus last year
column215: as lower average loan balances were largely offset by an improvement in net interest spreads
column216:
as we benefited from both an improvement in yields as well as lower funding costs.

"
column217:
"

Sequentially
column218: total revenues declined 4%
column219: on lower mortgage gain on sale margins as well as seasonally lower cards revenues.  Total operating expenses of $2.4 billion were up 4% year over year
column220: reflecting higher volume-related costs and repositioning charges
column221:
partially offset by efficiency savings.

"
column222:
"

On a sequential basis
column223: expenses declined on lower legal and related costs.  Credit costs of roughly $900 million dollars increased 12% year over year.  Net credit losses declined by 23% to $1.3 billion
column224: driven by an improvement in cards.  However
column225: the net loan loss reserve release was significantly lower at $370 million this quarter.  Earnings before tax
column226: excluding the impact of loan loss reserves
column227:
increased by nearly 20% to $1.4 billion.

"
column228:
"

Overall
column229: we continue to see progress in our North America consumer franchise.  Average deposits continue to grow
column230: up 10% year over year
column231: including 17% growth in checking account balances.  In branded cards
column232: accounts also grew
column233: up 3% from last year.  And
column234: for both card portfolios
column235:
we saw continued expansion in net interest spreads.

"
column236:
"

On slide nine
column237: we show results for international consumer banking in constant dollars.  On this basis
column238: both revenues and expenses grew 3% year over year.  In Latin America
column239: revenues grew 6% and expenses were up 7% from last year
column240: as spread compressions slowed revenue growth while volumes remained strong.  In Asia
column241: revenues were down slightly versus last year
column242: and expenses were flat.  And in EMEA
column243: revenues grew 2%
column244:
with a 2% decline in expenses.

"
column245:
"

While international consumer revenues continued to reflect spread compression in certain markets
column246: as well as the impact of regulatory changes
column247: particularly in Asia
column248: most underlying drivers showed sustained momentum in the first quarter.  Total average loans grew 4% from last year.  Card purchase sales were up 7%
column249:
and investment sales grew 24% year over year.

"
column250:
"

Based on this continued volume growth
column251: as well as the expected efficiency savings
column252: we currently believe both Latin America and Asia will return to positive operating leverage on a full year basis in 2013.  Credit costs of $829 million in the first quarter were up 6% from last year
column253:
on higher net credit losses due mostly to loan growth and portfolio seasoning.

"
column254:
"

Slide ten shows our international consumer credit trends in more detail. Credit quality in our international consumer portfolio remained strong in the first quarter
column255: with stable to improving credit trends on a sequential basis across each region.  In Asia
column256: the NCL rate returned to below 1%
column257: with 90-plus day delinquencies at around 50 basis points.  And
column258: in Latin America
column259:
the NCL rate was fairly stable at 4.6%. We continue to believe that the NCL rate in Latin America should normalize around 4.5% by the second half of 2013.

"
column260:
"

Slide 11 shows our securities and banking business. Revenues of $7.3 billion grew 8% from last year
column261: and 50% from the prior quarter.  Investment banking revenues of $1.1 billion were up 22% from the prior year
column262: with higher revenues in all major products.  Revenues increased 6% sequentially
column263:
and overall investment banking wallet share continued to improve in the quarter.

"
column264:
"

Equity market revenues of $826 million were down 10% from last year
column265: due in part to the impact of lower volatility on derivatives revenues
column266: and increased 78% from the fourth quarter
column267:
on higher cash equity volumes and improved derivatives performance.

"
column268:
"

Fixed income market revenues of $4.6 billion declined 3% from last year as rates and currencies revenues were down from a very strong prior year period
column269: partially offset by growth in securitized products.  Sequentially
column270:
fixed income revenues were up 69% on improved results across all products.

"
column271:
"

Lending revenues
column272: excluding the impact of gains and losses on hedges related to accrual loans
column273: were $333 million in the first quarter
column274: down 7% from last year
column275:
primarily related to loan sale activity and down 12% sequentially on lower average loans and a slight decline in spreads.

"
column276:
"

Total operating expenses of $3.6 billion were down 4% from last year
column277: and up 4% sequentially
column278: reflecting higher incentive compensation.  Net income of $2.5 billion grew 17% year over year
column279:
and more than doubled versus the prior quarter.

"
column281: on slide 12
column282: revenues of $2.6 billion were down 4% from last year on a reported basis and down 2% in constant dollars.  Treasury and trade solutions was down 3% in constant dollars
column283: as loan and deposit growth was more than offset by the impact of spread compression globally. And
column284: securities and fund services revenues grew 2% in constant dollars
column285:
as higher settlement volumes and fees more than offset lower spreads.

"
column286:
"

While spread compression dampened revenues this quarter
column287: the volume drivers for transaction services continued to show momentum.  Average trade loans grew 20% year over year
column288: average deposits were up 10%
column289: assets under custody grew by 8%
column290: and SFS settlement volumes grew 5%.  Expenses of $1.4 billion were up 3% from last year on a reported basis
column291: and up 4% in constant dollars
column292: mainly on higher volumes
column293:
and down 5% sequentially due in part to lower legal and related costs.

"
column294:
"

While spread compression is likely to continue to impact revenues in the near term
column295:
we believe we can achieve revenue growth and a return to positive operating leverage on a full year basis in 2013.

"
column296:
"

Slide 13 shows the results for corporate other. Revenues were flat versus the prior year
column297: while expenses of $568 million declined 28% on lower legal and related expenses.  Assets of $280 billion included approximately $83 billion of cash and cash equivalents
column298:
and $143 billion of liquid available for sale securities.

"
column299:
"

Slide 14 shows Citi Holdings assets. We ended the quarter with assets of $149 billion in Citi Holdings
column300: or roughly 8% of total Citigroup assets.  The $7 billion reduction in the first quarter reflected $2 billion of asset sales
column301: $4 billion of net paydowns
column302:
and roughly $1 billion of cost of credit.

"
column303:
"

As you can see on the slide
column304: other assets in local consumer lending increased during the quarter
column305: by nearly $3 billion.  These are primarily loans held for sale
column306:
where we were in the process of a transaction but had not yet closed as of quarter end.

"
column307:
"

On slide 15
column308: we show Citi Holdings financial results for the quarter.  Total revenues of $910 million were up 15% year over year as higher revenues in the special asset pool were partially offset by a decline in local consumer lending
column309:
driven by declining loan balances.

"
column310:
"

Citi Holdings expenses increased 23% year over year
column311: to $1.5 billion
column312: driven by higher legal and related costs in the special asset pool.  Excluding these higher legal costs
column313:
core operating expenses declined 18% year over year to roughly $860 million. This decline reflects declining assets as well as the expiration of certain transition services agreements related to prior sales activity.

"
column314:
"

Credit costs declined 44% year over year to roughly $750 million. Net credit losses declined significantly to $930 million
column315: and the net loan loss reserve release was over $350 million
column316:
including a release of roughly $375 million related to North America mortgages.

"
column317:
"

Looking at the past five quarters of Citi Holdings results on slide 16
column318: rep and warranty reserve bills and legal and related costs continued to weigh on Citi Holdings.  On an operating basis
column319: however
column320: excluding these items and repositioning
column321:
we maintained a modest positive operating margin again in the first quarter.

"
column322:
"

Credit trends were particularly favorable
column323: with North America mortgage NCLs declining to $630 million
column324: roughly 60% of which were offset by reserve releases.  We ended the quarter with $7.5 billion of loan loss reserves allocated to North America mortgage loans in Citi Holdings
column325:
or 36 months of coverage.

"
column326:
"

On slide 17
column327: we show mortgage loan and adjusted net credit loss trends over the past two years.  Since the first quarter of 2011
column328: we have reduced the North America mortgage loans in Citi Holdings by 28%
column329: driven by $18 billion of paydowns
column330: $8 billion of asset sales
column331:
and $8 billion of net losses.

"
column332:
"

In the first quarter
column333: we sold $2.8 billion of loans
column334: including $1 billion of delinquent mortgages and $1.8 billion of current loans.  A significant portion of the current loans were reperforming mortgages
column335:
where we had previously modified the loan and it subsequently remained current.

"
column336:
"

While we are of course encouraged by the sale of these reperforming mortgages in the quarter
column337: it is still unclear whether buyers will have an appetite for additional sales of this nature
column338:
and we will continue to test the market.

"
column339:
"

We have also significantly reduced the quarterly net credit losses in the portfolio
column340: down 50% since the first quarter of 2011
column341: to $630 million
column342: even while roughly $76 million of losses were accelerated into the recent quarter as a result of the continued actions we are taking to fulfill our commitments under the National Mortgage Settlement
column343:
or NMS.

"
column344:
"

We expect to fulfill our obligations under NMS in the second quarter. However
column345: we will continue to modify loans under the OCC Foreclosure Review Settlement announced last quarter
column346:
which we estimate will pull forward $30-40 million of losses into each quarter for the remainder of 2013.

"
column347:
"

On slide 18
column348: we show delinquency trends
column349: including both residential first mortgages and home equity loans.  30-plus day delinquencies improved by 19% sequentially to $6.1 billion
column350: with improvement in both portfolios.  Residential first mortgage delinquencies fell 20% sequentially to $4.8 billion
column351: driven by asset sales as well as fewer new entries into the early buckets.  And
column352:
home equity delinquencies also improved by 15% to $1.2 billion.

"
column353:
"

On slide 19
column354: we show our net interest revenue and margin trends.  Net interest revenue was roughly flat year over year
column355: at $11.9 billion
column356:
and declined 2% sequentially due to a lower day count. Our net interest margin increased by 1 basis point to 294 basis points in the first quarter.

"
column357:
"

On a full year basis
column358: we believe we should be able to maintain our net interest margin above the 288 basis points we achieved last year.  However
column359: there will be quarterly fluctuations and in particular
column360:
we expect the net interest margin to decline sequentially in the second quarter by a few basis points.

"
column361:
"

On slide 20
column362: we show our key capital metrics through the first quarter.  Under Basel III
column363: our estimated tier one common ratio increased to 9.3% versus 8.7% last quarter.  And
column364: our Basel I tier one common ratio was 11.8%
column365: including the impact of the market risk rules which became effective at the beginning of the quarter
column366:
up from 11.1% on a comparable basis last quarter.

"
column367:
"

In summary
column368: our results for the first quarter reflected a continued challenging operating environment
column369: with spread compression globally and elevated legal and related cost remaining as headwinds.  Against this backdrop
column370:
we continue to grow our core business while beginning to reduce the earning drag from Citi Holdings.

"
column371:
"

In securities and banking
column372: we again demonstrated our ability to grow revenues while keeping expense discipline.  And
column373: in consumer banking and transaction services
column374:
we continued to grow loans and deposits year over year while maintaining a high quality credit portfolio.

"
column375:
"

In Citi Holdings
column376: assets are now less than $150 billion
column377: and the net loss was less than $800 million this quarter
column378: even as we continue to face elevated legal and related costs.  And finally
column379: our liquidity and capital positions remained strong
column380:
with estimated aggregate liquidity resources in excess of $370 billion and an estimated Basel III tier one common ratio of 9.3% at quarter end.

"
column381:
"

Looking forward
column382: we remain confident in our ability to grow volumes to compensate for the impact of the low interest rate environment
column383:
and we remain on track to achieve the $900 million of efficiency savings expected this year from our previously announced repositioning actions.

"
column384:
"

With that
column385:
Mike and I are happy to take any questions.

John Gerspach

column730:
"

By providing the tax
column731: the U.S. tax
column732: we\u2019ve already lowered the DTA.  Let\u2019s just work through an example.  If I\u2019ve got earnings in a legal entity that has a 12.5% tax rate
column733: like in Ireland
column734: and I have no intention of repatriating those earnings
column735: they\u2019re going to be permanently reinvested outside
column736:
the only tax expense that would hit the P&L would be the 12.5% local tax.

"
column737:
"

Now what we\u2019re saying is current and future earnings out of that legal entity could be repatriated. They could be dividended back into the States at some point in time
column738: which means now that you would need to provide the differential between the 35% statutory U.S. rate and the 12.5% local rate.  So that 22.5% incremental tax that we\u2019re providing is both an income tax expense that is impacting the P&L.  You see it reflected in our effective tax rate.  And because it\u2019s a U.S. tax provision
column739:
it serves to reduce the DTA.

Matt O\u2019Connor - Deutsche Bank

you mentioned about Asia and the impact that Korea is having on that business. What percentage is Korea as a percentage of the loan balances in your Asia portfolio?

"
column1103: I can\u2019t give you the exact percentage
column1104: but you\u2019ll get a glimpse of that.  We\u2019ve got a page in the back of the book
column1106: that will actually give you the amount of loans that we have in key countries.  And so in the consumer loans
column1107:
Korea comprises about $24 billion of our consumer loan book.

"
column1109:
"

Your next question will come from the line of Andrew Marquardt with Evercore Partners

"
column1111:
"

I had a question on expenses. It was helpful in terms of talking about positive operating leverage expected this year for Latin America
column1113:
in consumer and [GTS]. How should we think about North America consumer? What do we need to see happen before we get to see positive operating leverage there?

"
column1115:
"

I\u2019d say we\u2019ve got to get more revenue production out of the U.S. card businesses.

"
column1117:
"

And any idea in terms of the timing or higher rates required as well?

"
column1119:
"

I think it\u2019s a business that we\u2019re in the process of repositioning. I think that you take a look at the U.S. consumer
column1120: there\u2019s a decent amount of deleveraging still underway.  I certainly don\u2019t see any releveraging necessarily on the part of the U.S. consumer
column1121: other than refinancing mortgage loans and perhaps taking out more student lending.  Maybe auto loans a little bit.  We\u2019re not really in that business.  But from our point of view
column1122: getting more growth in the revolving balances
column1123:
that\u2019s going to be a challenge over the course of the next couple of quarters.

"
column1125:
"

And in terms of the expense savings that you\u2019ve previously laid out
column1126: and you were targeting 900 for this year.  How much of that
column1128:
has been realized in the first quarter?

"
column1130:
"

There\u2019s just a very small amount of that that\u2019s actually been realized in the first quarter. A lot of the people that have been notified to date
column1132:
and there\u2019s a 60-day notice period. And so those are savings that will accrue more towards the latter half of the year.

"
column1134:
"

And then in terms of just the backdrop
column1135: as Mike had laid out early on
column1136: in terms of things still challenging and perhaps a little bit tougher
column1137: are there more levers to pull beyond the [one one] savings that you\u2019ve already laid out
column1138:
if indeed things are worse? How should we think about that?

"
column1140:
"

We\u2019re focused on really trying to manage expenses in terms of BAU
column1141: and trying to get more efficiencies into the business.  We recently announced that we\u2019ve brought somebody in externally to help us do that.  The businesses are going to be focused on that.  So we\u2019re mindful of the environment
column1142: clearly with an eye towards the expense side of things
column1143:
but today we\u2019re not going to talk about any big levers.

"
column1145:
"

And then a couple of [ticky tack] questions. In the corporate other line
column1149: you had mentioned how linked quarter
column1150:
revenue improvement was less negative this quarter versus last. I guess partly driven by hedging activities. What was that? And how should we think about that going forward?

"
column1152:
"

Hedging activities is something that\u2019s very difficult to predict. I think you\u2019ll see that we end up with some fluctuation in that line all the time
column1153:
and this is where we have some macro hedges against elements of the business. But it\u2019s very difficult to predict.

"
column1155:
"

Is that positive meaningfully this quarter?

"
column1157:
"

I don\u2019t have a huge positive feeling in my head about it. I just don\u2019t have the information in front of me. I\u2019m sorry.

"
column1159:
"

And then the last is just on liquidity continues to be pretty strong. Do you have your actual LCR ratio handy? I think last quarter maybe it was around 118?

"
column1162: I think we actually ended last quarter at 122.  I think we estimated it at 118 at the point in time we did the call
column1163: and then when the calculation was finalized
column1164: it actually increased.  And we\u2019re in the process still of doing those calculations
column1165:
so I don\u2019t have a comparable figure in front of me at this point in time.

"
column1167:
"

And do you have a target for that? Will that drift lower as you deploy excess liquidity? Since you\u2019re already well above the required.

"
column1169:
"

What we\u2019ve said is that certainly from where it was
column1171: we said that it could drift somewhat lower.  But again
column1172: this is another one of these ratios where the minimum requirement is 100%.  And so we need to maintain some buffer above that 100%
column1173:
just in order to be sure that you\u2019re not going to pierce it at some point in time. We haven\u2019t formalized exactly where we want to set that buffer.

"
column1175:
"

There are no further questions at this time.

"
column1177:
"

Thank you all for joining us today. If you have any other questions
column1179:
"

So our reproduction policy is as follows: You may quote up to 400 words of any transcript on the condition that you attribute the transcript to Seeking Alpha and either link to the original transcript or to www.SeekingAlpha.com.
