column1:
{"Citigroup Inc (C) CEO Discusses Q2 2013 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Citigroup (NYSE:C)

"
column19:
"

Erika Penala - Bank of America Merrill Lynch

"
column21:
"

Matt Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column26: and welcome to Citi\u2019s second quarter 2013 earnings review with Chief Executive Officer Mike Corbat and Chief Financial Officer John Gerspach. Today\u2019s call will be hosted by Susan Kendall
column28:
"

We ask that you please hold all questions until the completion of the formal remarks
column29: at which time you will be given instructions for the question-and-answer session. Also
column30: as a reminder
column31: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column38: and thank you all for joining us. On our call today
column41: will speak first. Then John Gerspach
column42: our CFO
column43: will take you through the earnings presentation
column44: which is available for download on our website
column45: citigroup.com. Afterwards
column46:
we\u2019ll be happy to take questions.

"
column47:
"

Before we get started
column48: I would like to remind you that today\u2019s presentation may contain forward-looking statements
column49: which are based on management\u2019s current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results in capital and other financial condition may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors
column50: including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today and those included in our SEC filings
column52: without limitation
column53:
the Risk Factors section of our 2012 Form 10-K.

"
column55:
let me turn it over to Mike.

"
column57:
"

Thank you
column58: Susan
column59: and good morning everyone. Earlier today
column60:
we reported earnings of $4.2 billion for the second quarter of 2013. Excluding CVA and DVA net income was $3.9 billion or $1.25 per share.

"
column61:
"

Overall
column62: we had strong
column63: high-quality earnings
column64: which were well-balanced across our products and geographies. As you know
column65:
generating such results consistently is one of my top priorities.

"
column66:
"

Although volatility did increase in June
column67: we had good performance across our securities and banking businesses during the quarter. Our transaction service business continues to be impacted by spread compression
column68: as does our global consumer bank. However
column69: we did grow our loans in our core businesses in a disciplined manner
column70: particularly in the emerging markets
column71:
and we did so while maintaining a high-quality portfolio.

"
column72:
"

Our capital position strengthened
column73: and our tier one common ratio increased to an estimated 10% on a Basel III basis
column74: and we believe our firm is well-positioned for the regulatory requirements regarding capital and leverage ratios
column75:
although they\u2019ve not yet been finalized.

"
column76:
"

We continue to make progress in two critical areas: Reducing the drag on earnings caused by Citi Holdings
column77: and the utilization of our deferred tax asset. We reduced our assets in City Holdings by $18 billion
column78: and holdings assets now total just under $131 billion
column79:
and are less than 7% of our GAAP balance sheet.

"
column80:
"

This was the largest percentage reduction in assets since 2010
column81: and it was driven not only by Morgan Stanley\u2019s purchase of the remaining 35% stake of the MSSB joint venture
column82: but also by continued opportunistic sales
column83: including over $3 billion of U.S. mortgages
column84:
bringing the total year to date to nearly $6 billion.

"
column85:
"

More significantly
column86: the loss in holdings was reduced to less than $600 million for the quarter. In fact
column87: holdings actually made a small profit when you exclude the impact of legal
column88: rep
column89: and warranty costs. Associated legal costs will likely remain elevated in the near term
column90:
but we took another significant step to get past legacy issues with our rep and warranty agreement with Fannie Mae.

"
column91:
"

Regarding DTA
column92: we again consumed a modest amount during the second quarter; $600 million of DTA was utilized
column93:
bringing the total to $1.3 billion for the first half of the year. We also made good progress executing the repositioning plans we announced at the end of last year.

"
column94:
"

Among other actions
column95: just after the end of the quarter
column96: we closed the sale of our consumer businesses in Turkey and Romania
column97:
and reached an agreement to sell our consumer business in Uruguay.

"
column98:
"

We\u2019re on track to realize about $900 million of expense savings this year
column99: and $1.2 billion next year
column100: due to these and our other repositioning actions. Looking to the second half of the year
column101: it\u2019s unclear whether the market volatility that emerged in the second quarter will continue
column102:
and if so to what degree.

"
column103:
"

Low short term rates continue to be a headwind against our deposit taking and accrual businesses such as consumer banking and transaction services
column104: and in the U.S.
column105: although the housing market is gaining strength
column106:
the lower volume of mortgage refinancing will impact our consumer business. We\u2019re already taking steps to make sure the mortgage business is sized correctly.

"
column107:
"

While still outpacing developed markets
column108: emerging market growth slowed
column109: but we remain very disciplined about to whom we\u2019ll offer credit in light of our targeted segments. As the Brazil credit card transaction indicates
column110: we\u2019ve managed our risk profile carefully in every country we do business
column111: and our target clients are stable
column112:
whether they be multinational corporates or high credit quality consumers.

"
column113:
"

John Gerspach will now go through the deck
column114: and then we\u2019ll be happy to take your questions. So with that
column115: over to you
column116:
John.

"
column117:
"

John Gerspach

"
column118:
"

Thanks
column119: Mike
column120: and good morning everyone. To start
column121: I\u2019d like to highlight some significant items affecting our results this quarter. First
column122: CVA and DVA were positive $477 million pretax
column123: and $293 million after tax in the second quarter
column124:
for a positive impact on EPS of $0.09.

"
column125:
"

For comparison purposes
column126: in the second quarter of 2012
column127: CVA and DVA were positive $219 million pretax
column128: or $140 million after tax
column129: for a positive impact of $0.05 per share. In addition
column130: in the second quarter of 2012
column131: we recorded a pretax loss of $424 million related to the sale of minority investments
column132:
which had a negative impact on EPS of $0.09 per share in that quarter.

"
column133:
"

Adjusting for these items
column134: we earned $3.9 billion in the second quarter of 2013
column135: or $1.25 per share
column136: as compared to $1 per share on an adjusted basis in the second quarter of 2012. Throughout today\u2019s earnings presentation
column137: I will be discussing our results excluding CVA and DVA
column138:
and gains or losses on the sale of minority investments to provide comparability to prior periods.

"
column139:
"

In addition
column140: as we show on slide four
column141: there are a few other items which are included in our results. First
column142: operating expenses in the second quarter included legal and related costs of over $800 million
column143: compared to roughly $700 million last quarter
column144:
and nearly $500 million in the prior year.

"
column145:
"

Legal and related costs at Citicorp were roughly $130 million in the second quarter
column146: mostly in corporate other
column147: while Citi Holdings legal expenses remained elevated
column148: at roughly $700 million
column149:
primarily reflected in the special asset pool.

"
column150:
"

Legal and related costs will likely continue to be elevated and somewhat volatile as we continue to put our legacy issues behind us. Second
column151: repositioning costs were $75 million in the second quarter
column152: compared to $148 million in the first quarter of 2013
column153:
and $186 million in the second quarter of last year.

"
column154:
"

We expect to have some level of repositioning charges each quarter
column155: but we are working to incorporate these actions into the daily management of our business. So
column156: going forward
column157: we would not expect to take large
column158:
episodic charges as we did in the fourth quarter of last year.

"
column159:
"

And finally
column160: the loan loss reserve release in the second quarter was $784 million
column161: including a release of roughly $525 million related to the North America mortgage portfolio in Citi Holdings. The net reserve release was $650 million in the prior quarter
column162:
and $1 billion in the second quarter of last year.

"
column163:
"

On slide five
column164: we show total Citigroup results for the quarter. Revenues of $20 billion grew 8% from last year
column165: driven by securities and banking
column166: while operating expenses of $12.1 billion increased 1%
column167:
reflecting the higher legal and related costs in Citi Holdings.

"
column168:
"

Credit costs of $2 billion declined 25% year over year. Net credit losses of $2.6 billion were down 25%
column169: and
column170: as I noted earlier
column171: the loan loss reserve release was also lower versus last year. We earned $3.9 billion of net income in the second quarter
column172: or $1.25 per share
column173: up from $1 per share last year on a comparable basis
column174: driven by revenue growth and lower net credit losses
column175:
partially offset by higher legal and related expenses and a lower net loan loss reserve release.

"
column176:
"

Our effective tax rate was also higher in the second quarter
column177: at 33% versus 20% last year
column178: reflecting higher earnings in North America
column179: a higher effective tax rate on international operations due to the previously disclosed change in our assertion surrounding the permanent reinvestment of earnings in certain international entities
column180:
and the resolution of certain tax issues in the second quarter. We expect our effective tax rate for the remainder of the year to be approximately 30%.

"
column181:
"

Citigroup end of period loans declined 1% year over year
column182: to $644 billion in the second quarter
column183:
as growth in Citicorp was more than offset by the wind down of Citi Holdings. And deposits grew 3% to $938 billion.

"
column184:
"

Turning to Citigroup expenses on slide six
column185: in addition to the legal and related and the repositioning costs I discussed earlier
column186: in the second quarter we recorded a $60 million charge for the estimated impact of the Fed\u2019s proposed supervisory assessment on large banks. This fee is expected to be retroactive to the beginning of 2012
column187:
so the $60 million charge represents the cumulative impact of six quarters of assessments.

"
column188:
"

Excluding this fee
column189: core operating expenses declined roughly 1% in constant dollars
column190: both year over year and sequentially. Year over year
column191: the expense decline reflects approximately $200 million of repositioning savings
column192:
partially offset by higher performance-based compensation expense.

"
column193:
"

And
column194: sequentially
column195: the expense decline reflects approximately $100 million of incremental repositioning savings
column196: as well as lower performance-based compensation expense compared to the first quarter
column197: partially offset by higher marketing and transaction-related costs. We remain on track to achieve approximately $900 million of repositioning savings
column198: full year 2013
column199:
with a run rate of approximately $1.2 billion beginning in 2014.

"
column200:
"

On slide seven
column201: we show the split between Citicorp and Citi Holdings. Citicorp generated second quarter revenues of $18.9 billion
column202: and net income of $4.5 billion. Year over year
column203: revenues grew 7%
column204: and expenses declined by 2%
column205:
driven by lower legal and related expenses.

"
column206:
"

Credit costs in Citicorp increased modestly year over year
column207: as the decline in net credit losses was more than offset by lower reserve releases. Citicorp loans increased by 4% year over year. Consumer loans grew 1%
column208: as growth in international loans was mostly offset by a decline in North America. And corporate loans were up 7%
column209: including the impact of adding approximately $7 billion of previously unconsolidated assets. Excluding this item
column210:
corporate loans would have increased 4% year over year.

"
column211:
"

Turning to Citi Holdings
column212: revenues were $1.1 billion and the net loss was $579 million in the second quarter
column213: an improvement from prior periods driven by a continued decline in credit costs. Citi Holdings ended the quarter with $131 billion of assets
column214: down $60 billion
column215: or 31%
column216: year over year. At quarter end
column217:
Citi Holdings accounted for just under 7% of total Citigroup assets.

"
column218:
"

Turning now to Citicorp
column219: our growth in the second quarter was broad-based across the region
column220: as shown here on slide eight. In North America
column221: revenues grew 7% year over year to $8.2 billion
column222: driven mostly by improved securities and banking performance
column223: while expenses and net credit losses declined
column224:
offset by a lower reserve release as credit continued to normalize.

"
column225:
"

In Asia
column226: revenues grew 7% to $4 billion
column227: mostly reflecting securities and banking
column228:
although we also grew consumer revenues while reducing expenses.

"
column229:
"

In Latin America
column230: our business is weighted more to consumer
column231: which drove 8% growth in revenues to $3.5 billion. Expenses grew on higher volumes and credit costs were also up year over year
column232: primarily reflecting portfolio growth and seasoning. However
column233:
we still grew earnings in the region.

"
column234:
"

And in EMEA
column235: our business is weighted more to the institutional franchise
column236: which continued to perform well
column237:
driving 8% revenue growth to $3.1 billion.

"
column238:
"

We generated solid revenue growth across each geography
column239: with overall expense discipline and stable to improving credit quality
column240:
resulting in pretax earnings of over $1 billion in each region.

"
column241:
"

Turning to slide nine
column242: we show the composition of Citicorp revenues and pretax earnings by region
column243: before the impact of loan loss reserves. These results also exclude corp other. For the first half of 2013
column244: 43% of Citicorp\u2019s revenues
column245: and nearly half of pretax earnings
column246:
were generated in the emerging markets. The higher relative profitability in the emerging markets reflects a lower cost base as well as the predominantly flow-driven nature of our institutional franchise in these markets.

"
column247:
"

Slide 10 shows the historical trend for Citicorp revenues on a trailing 12-month basis
column248:
with emerging markets contributing over two-thirds of Citicorp\u2019s total revenue growth over the past two years.

"
column249:
"

In the last 12 months
column250: Citicorp generated $32 billion of revenues in emerging markets. Over half of these revenues were generated in the consumer business
column251: where we target a high-quality consumer segment largely based in the major cities. And
column252: the remainder was institutional
column253: predominantly serving our large
column254: multinational clients as they fund their local operations
column255: manage currency needs
column256:
and move payments around the world.

"
column257:
"

Turning to slide 11
column258: we show results for international consumer banking in constant dollars
column259: including the impact of moving our credit card business in Brazil to discontinued operations in each period. On this basis
column260: revenues grew 5% year over year
column261:
while expenses grew 1%.

"
column262:
"

In Latin America
column263: revenues grew 8%
column264: and expenses were up 4% from last year. In Asia
column265: revenues returned to growth
column266: up 2% year over year
column267: while expenses were down 2%. And
column268: in EMEA
column269: revenues grew 2%
column270: with a 1% decline in expenses. While international consumer revenues continue to reflect spread compression in certain markets
column271: as well as the impact of regulatory changes
column272: particularly in Asia
column273:
most underlying drivers showed sustained momentum in the second quarter.

"
column274:
"

Total average loans grew 5% from last year. Card purchase sales were up 9%
column275: and investment sales grew 36% year over year. Both Latin America and Asia returned to positive operating leverage for the first half of 2013
column276:
and we expect to maintain this performance for the rest of the year.

"
column277:
"

Credit costs of $751 million in the second quarter were up 19% from last year
column278: on higher net credit losses due mostly to loan growth and portfolio seasoning. The loan loss reserve build was also higher this quarter
column279: at $123 million
column280: driven by portfolio growth as well as builds for specific credits and our commercial market businesses. Despite higher credit costs
column281:
positive operating leverage drove a 7% increase in earnings before tax to $1.2 billion.

"
column282:
"

Slide 12 shows the results for North America consumer banking. Total revenues of $5.1 billion in the second quarter were down 1% year over year. Retail banking revenues of $1.6 billion declined by 4%
column283: reflecting lower mortgage origination and servicing revenues
column284: as well as continued spread compression
column285: partially offset by a gain of roughly $180 million on the sale of an on-balance sheet mortgage portfolio. This sale of approximately $2.5 billion of conforming loans was opportunistic
column286:
given the favorable market environment earlier in the quarter.

"
column287:
"

Cards revenues of $3.5 billion were flat versus last year
column288: as lower average loan balances were largely offset by an improvement in net interest spreads. On a sequential basis
column289: net interest spreads were up slightly in Citi branded cards
column290: while spreads were lower in retail services
column291:
driven by a higher percentage of deferred interest promotional balances.

"
column292:
"

Total operating expenses of $2.4 billion were down both year over year and sequentially
column293: reflecting lower legal and related costs versus the prior year
column294:
and lower repositioning costs versus last quarter.

"
column295:
"

Credit costs of roughly $850 million increased 19% year over year. Net credit losses declined by 21% to $1.2 billion
column296: driven by an improvement in cards. However
column297: the net loan loss reserve release was significantly lower at $351 million this quarter
column298:
compared to $814 million last year.

"
column299:
"

Overall
column300: while we faced mortgage and spread related headwinds in North America this quarter that are likely to continue
column301: we also saw some progress in our core franchise. Average deposits continued to grow
column302: up 9% year over year
column303: including 16% growth in checking account balances. Commercial market loans were up 17%. Card purchase sales grew year over year in both portfolios
column304: and in branded cards
column305: accounts also continued to grow
column306:
up 3% from last year.

"
column307:
"

Slide 13 shows our global consumer credit trends in more detail. Credit quality in North America continued to improve in the second quarter
column308:
with declining net credit losses and delinquencies.

"
column309:
"

And
column310: in our international portfolios
column311: we also saw stable to improving credit trends on a sequential basis. In Asia
column312: the NCL improvement in the second quarter reflects higher recoveries
column313: but even excluding this benefit
column314: the rate would have remained under 1%
column315:
with 90-plus day delinquencies stable at under 50 basis points.

"
column316:
"

In EMEA
column317: we saw a net credit recovery in the second quarter while delinquencies continued to improve. And
column318: in Latin America
column319: the NCL rate improved to roughly 4%
column320:
while delinquencies were fairly stable. We currently expect the NCL rate in Latin America to remain in the range of 4% for the remainder of 2013.

"
column321:
"

However
column322: the rate could be higher if we incur any material losses on our exposures to home builders in Mexico
column323: which are included in commercial market loans. Our loans outstanding to the top three builders totaled roughly $300 million at the end of the second quarter
column324:
with nearly 100% collateralized.

"
column325:
"

While we currently believe that we are adequately reserved for any potential losses related to the home building industry in Mexico
column326:
we continue to monitor the performance of our clients as well as the value of our collateral.

"
column327:
"

Slide 14 shows our consumer loans by major country. Roughly 80% of our loans are in six markets: North America
column328: which is roughly half of our portfolio
column329: followed by Mexico
column330: Korea
column331: Australia
column332: Singapore
column333:
and Hong Kong.

"
column334:
"

While in certain markets
column335: including North America
column336: Korea
column337: and Australia
column338: loan growth has been hampered by the economic or regulatory environment
column339: in other countries we continue to expand
column340:
reflecting the quality of our franchise and the growing population of high-quality borrowers in these markets.

"
column341:
"

Importantly
column342: we are growing our loans with a disciplined focus on credit quality. In Mexico
column343: while the NCL rate ticked up at the end of 2012
column344: reflecting portfolio seasoning
column345: the loss rate of under 4% remains low on a historical basis
column346: driven by more stringent underwriting criteria and the repositioning of our cards portfolio over the past five years. And
column347: in Singapore and Hong Kong
column348: we have consistently maintained our focus on higher quality borrowers
column349:
resulting in low delinquency and loss rates.

"
column350:
"

Slide 15 shows our securities and banking business. Revenues of $6.4 billion grew 21% from last year
column351: and declined 12% from the prior quarter. Investment banking revenues of $1 billion were up 21% from the prior year
column352: with higher revenues in all major products
column353: and declined 2% sequentially
column354:
driven by lower debt underwriting activity.

"
column355:
"

Overall
column356: investment banking wallet share continued to improve in the first half of the year. Equity market revenues of $942 million were up 68% from last year
column357: reflecting improved derivatives performance as well as higher cash equity volumes. Sequentially
column358: equity market revenues increased 14%
column360:
"

Fixed income market revenues of $3.4 billion increased 18% from last year
column361: with strength across all major products
column362: and were down 27% sequentially from a strong first quarter. Private bank revenues of $645 million grew 9% from last year
column363: with growth across all regions
column364: primarily driven by investment products

column378:
and declined 19% sequentially.

column381: as loan and deposit growth was more than offset by the impact of spread compression globally
column382: and securities and fund services revenues grew 5%
column383:
as higher settlement volumes and fees more than offset lower spreads.

"
column384:

Spread compression continued to dampen revenues this quarter. However
column385: the volume drivers for transaction services showed sustained momentum. Average trade loans grew 16% year over year. Average deposits were up 7%. Assets under custody grew by 10%
column386:
and SFS settlement volumes grew 13%.

column388: driven mainly by higher volumes
column389: partially offset by efficiency savings. While spread compression is likely to impact revenues in the near term

Turning to the leverage ratio
column462: Citigroup\u2019s supplementary leverage ratio
column463: as calculated using the U.S. Basel III NPR
column464: was an estimated 4.9% for the second quarter. Unlike the tier one common ratio
column465: which is a period-end calculation
column466:
the supplementary leverage ratio is the average of the three month end ratios calculated in the quarter.

"
column467:
"

While our average for the three months was 4.9% for the second quarter
column468: this leverage ratio improved sequentially during the period
column469: with an exit rate of just above 5% for the month of June. We are still reviewing the final U.S. Basel III rules
column470:
but do not believe the final rules will have a significant impact on the estimated ratios.

column471:

Our supplementary leverage ratio estimate does not incorporate differences in the definition of leveraged assets as recently proposed by the international Basel committee. As you are all aware
column472: there has been quite a bit of activity and pronouncements relating to the capital requirements of large financial institutions over the past several weeks
column473:
and so our estimates are necessarily subject to our continued review and understanding of these recent developments.

"
column474:
"

In summary
column475: our results for the second quarter reflected a continued challenging operating environment
column478: and elevated legal and related costs remaining as headwinds. However
column480:
we continued to grow our core business while significantly reducing the earnings drag from Citi Holdings.

"
column481:
"

In securities and banking
column482: we had a strong second quarter
column483: even as market conditions became more volatile late in the quarter. In transaction services
column484: we continued to grow loan and deposit volumes to mostly offset the impact of global spread compression. And
column485: in consumer banking
column486: we also grew our loans in many markets year over year
column487:
overcoming spread compression to generate revenue growth and positive operating leverage in every region outside North America.

"
column488:
"

In North America consumer
column489: the environment remains challenging
column490: with a combination of spread compression
column491: consumer deleveraging
column492:
and a slowdown in mortgage refinancing activity expected to continue to put pressure on revenues for the remainder of the year.

"
column493:
"

In the mortgage business
column494: we are beginning to take actions to reduce our expense base with the decline in activity
column495: but we would expect there to be some lag as we continue to fulfill our backlog through the third quarter. We may face additional pressure
column496: if not only volumes but also margins decline further
column497:
as we look to the back half of the year.

"
column498:
"

Turning to Citi Holdings
column499: assets are now roughly 7% of total Citigroup
column500: and the net loss was less than $600 million this quarter
column501: even as we continued to face elevated legacy costs. While legal and related costs are expected to remain elevated in Citi Holdings in the near term
column502: we put a significant piece of our rep and warranty issues behind us with the recently announced Fannie Mae agreement. And finally
column503: our liquidity and capital positions remain strong
column504:
with estimated aggregate liquidity resources in excess of $380 billion and an estimated Basel III tier one common ratio of 10% at quarter end.

"
column505:

Finally
column506: we remain on track to achieve the expense savings from our fourth quarter repositioning actions
column507: even as some of our year over year savings were offset by higher performance related compensation
column508:
given our strong revenues in the first half of the year.

column1164: in terms of the runoff portfolio in North American mortgages
column1165: can you help us think about the pace of the runoff going forward? What\u2019s the appetite been like recently? You\u2019ve talked about that in the past. Any change in terms of
column1171: over the course of the last two quarters
column1172: we\u2019ve been able to sell about $6 billion of those mortgage loans. Roughly
column1173: a little bit shy of $3 billion in the first quarter and then $3.1 billion or so in the second quarter
column1174:
as we took advantage of some favorable market conditions. A large portion of what we were able to sell in the first half of the year were these reperforming loans that I talked about earlier.

"
column1175:
"

And the pricing on those loans is really sensitive to yield. And so with the recent rise in interest rates
column1176:
the market has changed for those reperforming loans. And so I\u2019ll have to reassess to see whether or not we can continue the pace of sale that we\u2019ve got for those types of assets.

"
column1178:
"

And I think as part of that
column1180: the focuses are a couple of things. One is that we want to obviously continue to reduce the size and drag of the portfolio
column1181: but that drag comes from a couple of perspectives. It not only comes from the cost of credit
column1182:
it comes from the operating expenses associated with the portfolio.

"
column1183:
"

And when we can go in particular at the delinquent part of the portfolio
column1184: and continue to sell that part of the mix down
column1185: it allows us to go back and get out a lot of high costs. And so we\u2019re focused in the aggregate
column1189: and so as the market affords opportunities
column1190:
we\u2019re going to continue to try and take advantage of them.

"
column1192:
"

And in terms of accelerating the pace of that
column1193: you previously talked about that the buyer liquidity has been a hurdle
column1194: just given the size of the portfolio that you need to reduce. But then also you\u2019ve brought up how there\u2019s been a difference in lifetime loss estimates more recently. Can you expand on that point a little bit more in terms of what you mean
column1195:
in terms of maybe just the buyer-seller perspective?

"
column1198: when we\u2019ve looked at or thought about some different larger
column1200: there\u2019s at least three components that go into the pricing that comes in. One is what\u2019s the buyer\u2019s cost of money? Second is what are their expectations around loss rates? And the third is
column1202: what\u2019s the capital they need to hold against it
column1203:
and what\u2019s the cost of capital?

"
column1204:
"

I would say in most every instance
column1205: when we see that from a bulk perspective
column1206: the numbers or the math associated with each of those three things
column1208: makes it a sale that\u2019s not worthwhile. So
column1210: we pretty simply look at our own view towards those three things
column1211: and if somebody\u2019s willing to pay us what we think the value of those assets
column1216: we haven\u2019t seen that. If and when that opportunity presents itself
column1217: we\u2019d love to act on it. But we haven\u2019t seen that to date
column1218:
and we\u2019re not running the portfolio with the belief that in the near term that\u2019s going to be out there.

"
column1221: you had mentioned the LCR currently at about 110. Is that comparable to last quarter? If I have it correctly
column1227:
"

And did I understand also that 110 is about the right level that you feel comfortable running at in terms of a buffer on top of the current minimums?

"
column1229:
"

That is the target that we established last quarter.

"
column1232: kind of just stepping back. Can you help just frame out
column1233: in terms of your near term
column1235: medium term goals of 10% ROE and ninety-one ten ROA
column1236: how the recent kind of global slowdown that you mentioned
column1237: as well as the U.S. mortgage market
column1238: may be shifting here? How much does that affect
column1242:
"

We\u2019re not changing those goals. We said that those goals were constructed in what we believed to be a slower growth
column1243: challenging environment. We said that we would hope to be able to achieve those goals
column1244: and we hadn\u2019t built in interest rate rises into those pieces. And I think that as global growth presents a headwind
column1245: or the market presents a headwind
column1246:
we\u2019ve got to take those in stride within the numbers that we\u2019ve put out there.

"
column1251:
"

Thank you all for joining us here today. If you have any follow up questions
column1252:
please reach out to investor relations. Thanks.

"
column1253:
"

Copyright policy: All transcripts on this site are the copyright of Seeking Alpha. However
column1254: we view them as an important resource for bloggers and journalists
column1255:
and are excited to contribute to the democratization of financial information on the Internet. (Until now investors have had to pay thousands of dollars in subscription fees for transcripts.) So our reproduction policy is as follows: You may quote up to 400 words of any transcript on the condition that you attribute the transcript to Seeking Alpha and either link to the original transcript or to www.SeekingAlpha.com. All other use is prohibited.

"

column1:
{"Citigroup's CEO Discusses Q3 2013 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Citigroup (NYSE:C)

"
column18:
"

Matt Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column19:
"

Erika Penala Najarian - Bank of America Merrill Lynch

"
column28: and welcome to Citi\u2019s third quarter 2013 earnings review with Chief Executive Officer Mike Corbat and Chief Financial Officer John Gerspach. Today\u2019s call will be hosted by Susan Kendall
column30:
"

We ask that you please hold all questions until the completion of the formal remarks
column31: at which time you will be given instructions for the question-and-answer session. Also
column33: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column40: and thank you all for joining us. On our call today
column41: our CEO
column42: Mike Corbat
column43: will speak first. Then John Gerspach
column44: our CFO
column45: will take you through the earnings presentation
column46: which is available for download on our website
column47: citigroup.com. Afterwards
column48:
we\u2019ll be happy to take questions.

"
column49:
"

Before we get started
column50: I would like to remind you that today\u2019s presentation may contain forward-looking statements
column51: which are based on management\u2019s current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results in capital and other financial condition may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors
column52: including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today and those included in our SEC filings
column55:
the Risk Factors section of our 2012 Form 10-K.

"
column57:
let me turn it over to Mike.

"
column58:
"

Mike Corbat

"
column59:
"

Thank you
column60: Susan. Good morning everyone. Earlier today
column61: we reported earnings of $3.2 billion for the third quarter. Excluding CVA and DVA and a tax benefit
column62: net income was $3.3 billion
column63:
or $1.02 per share.

"
column64:
"

Our results reflect a challenging operating environment
column65: including the slowdown in client activity based on uncertainty regarding Fed tapering
column66: concerns about the effect of a U.S. government shutdown
column67: and forecasts for slowing economic growth
column68:
particularly in the emerging markets.

"
column69:
"

Although I think we performed relatively well in this challenging
column70: uneven environment
column71: we cannot
column72: and are not
column73: satisfied with these results
column74:
and will be focusing on areas where we need to continue to improve.

"
column75:
"

Turning to our individual businesses
column76: the macro-environment had the biggest impact in our markets businesses
column77: and in particular fixed income
column78:
where the typical slowdown in third quarter activity levels was exacerbated.

"
column79:
"

We also pared back some of our risks in emerging markets that impacted trading opportunities
column80: but it was the right thing to do for the firm. We have more work to do in equities
column81: where our derivatives performance was not where we want it to be
column82:
but year to date we continue to make progress.

"
column83:
"

As for investment banking
column84: although there was some transactions we would have liked to participate in
column85: we increased our share of wallet so far this year. Our transaction services businesses are still being affected by spread compression
column86:
but we continue to work hard to offset that through volume growth and increased market share.

"
column87:
"

In trade loans
column88: one of the several areas where we leverage our unique global network to a competitive advantage
column89:
new originations grew 23% year-to-year.

"
column90:
"

In consumer banking
column91: as expected
column92: we face significant revenue pressure
column93: as U.S. mortgage originations were sharply reduced
column94: and we continue to adjust to regulatory changes in other markets
column95:
such as Korea.

"
column96:
"

We did see strong revenue and volume growth in other markets
column97: several of which we\u2019ve designated as invest to grow. And importantly
column98:
credit trends remain favorable as we focus on our target segments around the world.

"
column99:
"

Although we can\u2019t control the revenue environment
column100: we certainly can control our expenses
column101: and expenses for the quarter were $11.7 billion
column102: 4% below the second quarter and the prior year period. We achieved this while making investments and bearing the brunt of increased regulatory costs. We remain on track with the repositioning actions we announced late last year
column103: which have helped reduce our headcount by over 10
column104:
000 people year-to-year.

"
column105:
"

We\u2019re working on a variety of different efforts to improve our productivity. Some center on optimizing our global real estate footprint
column106: and have resulted in reducing our portfolio of sites by 73. Others seek to reduce the turnaround time for transactions and improve the client experience. More importantly
column107:
we\u2019re instilling the need for these efforts to be business as usual and not episodic.

"
column108:
"

We also continue to make progress in two critical areas which I\u2019ve identified for you before
column109:
reducing the drag on earnings caused by Citi Holdings and the utilization of our deferred tax assets. We reduced our assets in Citi Holdings by $9 billion during the quarter.

"
column110:
"

Holdings assets now total $122 billion and are 6% of our GAAP balance sheet
column111: and even without the benefit of an incremental loan loss reserve release
column112:
Holdings net loss was reduced for the third consecutive quarter.

"
column113:
"

While legal costs associated with Citi Holdings will likely remain elevated in the near term
column114: we took another significant step to get past legacy issues with our agreement with Freddie Mac
column115:
that following on to our agreement with Fannie Mae during the second quarter.

"
column116:
"

Regarding our deferred tax assets
column117:
we consumed $500 million of DTA during the third quarter. This modest amount brings the 2013 total year to date to $1.8 billion.

"
column118:
"

As you know
column119: I want Citi to be known as an indisputably strong and stable institution
column120: and again we made progress towards this goal. The capital we generated this quarter
column121: primarily through retained earnings and DTA utilization
column122:
resulted in our tier one common ratio increasing to an estimated 10.4% on a Basel III basis.

"
column123:
"

Other key metrics also strengthened
column124: including our supplementary leverage ratio
column125:
which increased to an estimated 5.1%.

"
column126:
"

Looking towards the end of the year
column127: we believe it\u2019s going to remain a challenging environment
column128: and growth uneven. As has been the case historically
column129: transitioning from a lower to higher rate environment doesn\u2019t happen without causing disruptions
column130: especially in the emerging markets
column131:
and we\u2019re clearly seeing evidence of that.

"
column132:
"

In addition
column133: the ongoing uncertainty regarding the Fed tapering is keeping many investors on the sidelines
column134:
and that may be for an extended period of time.

"
column135:
"

In the U.S.
column136: the twin impact from the government shutdown and dangerous flirtation with the debt ceiling are clearly impacting the economy and the financial markets. The housing market is still in recovery mode
column137:
but we expect refinancing volumes to continue to decrease. We\u2019ll continue to take steps to make sure our mortgage and other consumer businesses are sized correctly.

"
column138:
"

Internationally
column139: emerging growth has slowed and will likely remain uneven
column140: but we still believe these markets will outpace developed market growth. That being said
column141:
we manage our risk prudently and continue to adjust our appetite based on the latest trends and conditions.

"
column142:
"

John will go through the deck
column143:
and then we\u2019d be happy to take your questions. John?

"
column144:
"

John Gerspach

"
column145:
"

Thank you
column146: Mike
column147: and good morning everyone. To start
column148: I\u2019d like to highlight some significant items affecting our results this quarter. First
column149: CVA and DVA were negative $336 million pretax and $208 million after tax in the third quarter
column150: for a negative impact on EPS of $0.07. We also recorded a tax benefit of $176 million related to the resolution of certain tax audit items
column151:
which had a positive impact on EPS of $0.06 per share.

"
column152:
"

For comparison purposes
column153: in the third quarter of 2012
column154: CVA and DVA were negative $776 million pretax
column155: or $485 million after tax
column156: for a negative impact of $0.16 per share. We also had a tax benefit last year of $582 million
column157:
or $0.19 per share.

"
column158:
"

In addition
column159: in the third quarter of 2012
column160: we recorded a pretax loss of $4.7 billion related to to Morgan Stanley Smith Barney joint venture
column161: which had a negative impact on EPS of $0.94 per share in that quarter. Adjusting for these items
column162: we earned $3.3 billion in the third quarter of 2013
column163: or $1.02 per share
column164:
as compared to $1.06 per share on an adjusted basis in the third quarter of 2012.

"
column165:
"

Throughout today\u2019s earnings presentation
column166: I will be discussing our results
column167: excluding CVA/DVA
column168: the tax benefits
column169: and gains or losses on the sale of minority investments
column170:
to provide comparability to prior periods.

"
column171:
"

On slide four
column172: we show total Citigroup results for the quarter. We earned $3.3 billion in the third quarter
column173: roughly flat to last year
column174:
as lower operating expenses and lower credit costs were offset by a decline in revenues and a higher tax rate.

"
column175:
"

Earnings per share declined 4%
column176:
including the impact of higher preferred dividends in the recent quarter.

"
column177:
"

Citigroup end of period loans were flat year over year at $658 billion
column178: as growth in Citicorp was offset by the continued decline in Citi Holdings
column179:
and deposits grew to $955 billion.

"
column180:
"

On slide five
column181: we provide more detail on revenues in constant dollars
column182: which declined 4% from last year and 8% sequentially. As Mike discussed
column183:
we faced a challenging operating environment across many of our businesses in the third quarter.

"
column184:
"

In consumer banking
column185: revenues declined sequentially by roughly $350 million
column186: primarily driven by lower U.S. mortgage refinancing activity
column187:
as well as the absence of a $180 million gain in the second quarter.

"
column188:
"

Securities and banking revenues declined by nearly $1.3 billion sequentially
column189: as a seasonal decline in activity in the third quarter was exacerbated by uncertainty around the timing of Fed tapering
column190: the pending government shutdown
column191: and other geopolitical events. We also incurred losses on loan hedges
column192: as compared to gains in the prior quarter
column193:
as spreads tightened versus the end of the second quarter.

"
column194:
"

In transaction services
column195: revenues declined sequentially from a seasonally strong second quarter
column196: which also included a $50 million gain. Year over year
column197:
revenues increased as growth in volumes and fees more than offset the impact of spread compression.

"
column198:
"

Holdings revenues were up versus prior periods
column199: mostly driven by the absence of rep and warranty reserve bills this quarter. Finally
column200:
foreign currency translation accounted for roughly $200 million of the reported revenue decline versus prior periods.

"
column201:
"

As we show on slide six
column202: we maintained our focus on expense discipline in the third quarter. Excluding legal and repositioning costs
column203: core operating expenses were roughly $10.8 billion
column204: down over $400 million year over year
column205:
and over $250 million sequentially in constant dollars.

"
column206:
"

At the end of the second quarter
column207: I said we expected to see about $200 million of incremental repositioning savings by the end of the 2013. We achieved about half of that amount in the third quarter
column208: or roughly $100 million. The incremental $150 million of expense savings this quarter was comprised of lower performance-based compensation and lower transaction costs
column209:
both of which were driven by the more challenging revenue environment in the third quarter.

"
column210:
"

Legal costs remained elevated at nearly $700 million
column211: mostly reported in Citi Holdings
column212: and repositioning costs totaled $133 million for the third quarter
column213: mostly in Citicorp. Year to date
column214: repositioning costs have averaged around $125 million per quarter. Naturally
column215: there will be some variability quarter to quarter in these costs as we continue to pursue our efficiency efforts
column216:
but we do not anticipate taking another very large repositioning charge similar to the fourth quarter of last year.

"
column217:
"

On slide seven
column218: we show the split between Citicorp and Citi Holdings. Citicorp generated third quarter revenues of $17 billion
column219: and net income of $3.4 billion. Year over year
column220: revenues declined 7% and expenses were down 6%
column221: driven by repositioning savings
column222: lower performance-based compensation
column223: lower legal and related expenses
column224:
and the impact of FX.

"
column225:
"

Credit costs in Citicorp increased year over year. Net credit losses continued to improve. However
column226: reserve releases in North America cards continued to decline and were partially offset by reserve builds in Latin America consumer. We also built reserves in our unfunded corporate portfolio
column227: driven by an increase in commitments
column228:
as well as certain credits migrating to lower risk ratings in the quarter.

"
column229:
"

Year to date
column230: Citicorp revenues grew 1% and expenses declined 3%
column231: partially offset by the higher cost of credit
column232:
resulting in 5% growth in pretax earnings.

"
column233:
"

Turning to Citi Holdings
column234: revenues were nearly $1.3 billion and the net loss declined to roughly $100 million in the third quarter. Citi Holdings ended the period with $122 billion of assets
column235:
or 6% of total Citigroup assets.

"
column236:
"

Turning to Citicorp
column237: on slide eight
column238: we show results for international consumer banking in constant dollars. On this basis
column239: revenues grew 2% year over year while expenses declined 1%. In Latin America
column240: revenues grew 6% and expenses were up 4% from last year
column241: while in Asia revenues declined 2% and expenses were down 4%. Revenues were down in EMEA
column242:
reflecting market exits in Turkey and Romania.

"
column243:
"

International consumer revenues continued to reflect spread compression as well as the impact of regulatory changes in certain markets
column244: including Korea. However
column245: most underlying drivers showed sustained momentum in the third quarter. Total average loans grew 5% from last year
column246:
and card purchase sales were up 8%.

"
column247:
"

Credit costs of $836 million in the third quarter were up 34% from last year. Net credit losses increased in dollar terms
column248:
but remained relatively stable as a percentage of loans.

"
column249:
"

We also built loan loss reserves including nearly $170 million in Latin America
column250: roughly half of which was related to our exposure to the top three home builders in Mexico
column251:
with the remainder driven by continued portfolio growth as well as potential losses from recent hurricanes in that region.

"
column252:
"

I mentioned last quarter that we continue to monitor the performance of our clients in the home building industry in Mexico
column253: as well as the value of our collateral. At the end of the third quarter
column254:
our loans outstanding to the top three builders totaled less than $300 million.

"
column255:
"

The loan loss reserve build in the recent quarter was driven by further deterioration in the financial and operating condition of these companies and decreases in the value of our collateral
column256:
resulting from the breach of certain of these clients\u2019 credit agreements with us as well as lower valuations.

"
column257:
"

We will continue to monitor the performance of our home builder clients as well as the value of our collateral to determine whether additional reserves or chargeoffs may be required in future periods.

"
column258:
"

On slide nine
column259: we show revenue details for Asia consumers. Lower revenues in the third quarter reflected spread compression in retail banking as well as the continued impact of regulatory changes in certain markets
column260:
most significantly in Korea.

"
column261:
"

Sequentially
column262: the decline was also driven by lower investment sales revenues
column263:
which tend to fluctuate more in line with retail investor sentiment and the broader capital markets environment.

"
column264:
"

Card revenues improved both year over year and sequentially with continued growth in purchase sales across the region. And
column265: we saw strong revenue growth in certain markets
column266: including Hong Kong
column267: India
column268: Thailand
column269:
and China.

"
column270:
"

Turning to Korea
column271: we are in an ongoing process to reposition our consumer franchise in that market to improve its operating efficiency and returns. And
column272: upon completion
column273: Korea should better reflect our consumer franchise elsewhere around the world
column274:
with a footprint more concentrated in the major cities and a focus on high quality consumer segments.

"
column275:
"

We believe revenues in Korea could begin to stabilize in early 2014
column276:
but we expect this market to continue to present a drag on year over year revenue comparisons for Asia through at least next year.

"
column277:
"

Slide 10 shows the results for North America consumer banking. Total revenues were down 12% year over year
column278: and 6% sequentially. Retail banking revenues of $1.1 billion declined by 35% from last year and 29% sequentially
column279: reflecting lower mortgage origination revenues as well as continued spread compression on deposits
column280: partially offset by growth in deposits and commercial loans. Also
column281: as we mentioned last quarter
column282:
our mortgage revenues in the second quarter included a gain of roughly $180 million on the sale of an on balance sheet mortgage portfolio.

"
column283:
"

Cards revenues of $3.6 billion were roughly flat versus last year
column284: as an improvement in net interest spreads was offset by lower average loan balances. On a sequential basis
column285:
revenues grew 4% as average loan balances stabilized in Citi-branded cards and net interest spreads continued to improve.

"
column286:
"

In retail services
column287: spreads were lower
column288: driven by a higher mix of deferred interest promotional balances
column289:
but loan balances grew due to the acquisition of the Best Buy portfolio.

"
column290:
"

Total operating expenses of $2.4 billion were down 4% year over year
column291: primarily reflecting lower legal and related costs and repositioning savings. Third quarter results reflected a portion of the benefit we expect from actions we have taken to reduce the expense base in mortgages in light of the lower origination activities. However
column292:
we also saw higher expenses in cards as a result of the Best Buy portfolio acquisition.

"
column293:
"

The net reduction in expenses quarter over quarter was mostly driven by continued repositioning actions
column294: as well as reduced marketing expenses. Credit costs increased year over year as net credit losses continued to improve
column295: but the loan loss reserve release also declined to just over $200 million
column296:
driven by cards.

"
column297:
"

Overall
column298: while we face significant mortgage and spread-related headwinds in North America this quarter that are likely to continue
column299: we also saw some progress in our core franchise. Average deposits continued to grow
column300: up 8% year over year
column301: including 15% growth in checking account balances. Commercial market loans were up 15%
column302:
and card purchase sales grew year over year in both portfolios.

"
column303:
"

Slide 11 shows our global consumer credit trends in more detail. Credit quality in North America continued to improve in the third quarter
column304:
with a decline in the NCL rate reflecting both underlying improvement in the portfolio as well as the impact of purchase accounting for the Best Buy portfolio acquisition.

"
column305:
"

In Asia and EMEA
column306: we also saw stable to improving credit trends. And
column307: in Latin America
column308:
the net credit loss rate has remained fairly flat for the past several quarters. We expect the fourth quarter NCL rate in Latin America to remain roughly flat to third quarter levels.

"
column309:
"

However
column310: as we\u2019ve stated previously
column311: the rate could be higher if we incur any material losses on our exposures to home builders in Mexico. In addition
column312: as I mentioned
column313: we took reserves this quarter for estimated potential losses resulting from the two recent hurricanes in Mexico. Any such losses may increase our NCL rate in the coming quarters. However
column314:
we would expect these losses to be charged against the reserve and therefore they should be neutral to the overall cost of credit.

"
column315:
"

Slide 12 shows our securities and banking business. Revenues of $5.1 billion declined 10% from last year and 20% from the prior quarter. Investment banking revenues of $839 million were down 10% from the prior year and 19% from last quarter
column316: mostly in line with the overall market. While revenues declined in the third quarter
column317: our franchise continued to show momentum year to date
column318:
with revenues up 10% year over year and wallet share gains in most major products.

"
column319:
"

Equity market revenues of $710 million were up 36% from last year
column320:
reflecting market share gains as well as improvement in our derivatives trading performance.

"
column321:
"

Sequentially
column322: equity market revenues declined 25% as cash equity revenues declined broadly in line with overall market volumes and trading performance was weaker in derivatives. While our derivatives results were lower this quarter
column323: we continue to make progress in building this franchise
column324:
which contributed to the 24% growth in equities revenues year to date.

"
column325:
"

Fixed income market revenues of $2.8 billion declined 26% from a particularly strong third quarter last year
column326: when we benefited from an environment with strong liquidity
column327: more robust client activity
column328: and significant credit spread tightening. By contrast
column329: the recent quarter reflected a general slowdown in client activity
column330: exacerbated by uncertainty around the timing of Fed tapering
column331: the pending government shutdown
column332:
and other geopolitical events.

"
column333:
"

Sequentially
column334: fixed income revenues declined 17%
column335: reflecting the slowdown in activity
column336: as well as actions to pare back risk given volatility in the emerging markets. Private bank revenues of $614 million were up slightly from last year
column337: and down 5% sequentially
column338:
driven by lower capital markets activity.

"
column339:
"

Lending revenues
column340: excluding the impact of gains and losses on hedges related to accrual loans
column341: were $377 million in the third quarter
column342:
down 10% from last year on lower volumes and down 16% sequentially on lower spreads as well as losses on loan sale activity.

"
column343:
"

Total operating expenses of $3.4 billion were down both year over year and sequentially
column344:
reflecting the impact of headcount reductions and lower performance-based compensation.

"
column345:
"

For the first nine months of 2013
column346: total revenues increased 6% over last year
column347: driven by equities and investment banking
column348: while expenses declined 3%
column349:
resulting in 13% net income growth.

"
column350:
"

Moving to transaction services on slide 13
column351: revenues of $2.6 billion were up 2% from last year in constant dollars
column352:
as strong fee income growth more than offset a decline in net interest revenues.

"
column353:
"

Treasury and trade solutions was up 1% as volume and fee growth was partially offset by the impact of spread compression globally
column354:
and securities and fund services revenues grew 3% as higher settlement volumes and fees more than offset lower spreads.

"
column355:
"

Sequentially
column357:
reflecting seasonally strong client activity and a one-time gain of roughly $50 million in the prior quarter.

"
column358:
"

Spread compression continued to dampen revenues this quarter. However
column359: the volume drivers for transaction services showed sustained momentum. Trade loan originations grew 23% year over year. Average deposits were up 4%. Assets under custody grew by 9%
column361:
"

Expenses of $1.4 billion grew 4% year over year in constant dollars
column362: driven mainly by higher volumes
column363: partially offset by efficiency savings. While expense growth outpaced revenue growth in the third quarter
column364: we continue to believe the business can achieve positive operating leverage in total for the second half of 2013
column365:
even when excluding the repositioning costs incurred in the fourth quarter of last year.

"
column366:
"

Slide 14 shows the results for corporate other. Revenues were up versus the prior year
column367: driven by hedging activities
column368: partially offset by lower AFS sales
column369: while expenses declined
column370:
mostly reflecting lower legal and related costs.

"
column371:
"

Assets of $313 billion included approximately $119 billion of cash and cash equivalents and $139 of liquid available for sale securities.

"
column372:
"

Slide 15 shows Citi Holdings assets. We ended the quarter with assets of $122 billion in Citi Holdings
column373:
or 6% of total Citigroup assets. The $9 billion reduction in the third quarter reflected $4 billion of asset sales and $5 billion of net paydowns.

"
column374:
"

On slide 16
column375: we show Citi Holdings financial results for the quarter. Total revenues of $1.3 billion were up year over year and sequentially
column376:
primarily driven by the absence of rep and warranty reserve builds this quarter.

"
column377:
"

Citi Holdings expenses increased 16% year over year to $1.4 billion
column378: driven by higher legal and related costs. Excluding these legal costs
column379:
core operating expenses declined 16% to roughly $790 million.

"
column380:
"

Net credit losses continued to improve in the third quarter
column381: driven by North America mortgages. And we released $679 million of loan loss reserves
column382: including a release of roughly $725 million in North America mortgages
column383:
partially offset by losses on asset sales.

"
column384:
"

Regarding the mortgage reserve release
column385: roughly $425 million of reserves were utilized to offset net credit losses in the third quarter
column386:
and the incremental $300 million reserve release was driven by continued improvement in delinquencies and home prices year to date.

"
column387:
"

Looking to the fourth quarter
column388: assuming the U.S. economic environment remains favorable
column389: we expect to utilize loan loss reserves to offset virtually all of our mortgage net credit losses
column390:
but we do not currently anticipate additional reserve releases beyond that level. We ended the period with $5.7 billion of loan loss reserves allocated to North America mortgage loans in Citi Holdings or 40 months of NCL coverage.

"
column391:
"

Looking at the past five quarters of Citi Holdings results on slide 17
column392: the pretax loss in Citi Holdings improved again this quarter
column393: even excluding the incremental $300 million reserve release in mortgages. However
column394: while the adjusted operating margin on the upper left panel on this slide increased significantly in the past two quarters to roughly $500 million
column395:
it will likely trend lower as each of the last two quarters included some level of positive marks or episodic gains.

"
column396:
"

We expect mortgage net credit losses to continue to improve with reserve releases trending in line with NCLs. And legal costs will likely continue to be elevated and somewhat volatile in the near term.

"
column397:
"

On slide 18
column398: we show mortgage loan and adjusted net credit loss trends. We ended the quarter with $76 billion of North America mortgages in Citi Holdings
column399: down 20% from a year ago
column400:
while net credit losses declined 50% and the loss rate improved by over 130 basis points.

"
column401:
"

These mortgages include approximately $12 billion of loans originated in our legacy Citi Financial business
column402: the vast majority of which are residential first mortgages. While the NCL rates on Citi Financial loans have improved
column403: the loss rates on these loans tend to be higher at just over 5% in the third quarter
column404: as compared to less than 1% for residential first mortgages originated by Citi Mortgage. We sold roughly $500 million of mortgages this quarter
column406:
for a total of $6.4 of mortgage sales year to date.

"
column407:
"

On slide 19
column408: we show delinquency trends
column409: including both residential first mortgages and home equity loans. 30-plus day delinquencies continue to improve
column410: down 9% sequentially
column411: to $5 billion. FICO and LTV trends also remain favorable through the third quarter
column412:
and we provide these details in the appendix on slide 38.

"
column413:
"

On slide 20
column414: we show Citigroup\u2019s net interest revenue and margin trends. Net interest revenues totaled $11.5 billion in the third quarter. In constant dollars
column415:
net interest revenue was roughly flat to the prior quarter and down slightly versus last year.

"
column416:
"

Our net interest margin in the third quarter decreased by 4 basis points
column417: reflecting lower loan yields and an increase in cash balances
column418: partially offset by an improvement in funding costs. Looking to the fourth quarter
column419:
we expect NIM to remain roughly flat.

"
column420:
"

On slide 21
column421: we show our key capital metrics through the third quarter. Under Basel III
column422: our estimated tier one common ratio increased to 10.4%
column423: driven by retained earnings and DTA utilization. Citigroup\u2019s estimated supplementary leverage ratio was 5.1%
column424: up from 4.9% last quarter
column425:
and the supplementary leverage ratio for Citibank remained above 6% for the third quarter.

"
column426:
"

In summary
column427: we clearly faced a challenging environment in the third quarter
column428: with a slowdown in client activity
column429: a continued low rate environment
column430:
and declining mortgage originations all posing significant headwinds.

"
column431:
"

But against this backdrop
column433: with a continued focus on efficiency and growing our loan portfolio in a disciplined manner. We are on track to meet the repositioning targets we announced at the end of last year
column434:
and underlying credit performance remained favorable.

"
column435:
"

We also continue to make significant progress in winding down Citi Holdings
column436: which is now just 6% of total Citigroup assets. Year to date
column437: the quarterly drag from Citi Holdings is down significantly from last year
column438:
even excluding the incremental mortgage reserve release this quarter.

"
column439:
"

And
column440: finally
column441: we continue to grow our capital
column442: benefitting from a combination of earnings and further DTA utilization. We ended the quarter with an estimated Basel III tier one common ratio of 10.4%
column443: and an estimated supplementary leverage ratio of 5.1%
column444:
one of the strongest capital positions in our industry.

"
column445:
"

Looking to the fourth quarter
column446: in North America consumer we expect continued headwinds in mortgages
column447:
although some of this pressure should be offset by additional revenues from the acquisition of the Best Buy portfolio.

"
column448:
"

Net credit loss trends in North America should remain favorable
column449:
although we expect net loan loss reserve releases to moderate given the need to build reserves for new loans originated in the Best Buy portfolio.

"
column450:
"

In international consumer
column451: in total we expect continued volume growth
column452: albeit somewhat offset by ongoing spread compression globally. Growth will likely be driven by Latin America
column453: as we expect our repositioning efforts in Korea to continue to present a drag on year over year revenue comparisons in Asia in the near term. And
column454:
international consumer credit costs should generally trend in line with loan growth.

"
column455:
"

Turning to our institutional businesses
column456: our securities and banking results will likely continue to reflect the overall market environment
column457:
with a goal of steadily gaining wallet share over time with our target clients.

"
column458:
"

And
column459: in transaction services
column460: we expect continued volume and fee growth to help offset the ongoing pressure of the low rate environment. So
column461: in total we see a continued challenging operating environment in the near term
column462:
but we remain focused on those aspects of our business that we can control.

"
column463:
"

Our results year to date reflect the strength of our franchise and our progress towards our key priorities: gaining share with our clients
column464: generating consistent earnings
column465:
and building our capital base.

"

And with that

Mike and I are happy to take any questions.

column834: under purchase accounting the acquired portfolios now we bring them on our books at fair market value

column836: as you build each new loan
column837: as each new incremental loan comes on your books
column838: you need to start putting up loan loss reserves for the estimated inherent losses in those loans. And there\u2019s no benefit from old loans rolling off your books
column839:

Citigroup Inc. (NYSE:C)

"
