column31:
"

Hello and welcome to Citi\u2019s Fourth Quarter 2013 Earnings Review with Chief Executive Officer Mike Corbat and Chief Financial Officer John Gerspach. Today\u2019s call will be hosted by Susan Kendall
column33:
"

We ask that you please hold all questions until the completion of the formal remarks
column34: at which time you will be given instructions for the question-and-answer session. Also
column36: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column41:
"

Thank you
column42: Brian. Good morning and thank you all for joining us. On our call today
column43: our CEO
column44: Mike Corbat
column45: will speak first. Then John Gerspach
column46: our CFO
column47: will take you through the earnings presentation
column48: which is available for download on our website
column49: citigroup.com. Afterwards
column50:
we\u2019ll be happy to take your question.

"
column52: I\u2019d like to remind you that today\u2019s presentation may contain forward-looking statements
column53: which are based on management\u2019s current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results in capital and other financial condition may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors
column54: including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today and those included in our SEC filings
column57:
the Risk Factors section of our 2012 Form 10-K.

"
column58:
"

With that said
column59:
let me turn it over to Mike.

"
column60:
"

Mike Corbat

"
column61:
"

Thank you
column62: Susan. Good morning everyone. Earlier today
column63: we reported earnings of $2.7 billion for the fourth quarter
column64: excluding CVA and DVA and the impact of the credicard divestiture
column65: net income was $2.6 billion
column66:
or $0.82 a share.

"
column67:
"

In our institutional business
column68: our fourth quarter markets performance reflected an ongoing challenging environment sequentially while our rates and currencies revenues were relatively stable
column69: our credit and securitized products revenues were lower due to reduced client activity. And while on equities
column70: client flows were relatively stable
column71:
we underperformed in trading.

"
column72:
"

In contrast
column73: investment banking showed positive momentum during the quarter driven by strong M&A and equity underwriting and we increased our overall wallet share for the year. Transactions services products demonstrated resilience in the low interest rate environment and regain positive operating leverage for the second half of the year. Importantly we continue to grow both our client volumes and market share
column74:
while demonstrating strong fee revenue growth on a year-on-year basis.

"
column75:
"

Our consumer bank performed well internationally with Latin America showing continued revenue growth. The ongoing efforts to reposition our franchise in Korea continue to impact our Asian results
column76:
but the region had good performance otherwise. Our U.S business saw revenue boost from the acquisition of the Best Buy portfolio. We saw positive drivers in our Citi branded cards business and mortgage revenues broadly stabilized during the quarter.

"
column77:
"

For the full year 2013 with every bit as challenging as we thought it would be when we entered the year. Low interest rates
column78: changing expectations regarding the tapering of quantitative easing
column79: the increase in cost of legal settlements
column80:
all had significant impacts on our bottom line.

"
column81:
"

However
column82: while we didn\u2019t finish 2013 as strongly as I would have liked
column83: very pleased with the progress we made over the course of the year
column84:
especially in regard to several critical areas I highlighted in my first earnings call with you last January.

"
column85:
"

As a Company we improved our efficiency
column86: completing the repositioning effort we announced last December. We\u2019ve reduced our operating expenses by 2% and our headcount by 3% in 2013
column87: while exiting segments that didn\u2019t fit our strategy. Key metrics such as ROTCE and ROA also improved as we made progress towards the targets we announced in March. We also began to tap into our deferred tax asset with $600 million of DTA utilized in the fourth quarter
column88:
which brought the total amount utilized to $2.4 billion for the year.

"
column89:
"

Turning to Citi Holdings with a $39 billion reduction in assets
column90:
we shrunk its size by 25% in 2013. We narrowed its annual loss by half when compared to 2012 making good progress for getting to breakeven. We also managed to put several legacy issues behind this through settlements with Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

"
column91:
"

By focusing intently on our clients
column92:
we grew loans in Citicorp by 7% over 2012 and improved our market share across our institutional businesses. And our net income of $13.8 billion was 15% above 2012 and the highest since before the financial crisis.

"
column93:
"

Higher net income help to accelerate the growth of capital during the year and we exceeded our goal of ending 2013 with an estimated Basel III Tier 1 common ratio of 10% by 50 basis points. We also received no objection to the capital plan we submitted to our regulators in early 2013
column94:
in addition our supplementary leverage ratio increased to an estimated 5.4% exceeding the regulatory requirement.

"
column95:
"

But being pleased with our progress doesn\u2019t make us satisfied and I know our shareholders aren\u2019t either. We still have work to do to generate the results that our shareholders expect and reserve -- deserve.

"
column96:
"

Looking to 2014
column97: we expect to be tested again as we believe the environment while improving will remain challenging. We believe short-term interest rates will remain low for the foreseeable future and although we are working hard to put the remaining legacy issues behind us
column98:
legal headwinds will remain with us and the industry.

"
column99:
"

And while we do see an improving economic environment
column100:
growth won\u2019t be robust really by any means. We believe the deceleration of growth in Asia has bottomed out and the euro zone is continuing to recover that albeit slowly.

"
column101:
"

Our projections for key markets such as Mexico
column102:
India and Korea call for improvements over 2013 levels. In the U.S we believe our mortgage revenues have stabilized and we are working to reduce the costs associated with legacy assets in Citi Holdings as the recently announced sale of certain mortgage servicing rights shows.

"
column103:
"

We\u2019ve entered 2014 as a strong and stable institution as we work to leverage our unparallel global network to the benefit of our clients. We are completely focused on executing our strategy and remain committed to the targets we announced last year as well as our objective of returning capital to our shareholders.

"
column104:
"

With that
column105:
I will now turn it over to John and he can go through the deck and then we\u2019d be happy to answer your questions. John?

"
column106:
"

John Gerspach

"
column107:
"

Thank you
column108: Mike
column109: and good morning everyone. To start
column110: I\u2019d like to highlight some significant items affecting our results this quarter. First
column111: CVA and DVA were negative $164 million pre-tax and $100 million after tax in the fourth quarter
column112:
for a negative impact on EPS of $0.03 per share.

"
column113:
"

We also recorded an after tax benefit of $189 million related to the Credicard divestiture this quarter for a positive impact on EPS of $0.06 per share. For comparison purposes
column114: in the fourth quarter of 2012
column115:
CVA and DVA were negative $485 million pre-tax or $301 million after tax for a negative impact of $0.10 per share.

"
column116:
"

In addition
column117: last year we recorded a large repositioning charge of over $1 billion pre-tax or $653 million after tax which had a negative impact on EPS of $0.21 per share. Given the size of the repositioning charge in the fourth quarter of 2012
column118: I will be discussing our results today excluding this item. However
column119: we have continued to incur small repositioning charges as part of our ongoing expense initiatives
column120:
and these charges are included in our expense numbers for 2013.

"
column121:
"

Adjusting for CVA
column122: DVA and the impact of the credicard divestiture and the fourth quarter 2012 repositioning charges
column123:
we earned $2.6 billion in the fourth quarter of 2013 or $0.82 per share as compared to $0.69 per share in the fourth quarter of 2012.

"
column124:
"

On Slide 4 we show total Citigroup results. We earned 2.6 billion in the fourth quarter
column125: up over 20% from last year
column126:
as lower operating expenses and lower credit cards were partially offset by a decline in revenues and a higher effective tax rate.

"
column127:
"

The effective tax rate was 32% for the fourth quarter of 2013
column128: somewhat above the prior quarter and full year tax rate
column129:
primarily due to the amount of legal accruals estimated to be nondeductible.

"
column130:
"

On a full year basis
column131: revenues grew 1% while operating expenses were 2% lower and credit cards also declined by over 2.8 billion
column132: driving earnings growth of 15%. Citigroup end of period loans grew 2% year-over-year to 668 billion
column133: as 7% growth in Citicorp was partially offset by the continued decline in Citi Holdings
column134:
and deposits grew to $968 billion.

"
column135:
"

On Slide 5 we provide more detail on fourth quarter revenues in constant dollars. In consumer banking
column136: revenues grew by over $200 million
column137: sequentially
column138: driven by the Best Buy portfolio acquisition and continued growth in Latin America
column139:
and year-over-year the decline mostly reflected lower U.S. mortgage refinancing activity.

"
column140:
"

Securities and banking revenues declined by over $450 million
column141: sequentially
column142: reflecting lower markets revenues
column143: partially offset by growth in investment banking. And year-over-year
column144: fixed income revenues were down
column145:
however both equities and investment banking showed improvement.

"
column146:
"

In transaction services
column147: revenues have been fairly stable as growth in volumes and fees continued to be offset by lower spreads. Citi Holdings revenues improved year-over-year mostly reflecting the absence of rep and warranty reserve builds. Finally
column148:
foreign currency translation accounted for roughly $260 million of the reported revenue decline year-over-year.

"
column149:
"

On Slide 6 we show more expense details. Core operating expenses of 10.9 billion in the fourth quarter declined by roughly 340 million year-over-year in constant dollars
column150: driven by efficiency savings and a decline in Citi Holdings assets
column151:
partially offset by volume-related expenses.

"
column152:
"

Sequentially
column153: costs were down by roughly $50 million reflecting additional repositioning savings
column154: partially offset by seasonal marketing expenses
column155:
deal-related costs in securities and banking and higher than anticipated expenses in retail services in the quarter related to the integration of the Best Buy portfolio.

"
column156:
"

Legal and related costs were just over $800 million in the fourth quarter
column157: and as we had disclosed previously repositioning costs were somewhat higher than recent quarters at $234 million. In addition
column158:
we incurred an incremental $33 million of compensatory fees to Fannie Mae related to the sale of servicing rights out of Citi Holdings we announced yesterday.

"
column159:
"

On a full year basis
column160: core operating expenses of 44.3 billion in 2013 declined by nearly $900 million
column161: driven by firm wide efficiency savings and asset reductions in Citi Holdings
column162: partially offset by volume-related growth and investments in Citicorp
column163: as well as higher regulatory-related expenses. However
column164:
legal and related expenses continued to be elevated at roughly $3 billion.

"
column165:
"

On Slide 7
column166: we show the split between Citicorp and Citi Holdings. In Citicorp
column167: pre-tax earnings grew 4% year-over-year in the fourth quarter as a decline in revenues was more than offset by lower operating expenses and an improvement in credit. And on a full year basis
column168: pre-tax earnings improved by 5% with revenues roughly flat and expenses down by 4%
column169:
partially offset by lower loan loss reserve releases versus the prior year.

"
column170:
"

Turning to Citi Holdings
column171: revenues were 1.3 billion in the fourth quarter and the net loss was roughly 400 million. For the full year
column172: Citi Holdings losses declined by nearly half from $3.7 billion last year to $1.9 billion in 2013
column173:
driven by a significant improvement in credit and declining assets partially offset by higher legal and related costs. Citi Holdings assets declined by 25% during the year to 117 billion or 6% of total Citigroup assets.

"
column174:
"

Turning to Citicorp on Slide 8
column175: we show results for international consumer banking again in constant dollars. On this basis
column176: revenues grew 2% year-over-year in the fourth quarter
column177: while expenses increased by 3%
column178: driven entirely by repositioning charges of roughly $80 million. International consumer revenues continued to reflect spread compression as well as the impact of regulatory changes and the repositioning of our franchise in certain markets
column179:
particularly Korea.

"
column180:
"

However
column181: most key drivers remain positive with both average loans and card purchase sales up 6% from last year. On a full year basis
column182: revenues increased by 3% driven by Latin America
column183: while expenses grew 1% resulting in positive operating leverage. Credit cards increased in 2013
column184: however
column185: the NCL rate remains stable and loan loss reserve builds were mostly driven by portfolio growth
column186: as well as specific builds for Mexico homebuilders during the year
column187:
as we have previously discussed.

"
column188:
"

On Slide 9
column189: we show revenue details for Asia consumer. Lower retail banking revenues in the fourth quarter reflected the continued impact of regulatory changes
column190: spread compression and the repositioning of our franchise in Korea. Investment sales revenues remain muted in fourth quarter
column191:
in line with investor sentiment. And cards revenues improved slightly both year-over-year and sequentially with continued growth in purchase sales across the region.

"
column192:
"

Korea remains a headwind
column193: however
column194: we continue to believe revenues in Korea should begin to stabilize in early 2014. Importantly
column195: credit trends have remained stable in Korea and Korea's drag on year-over-year loan growth for total Asia has diminished in recent quarters. Over time
column196: Korea should better reflect our consumer franchise elsewhere around the world with a footprint more concentrated in the major cities
column197:
a focus on high quality consumer segments and improved returns.

"
column198:
"

Slide 10 shows the results for North America consumer banking. Total revenues were down 8% year-over-year and grew 3% sequentially. Retail banking revenues of 1.1 billion declined by 35% from last year
column199: mostly reflecting the lower mortgage refinancing activity. Sequentially
column200:
mortgage revenues have begun to stabilize but we'll continue to present a drag on year-over-year comparisons though at least the first half of 2014.

"
column201:
"

Branded cards revenues of 2.1 billion were flat versus last year and up 2% from last quarter
column202: driven by continued improvement in net interest spreads and growth in purchase sales
column203: offsetting the impact of lower average loans. Retail services grew 9% versus the prior quarter and prior year
column204: driven by the Best Buy portfolio acquisition. Average loans grew 18% year-over-year
column205: however
column206:
spreads declined as promotional balances increased.

"
column207:
"

Total operating expenses of 2.4 billion were down 6% year-over-year
column208: reflecting lower legal and related costs
column209: ongoing efficiency savings and the resizing of the mortgage business
column210:
partially offset by the impact of the Best Buy acquisition. Credit cost declined modestly year-over-year but grew 19% sequentially driven by lower reserve releases in branded cards and the impact of Best Buy.

"
column211:
"

Overall our North America business executed well in 2013 in the phase of many significant changes
column212: from the resizing of our mortgage business to the continued revitalization of the branded cards franchise and the Best Buy portfolio acquisition
column213:
and we continued to see momentum in the fourth quarter.

"
column214:
"

Average deposits were up 5%
column215:
commercial market loans grew by 10% and purchase sale growth improved in branded cards reflecting the impact of investments in that business as well as an acceleration of growth in the American Airlines portfolio since the merger with US Airways was approved.

"
column216:
"

We are pleased that we were recently awarded exclusive rights to issue new credit card accounts in support of American Airlines following the planned merger of the American and US Airways frequent flyer programs by mid 2015.

"
column217:
"

Slide 11 shows our global consumer credit trends in more detail. Credit remained favorable in North America in the fourth quarter. With the decline in the NCL rate reflecting both underlying improvement as well as the impact of the Best Buy portfolio which was acquired late in the third quarter. Looking forward we currently anticipate the NCL rate in North America to be in the range of 3% for full-year 2014 as new loans continued to season in the Best Buy portfolio.

"
column218:
"

In Asia
column219: credit trends remain stable in the fourth quarter
column220: and in Latin America we saw an uptick in both NCL and delinquency rates. The higher NCL rate in the fourth quarter primarily reflected the impact of portfolio seasoning in Mexico. Looking to full-year 2014
column221:
we currently expect this portfolio seasoning to continue with the NCL rate in Latin America being broadly in the range of the levels we saw in the second half of 2013. However the NCL rate maybe somewhat higher in the first quarter as we typically see a seasonal decline in card loan balances.

"
column222:
"

In addition
column223:
as we have said previously we took loan loss reserves in 2013 related to our exposure to Mexican home builders as well as the hurricanes in Mexico in the third quarter. Any losses from the home builders or the impact from the hurricanes may increase our NCL rate in the current quarters. However we would expect these losses to be charged against the reserve and therefore they should be neutral to the overall cost of credit. The increase in the delinquency rate in the fourth quarter was mostly driven by our exposure to home builders in Mexico.

"
column224:
"

Slide 12 shows our securities and banking business. Revenues of $4.6 billion declined 5% from last year and 9% sequentially. Investment banking revenues of $1 billion were up 3% from the prior year and 23% from last quarter
column225:
driven by M&A and equity underwriting partially offset by lower debt underwriting revenues. Full-year investment banking revenues of $4 billion grew by 8% as we continued to gain overall wallet share.

"
column226:
"

Equity market revenues of $539 million in the fourth quarter were up 16% from last year
column227: reflecting improved client activity in both cash and derivatives. Sequentially
column228: equity market revenues declined 24% as trading performance was weaker and client activity slowed somewhat in December. However we still made significant progress in a full year basis with equity market revenues up 22% reflecting market share gains
column229:
improvements in derivatives execution and a more favorable environment. Fixed income market revenues of $2.3 billion in the fourth quarter declined 15% from last year and 16% sequentially.

"
column230:
"

Overall trading conditions remained muted for fixed income as the government shutdown in the early weeks of the quarter as well as continued speculation around the timing of fed tapering resulted in an environment similar to the third quarter where it was more difficult to generate incremental trading revenues on client flows. In addition
column231:
both the year-over-year and sequential decline reflected the absence of any significant revenues from our Citi Capital Advisors business which we continued to wind down. This business was not a material revenue contributor historically but did have a strong fourth quarter in 2012.

"
column232:
"

And finally while our rates in currencies business showed resilience in the fourth quarter with revenues down only slightly from the third quarter we did see a decline in spread products
column233:
particularly in securitized products. For the full-year fixed income market revenues of $13 billion declined by 7%. Our full-year results reflected market share gains across most products including strong performance in credit and securitized products.

"
column234:
"

However
column235:
we saw fewer market opportunities in rates and currencies. Private bank revenues of $599 million were up slightly from last year and down 2% sequentially driven by lower capital markets activity. Lending revenues excluding the impact of gains and losses on hedges related to accrual loans were $393 million in the fourth quarter up from prior periods as higher volumes and lower losses from loan sale activity were partially offset by lower spreads.

"
column236:
"

Total operating expenses of $3.4 billion were down versus the prior-year driven by lower compensation expenses partially offset by higher legal and related costs and repositioning charges in the recent quarter. On a sequential basis expenses were flat as lower compensation expenses were offset by higher deal related and legal-end related costs as well as the impact of foreign exchange. On a full-year basis the franchise continued to show momentum with revenues up 4% driven by equities
column237:
investment banking and our private bank while expenses declined by 3% resulting in 16% growth in pre-tax earnings.

"
column238:
"

Moving to transaction services on Slide 13
column239: revenues of $2.6 billion were up 1% from last year in constant dollars as strong fee income growth more than offset a decline in net interest revenues. Treasury and trade solutions was flat year-over-year as volume in fee growth was offset by the continued impact of spread compression globally
column240:
and securities and fund services revenues were up 5% as higher settlement volumes and fees more than offset lower spreads. Client activity grew across the franchise.

"
column241:
"

Trade loan originations were up 12% year-over-year
column242: average deposits grew 9%
column243:
assets under custody were up 10% and SFS settlement volumes grew by 15%. Despite these volume gains expenses of $1.4 billion declined 3% year-over-year in constant dollars driven by efficiency savings as well as lower and legal related costs. Given the modest revenue growth in expense decline in the fourth quarter transaction services achieved positive operating leverage for the second half of 2013.

"
column244:
"

On Slide 14 we show expense and efficiency trends for the total institutional franchise. On a trailing 12 month basis
column245:
we have lowered our operating expenses every quarter for the past two years driving the total efficiency ratio from 67% in 2011 to 58% in 2013. Compensation has been a significant contributor with the comp ratio for the total institutional franchise improving to 29% in 2013.

"
column246:
"

In securities and banking we have reduced the annual cost base by $1 billion since 2011
column247:
and while we have additional work to do on a full-year basis for 2013 our efficiency ratio in securities and banking was 59% within our 2015 target range of 55% to 60%. And in transaction services the efficiency ratio was 54% somewhat above our 48% to 52% target.

"
column248:
"

However as you can see here we have been able to keep expenses flat at $5.7 billion even as we have gained market share and built significant volumes. This should position us well for margin expansion in the future as we look to continue increasing the C component of our revenues as spreads stabilize and we begin to see the cost savings from repositioning actions taken in 2013.

"
column249:
"

Slide 15 shows the results for corporate other. Revenues were up versus the prior year mainly driven by hedging activities partially offset by lower AFS sales while expenses declined
column250:
mostly reflecting lower legal and related costs. Assets of 314 billion included approximately 116 billion of cash and cash equivalents and 141 billion of liquid available for sale securities.

"
column251:
"

Slide 16 shows Citi Holdings assets. We ended the quarter with assets of 117 billion in Citi Holdings or 6% of total Citigroup assets. The $5 billion reduction in the fourth quarter reflected $4 billion of net pay downs and $1 billion of asset sales. These sales included roughly 400 million of North America mortgages most of which were non-performing.

"
column252:
"

On Slide 17 we show Citi Holdings financial results for the quarter. Total revenues of 1.3 billion were up year-over-year
column253: primarily driven by the absence of rep and warranty reserve builds this quarter. Citi Holdings expenses decreased 4% year-over-year to 1.5 billion
column254: driven by the decline in assets partially offset by higher legal and related costs. Excluding legal costs
column255:
operating expenses declined 16% to roughly 825 million while with North America mortgages comprising over a third of these operating expenses.

"
column256:
"

As I mentioned earlier
column257: yesterday we announced the sale of mortgage servicing rights for loans with a balance of roughly $10 billion. While this is only about 10% of our third party servicing portfolio in Citi Holdings
column258: the sale includes the majority of the delinquent loans we serviced for Fannie Mae
column259:
and it represents nearly 20% of the total loans currently serviced by Citi mortgage that are 60 days or more past due. This sale should benefit our mortgage expenses in Citi Holdings beginning in the second quarter.

"
column260:
"

Net credit losses continued to improved year-over-year and we released 540 million of loans loss reserves
column261:
substantially all of which was related to North America mortgages. Mortgage net credit losses in the fourth quarter included 184 million of incremental charge-offs related to three items.

"
column262:
"

First
column263: a change in charge-off policy for mortgages originated in Citi financial to more closely aligned to policies used in the Citi mortgage business. Second
column264: the acceleration of accounting losses associated with modified home equity loans determined to be collateral dependent. And third
column265:
a change in the estimate of net credit losses related to collateral dependent loans to borrowers that have gone through Chapter 7 bankruptcy. These incremental charge-offs were almost fully offset by related loan loss reserve releases during the quarter.

"
column266:
"

Looking at the past five quarters of Citi Holdings results on Slide 18
column267: excluding legal and related expenses the operating margin in Citi Holdings was positive again this quarter
column268: while credit costs continued to improve. The pre-tax loss in Citi Holdings was roughly 500 million
column269: driven by 647 million of legal and related expenses. Legal and related costs remained elevated during 2013
column270: driven largely by legacy private label securitization and other mortgage related issues. It remains difficult for us to determine the ultimate timing and cost of resolving these issues. However
column271: as we've said previously
column272:
we are hopeful we will have better clarity by sometime this year.

"
column273:
"

On Slide 19
column274: we show North America mortgage trends in Citi Holdings. We ended the quarter with $73 billion of North America mortgages
column275: down 20% from a year ago
column276: while net credit losses declined by 50% and the loss rate improved by roughly 120 basis points. Here
column277: we show the breakdown of residential first mortgages originated in Citi mortgage versus the legacy Citi financial business. As you can see
column278: while loan balances and net credit losses are declining in both portfolios
column279:
the loans originated in Citi financial are becoming a larger proportion of the total.

"
column280:
"

Given the borrower profile in Citi financial
column281: these loans tend to have higher loss rates at around 5% versus the loss rate of around 1% for Citi mortgage first mortgages. We ended the quarter with 4.9 billion of loan loss reserves allocated to North America mortgages and Citi Holdings or 39 months of NCL coverage. Looking at 2014
column282: assuming the U.S. economic environment remains favorable
column283:
we continue to expect to utilize loan loss reserves to offset a substantial portion of our mortgage net credit losses.

"
column284:
"

On Slide 20 we show Citigroup's net interest revenue and margin trends. Net interest revenue grew to $12 billion in the fourth quarter
column285: driven by growth in average interest earning assets and a sequential improvement in margin. Our net interest margin grew by 7 basis points in the fourth quarter
column286:
reflecting lower funding costs as well as stable loan and investment yields. We currently expect our net interest margin in 2014 should be at or around the 285 basis points we achieved in 2013 with fluctuations quarter-to-quarter.

"
column287:
"

On Slide 21 we show our key capital metrics. Quarter-over-quarter
column288: our estimated Basel III Tier 1 common ratio remained roughly flat at 10.5%
column289: as our Tier 1 common capital continued to grow driven by retained earnings and DTA utilization
column290: but our risk-weighted assets also increased by approximately $40 billion. Our DTA utilization this quarter was roughly $600 million bringing our total utilization for the year to roughly 2.4 billion
column291:
approximately 2 billion of which was comprised of foreign tax credit carryforwards.

"
column292:
"

The increase in risk-weighted assets quarter-over-quarter is entirely driven by an increase in our estimated risk-weighted assets associated with operational risks. We continued to further refine and enhance our models under Basel III and given the evolving regulatory and litigation environment
column293: we felt it prudent to increase our operational risks RWA during the quarter. Any changes to operational risks RWA
column294: however
column295:
do not have an impact with calculating our estimated Basel III supplementary leverage ratio which increased to 5.4% in the fourth quarter.

"
column296:
"

As we continue to move towards full Basel III implementation
column297: we expect there could be additional refinements or required enhancements to our Basel III models as well as further regulatory implementation guidance. In addition
column298:
our Basel III modeled remained subject to regulatory review and approval. Any such changes or requirements could result in additional increases in our risk-weighted assets or changes to other elements involved in the calculation of our Basel III ratios.

"
column299:
"

In summary
column300: we clearly faced a difficult environment in the fourth quarter with continued challenging trading conditions and low interest rates. However
column301:
against this backdrop we did make progress on several fronts. Investment banking revenues were strong driven by M&A and equity underwriting. Our consumer business returned to growth quarter-over-quarter driven by Latin America and the Best Buy portfolio acquisition.

"
column302:
"

In Citi Holdings
column303:
we continued to drive towards breakeven and we ended the year with a strong capital position at an estimated Basel III Tier 1 common ratio of 10.5% and a supplementary leverage ratio of 5.4%. On a full year basis we improved on each of our key financial targets with better operating efficiency in Citicorp and higher Citigroup returns on both assets and tangible common equity.

"
column304:
"

Looking forward to 2014
column305: in consumer we expect the low interest rate environment to continue. However
column306: some of the headwinds that affected us in 2013 should abate as we go through the year. In the U.S.
column307: we believe that mortgage revenues have broadly stabilized
column308: while the impact of capacity reductions will result in lower expenses. Branded cards is beginning to show visible improvement and we will benefit from a full year of Best Buy revenues. And for international
column309:
we believe revenues in Korea should begin to stabilize early this year alleviating the drag on Asia while Latin America should continue to grow.

"
column310:
"

Our securities and banking results will likely continue to reflect the overall market environment with a goal of steadily gaining wallet share over time with our target clients. And in transaction services we expect continued volume in fee growth to help offset the ongoing pressure of the low rate environment.

"
column311:
"

Turning to expenses
column312: core operating expenses excluding legal and related as well as repositioning costs were roughly $44.3 billion for full year 2013. Looking forward our goal is to continue improving Citicorp efficiency while winding down the assets and expenses in Citi Holdings. Our core operating expenses will vary with the revenue environment
column313:
but as an example looking at a low single-digit revenue growth scenario in Citicorp.

"
column314:
"

We would expect our core operating expenses in 2014 to come in at or somewhat below the level of 2013 as continued productivity efforts offset by volume related growth investments going to continue to increase in regulatory related expenses. And of course there would be variability quarter-to-quarter
column315:
particularly driven by our markets businesses. Repositioning expenses are expected to remain elevated in the first half of 2014 roughly in line with the levels we incurred in the fourth quarter.

"
column316:
"

Finally
column317: legal expenses which totaled approximately $3 billion for full year 2013 are expected to remain elevated into 2014. In this environment we remain focused on execution. Gaining share with our clients
column318: improving our efficiency
column319:
maintaining our credit discipline and winding down Citi Holdings in an economically rationale manner.

"
column320:
"

And with that
column321:
Mike and I are happy to take any questions.

"
column322:

may be you could talk about where the -- what can you do to get these efficiency targets in \u201915?

John Gerspach

column334: I meant to say if I didn\u2019t say that securities and banking is at least within the range right now
column335: but we do still have more work to do. In transaction services
column336: we\u2019ve been investing in that business and we haven\u2019t had as much repositioning effort necessarily in transaction services as we did in securities and banking during 2013. So I still think that there are things that we can do there
column337:
there are levers that we can pull as you put it going in to 2014.

"

column339: consumer is the one where we didn\u2019t make at least on the reported numbers; we didn\u2019t necessarily make progress during 2013. Consumer is at about 54% efficiency ratio for both 2013 and 2012. There we think that as we begin to get more of a rollout of our drive to common efforts rolling our rainbow and standardizing the platforms for the retail banking and cards businesses. We think then that\u2019s really going to begin to see some more efficiency improvements in consumer. So that is something that you should continue to see
column340:
you should start to see in 2014 and then continue into 2015.

"
column341:
"

John McDonald - Sanford Bernstein

"
column342:
"

Could you remind us on these repositioning expenses
column343:
what are the nature of these and why are they persisting at such a high rate? I think you indicated they might stay in the $250 million range for the first half of the year and then you expect them to come down?

"
column344:
"

John Gerspach

"
column345:
"

Yes
column346: let\u2019s just -- I mean the first half of the year we still think is going to be elevated and when you take a look at what we anticipate
column347: we still needing to do in the first half of the year. We still are looking to reduce our global real estate footprint. We still have facilities that are just larger than we currently need based upon how we\u2019ve been able to reduce headcount and there is still facilities
column348: there is leases that we need to exit. Part of the issue when it comes to real estate John is we can\u2019t just book reserves in advance of exiting the premises. Your reserve has to be taken after or in the same period that you\u2019ve actually left the building and so there would be more of that. We are still in the process of rationalizing our branch network in the U.S. You\u2019ve seen some of the announcements that we\u2019ve made regarding branches in Texas and elsewhere. Again
column349: we can make announcements that we\u2019re closing down the branches
column350: but the repositioning expenses to get out of those branches only happen when we\u2019ve actually left the premises. And as I mentioned as we rollout rainbow and we move towards standard platforms in consumer
column351:
certainly throughout 2014 there is going to be repositioning cost that we take as we continue to streamline the operations. It\u2019s not just about moving on to standard platforms. Now once we move on to standard platforms you want to standardize your processes around -- across the globe. And so that is going to incur some level of repositioning as we move forward. And then we will continue to look at delayering and rational -- rationalization of management structure throughout our businesses.

"
column352:
"

John McDonald - Sanford Bernstein

"
column353:
"

When you talk about getting to the efficiency targets in 2015
column354: that includes repositioning expenses
column355:
right?

column357:
"

Yes. When we\u2019ve given you the targets for 2015
column358:
they have been all inclusive.

"

John Gerspach

column362:
"

Go ahead.

"

And on the ROA and ROE side of the targets

what are the drivers there? Are you relying on a -- I hope that the legal costs come down to get you there or what else can help you get to that \u2013 those profitability goals?

Well
column370:
don\u2019t forget as we continue to improve the efficiency that should improve results in Citicorp and the biggest driving -- one of the big driving factors that I think we\u2019ve mentioned is don\u2019t forget those goals that we laid out for ROA and ROTCE were at the Citigroup level. And so we continue to look to drive Citi Holdings close to breakeven.

was there anything one time-ish about that strong $12 billion NII number that you\u2019re exiting the year at and is there any reason that\u2019s not a good starting point to try to grow off this year?

No John I\u2019m a little cautious always when it comes to trying to forecast out NIM. There is a component of NIM that gets impacted by our trading business and that can have some variability in it. So I think by -- if you think about where we started this year

But obviously if loan yields can improve a bit and if we can continue to lower the cost of our funding profile

"

Right

it seems like that.

thanks.

column426: there is certainly some seasonality involved but I think you have to take a look at a big change in environment that happened first half versus second half this year. When we started out

column788: I wish it was simply as easy as you take an action and you see a result. What happens with operational risk is someone else takes an action and that causes you to really need to add to your operational risk. And then it takes three
column789: five years for that operational risk to eventually kind of wash out. So unfortunately operational risk has a long half life and it's just going to be with us for a while
column790: but getting back to your original question Betsy as far the mortgage sale

column796: 25 times the size of the annual servicing fee for a performing loan. So when -- it may sound like it\u2019s a small sale
column797:

column965: guys. A couple of questions in terms of the regulatory costs that you mentioned in terms of being embedded in that 44 billion plus kind of core run rate

300 million incrementally this year as well. Are those costs that are kind of permanent each year or are we kind of coming to an end in terms of this year at least as far as you can tell that might be the last of it and are those permanent or will those then reverse at some point?

column970: very few of them will reverse. I think that those are just the incremental costs of doing business now for banks and I don't think we're the only bank that's going through that. I don't want to categorically say that 2014 is the last billed in that expense base

column979:

column982:

So I'd say it's a combination of new things as well as I guess what you could say are enhanced expectations on the part of various regulatory bodies as to how you're going to comply with various regulations.

column1132:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Ken Usdin with Jefferies. Please go ahead with your question.

"
column1135: just following on the credit side
column1136:
obviously there has been continued really strong results that have led you to release reserves a little bit above and beyond just four charge-offs. Can you talk about how we can think about the direction of reserve release and do you think it's possible that the overall Citigroup provision could be still down next year over this year?

"
column1138:
"

Let me separate that into two different answers \u2013 actually three
column1139: all right. When you look at the provision
column1140: I think we've already seen in our international consumer business that we're not releasing reserves anymore. As a matter of fact as our portfolios build because we've got the loan growth \u2013 the 8% growth in revenues in Latin America
column1143: you're going to see loan loss reserve build in and we actually had a build of something like $75 million
column1145: in the fourth quarter. So the international consumer has already made that turn. When you look at the U.S. consumer
column1146: there's probably still some level of reserve release to go through in some of our cards business
column1147:
but that is drawing to a close and we'll probably see the end of that sometime in 2014. And then the third piece would be in Holdings. What I would say in Holdings is we anticipate being able to offset the U.S. mortgage NCL \u2013 substantially offset the U.S. mortgage NCLs with continued reserve releases. But I don't see reserve releases over and above the NCLs that we have in the business. As a matter of fact the reserve releases will be probably on an ongoing basis be just slightly less than the NCLs that we're seeing in that U.S. mortgage business and Holdings.

"
column1149:
"

Okay. And the second question just relates to the top line. If we're in a low single-digit revenue growth environment
column1150:
it does seem like there is a better trajectory to be able to grow NII in a year-over-year basis. So I just wondered if I can ask you if you can help us separate. Can you get growth in both NII and on the fee side or what do you think will contribute a greater amount to kind of the overall top line performance?

"
column1153: I do think that you can \u2013 especially if the economy continues to improve and it doesn't have another one of these growth then back off and then growth and then back off and everybody gets concerned again. Even if we can just get the economy moving in a steady direction
column1154: I do think that you can get growth in both NII as well as fee. I don't think \u2013 I'm trying in my mind to figure out whether or not you can actually do a percentage where you get 50% of your growth here and 50% there. But I'll just leave it with the fact that you can grow both. And when it looks \u2013 it's something like our transaction services fees business and our cash business in transaction services
column1155: we're actually focused on moving more of that business away from an NII business and onto a fee-based business. And that's going to be important for us
column1156: because again we're continuing to capture market share in our cash management business and there is just a limit to how much more deposits that we can attract while still trying to keep our overall balance sheet somewhat flat at that $1.9 trillion range or thereabouts. So it's important then as we attract new clients
column1157:
we grow the volumes with existing clients that we move some of that business into fee-based business as opposed to just being paid for it by \u2013 with increasing levels of deposits.

"
column1159:
"

And the last thing then for '14 though
column1160: you think that even with year-over-year tough comp in mortgage banking and whatever of getting out of trading
column1161:
that's a reasonable expectation that there is still a good chance that we can see some fee growth?

"
column1165: I'm thinking about fee growth in transaction services and fee growth in things other than mortgage. Obviously
column1166: the mortgage comp in the first half of the year will be a challenge because as I said the mortgage revenues certainly have stabilized. So if you think in terms of \u2013 from a sequential basis
column1167:
on a sequential basis I do believe that you can see growth in both NII and fees. You're going to be challenged year-on-year with that comparison certainly in the first half of the year.

"
column1176:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Erika Najarian with Bank of America Merrill Lynch. Please go ahead with your question.

"
column1177:
"

Erika Penala Najarian - Bank of America Merrill Lynch

"
column1179:
good afternoon. My questions have all been asked and answered. Thank you.

"
column1184:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Moshe Orenbuch with Credit Suisse. Please go ahead with your question.

"
column1186:
"

I've really only got two things given that I think we're in our second movie to get second box of popcorn at this point. But you talked a lot about the legal costs. Can you talk given that you've settled some things that a number of your peers haven't yet
column1187:
could you talk where these costs are rising from?

"
column1189:
"

Certainly when you take a look at Holdings
column1190:
we've talked about this. Still the single largest piece there would be legacy issues related to private label securitizations and mortgages. And that seems to still \u2013 that certainly is an area that is still out there and there is \u2013 there are a lot of issues surrounding that.

"
column1192:
"

Okay. Just last thing is that you've talked a lot about trying to get Holdings down to breakeven. What about \u2013 I mean if you could structure your transaction with one name that would separate earnings out but would actually create book value
column1193:
would that be of interest or is that not of interest to Citigroup?

"
column1196: we look at it in a few ways. One is what's that the value
column1197: the residual value or the present value of the earnings of that business and can we get paid for that? Second thing is that if somebody's not willing to pay for that
column1198: we've obviously got a good use of that around DTA utilization. And again in that path of getting the essence at one-for-one benefit of Holdings from doing that. We've looked at a number of different structures that could be accomplished there. I think we're open to those but we don't want to find ourselves in a position where we're in essence giving away earnings
column1199: being forced to finance it for a period of time and giving away the upside in the oversight of the business. So if we could accomplish the things we want to accomplish
column1200:
we'd be open to it but we haven't seen that structure yet.

"
column1202:
"

Got it. Just as a comment
column1204: I would just say that selling its discount to tangible book reflects some concern about the book value of that and there is an asset that's clearly undervalued
column1212:
"

Your next question comes from the line of David Hilder with Drexel Hamilton. Please go ahead with your question.

"
column1214:
"

Hi. Thanks very much for your patience. Two unrelated questions. One
column1215:
I assume that some of that increase in regulatory costs is Volcker rule compliant. Do you see any potential exit of businesses or downsizing of businesses as a result of the final Volcker rule?

"
column1217:
"

I think that we've taken the actions that we need to take really associated with Volcker. As far as we already seized proprietary trading activities sometime in 2012
column1218: I think was the last proprietary trading business that we had. As you've seen in various press stories
column1219: we're in the process of winding down our Citi Capital Advisors business which is where we have most of our private equity funds. So we've got both those actions well in hand. As far as your comment or some of those costs related to Volcker
column1221: there are some. I mean the Volcker \u2013 there is a data requirement
column1222: metrics requirement that one would look at and say it's \u2013 I've heard some people describe it as burdensome. I would never use a word like that
column1223:
but there certainly is a data requirement that we\u2019re going to have to gear up for and that we are in a process of gearing up for.

"
column1225:
"

Thank you. And any sense of timing on when you might achieve breakeven for Citi Holdings?

"
column1228: a lot of that again -- as we\u2019ve talked about Citi Holdings
column1229:
the big drag there is around legal. And as we\u2019ve said unfortunately we can\u2019t control our timing in that. We love to continue to get these legacy legal issues behind this as quickly and as practically and as reasonably as possible.

"
column1235:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Matt Burnell with Wells Fargo Securities. Please go ahead with your question.

"
column1236:
"

Matthew Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column1237:
"

Thanks for taking my question. I\u2019ve got a few other follow ups that I'll work on offline. But bigger picture question I want to ask is in terms of the emerging markets trends
column1238: it sounds from your characterization John that you\u2019re a bit more positive about the future trends of economic growth across your emerging markets
column1240: that\u2019s in line with GDP expectations that are more positive for \u201914 and \u201915 than they were for the last couple of years
column1241: and yet investors continue to be concerned about the growth trajectory in the emerging markets. I guess
column1242: I\u2019m just trying to get a sense as to
column1243:
am I hearing you correctly about Citigroup being more optimistic about the growth trends within the emerging markets and what benefit that might have for potential revenue opportunities within transaction services outside of just short rates going up?

"
column1246: it's Mike. I think that you\u2019ve described our economic outlook correctly that I think we see a better world in terms of 2014 than \u201913. I think the overhang or the challenge to that is
column1247: when you go back and you look
column1248: so we\u2019re in a tapering phase and ultimately we\u2019ll be in a policy transition phase around interest rates. Those transitions at least in my history have never happened smoothly. I think the world is in a better place today in terms of the probability of that happening at least smoother around floating rate exchange regimes
column1251: around better external access that these countries have. And so I think as we look at that I think we probably think from a historic basis this transition is probably smoother
column1253: the economies continue to heal. A number of countries from the ways I\u2019ve just described things and in fact you saw this summer really five singled out in terms of concern and again the big concern is the theme around those five with current account deficit. And put away from that I think people felt the transition of the rest of the economies which probably are going to be pretty reasonable. So again
column1254:
I think we\u2019re cautiously optimistic on it and again think that our businesses are well positioned in that transition to take advantage of that growth both from a fundamental basis as well as hopefully from an interest rate basis as well.

"
column1255:
"

Matthew Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column1256:
"

Thanks for taking my question.

"
column1261:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Eric Wasserstrom with SunTrust. Please go ahead with your question.

"
column1262:
"

Eric Wasserstrom - SunTrust Robinson Humphrey

"
column1267:
"

Eric Wasserstrom - SunTrust Robinson Humphrey

"
column1269: how are you. I\u2019ll try to keep it tight. At this point you\u2019re somewhat ahead of the curve with respect to your peer group in terms of Basel III compliance and SLR compliance on both a holding company and bank level. So I\u2019m wondering at this point
column1270: as you look across the international capital and liquidity regimes
column1271:
where are your biggest concerns at this stage and what would you consider to be the binding operational constraint for you?

"
column1274: Eric as we look something that; and you can imagine with our business model something that we\u2019re focused on is around the concept of a level playing field around harmonization. And what makes it difficult for us is
column1277: countries where you\u2019ve just got almost unlimited number of things you\u2019re trying to solve for
column1278:
and so again I think that as we look at our metrics we think not just in the U.S. but globally we\u2019re at standards that serve us well. But again it's around trying to get some of these things lined up so that there is a level of playing field around the world and that there\u2019s actually a level playing field within those jurisdictions and countries between domestic and international institutions.

"
column1279:
"

Eric Wasserstrom - SunTrust Robinson Humphrey

"
column1280:
"

And is there any particular piece of proposed regulation or legislation that is concerning to you with respect to your current capital or liquidity position?

"
column1282:
"

I think the -- we\u2019ve commented on this in the past
column1283: it really is -- its not any individualities
column1284: it's how all the individual pieces actually fit together. And again to Mike\u2019s comments that he made earlier as far as harmonization
column1285: you can take a look at harmonization in one case and say you would like all the different regulatory bodies around the world to sort of view things the same way. But in the same fashion amongst all the different rules
column1286: you would like to see some harmonization as well. You would like to see a little bit perhaps a better interaction between the SLR ratio with the standardized approach with advanced approach
column1288: there is just -- there is a bunch of these things out there and I think they do get harmonized over time
column1289:
but until that happens it makes things a bit challenging.

"
column1290:
"

Eric Wasserstrom - SunTrust Robinson Humphrey

"
column1291:
"

And just so then operationally is CCAR your binding constraint or is it something else?

"
column1293:
"

Well CCAR is certainly a consideration. I mean CCAR becomes a piece of it
column1294: but you still -- you run your business based upon risk returns and your ability to monitor risk through some of the other things that I talked about. I wouldn\u2019t say that CCAR is the ultimate
column1295:
but it becomes the year-end pass/fail test on a few things.

"
column1296:
"

Eric Wasserstrom - SunTrust Robinson Humphrey

"
column1297:
"

And just one quick clean-up question. Citi Holdings is 6% of GAAP assets
column1298:
but what percent of risk weighted assets does it represent at this stage?

"
column1300:
"

It's about 19% of our risk weighted assets.

"
column1301:
"

Eric Wasserstrom - SunTrust Robinson Humphrey

"
column1307:
"

And we have no further questions in the queue at this time. I would like to turn the call back over to management for any closing remarks.

"
column1309:
"

Hi. This is Susan Kendall. Thank you so much for spending so much time with us today. If you have any follow-up questions
column1310:
please reach out to investor relations. Thank you.

"
column1312:
"

Thank you. This concludes today\u2019s conference call. You may now disconnect.

"
