column1:
{"Citigroup's Management Discusses Q4 2013 Results - Fixed Income Investor Review Conference (Transcript)": ["

Citigroup (NYSE:C)

"
column2:
"

Q4 2013 Fixed Income Investor Review Conference

"
column17:
"

Ian Jaffe - RBC Capital Markets

"
column20: and welcome to Citi\u2019s fixed income investor review
column21: with Chief Financial Officer John Gerspach and Treasurer Eric Aboaf. Today\u2019s call will be hosted by Peter Kapp
column22:
head of Fixed Income Investor Relations.

"
column23:
"

We ask that you please hold all questions until the completion of the formal remarks
column24: at which time you will be given instructions for the question-and-answer session. Also
column26: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column28:
"

Mr. Kapp
column30:
"

Peter Kapp

"
column33: and thank you all for joining us. On our call today
column36: will speak first. Then Eric Aboaf
column38: will take you through the fixed income investor presentation
column39: which is available for download on our website
column41:
we\u2019ll be happy to take questions.

"
column42:
"

Before we get started
column43: I would like to remind you that today\u2019s presentation may contain forward-looking statements
column44: which are based on management\u2019s current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results and capital and other financial condition may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors
column45: including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today and those included in our SEC filings
column46: including
column47: without limitation
column48:
the Risk Factors section of our 2012 Form 10-K.

"
column49:
"

With that said
column50:
let me turn it over to John.

"
column52:
"

John Gerspach

"
column55: and good morning everyone. We\u2019re very pleased to be hosting our fixed income investor review this quarter. Eric Aboaf
column57: will review some specifics on our strong balance sheet
column58: liquidity profile
column59: and capital position
column60:
as well as our 2013 issuance activity and current funding plans for 2014.

"
column61:
"

Before I turn it over to Eric
column62: however
column63: there are some key points from our fourth quarter results that I would like to highlight on slide two. 2013 was as challenging as we thought it would be. Low interest rates
column64: changing expectations regular Fed tapering
column65:
and increasing legal settlement costs all had significant impacts on our bottom line.

"
column66:
"

We reported 2013 adjusted earnings of $13.8 billion and fourth quarter adjusted earnings of $2.6 billion. And
column67:
our net interest margin was stable at 285 basis points for the year.

"
column68:
"

However
column69: we continue to make progress on our execution priorities. We improved our operating efficiency and completed the repositioning effort announced in December 2012. We continued to reduce the earnings drag associated with Citi Holdings and put several legacy issues behind us through settlements with Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. And
column70:
we utilized $2.4 billion of our deferred tax assets throughout the year.

"
column71:
"

Our credit quality remains stable
column72: and we\u2019ve maintained our balance sheet around $1.9 trillion. Finally
column73: our capital and liquidity remained strong
column74:
with an estimated Basel III tier one common ratio of 10.5% and high quality liquid assets in excess of $420 billion at the end of the fourth quarter.

"
column75:
"

Turning to slide three
column76: we summarize Citigroup\u2019s financial results for the quarter. On an adjusted basis
column77: we reported $2.6 billion of net income for the fourth quarter of 2013 and $13.8 billion for the year. For the full year
column78: revenues grew 1% while operating expenses were 2% lower and credit costs also declined by over $2.8 billion
column79:
driving earnings growth of 16%.

"
column80:
"

We improved the operating efficiency in Citicorp in 2013
column81: while reducing the net losses in Citi Holdings by nearly half. As a result
column82:
Citigroup returns on both GAAP assets and tangible common equity improved year over year.

"
column83:
"

And with that
column84:
let me turn it over to Eric.

"
column85:
"

Eric Aboaf

"
column86:
"

Thank you
column87: John. Let me start on slide four
column88: with a review of how we\u2019re managing our balance sheet to achieve our business objectives. First
column89: over the past year
column90: we\u2019ve purposely held our total assets at or below $1.9 trillion while adding loans and deposits in a disciplined manner. Second
column91: managing a compact balance sheet has allowed us to maintain our net interest margin
column92: which I\u2019ll discuss more in a moment. And third
column93:
this approach allows us to operate at appropriate levels of leverage and build towards our ROA goals.

"
column94:
"

Overall
column95: on the asset side
column96: net loans grew 3% year over year
column97: and 2% quarter over quarter
column98: as demand from our consumer and corporate customers continues to be supported by the underlying economic recovery
column99:
partially offset by the continued wind down of Citi Holdings.

"
column100:
"

Trading assets [in reverse] and by contrast were down 7% year over year and 4% quarter over quarter as we held less inventory in our markets business. Our counterparties became cautious during the second half of the year as they reacted to news on tapering and possible government default while also positioning themselves for rising interest rates. Cash and investments remained stable in the second half of the year as we maintained a liquid balance sheet.

"
column101:
"

On the liability side
column102: we maintained a diversified
column103: stable
column104: and low cost funding profile. Deposits were roughly half of our balance sheet
column105: up 4% year over year and 1% quarter over quarter
column106: as we maintained deposit pricing discipline. Total long term debt was flat in the second half of the year
column107: consistent with previous guidance. And our equity base grew
column108:
primarily due to retained earnings and preferred stock issuance.

"
column109:
"

On slide five
column110: you can see how our active balance sheet management has helped us maintain a stable net interest margin. In the fourth quarter
column111: net interest margin increased to 288 basis points as loan and investment yields somewhat stabilized and funding costs continued to improve
column112:
with continued reductions in deposit costs as well as a significant reduction in long term debt costs.

"
column113:
"

On a full year basis
column114:
our NIM improved from 282 basis points for 2012 to 285 basis points for 2013. Loan and investment yield declined throughout 2012 and most of 2013 as the low interest rate environment filtered through both floating rate and fixed rate assets.

"
column115:
"

However
column116: our funding costs also declined
column117:
offsetting declining yield. Our deposit costs of 50 basis points this quarter are down 15 basis points year over year with improvement in both our U.S. and international deposit base.

"
column118:
"

We also saw decline in the interest expense associated with our long term debt and more recently a stepwise reduction in long term debt rates of nearly 30 basis points. In particular
column119:
our debt and trust redemptions in the third and fourth quarters targeted higher [unintelligible] securities.

"
column120:
"

In addition
column121: we have increasingly replaced maturing debt with new issuance at more attractive levels
column122:
reflecting both the tightening of our credit spreads and the growing contribution of lower cost debt issued in the securitization market. This slower long term debt cost [is a good step off] for 2014.

"
column123:
"

We currently believe our net interest margin in 2014 should be at or around the full year 2013 level of 285 basis points with some fluctuations quarter to quarter. This should position us well for revenue growth as we add loans and deposits during the year.

"
column124:
"

Turning to slide six
column125: let me summarize our loan growth trajectory. Citicorp loans increased 9% year over year
column126: excluding FX
column127: with growth in both our consumer and corporate loan portfolio. Consumer loans grew 6% year over year. International consumer loan volumes increased 7% year over year
column128: led by double-digit growth in markets such as Mexico
column129: Hong Kong
column130: and India
column131:
offset by our ongoing repositioning efforts in Korea. North America consumer loan growth of 4% year over year included the $7 billion Best Buy portfolio acquisition in the third quarter.

"
column132:
"

"
column133:
"

Corporate loans grew 13% year over year
column134: excluding FX
column135: with 12% growth in Asia
column136: 7% growth in EMEA
column137: and 19% growth in North America
column138: which included the consolidation of a $7 billion trade loan portfolio in the second quarter. Within our corporate segment
column139: private bank loans grew 14% with the greatest growth in Asia and North America. Transaction services loans grew 16% ex FX
column140: with growth in each of our regions
column141:
reflecting strong initiation growth in trade finance throughout the year.

"
column142:
"

Traditional corporate lending balances increased 7% year over year
column143: as we funded previously extended commitments. Going forward
column144:
we expect demand for new loan commitments may remain episodic as many corporates remain highly liquid.

"
column145:
"

Citi Holdings loans decreased 20% year over year
column146: due to $16 billion of runoff and nearly $7 billion of asset sales
column147:
including sales of nearly $2.5 billion from nonperforming mortgages.

"
column148:
"

On slide seven
column149: I\u2019d like to review the credit trends in our Citicorp consumer and corporate loan portfolios globally
column150:
so that you can see how our geographically diversified portfolios that performed over time.

"
column151:
"

The top half of the page illustrates Citicorp\u2019s consumer credit trends across our four regions. In the fourth quarter
column152: total net credit losses declined to 2.39% of the portfolio. We have approximately $11 billion of reserves against this portfolio
column153:
representing 18 months of coincident NCL coverage.

"
column154:
"

Credit remained favorable in North America in the fourth quarter
column155: with a decline in the NCL rate reflecting both underlying improvement as well as the impact of the Best Buy portfolio
column156:
which was acquired late in the third quarter.

"
column157:
"

In Asia
column158: credit trends remained stable. In Latin America
column159: we saw an uptick in NCLs. The higher NCL rate in the fourth quarter primarily reflects the impact of portfolio seasoning in Mexico. Looking to full year 2014
column160:
we currently expect this portfolio seasoning to continue with the NCL rate in Latin America being broadly in the range of the levels we saw in the second half of 2013.

"
column161:
"

The bottom half of the page highlights the quality of our corporate portfolio. Nonaccrual loans as a percentage of corporate loans continued to improve
column162: and as of the end of the fourth quarter
column163:
were approximately 58 basis points for the entire portfolio. Current loan loss reserves allocated to our corporate loan portfolio provided nonaccrual loan coverage of approximately 1.5x.

"
column164:
"

On slide eight
column165: I\u2019d like to provide some additional texture around the international exposures in our loan portfolio. At the top of the page
column166: you can see our consumer business
column167:
where we have tailored our product offerings and geographic footprint to best serve customers who are urban based and globally minded.

"
column168:
"

This segment
column169: which tends to be more affluent and grows faster than the general population in many markets
column170: will be generally more resilient through economic cycles. We provide them with deposits and investment services and also lend to them through a mix of products - credit cards
column171: mortgages
column172:
personal loans - depending on market convention.

"
column173:
"

42% of our consumer loans are in the emerging markets
column174: with the five largest emerging geographies representing 28% of all consumer loans. The largest of our consumer exposures is in Mexico
column175: where we remain constructive on the economic outlook
column176:
and where we have a leading market position.

"
column177:
"

In Korea
column178: our loans have been declining. However
column179: NCLs remain relatively stable at 1.2% for the past year
column180:
even as we have actively repositioned the franchise to focus on achieving higher returns.

"
column181:
"

Singapore
column182: Hong Kong
column183: and India are all showing stable and 70 basis points or less loss rates
column184:
as you can see on slide 28 in the appendix.

"
column185:
"

The bottom half of the page highlights our corporate loan composition. Our clients here are top multinational corporate as well as regional [champions] who value our international network and the breadth and depth of our local capabilities.

"
column186:
"

Many of our institutional relationships begin with our transaction services business
column187: which is why you see a large position in trade finance in both developed and emerging markets. The operating partnerships central to that business also allow us to capture meaningful share of other products
column188: such as foreign exchange
column189: capital markets advisory
column190:
and credit extension.

"
column191:
"

About half of our corporate loans are in the emerging markets. However
column192:
our focus on diversification results in no single emerging market country accounting for more than roughly 5% of our total exposure.

"
column193:
"

We continue to believe that emerging markets GDP growth will outpace developed markets
column194: even though recent EM growth has slowed from what we believe is a more sustainable pace. At the same time
column195: our carefully selected investment grade and affluent oriented target markets
column196: which we also describe on slide 26 in the appendix in more detail
column197:
should leave us less exposed to volatility in these markets.

"
column198:
"

On slide nine
column199: let me shift briefly to the credit trends in North America
column200: the Citi Holdings mortgage portfolio. We ended the quarter with $73 billion of North America mortgages
column201: down 20% from a year ago
column202:
while net credit losses declined by 50% and the loss rate improved by roughly 120 basis points.

"
column203:
"

Here we show the breakdown of residential first mortgages originated in Citi Mortgage versus the legacy Citi financial business. As you can see
column204: while loan balances and net credit losses are declining in both portfolios
column205:
the loans originated in Citi Financial are becoming a larger proportion of the total.

"
column206:
"

The loss rate overall for North America mortgages was 2% for the fourth quarter
column207: down from 3.2% a year ago. The evolving composition of this portfolio partly obscures some of the underlying credit trends. Given the borrower profile in Citi Financial
column208:
these loans tend to have higher loss rates that are around 5% versus a loss rate of around 1% at Citi Mortgage.

"
column209:
"

We ended the quarter with $4.9 billion of loan loss reserves allocated to North America mortgages in Citi Holdings
column210: or 39 months of NCL coverage. Looking to 2014
column211: assuming the U.S. economic environment remains favorable
column212:
we continue to expect to utilize loan loss reserves to offset a substantial portion of our mortgage net credit losses.

"
column213:
"

Turning to slide 10
column214: let\u2019s discuss deposits
column215: which continue to serve as our primary source of funding for our bank. Our overall deposits have grown significantly over the past year
column216: in part reflecting elevated levels of market liquidity and strong corporate balance sheets. Citi\u2019s average deposits grew $27 billion or 4% year over year in constant dollar terms
column217:
even though we had a $26 billion reduction related to the transfer of deposits to Morgan Stanley during the second half of the year.

"
column218:
"

Consumer banking deposits increased 2% ex FX
column219: as 8% growth in consumer checking and savings balances was offset by deliberate reductions in higher cost time deposits. Corporate deposits increased 7% year over year ex FX
column220: as continued strong deposit flows led to 10% growth in transaction services
column221:
notwithstanding our declining deposit pricing during the year.

"
column222:
"

In addition
column223: through pricing actions
column224: we reduced some higher cost deposits from our market counterparties in our securities and banking business
column225: offset by good growth in private banking. Operating account balances increased this quarter to 80% of our total deposits
column226:
as we continue to focus on improving the overall quality of the base.

"
column227:
"

Now let me turn to slide 11
column228: to cover our long term debt
column229: which is the primary source of funding for our parent company
column230: and is also a valuable liquidity management and funding tool for our bank subsidiaries. Over the past years
column231: we\u2019ve significantly reduced our long term debt balances as Citi Holdings assets declined and our deposit base grew. During 2013
column232: we\u2019ve slowed the pace of reductions and the aggregate level of outstanding long term debt. As you can see
column233:
we stabilized at about $221 billion during the second half of the year.

"
column234:
"

During 2014
column235: we expect to maintain our long term debt at approximately these levels
column236: so we may small reductions in parent company debt
column237:
partially offset by small increases in securitization activity at the bank. We have maintained the weighted average maturity of our unsecured debt at approximately seven years to ensure the stability of our longer term debt funding base.

"
column238:
"

As of the end of the year
column239: we had holding company debt
column240: preferred stock
column241: and Basel III tier one common equity equal to 23% of our estimated Basel III liquidated assets
column242: consistent with prior periods
column243:
as we detail on slide 24.

"
column244:
"

While potential regulatory debt requirements have been widely discussed
column245: we don\u2019t yet have clarity around the exact forms or requirements
column246: although we continue to believe we are well positioned to adapt to the proposals being discussed. We will continue to evaluate opportunities to achieve our funding cost
column247: liquidity
column248:
and capital objectives.

"
column249:
"

Slide 12 provides further context for our debt issuance and redemption activity at our parent company. During 2013
column250:
we issued $19 billion of benchmark long term debt as well as $8 billion in structured notes and local country debt. We also exchanged $3 billion of trust preferreds for subordinated debt.

"
column251:
"

In addition to the U.S. dollar
column252: we issued in a range of foreign currencies
column253: euros
column254: Aussie dollars
column255: Japan yen
column256: Norwegian krone
column257: and at maturities ranging from 3 to 30 years
column258:
as we sought to diversify our funding sources and maintain a benchmark funding curve.

"
column259:
"

Combined with our maturities of $31 billion
column260: and buybacks of $12 billion
column261: we had total net redemptions of $15 billion last year. In 2014
column262: we currently expect to issue approximately $20 billion of benchmark long term debt
column263:
consistent with last year. We also expect to issue another $10 billion of structured debt and local country debt.

"
column264:
"

In addition to $25 billion of expected maturities
column265: we also expect to buy back or redeem approximately $10 billion of our debt throughout the year as opportunities arise to replace our higher coupon securities at attractive levels. This would result in approximately $5 billion of total net redemptions at our parent company during 2014. As we have said
column266: the market environment
column267: as well as clarity around NIM and debt requirements
column268: and other regulatory developments
column269:
could alter our outlook.

"
column270:
"

During late 2012
column271: and 2013
column272: we reentered the credit card securitization issuance market as we looked to diversify our funding sources at our bank after a multiyear absence. On slide 13
column273: we outline our recent activities and our expectations for securitizations in 2014. Citi was historically a very active issuer in the securitization markets
column274:
across a range of asset classes.

"
column275:
"

With our rapid deleveraging starting in 2009
column276: we created cash
column277: which in turn was used to fund our routine lending [row] and which temporarily reduced the need for securitizations. During this time
column278: our securitization oustandings declined to $24 billion
column279:
including $20 billion of net redemptions in 2012.

"
column281: we find that credit card back debt is less expensive than our marginal term deposit rate
column282: and helps us manage our liquidity position efficiently. During 2013
column283: we issued $11 billion of securitizations
column284: backed by Citi-branded card receivables. We structured our offerings with a focus on a balanced maturity profile and to respond to our investor preferences. Combined with the approximately $2 billion of maturities
column285: we had $9 billion of net new issuance in 2013
column286:
and we ended the year with outstanding securitizations at our bank of $34 billion.

"
column287:
"

Throughout 2014
column288: we currently expect to issue $10 billion to $12 billion in the securitization market
column289: primarily backed by Citi-branded credit cards. Factoring in $8 billion of securitization
column290: we anticipate net new issuance for the year of $2 billion to $4 billion. Last week
column291:
we issued $850 million of a 7-year fixed rate credit card securitization to kick off our issuance program for the year.

"
column292:
"

On slide 14
column293: I\u2019ll cover the size and composition of our liquidity portfolio
column294:
which is a direct result of our deposit and long term debt funding. We sized our liquidity portfolio to meet our operating needs and to withstand a variety of stress scenarios in addition to satisfying regulatory requirements.

"
column295:
"

As of the end of the fourth quarter
column296: we had $424 billion of high quality liquid assets
column297: somewhat higher than the $410 billion last quarter and an average of approximately $400 billion over the last two years. As we\u2019ve said before
column298:
our HQLA will fluctuate from quarter to quarter.

"
column299:
"

As an example
column300: our HQLA was unusually low in the fourth quarter of 2012
column301: driven by cash outflows and deposits related to the expiration of the [unintelligible] program as well as routine year-end customer balance sheet changes. More recently
column302:
growth in HQLA was driven by continued deposit inflows.

"
column303:
"

Over 80% of our HQLA as of year-end is held in the form of level one assets
column304: cash
column305: U.S. government securities
column306: and high quality foreign sovereigns. Just under 20% is held in level two assets: U.S. agency securities
column307: U.S. agency MBS
column308:
and investment grade debt.

"
column309:
"

As you know
column310: there is a 40% cap on level two securities under the proposed Basel committee liquidity rules
column311: which puts a real constraint on the size of the bank\u2019s agency MBS portfolio. Our level two assets represent less than 20% of our HQLA
column312:
leaving us significant flexibility to optimize our investments for both liquidity and yield.

"
column313:
"

On slide 15
column314: I\u2019d like to discuss our liquidity ratios under various proposed regulations. Under the Basel LCR guidelines
column315: as of year-end 2013
column316: our LCR was 117%
column317: up from 113% in the third quarter and representing a $62 billion liquidity cushion
column318: above the 100% proposed minimum future requirements. Our LCR calculated on this bases increased during the quarter
column319:
principally due to the increase in our HQLA balance and improvements in the mix of our deposits.

"
column320:
"

As you are well aware
column321: the U.S. agency has released a notice of proposed rulemaking in October
column322: which included several changes to the computation of the LCR for U.S. financial institutions. First
column323: the definition of level two assets in HQLA is more limited
column324: especially around investment grade credit. Second
column325: the proposal changed several assumptions regarding the classification of certain deposits
column326: debt buyback requirements
column327:
and certain repo financing.

"
column328:
"

Based on our understanding of these changes under the NPR
column329: we believe we are still in compliance with the proposed minimum requirements. However
column330: there are other aspects to the proposal that are less clear
column331:
and we are working with the industry associations and our regulators to better understand the details.

"
column332:
"

Depending on these discussions
column333: including the formulations of net outflows
column334: and as our regulators finalize the proposal
column335: we expect there could be additional requirements to the proposal
column336: or to our estimate
column337:
particularly resulting from any further clarity regarding implementation.

"
column338:
"

Additionally
column339:
the Basel committee recently released a consultative document with updated guidance regarding the NSFR. We continue to evaluate this guidance relative to our overall liquidity position.

"
column340:
"

There is a lot of detail to review
column341: but our initial estimate of NSFR at year-end is in the 90% to 95% range
column342: and we believe we should be able to close the gap under the revised guidance over the next 12 to 18 months without significant changes to our current plan. Of course
column343: once we complete our analysis of where we are
column344:
we\u2019ll be in a much better position to judge the actions and timeframes needed to close any gaps.

"
column345:
"

Turning to slide 16
column346: let me summarize our capital position
column347: which remains among the strongest in the industry
column348: as compared to both our U.S. and international banking [payers]. Our regulatory capital continued to increase during the fourth quarter
column349: driven by continued growth in retained earnings
column350:
and utilization of an additional $600 million in DTA.

"
column351:
"

However
column352: our estimated risk-weighted assets under the advanced approaches also increased by approximately $40 billion related to operational risk. We continue to further refine and enhance our models under Basel III
column353: and given the evolving regulatory and litigation environment
column354: we felt it prudent to increase our operational [unintelligible] RWA during the quarter. As a result
column355:
our estimated Basel III tier one common ratio under the advanced approaches remained at 10.5%.

"
column356:
"

It also remained slightly lower than our ratio under the standardized approach
column357: making advanced approaches the binding ratio for Citi this quarter. As you know
column358:
we must report the lower of the two ratios.

"
column359:
"

Our estimated SLR under the final U.S. Basel III rules increased to 5.4%
column360: while Citibank\u2019s SLR remained in excess of 6%. As you know
column361: the Basel committee updated their leverage ratio rules last week. Under the prior SLR guidance
column362:
we estimated that the U.S. adoption of the Basel guideline could reduce our SLR by approximately 40 basis points.

"
column363:
"

While we are still refining our estimates under the updated guidance
column364: we currently estimate that the revised Basel proposal could increase our SLR by approximately 10 basis points as compared to the U.S. rules. Of course
column365: this all depends on further analysis and guidance
column366:
as well as action by the U.S. regulators with respect to the Basel committees guidance.

"
column367:
"

Slide 17 shows the composition of our tier one capital under Basel III. On a fully phased-in basis
column368: our estimated Basel III tier one common ratio is 10.5%
column369: and our estimated tier one capital is 11.1%
column370: both of which are in excess of the expected minimum. Once the capital ratio rules are fully phased in
column371:
we would expect to hold up to 150 basis points in the category of additional tier one.

"
column372:
"

As of now
column373: we estimate that our additional tier one capital amounts to 70 basis points of RWA
column374: meaning we are nearly halfway to filling the additional tier one bucket. To reach the 150 basis points of additional tier one by 2019
column375:
we would need to issue approximately $10 billion of additional preferred stock over the next four to five years.

"
column376:
"

With our tier one common position currently in excess of the required levels
column377: and given the remaining time to final implementation in 2019
column378:
we believe we can issue preferred stock at a measured pace to reach our desired capital structure.

"
column379:
"

Our estimated SLR is above the proposed U.S. regulatory requirements. We believe that continued growth in our common equity position
column380: as well as modest issuance of preferreds
column381:
should provide ample cushion to this regulatory capital measure.

"
column382:
"

On slide 18
column383: let me comment on how we have positioned our balance sheet to respond to a range of interest rate scenarios. Our intention is to benefit from a rise in rates while limiting the impact of changes in AOCI on our regulatory capital position. As the economic conditions have improved since 2010
column384: we have adjusted our interest rate position progressively
column385:
with a goal of meaningful net interest revenue growth as rates begin to rise.

"
column386:
"

On the right side of the page
column387: we show how net interest revenues and AOCI would change in several different interest rate scenarios. At the top of the table
column388: you see that if interest rates were to increase by 100 basis points in a parallel shift
column389: we estimate our net interest revenue would increase by $1.8 billion over the first year
column390:
or an 11 basis point benefit to NIM as our assets would reprice faster than our liabilities.

"
column391:
"

In this scenario
column392: we estimate that our AOCI would decline by approximately $3.1 billion after tax
column393: reflecting a decline in the value of our securities portfolio
column394:
partially offset by a benefit related to our pension plan. The net effect of this change in our AOCI equates to a decline of approximately 36 basis points in our Basel III tier one common ratio.

"
column395:
"

Now for two other interest rate scenarios. If overnight rates were to rise by 100 basis points
column396: with proportionately smaller changes at longer maturity
column397:
we estimate that our net interest revenue would also increase by $1.8 billion in the first year.

"
column398:
"

Alternatively
column399: if the 10-year Treasury yield were to rise by 100 basis points
column400: with shorter maturities making proportionately smaller rate moves
column401: our first year benefit in net interest revenue would be only $100 million
column402: based on this static balance sheet analysis. If
column404: we decided to adjust our investment portfolio duration after such a rate rise
column405:
that could meaningfully increase the contribution to earnings.

"
column406:
"

While rising rates have the ability to reduce our Basel III regulatory capital ratios through AOCI
column407: we would expect to recover the AOCI through both increased revenue and accretion of our investment portfolio as they roll down the curve
column408:
and in approximately 18 months.

"
column409:
"

Moving to our last line
column410: let me summarize four major points. First
column411: while the environment remains challenging
column412: we continue to make progress on our execution priorities. Second
column413: our credit trends remain favorable
column414: reflecting the high quality of both our consumer and corporate portfolios. We manage our balance sheet efficiently
column415:
which contributed to stable net interest margin of 285 basis points for the full year.

"
column416:
"

Third
column417: during 2013 we continued to optimize our funding profile
column418:
with programmatic issuance of both benchmark debt and securitizations to support the operating needs of our parent and bank. Our 2014 funding plans are consistent with our 2013 actions.

"
column419:
"

Fourth and lastly
column420: our liquidity reserves and capital base remained among the strongest in the industry
column421: as reflected in our regulatory metrics. During the fourth quarter
column422:
Moody\u2019s and S&P acknowledged our progress by upgrading our standalone rating.

"
column423:
"

That concludes our fixed income review. John and I would be happy to take your questions.

"

One last one

I think the second part of that discussion tends to be how quickly do we want to issue preferred. On the other hand

The U.S. rule impact we\u2019ve done in aggregate so far. To be honest
column585: I don\u2019t know if you\u2019ve flipped through
column586: it\u2019s 118 pages. So we\u2019ve done the aggregate assessment for the impact of the 117
column587: we feel like we\u2019re still in compliance
column588: so above the minimum requirement in aggregate. I\u2019ve not done
column589: to be honest
column590: the bank dealer parent split
column591:
but we think that we\u2019d be within the range of where we need to be. We don\u2019t run with particularly large amounts of excess liquidity in one entity that funds another entity. And so we should be within the range of generally where we need to be.

"
column592:
"

David [McGowan] - Morgan Stanley

"
column594:
"

And you mentioned the cap on level two assets. Looking at your disclosures versus some of your peers
column595: you have relatively high cash balances
column596: and you teased out agency RMBS. Even with that cap
column597:
you have pretty low agency balances. Do you think there\u2019s room to optimize and generate some growth in NII as you do that?

"
column598:
"

Eric Aboaf

"
column599:
"

I do think there is some room. I think the question is when and how
column600: to be honest. If you think about it
column601: there are some banks out there with very large agency MBS portfolios that are way above the 40% cap
column602: [over the need to divest]. I think we\u2019re in the opposite situation. We\u2019ve got a pretty diversified set of assets. Like you say
column603:
we have a lot of cash. You can see that on page 14. And we have a modest sized agency MBS portfolio.

"
column604:
"

The challenge in a rising rate environment is that agency MBS are very tough to run
column605: because you have an extension risk there
column606: you\u2019ve got a fair amount of [unintelligible] exposure that you need to be careful about
column607: in particular without asset class. So if you\u2019re looking for us to change the [side] of that portfolio tomorrow
column608:
I don\u2019t think that really makes a lot of sense.

"
column609:
"

But over the next few years
column610: and as rates move up to different levels and maybe stabilize at some levels
column611: it\u2019s a natural asset class for us
column612: or for any bank
column613: to continue to invest in. And like you said
column614: we have cash. Ultimately
column615:
it will be a choice around rates and value of relative asset classes that we\u2019ll make at the time.

"
column617:
"

Your next question comes from the line of James Strecker with Wells Fargo.

"
column618:
"

James Strecker - Wells Fargo

"
column619:
"

Last week
column620: BofA
column621: [unintelligible] at issuing senior bank debt out of the bank
column622: more so to help with any LCR compliance at the opco versus cost of funding advantage in [unintelligible] terms
column623:
etc. Is that part of the matrix that you guys have evaluated potential issuance out of? Or are you not concerned with that?

"
column624:
"

Eric Aboaf

"
column626:
our LCR is very healthy for the aggregate company at 117% and above the requirement for the bank. So we\u2019re in good shape. We don\u2019t need to do anything particularly strenuous or different in the bank on a go-forward basis.

"
column627:
"

I think if we were to continue to think about diversifying our funding sources
column628: which we\u2019re always looking to do
column629: I\u2019d kind of look at the tiering of economics
column630: because in the end we\u2019d want to do that at the lowest possible cost
column631: to get the best kind of tenure construction. And we\u2019re still back to deposits tend to be the lowest cost
column632: and after that
column633: it\u2019s securitizations
column634:
which is why you\u2019ve seen us [unintelligible] back into a modest and relatively important program in that asset class.

"
column635:
"

After that
column636: we don\u2019t really see the need for unsecured at the bank
column637: and we\u2019re not necessarily going to go in that direction
column638: obviously
column639: unless some regulatory rules change
column640:
or for some other reason. But we don\u2019t see the motivation.

"
column642:
"

Switching gears a little bit
column643:
you mentioned potentially holding up to 150 basis points above the [unintelligible] risk weighted assets in preferreds. There\u2019s some caution or consideration on our side about how much of the tier one common buffers that everybody will presumably run with would count towards that bucket too. Is it feasible that you could ultimately have a point or maybe a point and a quarter versus the full 150 basis points? Or do you think you would optimize that to the full 150 basis points over time?

"
column644:
"

Eric Aboaf

"
column646: but one that I think is hard to answer today. I think over time we\u2019re going to get more regulatory guidance
column647: either formally or informally
column648: as an industry
column649: which is it really should be filled with preferreds or using common
column650: maybe a very acceptable alternative. And then obviously we\u2019re going to have to continue as a firm
column651: at our end
column652: to do the optimization of can we earn
column653: for the marginal amount of equity
column654: enough returns to offset the preferred dividend
column655: which we typically can. And that would encourage us then to return common equity to shareholders and then to have that bucket more closely align with a point and a half of preferreds. But I think time will tell
column657:
and obviously we\u2019ll address it over the next few years.

"
column658:
"

James Strecker - Wells Fargo

"
column659:
"

And I guess we could apply that same answer to 2% risk-weighted assets and subdebt
column660:
[unintelligible]?

"
column663:
"

James Strecker - Wells Fargo

"
column664:
"

And last but not least
column665: you had mentioned some of the things you think you\u2019re hearing and we\u2019ve opined on some of the things we think we know about OLA. Any color on whether you feel there could be a specific sub hold co requirement that comes out of the rules? Or are you just in the same bucket like everybody else
column666:
waiting for the rules?

"
column668:
"

We\u2019re in the bucket of everyone else
column669: and just waiting to see the rules. And when they come
column670:
we\u2019ll obviously try to interpret it as quickly as possible and comment for you.

"
column672:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Ryan O\u2019Connell with Morgan Stanley.

"
column673:
"

Ryan O\u2019Connell - Morgan Stanley

"
column674:
"

John
column675: on the earnings call
column676: you referred a couple of times to moving toward breakeven in Citi Holdings. Now
column677: we all know there are a lot of moving parts there
column678: but have you indicated a timeframe when you think Citi might achieve that? Are you thinking 2015
column679:
or something earlier?

"
column680:
"

John Gerspach

"
column681:
"

When we laid out the original targets for 2015
column683: both as far as achieving the efficiency ratios that we laid out
column684: but importantly
column685: as far as achieving the minimum return on assets of between 90 and 110 basis points for all of Citigroup
column686:
getting holdings closer to breakeven was clearly a part of that planning.

"
column687:
"

So we never said
column688: and I wouldn\u2019t say
column689: that in 2015 we will have holdings at breakeven. But
column690: that is clearly the path that we\u2019re going down. So if you take a look at 2012 compared to 2013
column691:
in that one-year span we cut the holdings losses by about half. So we\u2019ve made some good progress as far as getting holdings closer to breakeven.

"
column692:
"

Obviously there still is a ways to go
column693: but we do have two years to do it in. And ultimately
column694: what is going to drive that
column695: and we laid it out in a four-panel chart as part of that earnings presentation
column696: it\u2019s really going to be dependent on how quickly we can drive down the legacy legal costs. That
column698:
is the big driver in that.

"
column699:
"

Ryan O\u2019Connell - Morgan Stanley

"
column700:
"

And my second question is
column701: and we touched on international a bit before
column702: but international consumer. And there too I guess there are a couple of cross currents. On the other hand
column703: as you\u2019ve indicated
column704: [unintelligible] is stabilizing
column705: so at least my sense is
column706: overall
column707: that should help the pressure on the revenues in Asia. On the other hand
column708: you\u2019re getting good loan growth in Latin America
column709:
you\u2019re building reserves rather than leasing reserves.

"
column710:
"

So here\u2019s what I\u2019m trying to sort out
column711: if we look at international consumer banking earnings on a reported basis
column712: they were down about 10% for the full year. But if we exclude the effect of loan loss reserve releases
column713: as you pointed out
column714:
they\u2019re actually about 2% for the year.

"
column715:
"

So is it fair to assume that we should not think about material loan loss reserve releases in the future
column716: and then secondly
column717: that by the same token the effect of the past reserve releases ought to be tapering off? And I don\u2019t know what guidance you\u2019re prepared to give on this
column718: but in terms of a reasonable expectation for international consumer
column719: it\u2019s a big business for you all
column720:
low single digits growth? Is that realistic?

"
column722:
"

Well
column723: we\u2019ve never really laid out the growth targets from a net income point of view
column724: and nor do we usually give forward guidance. But your observations are pretty spot on. The way I look at the international consumer right now
column725: we have
column726: for the most part
column727: moved past reserve releases in the international consumer business. And so in thinking about that business on an ongoing basis
column728: it should be one that is driven by ultimately
column729: once we get past the stabilization of Korea
column730: it\u2019s a business that should be driven by the drivers
column731:
to be simple about it.

"
column732:
"

You know
column733: you should actually see
column734: as we grow the loans
column735: you should anticipate - and again it depends on the interest rate environment in each of the countries - that those loans should generate additional revenue
column736:
we should get net interest revenue off of the loans. Obviously the active management fees and the wealth management part of the business will be a little bit dependent on market environment. But you should see revenue growth along with loan growth.

"
column737:
"

Along with the loan growth
column738: then
column739: you\u2019re going to see some need to build reserves
column740: because as the portfolios grow
column741: we will need to increment the reserves
column742: not because of declining credit quality
column743: but just because the portfolios are expanding. And then as we\u2019re doing that
column744: we will grow those loan portfolios
column745:
again with the same credit discipline that we\u2019ve been showing.

"
column746:
"

So you can make your own assessment as to where the NCL rates are going
column747: but we\u2019ve given some near term guidance that certainly looking out into 2014
column748: we see that as somewhat stable as to where we\u2019ve been. So the NCLs should be somewhat stable
column749: loan loss reserves will need to grow in association with the growth in the portfolios
column750:
but that growing portfolio should produce expanding net interest.

"
column751:
"

Operator

"
column752:
"

Your next question comes from the line of [Pre De Silvo with Credit Suisse [ph]].

"
column753:
"

[Pre De Silvo - Credit Suisse [ph]]

"
column754:
"

If you turn to slide 12
column755: the $20 billion of benchmark debt that you plan to issue this year
column756:
does that include any preferred stock? Or is that not part of this equation?

"
column757:
"

Eric Aboaf

"
column758:
"

On page 12
column759: and I think the corresponding page would be page 11
column760: where we have the stacked long term debt
column761:
we\u2019re only capturing the debt structure. The preferred stock is obviously an equity account instrument.

"
column762:
"

[Pre De Silvo - Credit Suisse [ph]]

"
column763:
"

And then if you turn to slide 17
column764: the comments you made about up to $10 billion - I think in my calculation it came closer to $11 billion - of potential preferred [unintelligible] issue
column765:
just want to make sure that does not include any changes in RWA?

"
column766:
"

Eric Aboaf

"
column767:
"

That\u2019s right. The estimate we gave was based on the existing RWA. We did that because RWAs have actually been relatively flattish over the last year
column768: within a band. And we don\u2019t expect a lot of growth
column769:
and so we thought that would be the simplest way to do the estimate for you.

"
column771:
"

Operator

"
column772:
"

Thank you. That concludes the question and answer session. Mr. Kapp
column773:
do you have any closing remarks?

"
column774:
"

Peter Kapp

"
column775:
"

Thank you
column777: for joining the call today. If you have any follow up questions
column778:
please don\u2019t hesitate to reach out to us in investor relations. We\u2019ll talk to you again next quarter.

"

column1:
{"Citigroup's (C) Q1 2015 Results - Fixed Income Investor Review (Transcript)": ["

Citigroup Incorporated (NYSE:C)

"
column2:
"

Q1 2015 Fixed Income Investor Review

"
column7:
"

Peter Kapp - Head of Fixed Income IR

"
column13:
"

Gerard Cassidy - RBC Capital Markets

"
column16:
"

John McDonald - Sanford C. Bernstein

"
column27: and welcome to Citi's Fixed Income Investor Review with Chief Financial Officer
column28: John Gerspach. Today's call will be hosted by Peter Kapp
column29:
Head of Fixed Income Investor Relations.

"
column30:
"

We ask that you please hold all questions until the completion of the formal remarks at which time you will be given instructions for the question-and-answer session. Also
column32: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column38: Tiya. Good morning and thank you all for joining us. On our call today
column40: John Gerspach will take you through the Fixed Income Investor presentation
column41: which is available for download on our Web site
column42: citigroup.com. Afterwards
column43:
I will be happy to take questions joined by Deputy Treasurer Joe Bonocore. Unfortunately our other Deputy Treasurer Loretta Moseman was unable to join us this morning.

"
column44:
"

Before we get started
column45: I would like to remind you that today's presentation may contain forward-looking statements
column46: which are based on management's current expectations
column47: and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results and capital and other financial conditions may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors
column48: including the precautionary statements referenced in our own discussion today
column49: and those included in our SEC filings
column50: including
column52:
the Risk Factors section of our 2014 Form 10-K.

"
column54:
let me turn it over to John.

"
column57: Peter and good morning everyone. We are pleased to be hosting our Fixed Income Investor Review this quarter. I would like to begin by highlighting some key points from our first quarter 2015 results on Slide 2. Last week we reported a strong quarter earning 4.8 billion while making continued progress on our execution priorities. U.S. consumer banking performed well with growth in the retail bank. International consumer revenues were flat but loans
column58: deposits and purchase sales all continued to grow and we expect some of the headwinds in that business to abate as we go through the year. Our institutional businesses performed solidly with revenue growth in investment banking
column59: corporate lending
column60: security services and the private bank. And while parts of our fixed income business saw a slow start to the year
column61:
our rates and currencies franchise continue to see strong client activity.

"
column62:
"

Citi Holdings remained profitable again this quarter and we reduced its assets by 19% from a year earlier to $122 billion. Over the past few months we have made great progress towards divesting businesses in Citi Holdings
column63: including the announced sales of our consumer businesses in Japan
column64: Peru and Nicaragua
column65:
as well as OneMain financial. We expect these sales to close this year totaling roughly $32 billion of assets and we have several other active sales processes underway. Also we utilized 1.2 billion of deferred tax assets.

"
column66:
"

We continue to manage our balance sheet carefully
column67: growing loans and deposits in Citicorp
column68: while improving our net interest margin from last year. We continue to reduce funding costs and strengthen liquidity by increasing the quality of our deposits and optimizing our debt outstanding and our capital
column69:
leverage and liquidity ratios remained strong.

"
column70:
"

On Slide 3 we show total Citigroup results adjusted for the items noted on the slide. As I noted earlier
column71: during the quarter we earned $4.8 billion generating a return on assets of 105 basis points and a return on tangible common equity of 11%. Net income grew by over $660 million year-over-year with about one-third coming from core improvement in Citicorp and two-thirds attributable to lower legal and related expenses in Citi Holdings. Revenues declined on a reported basis to 19.8 billion but increased slightly year-over-year in constant dollars driven by 2% growth in Citicorp. Expenses declined 10 year-over-year mostly reflecting the lower legal and repositioning charges
column72:
as well as a benefit from FX translation. Our first quarter results provide a solid start to 2015. Better demonstrating our underlying earnings power and the impact of the actions we've taken to simplify and streamline our operations.

"
column73:
"

On Slide 4 we show trends in our balance sheet. We manage our balance sheet to optimize returns
column74: while also adapting to current and expected regulations. On a reported basis our total assets declined by $10 billion in the quarter and over $60 billion in the past year. As a result of the dollars\u2019 continued appreciation against foreign currencies especially the euro
column75: Mexican peso and yen. To provide more meaningful insights into our underlying business trends
column76: we have presented this slide and several others in today\u2019s presentation on a constant dollar basis. On this basis
column77:
we have held our total assets around 1.8 trillion over the past five quarters.

"
column78:
"

Net loans and deposits in Citicorp each grew 3% year-on-year across our businesses. Offset by the continued wind down of Citi Holdings. Trading assets and liabilities also increased during the year
column79:
driven impart by increased volatility in OpEx and rates markets which led to increases in both our derivative assets and derivatives liabilities. We reduced short-term borrowings by nearly $20 billion in the core. In response to continued growth in high quality deposits and our long-term debt declined driven mainly by reductions of non-TLAC eligible securities.

"
column80:
"

Slide 5 shows the trends in our loan portfolio. In constant dollars total Citigroup loans decreased 3% year-over-year as 2% growth in Citicorp was offset by significant reductions in Citi Holdings. Consumer loans grew 1% year-over-year with broad based growth driving a 3% increase in international consumer loans. Corporate loans grew 4% year-over-year. Traditional corporate loans in private bank volumes increased while TTS loans declined 10%
column81: spread compression in trade especially in Asia
column82:
led us to reduce our on balance sheet loans while we continue to support new origination for our clients. Citi Holdings loans decreased 35% year-over-year driven by a $17 billion reduction in North America mortgages as well as the reclassification of $10 billion of loans to held-for-sale related to our announced agreements to sell OneMain and the Japan credit card business.

"
column83:
"

On Pages 23 and 24 of the appendix
column84: we have updated information on our corporate credit portfolio including our energy exposures. Our total energy exposures are now $58 billion down modestly from year-end and funded loans to the energy industry was stable at nearly 22 billion
column85: or roughly 3% of Citigroup's total loans. While we did see some ratings downgrades during the quarter 82% of our energy portfolio remains investment grade in line with our overall corporate credit exposures
column86: reflecting our strategy of focusing on large cap multinationals. As a result of market developments and these downgrades
column87:
we build reserves against our energy exposures by approximately $100 million in the quarter. But we realized no material NCLs against the energy sector. While we are building reserves we continue to believe that our risk is well contained and we continue to expect any losses we may incur to be manageable.

"
column88:
"

On Slide 6 we show continued stability in our consumer and corporate credit trends. In the first quarter consumer credit remains favorable with a net credit loss rate of 222 basis points. In North America and Asia trends remain stable to improving and in Latin America the NCL rate increased somewhat from last quarter on a normalized basis. However
column89:
the delinquency rate in that region continued to improve which we expect to result in lower NCL rates later in the year. Our corporate portfolio also continues to see favorable credit performance. Non-accrual loans improved slightly to 40 basis points of corporate loans.

"
column90:
"

Turning to Slide 7 we show our deposit composition. Citicorp deposits grew 3%
column91: with high quality deposit flows across our franchise. Consumer deposits increased 2% driven by 5% growth in international markets. North America deposits were flat year-over-year even as we closed or sold roughly 175 branches over that period representing nearly 20% of our branch footprint. Corporate deposits increased 6% year-over-year as we saw continued high quality deposit growth
column92:
particularly in North America while at the same time we constrained flows of deposits with higher expected runoff rates under the LCR. Citi Holdings and other deposits declined significantly year-over-year mainly due to the agreement to sell our Japan retail bank which resulted in the reclassification of $21 billion of deposits to held-for-sale last year as well as the continuing transfer of MSSB deposits.

"
column93:
"

Slide 8 demonstrates the diversity and stability of our deposit franchise. A deposit base is geographically diverse and provides attractive local funding as we seek to match assets and liabilities by currency in each of our markets. Over 55% of our deposits are outside the U.S. We continue to work to improve deposit quality under the LCR. Our bankers understand the importance of growing higher quality deposits and working with clients to reduce lower quality deposits.

"
column94:
"

In our Consumer business our deposits which the LCR tends to value more highly have consistently had an 87% LCR liquidity value over the past year and in the Corporate business we have increased the liquidity value of deposits to approximately 66% over the past year by reducing 100% runoff balances such as non-operating deposits from financial institutions and by favoring higher LCR value deposits such as corporate operating deposits. Overall
column95:
Citigroup\u2019s deposits have a 73% liquidity value under the LCR up modestly over the past year.

"
column96:
"

On Slide 9
column97: we show Citigroup\u2019s net interest revenue and margin. Net interest revenue in constant dollars increased 2% year-over-year and net interest revenue per day seen below the bars has continued to increase steadily. Our net interest margin remained flat sequentially at 292 basis points in the first quarter and was up slightly from a year ago on improved funding cost. In the second quarter we expect our net interest margin to decline perhaps by 2 to 3 basis points
column98:
similar to the trend we\u2019ve seen in prior years.

"
column99:
"

Looking to the second half of the year
column100: our results will depend impart on the timing of divestitures including the OneMain and our Japan Retail business. We estimate that without these businesses on a combined basis
column101: our net interest margin would be lower by roughly 7 to 8 basis points
column102: before using any part of the associated gains to redeem high cost debt. As you can see on Slide 31 in the appendix
column103:
we continue to expect a NIM benefit from a rising rate environment. We estimate that 100 basis point parallel rate shock would increase our net interest revenue by 1.9 billion over the first year for a potential NIM benefit of 12 basis points similar to recent quarters.

"
column104:
"

On Slide 10
column105: we show the composition of our long-term debt outstanding. During the quarter
column106: our long-term debt declined by 12 billion to 211 billion. Bank issued debt accounted for 6 billion of the reduction
column107: as deposits increased we reduced our FHLB advances and securitizations outstandings at the bank. We now expect to issue less than $5 billion of securitizations for the year. We expect to continue to support this valuable program through a periodic issuance
column108: but as we do not expect securitizations to count towards TLAC
column109: we will likely reduce this balance overtime. Parent company debt declined by 6 billion during the quarter
column110: mainly reflecting the reclassification of OneMain as held-for-sale
column111:
senior and subordinated unsecured parent debt were broadly stable in the quarter. We currently expect to end the year with total parent company long-term debt of roughly $160 billion.

"
column112:
"

In addition to long-term debt we increased our total preferred stock outstanding to $14 billion including our offering earlier this week. As a result
column113:
preferred stock now provides nearly 110 basis points of additional Tier 1 capital.

"
column114:
"

On Slide 11
column115: we update our issuance and redemption expectations for long-term debt in 2015. In 2015
column116: we continue to expect to issue 20 billion to 25 billion of benchmark debt of which we issued $7 billion during the first quarter including offerings in dollars and euros. We offered an additional $5 billion yesterday toward our issuance expectations for the year. Year-to-date in addition to $5 billion of maturities
column117: we have reduced long-term debt by 8 billion reflecting $3 billion of buybacks of benchmark debt as well as the impact of our agreement to sell OneMain. For the balance of the year we expect additional redemptions of $4 billion to $5 billion of benchmark debt. We expect the combination of new issuance
column118:
maturities and redemptions to result in an increase on our long-term debt of approximately $5 billion for the year.

"
column119:
"

So far in 2015
column120:
we have issued $3.5 billion of preferred stock including the $2 billion earlier this week. We will remain opportunistic around market conditions and currently expect to issue an additional $2 billion or so of preferred in the second half of 2015. As we continue to build towards 150 basis points of additional Tier 1 capital.

"
column121:
"

On Slide 12
column122:
we update our estimates of our total loss absorbing capacity based on the FSB\u2019s November consultative document and our ongoing discussions with regulators and other industry participants. Comment letters recently submitted to the FSB focused on the proper calibration and implementation of TLAC requirements. Specifically discussions continue to focus on the appropriate level of required TLAC to achieve targeted policy objectives and the kinds of instruments that will qualify as loss absorbing capital. Comment letters also saw clarification with respect to internal TLAC requirements and their structure and made suggestions to improve the workability of the pending proposal.

"
column123:
"

However
column124: since November we have had no formal proposals or feedback as to our regulators stance on these issues. Accordingly
column125: consistent with our prior estimates
column126: we include CET1 capital
column127: preferred stock and unsecured parent issued senior and subordinated debt with at least one-year remaining until maturity as well as a small portion of our customer related debt in our estimates of TLAC. We estimate Citigroup's total loss absorbing capacity increased to $270 billion
column128:
including the recent preferred issuance or 21% of our risk weighted assets and over 11% of our total leverage exposure. We calibrate this 21% against potential requirements of 20.5% to 26.5% depending on the base TLAC requirement of 16% to 20% combined with our potential GSIB surcharge. We continue to await formal regulatory guidance or rules.

"
column129:
"

On Slide 13
column130: we address potential strategies for meeting TLAC requirements once rules are established. Our plans to meet potential TLAC requirements include actions to optimize our capital structure around other regulatory requirements
column131: as well as those specifically targeting TLAC needs. First
column132: we will meet our CET1 Tier 1 capital and total risk based capital requirements through an efficient capital structure
column133: which implies issuance of $4 billion to $6 billion of additional preferred stock and $8 billion to $10 billion of subordinated debt by the end of 2018. Second
column134: while the FSB proposal excluded structured notes
column135:
we are working with regulators and industry groups to address concerns cited as reasons for their exclusion.

"
column136:
"

With some revisions to the proposed requirements we may be able to increase the TLAC eligible component of this program
column137: potentially providing as much as $20 billion of benefit. We would then generate additional loss absorbing capacity
column138: if necessary by increasing issuance of TLAC eligible senior debt
column139: while reducing our use of other funding sources
column140: such as securitizations or repo to maintain our balance sheet efficiency. The right side of the slide illustrates one potential approach to addressing a hypothetical TLAC need. Assuming a TLAC requirement of at the midpoint of the FSB range or 18% of risk weighted assets and a 4% GSIB surcharge we would face a total requirement of 24.5% of risk weighted assets or roughly $315 billion. As indicated on the prior page
column141: we currently estimate our available TLAC at $270 billion
column142:
leaving a remaining need of $45 billion.

"
column143:
"

For the current CET1 ratio of 11%
column144: we would expect to retain $6 billion of additional CET1 as a buffer against ratio of volatility. We could issue 4 billion of preferred stock and $8 billion of subordinated debt and in this example we assume we could modify $10 billion of structured notes to qualify as TLAC. That leaves $17 billion of incremental senior debt issuance through 2018 or approximately $5 billion incremental per year. By issuing in multiple currencies
column145: we can diversify our funding base and better align the currency profile of our debt with our risk weighted assets. In summation
column146: we believe that we have a number of alternatives for addressing TLAC
column147:
but we need to see proposed rules.

"
column148:
"

Turning to Slide 14
column149: let me summarize our capital position
column150: which remains among the strongest in the industry. During the quarter
column151: our fully phased in CET1 capital ratio increased approximately 40 basis points to 11%
column152: driven by our retained earnings and approximately $1.2 billion of DTA utilization. Despite the dollars\u2019 significant appreciation FX had no impact on the CET1 ratio during the quarter. Under transition arrangements our CET1 capital ratio increased by only 20 basis points to 13.3%
column153: as our capital generation was partially offset by the phase in of increased capital divestitures. Our supplementary leverage ratio grew to 6.4% driven by strong capital generation and preferred stock issuance
column154:
as well as the decline in our leverage exposure. Citi Bank\u2019s SLR also increased in the quarter to 6.6%.

"
column155:
"

On Slide 15 we update our liquidity position. Our LCR under the U.S. rules is 111% in excess of the 100% minimum requirement. HQLA declined modestly to remain just over a 400 billion
column156:
while our improved deposit quality contributed to a modest reduction of our estimated outflows. We continue to expect the U.S. regulators to propose a U.S. version of the net stable funding ratio in 2015. We believe as we remain in compliance with the International NSFR.

"
column157:
"

Moving to our last slide let me summarize four major points. First
column158: we reported solid results in the first quarter with modest revenue growth and positive operating leverage in Citicorp. We made continued progress towards winding down Citi Holdings and we utilized an additional $1.2 billion of DTAs. Secondly
column159:
we have actively managed our balance sheet maintaining total assets around 1.8 trillion and optimizing our assets and liabilities to support client needs and improved returns. Credit trends remained favorable across both our consumer and corporate portfolios and we have managed our funding cost to maintain a stable net interest margin.

"
column160:
"

Third
column161:
our deposit base remains a key strength as we continue to prioritize high quality deposits. Our 2015 issuance plans are on-track to support our operations and position us to adapt to regulatory changes including preparations for formal guidance related to TLAC and lastly we have continued to prepare our business and balance sheet for the ongoing evolution of the regulatory environment. Our capital and liquidity remains strong.

"
column162:
"

This concludes our fixed income review and Joe and will be happy to take your questions.
