column1:
{"Citigroup's (C) CEO Mike Corbat on Q2 2015 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Citigroup Inc. (NYSE:C)

"
column6:
"

Susan Kendall - Head of Investor Relations

"
column7:
"

Mike Corbat - Chief Executive Officer

"
column8:
"

John Gerspach - Chief Financial Officer

"
column17:
"

Erika Najarian - Bank of America

"
column18:
"

Matt Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column20:
"

Gerard Cassidy - RBC Capital Markets

"
column27: and welcome to Citi's Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Review with Chief Executive Officer
column28: Mike Corbat; and Chief Financial Officer
column29: John Gerspach. Today's call will be hosted by Susan Kendall
column30:
Head of Citi Investor Relations.

"
column31:
"

We ask that you please hold all questions until the completion of the formal remarks at which time you will be given instructions for the question-and-answer session. Also
column33: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column39: Regina. Good morning and thank you all for joining us. On our call today
column41: Mike Corbat will speak first. Then John Gerspach
column42: our CFO will take you through the earnings presentation
column43: which is available for download on our website
column44: citigroup.com. Afterwards
column45:
we will be happy to take questions.

"
column46:
"

Before we get started
column47: I would like to remind you that today's presentation may contain forward-looking statements
column48: which are based on management's current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results and capital and other financial condition may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors
column49: including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today
column50: and those included in our SEC filings
column52: without limitation
column53:
the risk factor section of our 2014 Form 10-K.

"
column55:
let me turn it over to Mike.

"
column57:
"

Thank you
column58: Susan. Good morning everyone. Earlier today
column59: we reported earnings of $4.7 billion for the first quarter of 2015
column60: or $1.45 per share
column61: excluding the impact of CVA and DVA. It was a strong quarter overall
column62:
and we continued to make good progress towards our strategic and execution priorities.

"
column63:
"

With half the year behind us
column64:
we\u2019ve remained on track to hit our financial targets in terms of return on assets in our efficiency ratio. We again achieved both positive operating leverage and strong loan growth in our core Citicorp businesses. Citi Holdings was profitable again during the quarter and we continued to wine down its assets which are down 22% from a year ago and Holding\u2019s assets now comprise only 6% of Citigroup\u2019s balance sheet. We continued to utilize DTA this quarter bringing the total to $1.5 billion for the first half of 2015 and we added $3.5 billion to our regulatory capital during the quarter even as we returned roughly $1.7 billion to shareholders in the form of share buybacks and common dividends.

"
column65:
"

Our tangible book value increased to $59.18 and our common equity Tier 1 capital ratio increased to a 11.4% on a fully implemented Basel III basis. We submitted our resolution plan to the Fed and the FDIC which details how we would resolve Citi without the use of tax payer funds or harm to the financial system
column66: viable resolution planning is critical to our making Citi as simpler
column67: smaller
column68:
safer and stronger institution.

"
column69:
"

In terms of our businesses
column70: we saw balanced performance for the quarter across our institutional and consumer segments. In ICG
column71:
we\u2019ve grown our investment banking wallet share year-to-date and our Private Bank continued to show strong rise in revenue growth.

"
column72:
"

Treasury and Trade Solutions saw a revenue growth on a constant dollar basis. And our Markets and Securities Services revenue grew from a year ago driven by rates in currencies and security services.

"
column73:
"

In consumer banking
column74: high quality checking deposit growth improve spreads and higher mortgage originations drove revenue growth in the U.S. while we\u2019ve optimized our branch footprint to focus on seven cities. And internationally
column75: we also grew revenue
column76: despite continued spread headwinds with growth across investment sales
column77: deposits
column78:
loans and purchase sales.

"
column79:
"

We\u2019ve remained focused on our expenses and driving efficiencies throughout the organization. Despite significant investments in our regulatory and compliance functions
column80:
we continued to lower our overall headcount and we\u2019re reducing both our real estate footprint and our employees in higher cost locations.

"
column81:
"

These actions help to keep our expenses lower than they were a year ago even before the benefit of foreign exchange.

"
column82:
"

While I am pleased with our results for the first half of the year
column83: the environment remains challenging and unsettled. Growth forecast continued to be downwardly revised and we still don\u2019t have clarity on when interest rates will begin to rise. While some volatility may create trading opportunities
column84:
we would much prefer to see growth strength inconsistently across the developed and emerging markets.

"
column85:
"

But whatever the economic conditions are we will remain focused on our clients and executing our strategy on behalf of our shareholders.

"
column86:
"

John will now go through the deck and then we\u2019ll be happy to take your questions. John?

"
column87:
"

John Gerspach

"
column88:
"

Hey
column89: thank you Mike and good morning everyone. Starting on Slide 3
column90: I\u2019d like to highlight a couple of items CVA
column91: DVA and the prior period mortgage settlement that affect the comparability of our results to last year. Excluding these items
column92:
we earned a $1.45 per share in the recent quarter compared to a $1.24 in the second quarter 2014.

"
column93:
"

On Slide 4
column94: we show total Citigroup results. In the second quarter
column95: we earned $4.7 billion generating a return on assets of 101 basis points and a return on tangible common equity of 10.1%. Net income grew by over $700 million year-over-year driven by core improvement in Citicorp. Revenues declined on a reported basis to $19.2 billion
column96:
but increased 3% year-over-year in constant dollars. Expenses declined 7% year-over-year mostly reflecting a lower legal and repositioning charges as well as a benefit from FX translation and net credit losses improved offset by a lower net loan loss reserve release.

"
column97:
"

The tax rate in the second quarter was 29% somewhat lower than the 31% outlook we had provided on a full year basis.

"
column98:
"

Turning to the first half of 2015
column99: the total efficiency ratio for Citigroup including Citi Holdings was 56%. Net income grew by 17% year-over-year
column100: we generated a ROA of a 103 basis points and our return on tangible common equity was 10.5%. In constant dollars
column101:
Citigroup end of period loans declined 1% year-over-year to $632 billion as 4% growth in Citicorp was more than offset by the continued wine down of Citi Holdings.

"
column102:
"

Deposits also decreased 1% driven by Citi Holdings including the reclassification of $21 billion of Japan retail deposits to held for sale in the fourth quarter of last year.

"
column103:
"

On Slide 5
column104:
we provide more detail on second quarter revenues in constant dollars. Citicorp revenues were up 5% year-over-year mostly driven by growth in our institutional franchise and revenues declined in Citi Holdings reflecting continued asset reductions as well as the impact of classifying our OneMain business as held for sale at the end of last quarter.

"
column105:
"

As a result of the HFS accounting treatment
column106:
OneMain loans are classified as other assets. As such approximately $160 million of net credit losses were recorded as a reduction to other revenue during the second quarter. This lowered both revenues and cost of credit by an equal amount and therefore had a neutral impact on earnings.

"
column107:
"

On Slide 6
column108:
we show more detail on expenses in constant dollars. Citi core expenses were down 1% as ongoing efficiency savings and lower legal and repositioning cost will largely offset by higher regulatory and compliance cost. And Citi Holdings expenses also declined on lower assets.

"
column109:
"

On Slide 7
column110: we show the split between Citicorp and Citi Holdings. Citicorp net income grew 22% year-over-year in the second quarter. And as I just described
column111: we generated positive operating leverage again this quarter in Citicorp with 5% growth in revenues and 1% decline in expenses in constant dollars. And for the first half of 2015
column112:
we achieved the Citicorp efficiency ratio of 55.1%.

"
column113:
"

Turning to Citi Holdings
column114:
we were profitable again this quarter with over a $150 million in net income. Citi Holdings ended the quarter with a $116 billion of assets or 6% of total Citigroup assets.

"
column115:
"

On Slide 8
column116: we show results for international consumer banking in constant dollars. Net income grew 25% year-over-year driven higher revenues
column117: lower operating expenses and an improvement in credit cost
column118: partially offset by a higher effective tax rate. Revenues grew 1% year-over-year in the second quarter
column119: reflecting volume growth
column120:
partially offset by spread compression and ongoing regulatory headwinds in certain markets.

"
column121:
"

In Latin America
column122: we grew revenues 3% driven by modest loan and deposit growth in Mexico
column123:
partially offset by the impact of selling our consumer franchise in Honduras last year. And in Asia revenues were roughly flat year-over-year as 3% growth in retail banking revenues including wealth management was offset by lower card revenues.

"
column124:
"

Asia card loans and purchase sales both grew year-over-year by 4% and 5% respectfully but this growth was offset by lower spreads driven by continued higher payment rates and the impact of regulatory changes in certain markets. We continued to believe these headwinds will abate somewhat in the second half of 2015. Asia card revenues grew by 3% sequentially in the second quarter.

"
column125:
"

In total
column126: average international loans grew 2% from last year. Card purchaser sales grew 5% and average deposits grew 4%. Operating expenses declined 5% as lower repositioning cost were partially offset by the impact of volume growth
column127:
higher regulatory and compliance cost and technology investments and credit cost declined from last year.

"
column128:
"

Slide 9 shows the results for North America consumer banking. Net income of $1.1 billion declined slightly year-over-year as higher revenues
column129:
lower expenses and lower net credit losses were more than offset by a decline in the net loan loss reserve release.

"
column130:
"

Total revenues grew 1% year-over-year. Retail banking revenues of $1.3 billion grew 11% from last year
column131: reflecting continued loan and checking deposit growth
column132:
higher mortgage origination activity and improved deposit spreads. Branded cards revenues of $1.9 billion were down 5% from last year as 5% growth in purchase sales and improved spreads were more than offset by the impact of lower average loans mostly driven by the continued runoff of promotional rate balances and higher payment rates. And retail services revenues were flat to last year with improved spreads being offset by the continued impact of lower fuel prices and higher contractual partner payments.

"
column133:
"

Total expenses declined 3% mostly driven by ongoing efficiency savings as we have continued to rationalize our branch footprint and capture the benefits of our global scale in cards. Our retail banking results reflect the strong progress we\u2019re making in North America.

"
column134:
"

Over the past year
column135: we have reduced our branch count by 15% to 779 branches. And at the same time
column136: we've improved the overall productivity of our network
column137: concentrating our resources in 70 markets and deepening our relationships with our target clients. Despite the branch reductions
column138:
we grew checking account balances by 7% year-over-year. Card acquisitions per branch were up 10% year-over-year on a same store basis and we continued to enhance our retail mortgage origination platform reducing our reliance on third parties and better integrating our operations. Over 80% of our growth in origination volumes year-over-year came through retail channels.

"
column139:
"

Slide 10 shows our global consumer credit trends in more detail. Overall
column140: credit remained favorable in the second quarter. In North America and Asia
column141:
trends remained broadly stable and in Latin America. the NCL rate improved in line with a lower delinquency rate.

"
column142:
"

Slide 11 shows the expense trends for the global consumer banking. Over the last 12 months
column143: our consumer efficiency ratio was 54% including overall 150 basis points attributable to legal and repositioning charges. For the first half of the year
column144: the total efficiency ratio for global consumer banking was 53.3%
column145: down from 56% last year. We now expect the total consumer efficiency ratio for 2015 to be somewhere in the range of 52% to 53% consistent with our plans to begin gradually increasing the level of investment spend during the second half of the year
column146:
primarily in the U.S. branded cards.

"
column147:
"

Turning now to the Institutional Clients Group on Slide 12; revenues of 8.6 billon in the second quarter grew 2% from last year and declined 6% from the prior quarter
column148:
total banking revenues of 4.4 billon were roughly flat to last year and up 4% sequentially.

"
column149:
"

Treasury and Trade Solutions revenues of $2 billon were down 1% year-over-year on a reported basis. In constant dollars
column150: TTS revenues grew 5% from last year as growth in deposit balances and spreads more than offset a decline in trade revenues. This represents the sixth consecutive quarter that we've generated both revenue and operating margin growth in TTS on a year-over-year basis. And while trade revenues continue to present the headwind this quarter
column151:
we see some early positive signs that spread maybe stabilizing. Both cash and trade revenues increased sequentially up 3% in total.

"
column152:
"

Investment Banking revenues of 1.3 billon were down 4% from last year as higher M&A revenues were more than offset by lower underwriting activity as compared to a very strong second quarter last year consistent with overall market trends. Year-to-date
column153:
investment banking revenues were up 4% driven by strong M&A results and we have gained overall wallet versus 2014 particularly in North America.

"
column154:
"

Private Bank revenues of 746 million grew 13% year-over-year
column155: driven by strong growth in investments and capital markets products as well as higher loan and deposit balances. And Corporate Lending revenues of 445 million were down 2% on a reported basis. In constant dollars
column156:
lending revenues grew 4% from last year as higher volumes were partially offset by lower spreads.

"
column157:
"

Total Markets and Security Services revenues of 4.2 billion grew 4% year-over-year and declined 12% sequentially. Fixed income revenue of 3.1 billion were down slightly from last year as continued strength in rates and currencies was offset by lower revenues in spread products.

"
column158:
"

Rates and currencies revenues grew by double digits year-over-year in the second quarter as investor client activity and market volatility were improved versus last year
column159:
G10 rates was the key driver of growth. In North America in particular as we saw strong client activity and a favorable trading environment offset by a small decline in G10 foreign exchange.

"
column160:
"

Local market rates and currencies grew modestly year-over-year driven by our franchise in Asia. In spread products however
column161:
activity levels declined versus last year in credit products in particular resulting in lower revenues.

"
column162:
"

On a sequential basis
column163:
fixed income revenues declined 12% driven by seasonal factors as well as the lower rates and currency activity as compared to a strong first quarter.

"
column164:
"

Equities revenues of 653 million were down 1% year-over-year and down 25% sequential. Our equities revenues this quarter included a charge of 175 million for valuation adjustments related it certain financing transactions. And as of today
column165: we have a remaining exposure with respect to these transactions of less than a $100 million. Excluding the adjustments
column166: equities revenues would have increased by 26% from last year
column167: driven by growth and derivatives
column168:
improved trading performance EMEA and strong client momentum in Asia.

"
column169:
"

In Security Services
column170:
revenues were up 7% year-over-year and 3% sequential reflecting increased activity and higher client balances. Total operative expenses of 4.8 billion grew 2% year-over-year as higher regulatory and compliance cost were partially offset by ongoing efficiency savings and the impact of FX translation and credit was a positive in the quarter.

"
column171:
"

On Slide 13
column172: we show expense and efficiency trends for the Institutional business. Over the last 12 months
column173:
our efficiency ratio was 57% including roughly 140 basis points attributable to legal and repositioning charges and our comp ratio was 27%. We continued to expect to achieve a total ICG efficiency ratio closer to the mid-point of the 53% to 57% target range for the full year 2015.

"
column174:
"

Slide 14 shows the result for the Corp and other. Revenues were higher year-over-year and sequential
column175: driven mainly by gains on debt buybacks as well as real estate sales in the recent quarter
column176: partially offset by hedging activities and expenses were down
column177:
mainly reflecting lower legal and related costs.

"
column178:
"

Slide 15 shows Citi Holdings asset which totaled a $116 billion at quarter end

column180: we closed the sales of our consumer businesses in Peru and Nicaragua and we have signed agreements to sell an additional $32 billion of assets including our consumer businesses in Japan
column181: Egypt
column182:
Costa Rica and Panama as well as OneMain Financial.

"
column183:
"

On Slide 16
column184: we show Citi Holdings financial results for the quarter. Revenues of 1.7 billion declined by over 300 million from last year
column185: driven by the reduction in assets as well as the impact of classifying our OneMain business as held for sale at the end of the quarter. As I described earlier
column186: as a result of the HFS accounting treatment
column187: approximately $160 million of net credit losses were recorded as a reduction in revenue during the second quarter. The HFS treatment had no impact on expenses which declined 13% year-over-year
column188:
primarily due to the asset reductions.

"
column189:
"

On Slide 17
column190: we show Citigroup\u2019s net interest revenue and margin trends. The bars represent net interest revenue per day for each quarter in constant dollars
column191:
showing a consistent growth trend year-over-year even as the contribution from Citi Holdings has continued to strength.

"
column192:
"

Our net interest margin increased sequentially to 295 basis points
column193: driven by a higher than expected contribution from trading NIM which can fluctuate quarter-to-quarter. Excluding this impact
column194:
our net interest margin would have been closer to 291 basis points and we expect to maintain roughly this level for the third quarter.

"
column195:
"

Looking to the fourth quarter
column196: our results will depend in part on the timing of divestiture including OneMain at our Japan retail business. We estimate that without these businesses on a combined basis
column197:
our net interest margin would be lower by roughly 7 basis points before using any part of the associative gains to redeem high cost dept.

"
column198:
"

We believe we can ultimately mitigate more than half of this NIM pressure through a combination of the upcoming debt redemption actions as well as the April acquisition of the Costco portfolio.

"
column199:
"

On Slide 18
column200: we show our key capital metrics on a fully implemented Basel III basis. During the quarter
column201:
our CET 1 capital ratio improved to a 11.4% driven by retained earnings and DTA utilization. Our supplementary leverage ratio improved to 6.7% and our tangible book value grew to $59.18 per share.

"
column202:
"

In summary
column203: we continued to make progress in the second quarter with revenue growth and positive operating leverage in Citicorp
column204:
lower legal and repositioning expenses and continued favorable credit trends.

"
column205:
"

For the first half of 2015
column206: we are tracking well to our financial targets with a Citicorp efficiency ratio of 55%
column207: a Citigroup ROA of a 103 basis points and a return on tangible common equity of 10.5%. Of course we would expect our results to be stronger in the first half of the year given the seasonality of our markets business. But for the full year
column208:
we continued to expect to deliver a Citicorp efficiency ratio in the mid 50% range and a Citigroup ROA of over 90 basis points.

"
column209:
"

Finally
column210:
we ended the quarter with a strong capital position improving our CET 1 ratio to a 11.4% and our supplementary leverage ratio to 6.7% even as we returned roughly $1.7 billion of capital to shareholders in the form of buybacks and common dividends this quarter.

"
column211:
"

Turning to the second half of this year
column212: we continued to expect modest revenue growth in Citicorp. In consumer
column213: in North America
column214: we expect continued underlying revenue growth in our retail banking franchise
column215: although comparisons for the prior year will be impacted by certain onetime items that benefited our mortgage business last year as previous disclosed. And the North America cards
column216:
revenue will likely remain under pressure in the second half of the year as it will take some time for our incremental investment spend to drive top line results.

"
column217:
"

In international consumer
column218: we continue to believe we can generate revenue growth and positive operating leverage year-over-year in the second half of 2015
column219:
driven by continued modest growth in Mexico as well as continued volume growth and abating spread headwinds in Asia as we begin to lap some of the spread compression and regulatory changes we absorbed last year.

"
column220:
"

Turning to the institutional franchise
column221: we continued to see good momentum across Corporate Lending
column222: Treasury and Trade Solutions
column223:
Security Services and the Private Bank which together generated 8% year-over-year revenue growth in the first half of the year in constant dollars.

"
column224:
"

Investment banking revenues will depend in part on the overall market
column225:
but we continue to feel good about the strength of our franchise generating 4% year-over-year revenue growth in the first half with overall wallet share gains versus 2014.

"
column226:
"

And finally
column227: in markets we expect our overall performance to reflect the market environment with the goal of continuing to gain wallet share with our target clients. In Citi Holdings we remained focused on winding down the portfolio
column228:
while staying above breakeven.

"
column229:
"

As I\u2019ve described earlier we have signed agreements with a sale of $32 billion of assets virtually all of which we expect to close by year-end. And in particular
column230:
we continue to work towards a late third quarter sale of OneMain financial. We expect credit cost to increase somewhat in the second half of the year driven by loan growth as well as lower loan loss reserve releases and we expect to keep balance sheet discipline staying at or below our current size.

"

"

And with that Mike and I are happy to take any questions.

column1:
{"Citigroup's (C) Q2 2015 Results -- Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Citigroup
column13:
"

David Knutson - Legal & General Investment Management

"
column20:
"

Welcome to Citi's Fixed Income Investor Review with Chief Financial Officer John Gerspach. Today's call be hosted by Peter Kapp
column21: Head of Fixed Income Investor Relations. [Operator Instructions]. Mr. Kapp
column25: Brent. Good morning and thank you all for joining us. On our call today
column28: will take you through the fixed income investor presentation which is available for download on our website
column30:
I would like to remind you that today's presentation may contain forward-looking statements which are based on Management's current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances.

"
column31:
"

Actual results and capital and other financial condition
column32: may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors
column33: including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today and those included in our SEC filings
column36:
the Risk Factors section of our 2014 Form 10-K.

"
column38:
let me turn it over to John.

"
column41: Peter and good morning
column42: everyone. We're pleased to be hosting our fixed income investor review this quarter. I'd like to begin by highlighting some key points from our second quarter 2015 results
column43:
on slide 2.

"
column44:
"

Last week
column45: we reported a strong quarter
column46:
earning $4.7 billion while making continued progress on our execution priorities. We saw balanced performance across our institutional and consumer segments.

"
column47:
"

We grew revenues and achieved positive operating leverage in Citicorp. And Citi Holdings was again profitable during the quarter. Holdings assets are down 22% over the past year
column48: to $116 billion and we have signed agreements to sell an additional $32 billion of these assets
column49: virtually all of which we expect to close by year end. For the first half of the year
column50: Citigroup's efficiency ratio was 56%
column51:
our ROA was 103 basis points and we generated a return on tangible common equity of 10.5%.

"
column52:
"

We utilized $1.5 billion of deferred tax assets through the first half of 2015
column53: contributing to continued strong capital generation. We have continued to maintain an efficient balance sheet
column54:
growing loans and deposits in Citicorp and generating a net interest margin of 295 basis points for the quarter. Credit quality remains strong across our consumer and corporate loan portfolios.

"
column55:
"

We maintained a strong funding profile
column56: as our deposit quality continues to improve and we executed against our debt issuance plans. And our capital
column57: leverage and liquidity ratios remained strong
column58:
as we generated $3.5 billion of CET1 capital during the quarter.

"
column59:
"

On slide 3
column60: we show total Citigroup results
column61: adjusted for the items noted on the slide. As I noted earlier
column62: during the quarter
column63: we earned $4.7 billion. Net income grew by over $700 million year over year
column64:
driven by core improvement in Citicorp.

"
column65:
"

Revenues declined on a reported basis
column66: to $19.2 billion
column67: but increased 3% year over year in constant dollars
column68: driven by 5% growth in Citicorp. Expenses declined 7% year over year and 1% in constant dollars
column69: mostly reflecting the lower legal and repositioning charges. Our second-quarter results provide a solid start to 2015
column70:
better demonstrating our underlying earnings power and the impact of the actions we've taken to simplify and streamline our operations.

"
column71:
"

Turning to slide 4
column72: we show trends in our balance sheet. Our discipline in maintaining total assets at approximately $1.8 trillion over the past year and our efforts to improve the efficiency of our balance sheet
column73:
help us prepare for regulatory requirements and achieve our return targets.

"
column74:
"

On a reported basis
column75: our total assets declined by over $80 billion in the past year
column76: largely as a result of the dollar's appreciation against foreign currencies
column77: especially the euro
column78: Mexican peso and yen. To provide more meaningful insights into our underlying business trends
column79: we presented this slide and several others in today's presentation
column80:
on a constant dollar basis.

"
column81:
"

On this basis
column82: net loans and deposits in Citicorp grew 4% and 3%
column83: respectively
column84: year over year across our businesses
column85: offset by the continued wind-down of Citi Holdings. We have maintained a liquid balance sheet
column86:
with 27% of our assets in cash and investments and approximately half of our balance sheet funded by deposits.

"
column87:
"

We were able to further reduce short-term borrowings by $13 billion in the quarter and $32 billion from last year
column88: as a result of growth in high quality deposits
column89:
as we managed our liquidity profile.

"
column90:
"

Slide 5 shows the trends in our loan portfolio. In constant dollars
column91: total Citigroup loans decreased 1% year over year
column92: as 4% growth in Citicorp was offset by continued significant reductions in Citi Holdings. Consumer loans grew 1% year over year
column93: with broad-based growth driving a 3% increase in international consumer loans. Corporate loans grew 6% year over year. Our corporate lending portfolio increased 10%
column94: with growth in North America and EMEA
column95:
as we continued to support our target clients.

"
column96:
"

Private bank volumes increased
column97: particularly in North America and TTS loans declined 11%
column98: as we have maintained our return profile by reducing our balances of trade finance receivables in response to spread compression in certain markets
column99: especially China. Citi Holdings loans decreased 33% year over year
column100: driven by a $16 billion reduction in North America mortgages
column101:
as well as the impact of our previously announced agreements to sell OneMain and the Japan credit card business.

"
column102:
"

On slide 6
column103: we show continued stability in our consumer and corporate credit trends. In the second quarter
column104: consumer credit remained favorable
column105: with a net credit loss rate of 224 basis points. In North America and Asia
column106: trends remained broadly stable. And in Latin America
column107: the NCO rate decreased somewhat from last quarter
column108:
consistent with delinquency trends.

"
column109:
"

Our corporate portfolio also continues to see favorable credit performance. Nonaccrual loans remained stable
column110: at 38 basis points of corporate loans. Latin America declined
column111: as we sold the nonaccrual loans. And North America increased
column112:
primarily driven by downgrades in our energy portfolio.

"
column113:
"

We built reserves against our energy exposures by approximately $43 million in the quarter
column114: mainly related to our North America E&P exposures. We again realized virtually no NCL's against the energy sector during the quarter. While we are building reserves
column115:
we continue to believe that the risk is well contained and we expect any losses we incur to be manageable.

"
column116:
"

Turning to slide 7
column117: we show our deposit composition. Citicorp deposits grew 3% in constant dollars
column118: with continued high quality deposits flows across our franchise. Consumer deposits increased 3%
column119:
with 4% growth in international markets.

"
column120:
"

Corporate deposits increased 8% year over year
column121: with a continued focus on growing high quality deposits and limiting lower quality deposits
column122: such as non-operating deposits of financial institutions. Citi Holdings and other deposits declined significantly year over year
column123: driven by the impact of our agreement to sell the Japan retail business which resulted in the reclassification of $21 billion of deposits to held for sale last year
column124:
as well as the continued transfer of MSSB deposits to Morgan Stanley which has now been completed.

"
column125:
"

Slide 8 demonstrates the diversity and stability of our deposit franchise. Over 55% of our deposits are outside the U.S.
column126:
providing local funding for our overseas operations. We run these operations with balance sheets that are largely matched by currency and liquidity characteristics.

"
column127:
"

Overall
column128: Citigroup's deposits have a 74% liquidity value under the LCR
column129: up 100 basis points from last quarter. We expect deposit quality to remain relatively stable at this level
column130:
based on our current business mix. Each 100 basis point improvement in liquidity value reduces our HQLA requirement by approximately $9 billion.

"
column131:
"

In our consumer business
column132: our deposits have an 87% LCR liquidity value. Our efforts to deepen our relationships with retail customers
column133: including increasing the penetration of direct deposit and bill pay
column134: as well as other products like mortgages and credit card
column135:
have also served to increase the stickiness of our deposits.

"
column136:
"

And in the corporate business
column137: we have increased the liquidity value of deposits to approximately 68%. We have reduced non-operating deposits with 100% runoff to $56 billion currently
column138: down by about one-third over the past year. And we continue to work with clients to grow operating accounts
column139:
while reducing lower LCR liquidity value deposits.

"
column140:
"

On slide 9
column141: we update our regulatory liquidity metrics. Our LCR
column142: under the U.S. rules
column144: in excess of the 100% minimum requirement and consistent with the levels we have maintained over the past year. Over time
column145: we would expect to manage our LCR in the range of 105% to 110%
column146:
based on current regulatory requirements.

"
column147:
"

As of June 30
column148: our HQLA was $386 billion
column149: down $15 billion from the prior quarter. Our estimated net outflows under the LCR declined by $14 billion during the quarter
column150: reflecting the improvement in the LCR liquidity value of our deposits
column151:
as well as the continued reduction of our short-term borrowings. Continued discipline around our funding structure will allow us to maintain an efficient level of liquidity.

"
column152:
"

On the right side
column153: you can see the composition of our HQLA as of the end of the quarter
column154:
over 80% of which is in cash and sovereign debt. We continue to expect the U.S. regulators to propose a U.S. version of the net stable funding ratio sometime during 2015. We believe that our NSFR is in excess of 100% under the international version of the NSFR rule.

"
column155:
"

On slide 10
column156: we show Citigroup's net interest revenue and margin. Our net interest margin increased sequentially
column157: to 295 basis points
column158:
driven by a higher-than-expected contribution from trading NIM which can fluctuate quarter to quarter.

"
column159:
"

Excluding this impact
column160: our net interest margin would have been closer to 291 basis points and we expect to maintain roughly this level for the third quarter. Looking to the fourth quarter
column161: our results will depend in part on the timing of a number of upcoming actions
column162:
including the completion of our OneMain and Japan retail business sales and our planned debt buybacks.

"
column163:
"

And as you can see on slide 29 in the appendix
column164: we continue to expect a NIM benefit from a rising rate environment
column165: consistent with recent quarters. Our estimate of the net interest revenue benefit and a 100 basis point instantaneous rate shock scenario
column166: increased modestly to $2 billion
column167: of which $1.4 billion reflects the impact of U.S. rates. In managing our interest rate risk
column168: we routinely consider the impact of many scenarios
column169: including a range of market and macro-economic conditions
column170:
as well as the expected behavior of our clients.

"
column171:
"

On slide 11
column172: we show the composition of our long-term debt outstanding. During the quarter
column173: our long-term debt increased slightly
column174: to $212 billion. Bank-issued debt declined $2 billion
column175: as we reduced our reliance on credit cards securitizations
column176: in anticipation of the potential impact of TLAC. Parent company debt increased by $3 billion during the quarter
column177:
to $155 billion.

"
column178:
"

We currently expect to end the year with total Parent company long-term debt of roughly $160 billion. Our weighted average maturity fell to 6.7 years
column179: due in part to the repurchase of some longer-dated securities during the quarter. Over time
column180: we intend to maintain our WAM at around seven years. And our total preferred stock stands at $14 billion
column181:
providing nearly 110 basis points of additional Tier 1 capital.

"
column182:
"

On slide 12
column183: we update our issuance and redemption expectations for long-term debt in 2015. For the full year 2015
column184: we expect to issue approximately $25 billion of benchmark debt. We issued nearly $16 billion of senior and subordinated debt during the first half of the year
column185: including offerings in dollars
column186:
euros and Canadian dollars.

"
column187:
"

For the remainder of the year
column188: we expect to issue approximately $10 billion of benchmark debt. Year to date
column189: in addition to $10 billion of maturities
column190: we have reduced long-term debt by an additional $11 billion
column191: including $6 billion of buybacks. For the balance of the year
column192:
we expect additional repurchases of $4 billion to $5 billion of benchmark debt.

"
column193:
"

As previously indicated
column194: we expect to buy back some of our higher-cost debt in connection with the completion of our sell of OneMain. Consistent with our prior debt buybacks
column195:
these will be NPV positive and will help us lower our cost of funds.

"
column196:
"

In the first half of 2015
column197: we issued $3.5 billion of preferred stock. We will remain opportunistic around market conditions and currently expect to issue an additional $2 billion or so of preferred in the second half of 2015
column198: as we continue to build towards 150 basis points of additional Tier 1 capital. On slide 13
column199: we update our estimates of our total loss absorbing capacity
column200:
based on the FSB's November 2014 consultative document and our ongoing discussions with regulators and other industry participants.

"
column201:
"

We have yet to see any formal proposals or feedback from our regulators
column202: although we continue to expect something this year. Accordingly
column203: consistent with our prior estimates
column204: we include CET1 capital
column205: preferred stock and unsecured parent-issued senior and subordinated debt with at least one year remaining until maturity
column206: as well as a small portion of our customer-related debt
column207:
in our estimates of TLAC.

"
column208:
"

We estimate Citigroup's total loss-absorbing capacity increased to $273 billion or 21.3% of our risk-weighted assets and 11.4% of our total leverage exposure. We calibrate this 21.3% against potential requirements of 22% to 26%
column209:
depending upon the base TLAC requirement of 16% to 20% and at 3.5% GSIB surcharge.

"
column210:
"

I'll discuss the Fed's final GSIB rules more in a minute. This range translates to $282 billion to $333 billion of required TLAC or $9 billion to $60 billion more than our current TLAC estimate.

"
column211:
"

We have identified a number of sources with which to meet this incremental TLAC need
column212: as necessary. As we have previously communicated
column213: we already expect to issue $4 billion to $6 billion of preferred stock
column214: as well as net issuance of $6 billion to $8 billion of subordinated debt
column215:
to meet our other existing regulatory capital requirements.

"
column216:
"

And then
column217: to the extent additional TLAC is required
column218: we estimate approximately $10 billion of existing principal-protected notes
column219: within our customer related debt
column220: may become eligible under the final rules. And an addition $10 billion of customer-related debt could possibly be included
column221:
with some structural changes to our issuance program. These sources alone total nearly $35 billion of potential TLAC-eligible funding.

"
column222:
"

Beyond that
column223: if necessary we would look to issue incremental senior debt to replace non-TLAC eligible funding
column224: including non-eligible customer-related debt
column225: securitizations and repo financing. So we have multiple ways of addressing our potential TLAC requirements based on proposals to date
column226:
but we continue to await formal regulatory guidance or rules.

"
column227:
"

Turning to slide 14
column228: let me summarize our capital position which remains among the strongest in the industry. During the quarter
column229: our fully phased in CET1 capital ratio increased approximately 30 basis points
column231: driven by our retained earnings and DTA utilization and after returning $1.7 billion to shareholders
column232:
through share repurchases and common stock dividends.

"
column233:
"

Risk-weighted assets under advanced approaches also decreased $5 billion
column234: to $1.279 billion. Under transition agreements
column235: our CET1 capital ratio increased by 50 basis points
column236: to 13.8%. Our supplementary leverage ratio grew to 6.7%
column237: driven by the strong capital generation and $2 billion of preferred stock issuance
column238: as well as a decline in our leveraged exposure. Citibank's SLR also increased 10 basis points in the quarter
column240:
"

On slide 15
column241: let me address the final U.S. GSIB surcharge rule released yesterday. Our review of the rule is ongoing. With that said
column242: I'd like to make several observations about our current understanding. While in many ways the final rule is consistent with the December proposal
column243:
it does include several important changes.

"
column244:
"

First
column245: the final rule determines the GSIB surcharge based on fixed aggregate measures of systemic importance
column246: rather than the relative measures used in the proposed rule. Second
column247: it replaces a spot FX rate with a three-year average of daily exchange rates. And third
column248:
it better recognizes the regulatory treatment of certain types of short-term wholesale funding.

"
column249:
"

Most notably
column250: it reduces the penalty for holding non-operational deposits which have been addressed separately through the LCR. Under the original proposal
column251: we estimated that we would be subject to a 4% GSIB surcharge. We now expect a 3.5% surcharge
column252: based on our current interpretation of the final rule
column253:
consistent with the Fed's estimate.

"
column254:
"

While this final rule did not go as far as we would have liked
column255: especially with respect to the treatment of deposits
column256: it is clearly a move in the right direction. As described
column257: this rule affirmatively allows the industry to better measure the impact of specific actions on each firm's GSIB surcharge
column258:
consistent with the Fed's policy objectives.

"
column259:
"

Moving to our last slide
column260: let me summarize four major points. First
column261: we reported solid results in the second quarter
column262: with revenue growth and positive operating leverage in Citicorp
column263:
lower legal and repositioning expenses and continued favorable credit trends. And we utilized $1.5 billion of DTAs in the first half.

"
column264:
"

Second
column265: we have actively managed our balance sheet
column266:
maintaining total assets around $1.8 trillion and optimizing our assets and liabilities to support client needs and improve returns. Credit trends remain favorable across both our consumer and corporate portfolios and we have maintained a stable net interest margin.

"
column267:
"

Third
column268: our deposit base remains a key strength
column269: as we continue to improve the liquidity value of our deposits. Our 2015 issuance plans are on track
column270: including preparations for formal guidance related to TLAC. And lastly
column271:
we have continued to prepare our business and balance sheet for the ongoing evolution of the regulatory environment. Our capital and liquidity remains strong.

"
column272:
"

This concludes our fixed income review. I'll now be happy to take your questions.

column593: we try to look very closely at every one of the activities that we're involved in. I think you'll note that we have been steadily moving down the league tables
column594: when it comes to leverage finance. And so that might give you some indication of one of the areas
column595: at least
column596:
that we would look at with somewhat less enthusiasm than others.

"
column598:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Scott Cavanagh with APG. Please go ahead.

"
column599:
"

Scott Cavanagh

"
column600:
"

It's clearly a star performer in the industry
column601: on this perspective. So I just had a question on upcoming regulatory rulings or potential rulings. When we think about the single credit counterparty limit
column602:
how does this impact you? And what are you guys expecting?

"
column603:
"

John Gerspach

"
column604:
"

I'm sorry
column605: Scott
column606:
that's one area that -- I just don't have anything prepared on that one. I haven't looked at that in the last couple of days and I'm sorry. I just can't.

"
column607:
"

Operator

"
column608:
"

Thank you
column609: that concludes the question-and-answer session. Mr. Kapp
column610:
do you have any closing remarks?

"
column611:
"

Peter Kapp

"
column612:
"

Thank you
column613: everyone
column614: for joining the call today. If you have follow-up questions
column615:
please don't hesitate to reach out to us in Investor Relations. We'll talk to you again next quarter.

"
column617:
"

Thank you. This concludes today's conference call. You may now disconnect.

"

column1:
{"Citigroup's (C) CEO Mike Corbat on Q3 2015 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Citigroup Inc. (NYSE:C)

"
column6:
"

Susan Kendall - Head of IR

"
column14:
"

John McDonald - Sanford C. Bernstein

"
column16:
"

Gerard Cassidy - RBC Capital Markets

"
column17:
"

Erika Najarian - Bank of America

"
column21:
"

Matthew Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column26: and welcome to Citi's Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Review with Chief Executive Officer
column27: Mike Corbat; and Chief Financial Officer
column28: John Gerspach. Today's call will be hosted by Susan Kendall
column30:
"

We ask that you please hold all questions until the completion of the formal remarks at which time you will be given instructions for the question-and-answer session. Also
column32: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column38: Regina. Good morning and thank you all for joining us. On our call today
column40: Mike Corbat will speak first. Then John Gerspach
column41: our CFO will take you through the earnings presentation
column42: which is available for download on our website
column43: citigroup.com. Afterwards
column44:
we will be happy to take questions.

"
column45:
"

Before we get started
column46: I would like to remind you that today's presentation may contain forward-looking statements
column47: which are based on management's current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results and capital and other financial condition may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors
column48: including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today
column49: and those included in our SEC filings
column50: including
column52: the risk factor section of our 2014 Form 10-K. With that said
column53:
let me turn it over to Mike.

"
column55:
"

Thank you Susan and good morning everyone. Earlier today we reported earnings of $4.2 billion for the third quarter of 2015 or $1.31 per share excluding the impact of CVA and DVA. The quarter had more than its fair share of volatility and our results speak to the resilience of our franchise globally. And despite the revenue headwinds we once again proved our ability to manage our expenses and will remain on track to deliver our full year efficiency and return on asset targets.

"
column56:
"

I feel good about the quality and consistency of the earnings that we have demonstrated through the course of the year. We have also made strong progress against our other core priorities. We achieved both positive operating leverage and continued loan and deposit growth in our core businesses. We continued to improve the quality of our balance sheet by replacing legacy assets from Citi Holdings with high solid loans in Citicorp.

"
column57:
"

Citi Holdings was profitable again this quarter
column58:
Holdings assets declined 20% on a year-over-year end basis and we will end at 110 billion for the quarter which represents only 6% of Citigroup's balance sheet. We expect to close an additional 31 billion of asset sales during the fourth quarter. We utilized an additional 700 million in deferred tax assets this quarter bringing the total utilization to $2.1 billion through the third quarter which has contributed $3.5 billion to our regulatory capital. In total we generated $14 billion of regulatory capital so far this year and have been able to return over 4 billion of that capital to our shareholders in the form of share buybacks and common dividends.

"
column59:
"

We grew our tangible book value to over $60 per share and our Common Equity Tier 1 capital ratio increased to 11.6% on a fully implemented basis. With one quarter to go we are on track to hit our financial targets in return of assets and our efficiency ratio and we also earned a 10% return on tangible common equity so far this year.

"
column60:
"

Turning to the results of our businesses
column61: while the uncertain environment clearly dampened client activity in our market products
column62: we made good progress in other areas. With revenue growth in treasury and trade solutions
column63: security services
column64:
and the private bank equities also grew. And while our total fixed income revenues were under pressure we saw continued strength in our emerging market franchise. We also continued to see momentum in M&A year-to-date as a result of investments we\u2019ve made in that business.

"
column65:
"

Internationally our consumer banking business was also impacted by slowing growth and shifting consumer sentiment most notably in Asia. In the U.S. our retail franchise continued to grow revenues
column66: loans
column67:
and deposits even as we continued to sharpen the focus of our branch footprint. And in branded cards we are seeing growth in active accounts and purchase sales although it\u2019s going to take some time for the full benefit of our investments in this business to be reflected in our results.

"
column68:
"

As we look to the end of the year
column69: we still don\u2019t have clarity on many important issues. Predictions on the timing of an interest rate increase seem to change every day. We don\u2019t yet know the long-term impact of recent volatility on consumer and business sentiment. And in many large markets
column70:
there are high degrees of political risk which have economic ramifications.

"
column71:
"

I think that this quarter showed that we are well equipped to handle what the world throws our way whether it\u2019s managing our risk
column72: our expenses
column73: or our capital. Challenging environments have become the norm and the work we\u2019ve done to make our firm simpler
column74: smaller
column75: safer
column76:
and stronger has given us a resilient and sturdy platform from which to operate. John will now go through the deck and then we\u2019ll be happy to take your questions. John.

"
column77:
"

John C. Gerspach

"
column78:
"

Hey
column79: thank you Mike and good morning everyone. Starting on slide 3
column80: we highlight the impact of CVA
column81: DVA
column82: on our reported results. Excluding this item we earned $1.31 per share in the recent quarter compared to $0.95 in the third quarter of 2014. On slide 4
column83:
we show a total city group results. In the third quarter we earned $4.2 billion generating a return on assets of 91 basis points and a return on tangible common equity of 8.9%. Revenues of 18.5 billion were down 8% from last year mostly reflecting an impact of foreign exchange translation.

"
column84:
"

In constant dollars revenues declined 2% year-over-year as the slight improvement in Citicorp was more than offset by lower revenues in Citi Holdings. Expenses declined 18% year-over-year driven by lower legal and repositioning charges
column85:
as well as the benefit from FX translation. And net credit losses continued to improve offset by a significantly lower net loan loss reserve release.

"
column86:
"

Turning to the first nine months of 2015
column87: the total efficiency ratio for Citigroup including Citi Holdings was 56.5%. Net income grew about 22% year-over-year. We generated an ROA of 99 basis points and our return on tangible common equity was 10%. In constant dollars
column88:
Citigroup end of period loans declined to 1% year-over-year to 622 billion as 5% growth in Citicorp was more than offset by the continued line down of Citi Holdings. And deposits were flat versus last year at 904 billion also reflecting 4% growth in Citicorp offset by a decline in Citi Holdings.

"
column89:
"

On slide 5
column90: we provide more detail on third quarter revenues in constant dollars. Citicorp revenues were up slightly year-over-year and Citi Holdings revenues declined by nearly 30% mostly reflecting higher gains on asset sales in the prior year including the impact of selling our consumer operations in Spain and Greece. On slide 6
column91:
we show more detail on expenses in constant dollars. Citicorp expenses were down 13% year-over-year driven by significantly lower legal and repositioning cost. And Citi Holdings expenses also declined on lower assets.

"
column92:
"

On slide 7
column93:
we show the split between Citicorp and Citi Holdings. Year-to-date Citicorp has contributed over 97% of our net income while Citi Holdings although profitable has had a limited impact on total earnings. As I just described we generated positive operating leverage again this quarter in Citicorp with revenues up slightly and expenses down 13% in constant dollars. And for the first nine months of 2015 we achieved a Citicorp efficiency ratio of 55.4%. Citi Holdings remained profitable this quarter and ended the period with $110 billion of assets.

"
column94:
"

On slide 8
column95: we show results for international consumer banking in constant dollars. In total international consumer banking revenues grew 2% year-over-year. In Latin America
column96: excluding the gain of approximately $180 million this quarter on the sale of our merchant acquiring business in Mexico
column97:
revenues were roughly flat versus last year as a modest increase in loan and deposit balances was offset by continued spread compression.

"
column98:
"

Card loan balances in Mexico remained under pressure this quarter reflecting both slower economic growth and ongoing shifts in consumer behavior. However
column99: we were able to offset this impact with growth in personal loans and other retail banking products. Overall
column100:
we are maintaining a strong share of consumer loans and deposits in Mexico and importantly credit continues to perform well which I will discuss more in a moment.

"
column101:
"

Turning to Asia
column102:
consumer revenues declined 6% year-over-year driven by lower investment sales revenues as well as continued high payment rates and ongoing regulatory pressure in cards. We saw an industry wide slow down in activity in Asia during the quarter reflecting changes in consumer sentiment driven by slowing economic growth and the recent volatility in the capital markets.

"
column103:
"

In retail banking we continued to see year-over-year revenue growth in lending
column104: insurance
column105: and deposit products. However
column106:
this was more than offset by lower investment sales revenue. And in cards we saw a slower than expected growth in purchase sales this quarter. Card loans still grew modestly year-over-year but this growth was muted by the impact of continued high payment rates. And regulatory changes remained a headwind as well although we continued to believe this will abate somewhat as we go forward.

"
column107:
"

In total
column108: average international loans grew 3% from last year
column109: card purchase sales grew 5%
column110:
and average deposits grew 4%. Operating expenses grew 1% as higher regulatory and compliance cost and technology investments were mostly offset by lower legal and repositioning cost as well as ongoing efficiency savings. And credit cost increased 7% from last year driven by our loan loss reserve build in Latin America.

"
column111:
"

Our NCL and delinquency rates continued to improve this quarter in Latin America. However
column112: given the macroeconomic environment we did build another loan loss reserves in particular in Brazil. We have taken a cautious approach in Brazil for several years now including the sale of our mass market credit card business
column113: Credicard in late 2013. At less than $3 billion
column114:
the Brazil consumer portfolio now represents just 1% of our global consumer loans and we do not expect it to have a material impact on our total consumer cost of credit as we look forward.

"
column115:
"

Slide 9 shows the results for North America consumer banking. Total revenues declined 4% year-over-year and were flat sequentially. Retail banking revenues of 1.3 billion grew 3% from last year as continued loan and deposit growth and improved deposit spreads were partially offset by the impact of $15 million mortgage repurchase reserve release in the prior year.

"
column116:
"

In branded cards revenues of $1.9 billion were down 9% from last year driven by a modest decline in average loans and an increase in acquisition and rewards cost as we have continued to ramp up new account acquisitions in our core products. We feel confident that we now have the right products to drive high quality account growth.

"
column117:
"

We expect the investments we are making today to generate higher net interest revenue overtime as growth in active accounts
column118: better customer engagement
column119:
and higher purchase sales translated to higher full rate balances. We feel good about our progress to date of nearly 6% year-over-year growth in active accounts and 12% growth in purchase sales in our core products. Of course this has the revenue growth in cards will take some time and the full benefits of our actions may not be completely reflected in our results for perhaps another two years as we build new loans to offset the continued run off in our legacy products. In the interim we will benefit from inorganic growth next year with the acquisition of the Costco portfolio.

"
column120:
"

Finally
column121: turning to retail services
column122: revenues declined 2% from last year reflecting the continued impact of lower fuel prices as well as higher contractual partner payments
column123: as we continued to share some of the benefits of higher yields and lower net credit losses with our retail partners. Excluding the impact of loan loss reserves
column124: pretax income grew 7% in retail services. Total expenses of 2.3 billion in North America declined 6% as incremental investments were more than offset by lower repositioning cost and ongoing efficiency savings
column125:
as we have continued to capture scale benefits in cards and rationalize our branch footprint.

"
column126:
"

Since the beginning of 2014 we have closed or sold over 200 branches and plan to exit roughly 50 more by the end of the first quarter of 2016 including our Boston area branches. With these actions we are concentrating our presence in our most productive urban markets and also adjusting our model to reflect a significant shift in transaction activity to digital channels requiring fewer branches and lower headcount per branch. This shift also improves our ability to retain customer relationships as the physical footprint changes. Even when we exit the market entirely
column127:
we have found that we are able to retain a significant portion of the consumer deposits overtime.

"
column128:
"

Slide 10 shows our global consumer credit trends in more detail. Asia credit was stable again this quarter with a loss rate of roughly 80 basis points. The loss rate in North America continued to decline to 2.2%. And both the NCL and delinquency rates improved again this quarter in Latin America driven by favorable trends in our Mexico cards portfolio that we expect to continue.

"
column129:
"

Slide 11 shows the expense trends for global consumer banking. For the first nine months of the year the total efficiency ratio for global consumer banking was 53% down from 55% last year. And we expect the ratio to be roughly 53% for the full year.

"
column130:
"

Turning now to the institutional clients group on slide 12
column131: revenues of 8.4 billion in the third quarter declined 3% from last year. Total banking revenues of 4 billion excluding the impact of gains on loan hedges were down 7% versus the prior year
column132:
mostly reflecting lower investment banking activity. Treasury and trade solutions revenues of 1.9 billion were flat year-over-year on a reported basis.

"
column133:
"

In constant dollars TTS revenues grew 7% from last year as growth in deposit balances and spreads more than offset a decline in trade revenues. This represents the seventh consecutive quarter that we\u2019ve generated both revenue and operating margin growth in TTS on a year-over-year basis. Investment banking revenues of 937 million were down 25% from last year. Equity underwriting revenues were down 43% reflecting lower industry wide activity this quarter.

"
column134:
"

Debt underwriting revenues were down 17% driven by high yield and leverage loans
column135: products where our core clients were less active this quarter than in the prior year. And M&A revenues were down 24% compared to a very strong quarter last year. Year-to-date in 2015 we have continued to gain momentum in M&A with 16% revenue growth
column136: sustained wallet share gains
column137:
and a strong share of announced value. Private bank revenues of 715 million grew 8% year-over-year driven by strong growth in managed investments revenue as well as higher loan and deposit balances. And corporate lending revenues of 403 million were down 9% on a reported basis.

"
column138:
"

In constant dollars lending revenues declined 4% from last year as higher volumes were more than offset by lower spreads and the impact of loan sale activity. Total markets and securities services revenue of 4 billion declined 5% year-over-year. Fixed income revenues of 2.6 billion were down 16% as we saw lower activity levels and a less favorable environment in the recent quarter particularly in securitized products in G10 FX. The revenue impact was most significant in North America and Western Europe and was partially offset by strong performance again this quarter in our emerging markets franchise where our fixed income revenues grew 4% year-over-year. Our G10 rates business as roughly flat year-over-year for the quarter but we did see significantly lower than expected revenues in the back half of September.

"
column139:
"

Turning to equities
column140: excluding the impact of reversing $140 million of the valuation adjustment we recognized in the second quarter
column141: revenues increased by 12% from last year driven by growth in derivatives with particular strength in North America and Asia. And in security services revenues declined 4% on a reported basis and were up 7% in constant dollars
column142:
reflecting increased activity and higher client balances.

"
column143:
"

Total operating expenses of 4.7 billion decreased 4% year-over-year as higher regulatory and compliance cost were more than offset by lower compensation expense and the impact of FX translation. Total credit costs were 309 million up sequentially reflecting a net loan loss reserve build this quarter compared to a net release last quarter.

"
column144:
"

In both quarters we built reserves for energy related exposures. However the build was more than offset last quarter by reserve releases in other portfolios. In the third quarter we built energy related reserves of roughly $140 million or about half of the total ICG build. The remainder was split between other portfolios and the impact of overall volume growth. Of course we are working closely with our clients to mitigate the risk of losses actually being realized. Total net credit losses were $34 million this quarter and while corporate non-accrual loans increased during the quarter
column145:
more than two thirds of the loans we added remained performing.

"
column146:
"

On slide 13
column147:
we show expense and efficiency trends for the institutional business. Over the last 12 months our efficiency ratio was 57% including over 100 basis points attributable to legal and repositioning charges. And our comp ratio was 27%. We continued to expect to achieve a total ICG efficiency ratio in the range of 55% to 56% for the full year 2015.

"
column148:
"

Slide 14 shows the results for corporate and other. Revenues were higher year-over-year driven primarily by gains on debt buybacks and expenses were down mainly reflecting lower legal and related costs. Slide 15 shows holdings assets which totaled $110 billion at quarter end
column149: down 20% from a year ago. We have continued to make great progress in opening down Citi Holdings with signed agreements to selling additional $37 billion of assets
column150:
$31 billion of which we currently expect to close in the fourth quarter. By year-end we currently expect Citi Holdings assets to be somewhere in the range of $70 billion to $75 billion.

"
column151:
"

On slide 16
column152:
we show Citi Holdings financial results for the quarter. Revenues of 1.4 billion declined 32% from last year mostly reflecting lower gains on asset sales as well as divestiture activity. Expenses also declined driven mainly by the lower assets and cost of credit remains favorable driven by the North American mortgage portfolio where the total NCL rate improved to 1.2%.

"
column153:
"

On slide 17
column154: we show Citigroup's net interest revenue and margin trends. The bars represent net interest revenue per day for each quarter in constant dollars showing a consistent growth trend year-over-year even as the contribution from Citi Holdings has continued to shrink. Our net interest margin was 294 basis points in the third quarter
column155:
roughly in line with the prior quarter as trading NIM continued to be higher than expected.

"
column156:
"

Looking to the fourth quarter
column157: our net interest margin will depend on a number of factors including the level of trading them
column158: the timing of expected divestitures in Citi Holdings
column159:
and a magnitude in timing of any debt redemption actions. Given all that we currently expect our net interest margin in the fourth quarter to be in the range of 285 to 290 basis points.

"
column160:
"

On slide 18 we show our key capital metrics on a fully implemented basis. During the quarter our CET1 capital ratio improved to 11.6% driven by retained earnings and DTA utilization even as we return $2.1 billion to shareholders in the form of share buybacks and common dividends. Our supplementary leverage ratio improved to 6.8% and our tangible book value grew to over $60 per share.

"
column161:
"

In summary we continue to operate well in a challenging environment this quarter with continued cost discipline
column162: significantly lower legal and repositioning cost
column163: and great progress towards the wind down of Citi Holdings. Three quarters into the year we have an efficiency ratio in Citicorp of 55.4%
column164: a Citigroup ROA of 99 basis points
column165:
and we earn the return on tangible common equity of 10%.

"
column166:
"

We continued to utilize our deferred tax assets this quarter and we ended the period with a very strong capital position. We are certainly seeing the impact of slower global growth and macro uncertainty on our top line results
column167:
but we feel good about our ability to manage risk through this cycle. We are remaining disciplined on target client strategy and feel strongly to focusing on these higher quality and more resilient segments is the right strategy in any economic environment.

"
column168:
"

Looking to the fourth quarter
column169: in North America consumer revenues will likely be roughly flat to the third quarter and in international consumer we expect revenue to be slight to slightly higher than last year on a constant dollar basis as we expect continued modest volume growth with Asia revenues beginning to stabilize. Turning to the institutional franchise
column170: we continue to see good momentum across treasury and trade solutions
column171: security services
column172:
and the private bank which together generated 8% year-over-year revenue growth in the first nine months of the year in constant dollars.

"
column173:
"

Investment banking revenues will depend in part on the overall market but we continue to feel good about the strength of our franchise particularly in M&A. And finally in markets we expect our overall performance to reflect the market environment with the goal of continuing to gain wallet share with our target clients.

"
column174:
"

In Citi Holdings there are series of transactions that will impact the fourth quarter. As I noted earlier we currently expect to close roughly $31 billion of previously announced asset sales including our retail and cards businesses in Japan and one main financial. We will continue with other ongoing portfolio of sales and we also plan to redeem high cost debt.

"
column175:
"

As we have said previously we expect the net gain on the sale of OneMain to be roughly $1 billion including the cost of planned debt redemption actions. In addition
column176:
we expect to incur gains and losses on other sales including some that maybe recognized through the cost of credit like and we expect to see higher transaction related repositioning and other expenses as we are up. And so on a net basis including the impact of all of these other transaction related items we would not expect the full $1 billion gain on OneMain to fall through the bottom lot.

"
column177:
"

Finally for total Citigroup we expect our cost of credit to be roughly flat to the third quarter excluding any impact from the portfolio of sales out of Citi Holdings. And with that Mike and I are happy to take any questions.

"
column178:
"

Question-and-Answer Session

"
column179:
"

Operator

"
column180:
"

[Operator Instructions]. Our first question will come from the line of Jim Mitchell with Buckingham Research. Please go ahead.

"
column181:
"

James Mitchell

"
column182:
"

Hey
column183:
good morning guys. Just maybe a model question.

"
column184:
"

Michael L. Corbat

"
column185:
"

Good morning Jim.

"
column186:
"

James Mitchell

"
column187:
"

Hey good morning. Just the asset sales
column188: 31 billion this quarter
column189: potentially 37 billion in total
column190:
can you help us think about the impact on capital ratios when they are done?

"
column191:
"

John C. Gerspach

"
column192:
"

Well when you take a look at
column193: I gave you that where I thought that Citi Holdings would end up on a total asset basis
column194: GAAP asset basis for the end of the quarter or somewhere in that range of $70 billion to $75 billion of assets. So
column195: we will certainly see a reduction but as we have said in the past particularly the Japan retail business is not risk asset heavy. So
column196: associated with that is $31 billion worth of sales
column197:
you are looking at something that might be roughly half of that in risk weighted assets.

"
column198:
"

James Mitchell

"
column199:
"

Right
column200: okay. That is helpful
column201: and I guess as we think about even though that is not a huge impact is that
column202: I mean your capital ratios have expanded pretty significantly over the past 12 months. I know this is not a easy question to answer but if you look at your capital return
column203: payout ratio is still below peers with the improvement in ratios sort of now better than most with asset sales
column204:
do you think you can get closer to peer payout ratios next year in CCAR or is there anything else we should be thinking about?

"
column205:
"

Michael L. Corbat

"
column206:
"

Jim
column207: it is Mike. I would answer that a couple of ways
column208: one is as long as the stock continues to trade below tangible book our primary actions are going to be focused on share buyback rather than dedicating that right now towards dividend. And again we -- as our capital numbers speak
column209: we had another strong quarter
column210: we have had a strong year-to-date in terms of capital generation
column211: and we have got to position the firm overtime to bring that capital back or we are simply creating our own denominator problem. So
column212: we are focused on it. We don\u2019t know CCAR scenarios
column213:
we don\u2019t know all the processes yet but again we are very focused on it.

"
column214:
"

James Mitchell

"
column215:
"

Okay
column216: fair enough
column217: I will stop there
column218:
thanks.

"
column219:
"

Operator

"
column220:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Glenn Schorr with Evercore ISI. Please go ahead.

"
column221:
"

Glenn Schorr

"
column222:
"

Hi
column223:
thanks very much.

"
column224:
"

John C. Gerspach

"
column225:
"

Hi Glenn.

"
column226:
"

Glenn Schorr

"
column227:
"

Hello there. I guess I wanted to start with credit and energy specifically. I mean the performance overall has been great. I hear your comments
column228: and I have heard past comments about mostly investment grade
column229: largely large corporate. I am just
column230: I am sitting back and I listened to some of our energy team and they talked about the death and destruction in the oil patch and I see the large numbers that large banks like yours have and I am trying to square the circle there and say why should we feel good about future reserves or current reserves on the energy books. So
column231: I guess let's just revisit why we take comfort in your exposures and then maybe you could help with talking through what you do have reserved away exposures are
column232: I would appreciate it
column233:
thanks?

"
column234:
"

John C. Gerspach

"
column235:
"

Alright Glenn
column236: so again as we have said in the past
column237: and I will give you a bit of a run down
column238: our energy related loans
column239: the total exposure remains about constant to where we were last year at about $60 billion worth of total energy related exposure. The funded book has actually gone down slightly to $21 billion during the quarter. And the book does remain primarily investment grade. We have had some downgrades
column240: we have also taken on some new business which in this market you can imagine is not necessarily at the same high level. But the overall book remains two thirds investment grade
column241:
down a little bit from -- the funded book remains two thirds investment grade and the overall exposure is still about 80% investment grade. So we feel very good about the credit quality.

"
column242:
"

Having said that we continue to work with our clients. We have been building reserves because it certainly is prudent in this environment. We told you that we took a 140 of reserves this quarter
column243: that is roughly equal to what we took during the first half of the year. We took about 100 in the first quarter
column244:
40 in the second. So this is something that we are looking at every day and we are adjusting the provisions accordingly. But it still remains a very high quality book and not one that is necessarily dramatically dependent on the specific price of that.

"
column245:
"

Again our exposure
column246:
to what you would consider to be close to the well head you know still remains fairly small. Roughly confident about a funded book of about $6 billion and we\u2019ve worked our way through a lot of the reconsideration events of the taking a look at reserve levels. So again all I can say is that it is something that we are looking at and it is something that we still feel really good about.

Glenn Schorr

column248:

Okay

But for instance the strength that we have got on our SLR ratio has enabled us to pursue a little bit more growth in the prime brokerage area and we see that as a way of getting additional penetration into some of our key investor clients. So again we are using it where appropriate but everything that we do is carefully thought out on several plains as you can imagine.

column326: when we were looking at what we thought would be a difficult environment in 2015 and the environment has actually proved to be even more difficult I think than we thought at that point in time when we said we can operate overall Citicorp with an efficiency ratio of in the mid 50s. And that's where we are. And given this environment we still feel
column327: again we haven\u2019t worked our way all the way through our budget considerations and everything else but in this type of environment we think that that is a pretty good efficiency ratio to be operating under. Michael L. Corbat

I would say that some preview around that Mike is that
column375: as John said

We have talked about changes in interest rates and as of now roughly 100 basis points upward shift of rates translate somewhere into about 2 to 2.1 of revenue which we would hope we believe largely translates into EBIT and so they are tailwinds that can come out of some of those shifts. But again as we have seen
column383: as the Fed has contemplated its move you would want those moves to come on the back drop of perception of economic strength. And if economic strength is there you get the double tailwind of not just the rate push but you get some stability
