And I just don\u2019t think that we\u2019re going to get to a point where even if we shut holdings down that we are going to be able to relieve ourselves of that $49 billion of risk weighted assets. So that may come overtime but it\u2019s going to be time not a quarter or two. So I think it is really

the rewards product would be thank you.

What we see in times of market volatility and market uncertainty is that our wealth management clients are not as active as you would imagine. It is just not as active in putting more of their funds to work in the markets and that therefore has an impact on our investment sales. So it\u2019s a little bit of market sentiment
column495: it\u2019s a little bit of consumer confidence
column496: its all of those things and as far as how does what do we think about it going forward at the markets sort of clear themselves as people become a little bit more confident again
column497:
they know where they are going. We see that activity come back but this was a particularly tough quarter for investment sales.

Ken Usdin

column499:
"

Right

got it. Thanks very much.

column509: its looks as though the RWA on a constant dollar basis have been relatively stable. I just wanted to get a sense as to how we should be thinking about it in 2016 where maybe you don\u2019t have the offset of the holdings run off and you still have continued core growth in Citicorp

column517: don\u2019t forget we take that into consideration as part of our overall capital hedging program because our capital hedging program is built on a ratio hedge. So we hedge to our CET1 ratio. And so just as our capital in various countries is going to be impacted by fluctuations in FX rates
column518:
we also know that our risk weighted assets are going to be impacted by that as well. So all of that is baked into capital hedge. But that means that for the quarter we actually saw a non-FX related reduction in RWA of about $10 billion. So that\u2019s what's baked into that number and some of that is in holdings and some of that is in Citicorp.

column519:
"

We have not worked our way through our overall 2016 plan as yet. so I cannot give you guidance as to where we are going to think about what we are going to think about RWA levels going into next year. But we\u2019ll take all of that into account as we finalize the budget and as the budget gets finalized around both our efficiency targets as well as our ROA targets and our ROPCE targets as well.

Steven Chubak

column529:

column627: this quarter it did present certain challenges. I don\u2019t think the environment is going to change dramatically in the fourth quarter. But again we\u2019ll have to just see how everything continues to develop off of there. What is happening
column628:
it is not just of course of the fact that you get loan growth but what also matters is where you get the loan growth and in what loan products do you get loan growth in. And so the key for us is to begin to see the loan growth in those higher margin credit card products. We like to see the loan growth in the retail bank that\u2019s fine but those loans are usually slightly lower margins because they\u2019re securitized. Then there is a fixed payment scheme as opposed to revolving behavior that you have on cards. So loan growth is one thing and I feel pretty good about our ability to grow loans but I feel better when we begin to see even better growth coming out of the card products.

Well I am not going to go into specific things but in general the hedges that we\u2019ve got on our loan book that\u2019s just part of our ongoing risk management efforts. We use loan hedges to manage credit risk concentrations primarily and to the extent that we can and for the most part we do we use single name CDS to hedge those concentration risk. So it is not because we\u2019re worried about any particular name but because we are just trying to manage again our concentration of risk in a particular sector.

column649:

column650: credit spreads were generally widening and that had two impacts. We had gains on those loan hedges and at the same point in time we took provisions on the loans. I am not going to say it is always going to line up correctly but I think if you go back to the last two quarters what you\u2019ll see in each of the last two quarters to the extent we had small losses on the loan hedges
column651: that gave us then the opportunity it usually matched up with an opportunity to release reserves in the corporate portfolio and to the extent where we had a small gain

We are not trying to be one of the top three or four producers of mortgages but we do want to be in a position to be able to support our retail clients when it comes to their mortgage needs.

column1:
{"Citigroup's (C) CEO Michael Corbat on Q4 2015 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Citigroup Inc. (NYSE:C)

"
column2:
"

Q4 2015 Results Earnings Conference Call

"
column6:
"

Susan Kendall - Head of IR

"
column7:
"

Michael Corbat - Chief Executive Officer

"
column8:
"

John Gerspach - Chief Financial Officer

"
column18:
"

Matt Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column20:
"

Erika Najarian - Bank of America

"
column24:
"

Hello and welcome to Citi's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Review with Chief Executive Officer
column25: Mike Corbat and Chief Financial Officer
column26: John Gerspach. Today's call will be hosted by Susan Kendall
column28:
"

We ask that you please hold all questions until the completion of the formal remarks at which time you will be given instructions for the question-and-answer session. Also as a reminder
column29: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column30: please disconnect at this time. Ms. Kendall
column34: Brent. Good morning and thank you all for joining us. On our call today
column37: will speak first then John Gerspach
column39: will take you through the earnings presentation which is available for download on our website
column41:
we'll be happy to take your questions.

"
column42:
"

Before we get started
column43: I would like to remind you that today's presentation may contain forward-looking statements which are based on management's current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results in capital and other financial condition may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today and those included in our SEC filings
column44: including without limitation the Risk Factors section of our 2014 Form 10-K. With that said
column45:
let me turn it over to Mike.

"
column46:
"

Michael Corbat

"
column47:
"

Thank you
column48: Susan. Good morning everyone. Earlier today
column49: we reported earnings of $3.4 billion for the fourth quarter of 2015 or $1.06 per share excluding the impact of CVA and DVA. And for the full year
column50:
we earned $17.1 billion or $5.35 per share. I'll go into more detail on the year after making a few points about the quarter.

"
column52: our institutional businesses saw improved performance from the fourth quarter of last year. Revenues increased in Treasury and Trade solutions
column53: Investment Banking and our private bank
column54:
as well as across our equities and fixed income businesses.

"
column56: our North American performance continued to be impacted by investments we're making in our branded cards business
column57:
but we saw continued underlying growth and efficiency gains in retail banking.

"
column58:
"

And internationally
column59: market sentiment clearly affected our investment sales contributing to lower overall revenues from a year ago. However
column60: we did continue to see growth in deposits
column61: loans
column62:
and card purchase sales and credit continued to be stable in our cards and our retail portfolios.

"
column63:
"

We had a substantial decrease in Citi Holdings assets during the quarter largely driven by the closing of the sale of OneMain and consumer franchises in several countries. Holdings assets ended the year at $74 billion or a 43% reduction from the previous year. And importantly
column64:
we believe the actions we took this quarter will enable Citi Holdings to be marginally profitable in 2016.

"
column65:
"

Overall
column66: we had strong performance in 2015. The $17.1 billion we generated in net income was the highest since 2006 when our company was very different in terms of headcount
column67: footprint
column68:
mix of business and assets.

"
column69:
"

Over the last year
column70: we grew revenues 3% in constant dollars while holding our core operating expenses flat. And as we committed
column71: we significantly reduced our legal and repositioning costs and we drove loan and deposit growth of 5% in Citicorp
column72:
while reducing the overall size of our balance sheet.

"
column73:
"

We also made significant progress on DTA utilization
column74:
generating significant regulatory capital and ending the year with a Common Equity Tier 1 ratio of 12% on a fully implemented basis.

"
column75:
"

I'm especially pleased with our progress over the last three years. In early 2013
column76: in addition to announcing my execution priorities
column77: we set several financial targets we hope to reach by the end of 2015 in terms of return on assets
column78:
a Citicorp efficiency ratio and a return on tangible common equity.

"
column79:
"

At 94 basis points
column80: we reached our target in terms of return on assets
column81: while at 57.1%
column82:
the Citicorp efficiency ratio was just over our target and it was more than 300 basis points lower than in 2012. Excellent progress that I think compares very favorably to that of our peers.

"
column83:
"

Although we weren't able to begin to return meaningful capital to our shareholders until 2015
column84:
we were still able to increase our return on tangible common equity to 9.2% for Citigroup and we reached 11% excluding the capital which supports our disallowed DTA.

"
column85:
"

In addition to these financial targets
column86:
we made significant progress against each of my execution priorities. We've become a simpler and smaller company. We've made the tough decisions regarding what businesses couldn't generate the returns our shareholders expect and deserve.

"
column87:
"

And as an example
column88: we've exited or are in the progress of exiting from 19 consumer markets. We said we'd wind down Citi Holdings and drive it to breakeven and now consists of only 4% of our balance sheet and not only as holdings broken even
column89:
it\u2019s been profitable for six straight quarters.

"
column90:
"

Overall

column92: 000 people
column93: assets by over $130 billion and reduced our legal entities by over one third. We've shrunk our real estate footprint by almost 20%
column94:
including 182 operation centers as part of our efforts to establish shared service centers and mine the efficiencies in our opportunities of our business model.

"
column95:
"

The other side of the coin is to make sure that we allocate these finite resources to where they can get the best returns. In our Institutional businesses
column96: we've successfully focused on our target clients
column97:
achieving wallet share and market share gains.

"
column98:
"

In Global Consumer

column100:
while investing in our mobile channels. We've simplified our branded cards portfolio reducing our offerings by 60% and are preparing to launch the Costco card this year.

"
column101:
"

Our customer satisfaction is measured by net promoter scores has improved meaningfully. We are unquestionably a safer and stronger company. As 2015 shows
column102:
we've significantly improved both the quality and consistency of our earnings.

"
column103:
"

We said we would begin to consistently utilize DTA. After it increased to $55 billion in 2012 we've utilized over $7 billion of DTA in the last three years. This contributed to the generation of $50 billion of regulatory capital over the last three years.

"
column104:
"

Last year
column105:
we were able to begin returning some of that capital to our shareholders and we've reduced our outstanding common shares by over 70 million and increased our common dividend.

column106:
"

We've already exceeded regulatory thresholds for the Common Equity Tier 1 and supplementary leverage ratios. We continue to invest in our capital planning process to ensure that it's sustainable and can meet the increasing expectations placed on a bank of our scale and scope.

"
column107:
"

We've also made the necessary investments in our compliance
column108:
risk and control functions which are critical to maintaining our license to do business. Everyday we work to be an indisputably strong and stable institution.

column109:
"

While as the early days of 2016 have shown

column111: Mexico or India
column112: growth globally remains muted and makes other factors
column113: whether they be the price of oil or interest rates
column114:
difficult to predict.

column115:
"

Volatility may present some trading opportunities but more often keeps investors on the sidelines and dampens consumer sentiment.

column116:
"

As I discussed earlier
column117:
we've worked hard to transform our company and the changes we've made have put us in a strong position to navigate the current environment. We've continued to reduce our exposure to lower return consumer markets.

"
column118:
"

We run a very balanced and tightly risk managed loan book. We've become even more disciplined in our focus on target clients. And our capital and liquidity are amongst the highest in the industry.

column1186:
"

So not necessarily making it more efficient by making it smaller
column1187:
but there's still elements of balance sheet optimization such as shifting more of the balance sheet towards those higher ROA businesses.

"
column1188:
"

So I'd say that maybe the word going forward will be optimization rather than making it more efficient. But in anyway it's still targeting our focus on improving the overall ROA.

"
column1190:
"

Got it. Excellent. Thanks very much.

"
column1192:
"

Thank you. We have no further questions in queue at this time.

"
column1196: and thank you all for spending the time with us today. If you have any follow up questions
column1197:
please reach out to Investor Relations. Thanks.

"
column1199:
"

Thank you. This concludes today's conference call. You may now disconnect.

"

column1:
{"Citigroup's (C) CEO Mike Corbat on Q1 2016 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Citigroup Incorporated (NYSE:C)

"
column2:
"

Q1 2016 Results Earnings Conference Call

"
column15:
"

Gerard Cassidy - RBC Capital Markets

"
column20:
"

Erika Najarian - Bank of America/Merrill Lynch

"
column21:
"

Matt Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column27:
"

Hello and welcome to Citi\u2019s First Quarter 2016 Earnings Review with Chief Executive Officer
column28: Mike Corbat; and Chief Financial Officer
column29: John Gerspach. Today\u2019s call will be hosted by Susan Kendall
column30:
Head of Citi Investor Relations.

"
column31:
"

We ask that you please hold all questions until the completion of the formal remarks at which time you will be given instructions for the question-and-answer session. Also as a reminder
column32: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column33: please disconnect at this time. Ms. Kendall
column37: Brent. Good morning and thank you all for joining us. On our call today
column40: will speak first then John Gerspach
column41: our CFO will take you through the earnings presentation which is available for download on our website
column42: citigroup.com. Afterwards
column43:
we\u2019ll be happy to take any questions.

"
column44:
"

Before we get started
column45: I would like to remind you that today\u2019s presentation may contain forward-looking statements which are based on management\u2019s current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results and capital and other financial condition may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today and those included in our SEC filings
column46:
including without limitation the Risk Factors section of our 2015 Form 10-K.

"
column47:
"

With that said
column48:
let me turn it over to Mike.

"
column49:
"

Mike Corbat

"
column50:
"

Thank you
column52: everyone. Earlier today
column53: we reported earnings of $3.5 billion for the first quarter of 2016 or $1.10 per share. These results reflect a difficult macro environment
column54: which was more challenging than we anticipated when we entered the year. That said
column55: we continue to make progress in key areas. We grew loans and deposits in our core businesses
column57:
generated and returned capital to our shareholders and reduced our expenses while absorbing a significant repositioning charge.

"
column58:
"

In our institutional businesses
column59: market sensitive products clearly suffered from weak investor sentiment during the quarter. This primarily impacted our trading and investment banking revenues. However
column60: our accrual and transaction service businesses posted 7% year-on-year growth
column61:
consistent with recent quarters. These businesses are gaining market share and now contribute almost half of our institutional revenues.

"
column62:
"

Investor sentiment was also impacted our consumer business including wealth management and especially in Asia. And while U.S. branded cards showed stronger performance across key indicators
column63: both top and bottom-line results remained lower due to the investments we are making in that business. Overall
column64:
credit trends remained very stable in our consumer portfolios as we continued to focus on our targeted segments.

"
column65:
"

Our global consumer bank is now entirely focused on our priority markets of the U.S.
column66: Mexico and Asia
column67:
and we see real path for growing our franchise. We\u2019ve been optimizing our footprint in terms of countries and branches to make sure we are allocating our resources to areas where they can generate the best returns.

"
column68:
"

In the last three years
column69: we have exited or are in the process of exiting from 19 consumer markets. And in February
column70: we announced we would sell our consumer businesses in Brazil
column71: Argentina and Colombia and focus solely on our growing institutional business in South America. During the quarter
column72: we also reduced our branch footprint by 82 while increasing our average deposits in our nearly 2
column73:
700 branches globally.

"
column74:
"

We also took a repositioning charge in the quarter. Repositioning is part of our effort to make share Citi is appropriately sized and structured for the current environment. We have identified opportunities for greater efficiencies in our regional models including additional delayering and shifting staff to our service centers which now host more than half of our people. That will drive an additional reduction of headcount which was down 3% during the quarter to 225
column76: almost 40
column77:
000 fewer than when I became CEO.

"
column78:
"

We also drove another significant reduction of assets in Citi Holdings
column79: which were down 10% from the end of last year and down 44% from one year ago. For the seventh quarter in a row
column80: Holdings was profitable. And while our work isn\u2019t done with Holdings assets now accounting for just 4% of our balance sheet
column81: we won\u2019t report Holdings results -- we won\u2019t report Holdings separately after this year. And being able to do
column82: this is a testament to the excellent work of the Holdings team
column83:
which we expect to remain intact and continue to unwind the remaining assets.

"
column84:
"

The wind down of Citi Holdings is a significant milestone for our institution and it\u2019s been a long time goal. We said
column85: we take Citi Holdings to a point where its assets weren\u2019t meaningful enough to merit separate reporting and that\u2019s what we\u2019re doing. Another area we\u2019ve focused on is shrinking our deferred tax assets. In the first quarter
column86: we utilized an additional $1.6 billion in DTAs
column87:
which contributed to a net increase of $6 billion in regulatory capital and our CET1 ratio increasing to 12.3%.

"
column88:
"

We continue to return capital to our shareholders
column89: repurchasing 31 million in common shares during the quarter
column90: bringing the net reduction of outstanding shares to just under a 100 million over the last four quarters. Our tangible book value per share increased almost $2 to $62.58 in the quarter. We continue to make progress in our efforts to be a safer and stronger institution. And earlier this week
column91:
we learned that neither the Fed nor the FDIC found any deficiencies in our 2015 resolution plan.

"
column92:
"

And last week
column93: we submitted our capital plan to the Federal Reserve. We believe that the combination of an even stronger capital position and the improvements we\u2019ve made in our capital planning process as well as in our risk management
column94:
compliance and control functions have allowed us to make a strong submission.

"
column95:
"

While 2016 didn\u2019t get off to the start we\u2019d hoped for
column96: the environment stabilized in the second half of the quarter. Volatility decreased as some of the more pessimistic scenarios failed to materialize. However
column97: the outlook is still right with risks from political elections to interest rates. I think as we\u2019ve shown in this quarter
column98: we can manage through challenging times. We think we have -- where we have too much capacity
column99: we\u2019ll reduce it
column100: while still serving our clients. We think certain sectors are showing science of weakness
column101:
we\u2019ll manage our exposures even more tightly.

"
column102:
"

John will now go through the presentation and then we\u2019ll be happy to take your questions. John?

"
column103:
"

John Gerspach

"
column104:
"

Thank you
column105: Mike and good morning everyone. Starting on Slide 3
column106: we highlight the impact of CVA/DVA on our prior period results. Beginning this quarter
column107: we adopted Fed B\u2019s new accounting standard on the reporting of DVA or debt valuation adjustments. Under the new rule
column108: changes in DVA that relate to Citi\u2019s own credit spreads are no longer recognized in earnings
column109: but instead are reflected in OCI. So
column110: we longer need to adjust our reported revenues in net income to exclude this item. Going forward therefore
column111: we will speak to reported results in our earnings presentation
column112:
which should be largely comparable to the historical results excluding CVA/DVA.

"
column113:
"

On Slide 4
column114: we show total Citigroup results. In the first quarter
column115: we earned $3.5 billion. Revenues of $17.6 billion declined 11% from last year
column116: mostly driven by lower industry-wide activity in markets and investment banking
column117: a continued wind down of Citi Holdings and the impact of FX translation. In constant dollars
column118: revenues were down 9% including a 6% decline in our core Citicorp businesses. Expenses decreased 3% year-over-year
column119: driven by the wind down of Citi Holdings
column120: lower legal expenses and the benefit from FX translation
column121: partially offset by higher repositioning costs and ongoing investments in the franchise. And net credit losses continued to improve offset by a loan loss reserve build this quarter compared to a net release in the prior year. In constant dollars
column122: Citigroup end of period loans grew 1% year-over-year to $619 billion
column123:
as 5% growth in Citicorp was partially offset by the continued wind down of Citi Holdings and deposits grew 5% to $935 billion.

"
column124:
"

On Slide 5
column125: we show the split between Citicorp and Citi Holdings. Citicorp revenues of $16.1 billion were down 9% from last year on a reported basis. In constant dollars
column126: as I mentioned
column127: revenues were down 6% from last year
column128: mostly driven by capital markets related businesses
column129: fixed income
column130: equities
column131:
investment banking and Asia Wealth Management as well as the impact of our continued investments in U.S. branded cards.

"
column132:
"

Citicorp expenses increased 2%
column133: reflecting the higher repositioning charges and ongoing investments in our franchise
column134: partially offset by efficiency savings and the benefit from FX translation. And cost and credit grew 29% from the first quarter of last year
column135: almost entirely driven by the energy sector. Otherwise
column136: credit quality remained favorable. In ICG
column137: we saw very little net cost of credit outside of energy this quarter. And in consumer
column138: our NCL and rates
column139: both continued to improve
column140:
although we are not benefiting from reserve releases as we had in the prior year.

"
column141:
"

Citi Holdings contributed pretax earnings of $477 million this quarter
column142: mostly driven by gains on asset sales. For the remainder of the year
column143: we expect Citi Holdings to be closer to breakeven. We reduced Citi Holdings assets by $8 billion this quarter and in the period with $73 billion of assets or just 4% of total Citigroup with signed agreements in place to sell $10 billion of this remaining amount. And as Mike noted earlier
column144:
2016 is the last year we\u2019ll report Citi Holdings as a separate segment.

"
column145:
"

Turning now to each business
column146: on Slide 6
column147: we show results for international consumer banking in constant dollars. In total
column148: international consumer banking revenues decline 2% year-over-year. And Latin America consumer
column149: which is now comprised solely of our Mexico franchise
column150: revenues grew 2% as growth in retail banking continued to be partially offset by pressure in cards. We saw good momentum in retail banking drivers
column151: including 11% growth in average deposits and 9% growth in average retail loans. However
column152: card balances remained under pressure in Mexico
column153: as continued growth in purchase sales was offset by higher payment rates
column154:
reflecting our focus on higher credit quality segments of the market.

"
column155:
"

Turning to Asia
column156: consumer revenues decline 4% year-over-year
column157: driven by weak investment sales revenues
column158: as well as continued but abating regulatory pressures in cards. Outside of wealth management
column159: retail banking revenues continued to grow year-over-year. And in card
column160: we believe we are through the most significant regulatory headwinds
column161:
which I\u2019ll discuss more in a moment.

"
column162:
"

In total
column163: average international loans grew 1% from last year. Card purchase sales grew 4% and average deposits grew 5%. Operating expenses grew 4%
column164: driven by higher repositioning charges and an increase in technology investments
column165: primarily in Mexico
column166: while core expenses in Asia were roughly flat. And finally
column167: total international consumer credit costs increased 7% from last year
column168:
reflecting the impact of reserve releases in the prior period. Net credit losses declined and the NCL rates improved to 1.6%.

"
column169:
"

On Slide 7
column170: we show Asia consumer in more detail. The first quarter is historically a strong period for wealth management in Asia with higher transaction activity driving strong investment sales revenues. Given weak investor sentiment during the quarter
column171: we didn\u2019t see the typical rebound in transaction activity and therefore our wealth management revenue declined significantly from last year. However
column172: we have seen consistent net inflows in our assets under management
column173: as you can see on the slide with the declining year-over-year trend in AUMs
column174: driven by the impact of lower equity market values. Therefore
column175:
we remain well-positioned to serve these clients as market confidence improves in the future.

"
column176:
"

Turning to cards
column177: card purchase sales have slowed in the current environment but payment rates have stabilized and as a result our average card loans have continued to grow. As we begin to cycle past the most significant regulatory headwinds
column178: this loan growth is starting to have a positive impact on revenue. So
column179: while card revenue still declined year-over-year
column180:
the trends continue to improve and we believe we\u2019re on a path to achieve revenue growth in cards by the second half of the year. And credit trends remain favorable across the entire consumer business in Asia.

"
column181:
"

Slide 8 shows the results for North America consumer banking. Total revenues declined 4% year-over-year. Retail banking revenues of $1.3 billion were roughly flat
column182: excluding a $110 million gain on the sale of our Texas branches last year as continued growth in loans in deposit spreads was offset by lower mortgage gain on sale revenues. In branded cards
column183: revenues of $1.9 billion were down 6% from last year
column184: driven by higher acquisition and rewards costs as we have continued to ramp up new account acquisitions in our core products. I\u2019ll talk more about branded cards in a moment. So
column185: we continue to feel good about the investments we are making. And in fact
column186:
we saw a year-over-year growth in our average loans this quarter for the first time since 2008.

"
column187:
"

And turning to retail services
column188: revenues of $1.7 billion increased 3% from last year
column189: mostly reflecting gains on the sale of two small portfolios. Even including the impact of these asset sales
column190: average loans were flat year-over-year and purchase sales increased 2%. Total expenses of $2.5 billion in North America increased 7%
column191: driven by higher repositioning costs and marketing investments
column192: partially offset by efficiency savings as we continue to capture scale benefits in cards and rationalize our branch footprint. As previously announced
column193: we exited over 50 branches this quarter
column194:
as we continue to concentrate on our key markets and adapt to a significant shift in customer behavior to digital channels.

"
column195:
"

And finally
column196: credit costs in North America increased 17% from last year
column197: driven by a reserve build of approximately $80 million this quarter in our commercial portfolio related to energy credits. Our energy exposure in the commercial business is significantly smaller than the corporate portfolio we report in the ICG. On a global basis
column198: we have energy exposure of $2.1 billion in the commercial business with $1.4 billion funded
column199:
90% of which is in North America. The credits are mostly in the E&P and services and drilling segments and are predominantly non-investment grade. We have no exposure in the commercial portfolio to junior or second lien positions and our funded reserve ratio is roughly 9%. We provide more details on this portfolio in the appendix to our earnings presentation.

"
column200:
"

On Slide 9
column201: we show some key performance indicators for North America branded cards including year-over-year growth in average active accounts
column202: average card loans
column203: and purchase sales for our total portfolio. In the second half of last year
column204: we began to ramp up new account acquisitions in our core products and these investments are beginning to have a significant impact. Growth in average active accounts and purchase sales began to accelerate late last year and these trends are now driving total loan growth as well even as our legacy portfolios continue to shrink. Card revenues were still down year-over-year this quarter but we believe we can return to growth sometime in the latter part of 2016
column205:
not including the benefit of acquiring the cost Costco portfolio.

"
column206:
"

Slide 10 shows our global consumer credit trends in more detail. Credit remained broadly favorable again this quarter with stable to improving NCL and delinquency rates in every region.

"
column207:
"

So
column208: as we look at our consumer franchise globally
column209: there are few things to highlight on Slide 11. First is the impact of the current environment on market sensitive businesses including wealth management as well as mortgage
column210: which together drove a year-over-year decline in revenues of nearly $150 million. Second is our continued investment in U.S. cards
column211: which is putting pressure on revenues today
column212: but is also starting to drive real underlying performance improvement. And third is the impact of regulatory changes in our business particularly in Asia
column213: which we believe is abating. When you pull back these drivers
column214: you can see we are achieving growth
column215: although muted
column216: driven by overall growth in personal loans
column217: card volumes and deposits. And we\u2019ve achieved this growth with very little change in our core expenses
column218:
in fact year-over-year the entire increase in our consumer operating expenses was driven by the combination of investments and higher repositioning costs.

"
column219:
"

As we move forward
column220: we believe
column221: we are making the right investments to grow the higher return markets and products in our franchise and that as these investments mature and we cycle past the remaining regulatory headwinds
column222:
we will be well positioned to drive higher returns to something in the range of 20% RoTCE in a more normal rate environment.

"
column223:
"

Turning now to the intuitional clients group on Slide 12
column224: revenues of $8 billion in the first quarter declined 12% from last year
column225: driven by market sensitive businesses
column226: fixed income
column227: equities
column228: and investment banking
column229: total banking revenues of $4 billion excluding the impact of loan hedges declined 6%. Treasury and trade solutions revenues of $2 billion grew 8% last year in constant dollars
column230:
driven by continued growth in transaction volumes with new and existing clients as well as improved deposit spreads.

"
column231:
"

Investment banking revenues of $875 million were down 27% from last year
column232: driven by an industry-wide slowdown in activity levels as well as our strong performance in M&A the prior year. Private bank revenues of $746 million grew 5% year-over-year
column233: driven by higher loan and deposit balances. And corporate lending revenues of $455 million were down 4% on a reported basis. In constant dollars
column234:
lending revenue declined 2% from last year as higher volumes were more than offset by the impact of positive fair value marks in the prior period.

"
column235:
"

Total market and security services revenues of $4.1 billion declined 15% from last year. Fixed income revenues of $3.1 billion were down 11% from last year. Rates in currencies grew 5% year-over-year with particular strength in March as market conditions improved versus the start of the year. However
column236:
this growth was more than offset by lower activity levels and a less favorable environment in both securitized products and commodities.

"
column237:
"

Equities revenues declined 19%
column238: reflecting the impact of lower volumes in cash equities as well as weaker performance in derivatives. In security services
column239: revenues grew 3%
column240: reflecting a modest gain on the sale of our private equity fund services businesses. And other included a charge of approximately $180 million
column241: reflecting the write-down of virtually all of our investments in Venezuela as a result of changes in the exchange rate. Total operating expenses of $4.9 billion were up 5% year-over-year
column242:
driven by higher legal and repositioning costs. Core expenses were down 1% as higher regulatory in compliance costs and investments were more than offset by lower compensation expense and the impact of FX translation.

"
column243:
"

On a trailing 12-month basis
column244: excluding the impact of severance
column245: our comp ratio remained at 27%. Total credit costs of $390 million were down from the fourth quarter but up significantly from last year. Nearly all of the ICG credit costs this quarter were related to energy. We built roughly $260 million of additional reserves and recognized losses of roughly $150 million in the energy sector. The reserve builds were concentrated in the E&P and services and drilling segments driven by ratings migration due to sustained low oil prices as well as the impact of regulatory guidance. At quarter end
column246:
our total energy exposure in ICG was $57 billion of which approximately $22 billion was funded. The funded reserve ratio was 4.2% including a funded reserve ratio of over 10% on the non-investment grade portion.

"
column247:
"

We have very little second lien exposure in the corporate portfolio with $85 million of total exposure and reserves against roughly a third of this amount. We provide more details on the corporate portfolio as well as the nature of our unfunded exposures in the appendix to our earnings presentation.

"
column248:
"

As we look at the potential for additional energy and non-energy provisions for the rest of 2016
column249: if oil prices were in the range of around $30 per barrel
column250:
we now estimate our full-year ICG cost of credit would be roughly $1.4 billion. This is higher than our previous estimate of roughly $1 billion with about two-thirds of the increase related to the potential impact of regulatory guidance and the remainder reflecting our revised view on the portfolio.

"
column251:
"

If you look across both the commercial and corporate portfolios
column252: our total exposure to reserve based lending in North America is roughly $4 billion of which $2 billion is funded and we have a 9% funded reserve ratio against these loans. We estimate that our total RBL exposure could be reduced by roughly $500 million as a result of the upcoming spring redeterminations
column253: and year-to-date
column254:
we have seen no material draw downs against these facilities.

"
column255:
"

Turning back to ICG
column256: we saw a significant increase in corporate non-accrual loans this quarter
column257: up by $730 million sequentially with roughly $500 million related to energy and $90 million related to metals and mining. Our total metals and mining exposure was $13 billion at the end of the first quarter with roughly $5 billion funded
column258:
and we did not incur any cost of credit on the portfolio in the first quarter.

"
column259:
"

The increase in non-accrual loans in metals and mining as well as other sectors outside of energy did not result in a material cost of credit as we have significant collateral against many of the loans. Nearly two-thirds of both the total additions as well as the energy-related additions to non-accrual loans this quarter remain performing.

"
column260:
"

On Slide 13
column261: we show the year-over-year EBT walks for ICG
column262: highlighting several themes. First
column263: despite the challenging market conditions this quarter
column264: we continued to see growth in several of our accrual and transaction services businesses including treasury and trades solutions
column265: private banks
column266:
and security services.

"
column267:
"

The market environment had a biggest impact on fixed income
column268: equities
column269: and investment banking
column270: which together were down 16% year-over-year. To offset these pressures
column271: we continue to actively address our structure
column272: reducing capacity in areas where revenues are likely to remain muted
column273: while preserving our client facing capabilities
column274: and these actions drove much of the repositioning charge in ICG this quarter. The remaining EBT drivers were the write-down of our investments in Venezuela
column275:
mark-to-market losses on low hedges driven by spread movements and of course the higher credit cost in energy.

"
column276:
"

Turning to the next slide
column277: as I noted
column278: we saw continued growth this quarter in many of our ICG businesses. Together
column279: TTS
column281: private bank and security services account for nearly half of total ICG revenues and they grew 7% year-over-year this quarter in constant dollars. This growth trend has been consistent over time as we\u2019ve deepened our relationships with our target clients and gained market share
column282: particularly as some peers have retrenched and reduced their global presence. Our strategy focused on providing integrated solutions to a targeted set of clients on a global basis is clearly yielding positive results. It does not mean that we would be immune to revenue swings in more market sensitive businesses like markets and investment banking
column283: but our mix of traditional banking and transaction services does provide a stable
column284: growing base of revenues in more efficient
column285: higher return businesses where we believe revenues are likely to remain muted and we\u2019re taking appropriate measures to optimize our capacity without diminishing our client capabilities
column286: and we are remaining disciplined on credit. So
column287: while we will not be immune to credit cycles
column288:
we strongly believe that our focus on larger multinational clients should result in better performance through the cycle. All of these reasons are why we are still confident that our ICG business is capable of producing an RoTCE in the range of 14% in a more normal environment.

"
column289:
"

Slide 15 shows the results for corporate/other. Revenues increased year-over-year
column290: mostly reflecting higher investment income. And expenses were down
column291:
mainly reflecting lower legal and related costs.

"
column292:
"

On Slide 16 we show Citigroup\u2019s net interest revenue and margin trends. The bars represent net interest revenue per day for each quarter in constant dollars
column293: showing consistent growth year-over-year in Citicorp while Citi Holdings has continued to shrink. Our net interest margin was 292 basis points this quarter
column294: flat for the fourth quarter as the sale of OneMain was fully offset by the impact of higher rates. Our NIM should be fairly stable at this level in the second quarter as we continue to offset the impact of the wind down of Citi Holdings
column295: with improvements in the core franchise. And we expect the acquisition of the Costco portfolio to provide a benefit of about 3 basis points
column296:
resulting in a NIM of roughly 295 basis points in the second half of the year.

"
column297:
"

On Slide 17
column298: we show our key regulatory capital metrics
column299: on a fully implemented basis. During the quarter
column300: our CET1 capital ratio increased to 12.3%
column301: driven by net income
column302: OCI movements and approximately $1.6 billion of DTA utilization
column303:
partially offset by $1.5 billion of common share buybacks and dividends. Our supplementary leverage ratio improved to 7.4%. And our tangible book value per share grew by 9% year-over-year to $62.58.

"
column304:
"

Before we turn it over to questions
column305: I\u2019d like to make a few comments regarding our expectations for full year 2016. Clearly
column306: this year started with a more challenging environment than we had anticipated
column307: resulting in lower revenues and a higher operating efficiency ratio than we had planned
column308: even before the pull forward of certain repositioning actions into the quarter. While the expense saves resulting from these repositioning actions will help offset some of this pressure
column309: we still expect our full year operating efficiency ratio to be higher than we had anticipated
column310: in the range of around 58%. This outlook assumes that equity and fixed income market revenues will be roughly flat sequentially in the second quarter and then exhibit a normal seasonal decline into the third and fourth quarters. We believe investment banking revenues should recover from first quarter levels
column311: if the environment is favorable
column312: based on the significant backlog of deals we have pending with our clients. And we should be able to continue growing the accrual and transaction services businesses year-over-year in ICG
column313:
as I described earlier.

"
column314:
"

On the consumer side
column315: we continue to believe we can achieve year over year revenue growth in our existing U.S. branded cards and Asia cards businesses in the latter half of 2016. And of course
column316:
we will benefit from the acquisition of the Costco portfolio in June.

"
column317:
"

Turning to Citicorp expenses
column318: there are a few things to consider. First
column319: we believe that regulatory and compliance costs have started to plateau. And we expect the repositioning actions we took in the first quarter to payback with roughly $400 million of total savings during the remainder of the year. So
column320: even though we expect to incur significant additional expenses related to Costco in the second half
column321: we believe our core operating expenses in Citicorp can remain roughly flat sequentially going into the second quarter and then decline somewhat thereafter. Repositioning cost should be significantly lower for the remainder of the year. And in total
column322: legal and repositioning costs should run in the range of about 225 basis points of Citicorp revenue this year
column323: higher than our original estimate of 200 basis points
column324:
again due to lower revenue assumptions.

"
column325:
"

While this quarter\u2019s results were disappointing
column326: we believe we are taking the right actions to address our cost base
column327:
while at the same time continuing to invest in those areas where we have a competitive advantage and can achieve strong returns over time. We continue to demonstrate strong capital generation this quarter and we remain highly focused on resource allocation across the franchise.

column812: but it's probably my fault. But I don't think -- I certainly didn't intend to indicate that op risk would be a source of capital release as a matter of fact if anything I think that the op risk portion of the advanced approach RWA is very sticky right now. There just isn't a clear cut agreement either amongst us or even of the regulatory bodies really as to how you reduce op risk
column813: so that's one of the reasons why when you've given you the Holdings\u2019 RWA in the past and this quarter for instance the Holdings' RWA is like $130 billion and of that $130 billion
column814: $49 billion is op risk. That's the same 49 billion that was there in the fourth quarter
column815: that's the same 49 billion that was there in the third quarter
column816: so we really
column817: we tend to think overall if you take a look at the Ks and the Qs I believe that our op risk RWA is like $325 billion and I consider that to be fairly sticky for now. Because I just don't have a good methodology in place to figure out how we drive that down. It's one of the very -- it frustrates me
column818: I think it frustrates probably every CFO and Chief Risk Officer that you would talk to at a major bank right now
column819:
but that's kind of where we are.

column878:
of the global total. So how do we think about that pressure relative to the pretty positive guidance and recent trend that you\u2019ve indicated?

John Gerspach

column880:

Well

column882: how we\u2019re operating today. One of the things that we\u2019ve done overtime is we\u2019ve moved a lot more of our trade business
column883: is being less balance sheet intensive. So it\u2019s we do a higher percentage of our business now on originate to sell and what that has given us is the balance sheet then to expand into the supplier finance aspects of trade. That has got better spreads and it really deepens the relationship then that we have with our client customers
column884: so in recognizing everything you said
column885:
trade is not what I would call a tremendous growth business at this point in time. But it\u2019s got the relationship qualities to it and it\u2019s really adding to the overall franchise in a very positive way.

John Gerspach

I wouldn\u2019t say it\u2019s moving down the ecosystem. I\u2019d say that we\u2019re expanding the business that we can do with our target market clients by helping them in working capital management. And what we\u2019ve done is we\u2019ve gotten out a lot of the FI kind of sponsored business which is episodic it is very low spreads. We\u2019ll still originate those things
column891:
but then we tend to syndicate and so the trade finance receivable. So what we really want to do as we want to use trade as we do in almost every one of our product areas. We want to use our trade capabilities to help our clients manage their business.
