column1:
{"Citigroup's (C) CEO Michael Corbat on Q2 2016 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Citigroup Inc. (NYSE:C)

"
column8:
"

Michael Corbat - Chief Executive Officer

"
column9:
"

John Gerspach - Chief Financial Officer

"
column16:
"

Erika Najarian - Bank of America Merrill Lynch

"
column18:
"

Eric Wasserstrom - Guggenheim Securities LLC

"
column22:
"

Matt Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities
column27:
"

Gerard Cassidy - RBC Capital Markets

"
column28:
"

Presentation

"
column30:
"

Hello and welcome to Citi\u2019s Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Review with Chief Executive Officer
column31: Mike Corbat; and Chief Financial Officer
column32: John Gerspach. Today\u2019s call will be hosted by Susan Kendall
column34:
"

We ask that you please hold all questions until the completion of the formal remarks at which time you will be given instructions for the question-and-answer session. Also as a reminder
column35: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column36: please disconnect at this time. Ms. Kendall
column40: Brent. Good morning and thank you all for joining us. On our call today
column41: our CEO
column42: Mike Corbat
column43: will speak first
column44: then John Gerspach
column45: our CFO will take you through the earnings presentation which is available for download on our website
column46: citigroup.com. Afterwards
column47:
we\u2019ll be happy to take questions.

"
column48:
"

Before we get started
column49: I would like to remind you that today\u2019s presentation may contain forward-looking statements which are based on management\u2019s current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results and capital and other financial condition may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today and those included in our SEC filings
column50:
including without limitation the Risk Factors section of our 2015 Form 10-K.

"
column52:
let me turn it over to Mike.

"
column57: we reported earnings of $4 billion for the second quarter of 2016
column58: or $1.24 per share. These results are a significant improvement from the first quarter not just in the overall amount of earnings
column59:
but in the proportion generated from our core business in Citicorp relative to the assets were winding down in Citi Holdings.

"
column60:
"

The results also show our institution\u2019s ability to generate solid earnings in a challenging and volatile environment. We grew both our consumer and institutional loan books
column61: reduced our expenses
column62: further reduced Citi Holdings\u2019 assets
column63:
and utilized additional deferred tax assets.

"
column64:
"

We meaningfully improved our efficiency ratio
column65: our return on assets
column66:
and return on tangible common equity from the first quarter. We generated and returned capital to our shareholders and the plan which was just approved significant increases to the amount of capital we\u2019ll return over the next year.

"
column67:
"

In our institutional franchise
column68:
both our markets and investment banking businesses are rebounding client activity from the last quarter. And our treasury and trade solutions business continued to grow revenues as we won new mandates in support of our clients\u2019 needs around the world. These results really show the benefits of our global network and the competitive advantages it provides.

"
column69:
"

In global consumer banking
column70: we had positive operating leverage in our international franchise
column71: highlighted by solid year-over-year growth in Mexico and continued sequential improvement in Asia. And as you know
column72: we\u2019ve been investing in our U.S. branded cards business. On June 17
column73: we acquired the Costco portfolio
column74:
gaining over 11 million cardholders in the process.

"
column75:
"

And earlier this week
column76: we announced the renewal of our partnership with American Airlines
column77: and in retail services
column78: we\u2019re renewing our partnership with the Home Depot. We\u2019re excited about the growth prospects of these businesses. In Citi Holdings
column79: we drove another significant reduction of assets
column80:
which were down 10% from the first quarter and 47% from one year ago.

"
column81:
"

For the eighth quarter in a row
column82: Holdings was profitable and the $93 million in net income was just 2% of Citigroup\u2019s total earnings for the quarter. We passed a significant milestone in the utilization of our deferred tax assets
column83: and in the second quarter
column84: we utilized $900 million in DTA
column85:
bringing the total to $10 billion since the DTA reached its peak in 2012.

"
column86:
"

While our remaining DTA does hamper
column87: our return on tangible common equity utilization helps fuel our generation of regulatory capital. And as you know
column88:
returning that capital to our shareholders has been a critical priority of ours.

"
column89:
"

During the quarter
column90: we reduced our outstanding common shares by approximately $30 million
column91: bringing the total to 105 million shares over the last four quarters. Even so
column92: our common equity Tier 1 ratio increased to 12.5%. In addition
column93:
our tangible book value per share increased to $63.53 in the quarter.

"
column94:
"

We\u2019ve been clear about our desire to increase the capital return over time and earlier this month
column95: we were pleased to learn that Federal Reserve did not object to the capital plan we submitted. And as a result
column96:
we\u2019ll return $10.4 billion in capital to our shareholders over the next four quarters.

"
column97:
"

The plan includes more than tripling our dividend to $0.16 per share and repurchasing $8.6 billion in common stock. This result combined with the feedback we received from the Fed and the FDIC on our resolution plan shows the progress we continue to make to becoming a safer and stronger institution.

"
column98:
"

Looking forward
column99: the environment remains challenging. We\u2019re continuing to navigate the consequences of the UK referendum on the EU from its economic impact to how exactly it will structure our legal vehicles to continue to best serve our clients. And while the UK has a new leader
column100:
the U.S. is still in the midst of a unique presidential campaign and such geopolitical and economic uncertainty doesn\u2019t create a clear picture for potential interest rate increases.

"
column101:
"

I think we\u2019ve navigated the most recent volatility very well as a result of our strategic client segmentation and strong risk management. Our credit quality remains very high and our institution is showing its resilience and strength of our model. While there has been a high degree of uncertainty in the wake of the referendum
column102: the capital markets are open
column103: strategic transactions are getting done
column104:
and we feel good about the client activity we\u2019re seeing.

"
column105:
"

And while we don\u2019t know what\u2019s coming \u2013 what will come in the months as we look forward
column106: we\u2019re always going to be looking at and continuing to optimize our resources. And I believe
column107: we\u2019re very well-positioned from the capital
column108: liquidity
column109:
and capacity perspective. John will now go through the presentation and then we\u2019d be happy to answer your questions. John?

"
column110:
"

John Gerspach

"
column111:
"

Thank you
column112: Mike
column113: and good morning
column114: everyone. Starting on Slide 3
column115: we show total Citigroup results. Revenues of $17.5 billion declined 8% from last year
column116: but expenses decreased 5%
column117: each driven primarily by the continued wind down of Citi Holdings
column118: as well as the impact of foreign exchange translation. And credit costs improved
column119: reflecting lower net credit losses
column120:
partially offset by a smaller net reserve release compared to the prior year.

"
column121:
"

We earned $4 billion in the second quarter
column122: or $1.24 per share
column123: each down 14% versus the prior period. Our preferred dividends were higher this quarter. However
column124: we were able to offset this impact through share buybacks
column125: which drove a 4% decline in our average diluted shares outstanding. In constant dollars
column126: Citigroup end of period loans grew 2% year-over-year to $634 billion
column127: as 6% growth in Citicorp was partially offset by the continued wind down of Citi Holdings
column128:
and deposits grew 5% to $938 billion.

"
column129:
"

On Slide 4
column130: we show the split between Citicorp and Citi Holdings. Citicorp is the predominant driver of profitability in the second quarter
column131: contributing 98% of total net income. Citicorp revenues of $16.7 billion were down 3% from last year on a reported basis. In constant dollars
column132: Citicorp revenues were flat to the prior year
column133:
as growth in our institutional franchise was offset by lower consumer revenues and the absence of prior period real estate gains in Corp other.

"
column134:
"

Citicorp expenses decreased 1%
column135: reflecting efficiency savings and a benefit from FX translation
column136: partially offset by continued investments in the franchise. And cost of credit grew 13% from the second quarter of last year
column137:
driven by a smaller reserve release versus the prior year. Credit quality remained broadly favorable across the franchise and net credit losses declined 5% year-over-year.

"
column138:
"

Pre-tax earnings of $5.7 billion in Citicorp were down from last year
column139: but improved over 25% sequentially on higher revenues
column140: lower operating expenses
column141:
and the lower cost in credit.

"
column142:
"

Turning to Citi Holdings
column143: both revenues and expenses declined significantly year-over-year
column144: as we continue to wind down the portfolio. We reduced Citi Holdings\u2019 assets by $7 billion this quarter
column145: ending the period with $66 billion of assets
column146: or just 4% of total Citigroup
column147:
with signed agreements in place to sell $7 billion of this amount.

"
column148:
"

Turning now to each business
column149: Slide 5 shows the results from North America consumer banking. Total revenues declined 3% year-over-year. Retail banking revenues of $1.3 billion grew sequentially
column150: but were down 4% from last year
column151:
as continued growth in consumer and commercial banking was more than offset by lower mortgage activity.

"
column152:
"

Average retail banking loans and checking deposits grew 10% and 9% respectively from last year. In branded cards
column153: revenues of $1.9 billion were down 1% from last year
column154: as a modest benefit from the Costco portfolio
column155: which we acquired on June 17
column156: was offset by the continued impact of higher rewards costs in our existing portfolio
column157:
as well as higher payment rates.

"
column158:
"

I\u2019ll talk more about branded cards in a moment
column159: but we continue to see good momentum from the investments we\u2019re making in our core products. In addition
column160: the early results from Costco have been very encouraging. New account acquisitions have far exceeded our expectations at over 337
column161:
000 to-date.

"
column162:
"

Purchase sales for the first 3.5 weeks totaled $5.7 billion
column163: with roughly two-thirds being out of store
column164: and the loan portfolio
column165:
which we acquired at $10.6 billion in size had already grown to a $11.3 billion by the end of the second quarter.

"
column166:
"

Costco is a great partner and we\u2019re excited about the potential for this business. We\u2019re also very pleased with the renewal of our American Airlines partnership
column167: which was announced earlier this week. We will continue to be the exclusive issuer of credit cards in the majority of acquisition channels
column168: including digital and mobile channels
column169: direct-mail
column170: e-mail
column171: phone and Admiral\u2019s Club lounges. At the same time
column172:
we were able to maintain a high-quality growing portfolio and attractive returns.

"
column173:
"

The impact of the renewal should lower pre-tax earnings by approximately $50 million per quarter through the end of next year
column174: primarily due to higher expenses
column175: including the amortization of intangibles. This impact on pre-tax earnings is expected to increase somewhat in 2018 and beyond
column176:
as certain additional revenue sharing arrangements become effective.

"
column177:
"

Finally
column178: turning to retail services
column179: revenues of $1.5 billion decreased 4% from last year
column180: reflecting the absence of two portfolios we sold in the first quarter
column181: as well as the impact of renewing and extending several partnerships
column182: principally Home Depot. We now have all of our significant partnerships in retail services secured through 2020 or beyond. We expect revenues to remain around this $1.5 billion level per quarter through the end of next year
column183:
as expected volume growth is likely to be offset by the impact of absorbing the more competitive terms in our partnership renewals.

"
column184:
"

We currently expect to operate the retail services business at an ROA in the range of 250 basis points. And we remain open to inorganic growth through new programs and acquisition opportunities
column185: given the right strategic fit and return profile. Total expenses of $2.4 billion in North America increased 5%
column186: driven by the Costco portfolio acquisition
column187: as well as continued marketing investments
column188:
partially offset by efficiency savings.

"
column189:
"

And finally
column190: credit cards in North America increased 13% from last year
column191: mostly reflecting a reserve building branded cards
column192:
driven by volume growth and the impact of Costco compared to a reserve release in the prior period.

"
column193:
"

On Slide 6
column194: we show results for international consumer banking in constant dollars. In total
column195: revenues were flat and expenses declined 1% from last year. In Latin America
column196: consumer revenues were up 4%
column197: as continued growth in retail banking
column198: which grew 7% year-over-year
column199: was offset by a decline in cards. These retail banking results reflect strong volume growth
column200: with average loans and deposits increasing 8% and 10%
column201: respectively. Latin America cards revenues declined 3% from last year. However
column202:
we are seeing continued signs of recovery in that business with purchase sales of 7% versus last year.

"
column203:
"

And finally
column204: expenses declined 5% year-over-year in Latin America
column205: mostly on lower legal and repositioning costs
column206: resulting in significant positive operating leverage. Excluding the impact of the gain on the sale of our merchant acquiring business in the third quarter of last year
column207:
we expect this positive operating leverage to continue in the second-half of 2016.

"
column208:
"

Turning to Asia
column209: consumer revenues declined 4% year-over-year
column210: driven by lower wealth management and retail lending revenues
column211: while cards revenues were flat to the prior year
column212: which I\u2019ll discuss more in a moment. Expenses grew 2% in Asia
column213:
in part due to higher repositioning costs.

"
column214:
"

On Slide 7
column215: we show Asia consumer in more detail. While wealth management revenues were down year-over-year
column216: we did see sequential growth in both revenues and AUM inflows during the quarter
column217: with a declining year-over-year trend in AUMs
column218: driven by the impact of lower equity market values. We also saw improvements in card revenues
column219: which were flat to last year
column220: and we continue to believe
column221:
we are on track to deliver year-over-year growth in the second-half of 2016.

"
column222:
"

Retail banking revenues
column223: excluding wealth management were also up sequentially
column224: but declined 2% year-over-year
column225: mostly reflecting the repositioning of our retail loan portfolio away from lower return mortgage loans
column226:
as well as some derisking in our commercial portfolio. These actions were partially offset by 3% growth in personal loans as you can see on the lower right.

"
column227:
"

The net impact was a decline in lending revenues year-over-year in the second quarter. However
column228: we expect these revenues to stabilize in the second-half of the year with continued growth in higher return personal loans
column229: and therefore
column230: an improvement in the overall yield of the portfolio. In total
column231: we expect Asia consumer revenues to return to growth in the second-half of 2016
column232:
resulting in positive operating leverage year-over-year.

"
column233:
"

On Slide 8
column234: we show some key performance indicators for our global branded cards franchise
column235: including year-over-year growth in purchase sales
column236: average card loans
column237:
and revenues.

"
column238:
"

In North America
column239: as you can see
column240: these trends show a positive improvement from the Costco portfolio acquisition. But even excluding that transaction
column241: we continue to show solid progress in our existing franchise
column242: with organic growth in purchase sales and average loans of 10% and 3%
column243: respectively
column244: and improving year-over-year revenue trend
column245:
which we expect to turn positive in the fourth quarter of 2016.

"
column246:
"

Turning to Asia
column247: as I discussed earlier
column248: card revenues were flat to the prior year
column249: as we continued to move past many of the regulatory headwinds in that region. Growth in purchase sales slowed this quarter in Asia
column250:
in part due to actions we took to lower the value of rewards on certain products in Australia. In response to regulation that capped interchange rates in that market.

"
column251:
"

We moved ahead of the market in changing our rewards program
column252: and this had a dampening effect on purchase sales this quarter. However
column253: we expect these trends to recover
column254: as peers follow suit and consumers adjust to the new programs. We also reduced promotional rate balances during the quarter
column255: which had a positive effect on yields. But combined with the slower purchase sales growth
column256:
this resulted in more modest loan growth year-over-year.

"
column257:
"

We have continued to manage well through the economic environment in Asia
column258: which have seen slower overall market activity relative to last year. And finally
column259: in Latin America
column260: the trends are improving as well
column261: with a sustained recovery in purchase sales beginning to drive loans and revenues. With continued momentum in the back half of the year
column262:
we would expect to see loan growth turn positive again year-over-year with revenue growth to follow thereafter.

"
column263:
"

Slide 9 shows our global consumer credit trends in more detail. Credit remained broadly favorable again this quarter with stable to improving NCL and delinquency rates in every region. The NCL rates in Latin America showed particular improvement this quarter
column264:
reflecting seasonal payment trend. We expect the NCL rate in Latin America to return to around 4.5% for the second-half of the year.

"
column265:
"

On Slide 10
column266: we show the year over year EBT walk for consumer on a year-to-date basis. We continue to face headwinds from market sensitive businesses like wealth management and mortgage on a first-half basis. As you can see
column267: the continued impact of our cards initiatives on revenues as well
column268: which should abate as we go into the second-half of the year. But the year-over-year impact from regulatory headwinds has slowed from the first quarter
column269: and the impact of business growth has become more pronounced
column270:
driven by the momentum we\u2019re seeing in our retail and commercial businesses in North America and Latin America.

"
column271:
"

Our expense growth in the first-half was predominantly driven by investments across our franchise
column272: as well as higher repositioning charges in the first quarter
column273:
and credit headwinds reflect the absence of prior period reserve releases. Underlying credit quality has remained stable with the net loss rate declining year-over-year.

"
column274:
"

Turning now to the institutional clients group on Slide 11
column275: revenues of $8.8 billion in the second quarter grew 2% from last year
column276: driven by fixed income and treasury and trade solutions. Total banking revenues of $4.4 billion declined 2%. Treasury and trade solutions revenues of $2 billion grew 9% from last year in constant dollars
column277:
driven by continued growth in transaction volumes with new and existing clients.

"
column278:
"

We continue to capture market share and saw strong momentum across payment products
column279: such as U.S. dollar clearing
column281: where purchase sales grew 9% year-over-year. Our focus remains on delivering integrated working capital solutions to our multinational clients
column282: addressing their full spectrum of supply chain
column283: trade services
column284: liquidity management
column285: procurement and payment needs around the world. We\u2019re seeing the demand for our services increase
column286: as corporations seek to optimize their resources in a slow growth environment
column287: at the same time
column288:
some of our peers are pulling back from global strategies.

"
column289:
"

Investment banking revenues of $1.2 billion were down 6% from last year
column290: mostly on lower industry-wide equity underwriting activity
column291: but showed a significant improvement from the prior quarter
column292: reflecting a rebound in both market conditions
column293:
as well as our wallet share in all major products.

"
column294:
"

Private bank revenues of $738 million were down 1% year-over-year on lower managed investments and capital markets activity. And corporate lending revenues of $389 million were down 18%
column295:
as higher loan volumes were more than offset \u2013 more than offset by an adjustment to the residual value of a lease financing as well as higher hedging costs.

"
column296:
"

Total markets and security services revenues of $4.7 billion grew 10% from last year. Fixed income revenues of $3.5 billion were up 14% from last year. Rates in currencies drove these results
column297: with revenues up 25% year-over-year
column298: including particularly strong performance in the days following the UK referendum. We saw continued growth in activity throughout the quarter with our corporate client base
column299:
which comprises over 40% of our direct client revenues in rates and currencies.

"
column300:
"

We believe a greater portion of our rates and currencies revenues are generated with corporate clients relative to that of our peers
column301: which is directly tied to the strength of both our global network and our treasury and trade solutions business. We view this as a differentiating advantage and one that provides scale and stability to our fixed income platform. Spread product revenues declined this quarter versus last year. However
column302: on a sequential basis
column303:
we did see a recovery particularly in securitized products.

"
column304:
"

Turning to equities
column305: excluding the valuation adjustments in the prior year of approximately $175 million
column306: our revenues were down 4% year-over-year
column307: driven by lower market activity
column308: as well as the comparison to strong trading performance in Asia in the prior year. And sequentially
column309: revenues grew 12%
column310:
reflecting improved performance in derivatives.

"
column311:
"

Finally
column312: in security services
column313: revenues declined 3% year-over-year in constant dollars
column314: mostly driven by the absence of revenues from divestitures. Excluding this impact
column315: underlying revenues were up 2%. Total operating expenses of $4.8 billion were down 2% year-over-year
column316:
driven by repositioning savings and a benefit from FX translation.

"
column317:
"

On a trailing 12-month basis
column318: excluding the impact of severance
column319: our comp ratio remained at 27%. Total credit costs of $82 million were higher than last year
column320: but down significantly from the prior quarter. Total net credit losses were $141 million
column321: with roughly two-thirds offset by related reserve releases. We also built roughly $30 million of reserves related to non-accrual loans
column322:
which increased by approximately $135 million during the quarter.

"
column323:
"

The cost of credit related to energy was minimal
column324: as net credit losses were mostly offset by previously existing reserves and the portfolio benefited from the stabilization in oil prices
column325: as well as increased capital markets activity. Given our target client focus on high-quality corporate credits
column326:
certain energy clients were able to access the capital markets as the market environment became more favorable in the second quarter.

"
column327:
"

This allowed these clients to improve liquidity
column328: resulting in either paydowns or improvements in the credit quality of our exposures. And our reserve-based energy exposures declined this quarter by roughly $400 million in ICG
column329: reflecting the impact of the spring redeterminations. We provide more details on our energy portfolio in the appendix to our earnings presentation. Outside of energy
column330:
the cost of credit was concentrated in a few specific credits.

"
column331:
"

Looking forward
column332: we remain cautious and the environment is uncertain
column333:
but we could see total ICG cost of credit in the back-half of the year in the range of $300 million to $500 million.

"
column334:
"

On Slide 12
column335: we show the year-over-year EBT walk for ICG on a year-to-date basis
column336: which shows significant improvement from the first quarter. We continue to see first-half growth
column337: although modest in our accrual and transaction services businesses
column338: despite certain headwinds this quarter
column339: led by our continued momentum in treasury and trade solutions. And with the strong second quarter performance in markets
column340: we are now flat to last year in fixed income and equities
column341: but remain down year-over-year in investment banking
column342:
given lower overall market activity.

"
column343:
"

We remain disciplined in our core expense management
column344: as we work to realize the benefits of the repositioning actions taken earlier this year to address the structure and capacity in certain parts of our franchise. These higher repositioning costs alone drove approximately $240 million of EBT decline year-over-year in the first-half. The remaining EBT drivers were the write-down of our investments in Venezuela
column345: mark-to-market losses on loan hedges driven by spread movements
column346: and of course
column347:
the higher credit costs in energy in the first quarter.

"
column348:
"

Slide 13 shows the results for corporate/other. Revenues decreased year-over-year
column349: mostly reflecting the absence of real estate gains in the prior year
column350: as well as the lower debt buyback activity
column351:
and expenses increased driven by higher corporate-wide marketing expenses and an increase in legal and related costs.

"
column352:
"

On Slide 14
column353: we show Citigroup\u2019s net interest revenue and margin trends. The bars represent net interest revenue per day for each quarter in constant dollars
column354: showing consistent growth year-over-year in Citicorp
column355:
while Citi Holdings has continued to shrink.

"
column356:
"

Our net interest margin was 286 basis points this quarter
column357: lower than our initial outlook of around 292 basis points
column358: driven by an equal combination of higher cash balances
column360: and lower low yields. Looking to the second-half of the year
column361: NIM should recover to around 290 basis points or slightly higher
column362: driven by a 3 basis point improvement from Costco
column363: as well as the normalization of average cash balances. This is lower than our prior outlook of around 295 basis points for the remainder of the year
column364: reflecting somewhat lower loan yields
column365:
as well as the absence of a previously assumed rate increase in the U.S.

"
column366:
"

On Slide 15
column367: we show our key capital metrics. During the quarter
column368: our CET1 capital ratio increased to 12.5%. Our supplementary leverage ratio improved to 7.5%
column369:
and our tangible book value per share grew by 7% year-over-year to $63.53.

"
column370:
"

Before I turn it over to questions
column371: let me make a few comments on our outlook for the third quarter. In consumer banking
column372: revenues in North America should grow sequentially
column373: driven by branded cards
column374: mostly reflecting the impact of the Costco acquisition
column375:
which should generate incremental revenues of roughly $200 million over the second quarter.

"
column376:
"

International consumer revenues should grow modestly from the second quarter
column377: resulting in year-over-year improvement in both Asia and Mexico
column378:
excluding the gain on the sale of our merchant acquiring business last year.

"
column379:
"

Turning to the institutional business
column380: we expect market revenues to reflect the normal seasonal decline from the second quarter
column381: while investment banking revenues should be largely stable
column382: assuming that market conditions remain favorable. And we expect continued year-over-year growth in our treasury and trade solutions business
column383:
as we continue to win new mandates and support our clients day-to-day banking needs around the world.

"
column384:
"

Finally
column385: to complete the revenue picture in Citicorp
column386: Corp other revenues are expected to be close to zero
column387: down from recent levels in the $100 million to $200 million
column388:
driven by a lower debt buyback activity and the absence of certain other episodic gains.

"
column389:
"

Core expenses in Citicorp should be slightly down from the second quarter
column390: reflecting the impact of repositioning savings
column391: partially offset by higher expenses related to Costco and other branded cards investments. And credit costs in Citicorp should be somewhat higher than the second quarter
column392:
mostly driven by reserve builds for volume growth and the impact of the Costco portfolio acquisition. Citi Holdings should be at break-even for the quarter.

"
column393:
"

And with that Mike and I are happy to answer any questions.

column1079: it actually started in the second quarter. But
column1081: we only had the portfolio for 13 days. But if you remember we kind of went through a similar set of discussions about LLR build when we acquired Best Buy back in 2013. And so as you correctly stated when we\u2019d purchase a loan portfolio
column1082: we acquired the receivables and they\u2019re recorded at fair value
column1083: so there\u2019s no corresponding loan loss reserve. Therefore
column1086:
"

If you think about the difference between an acquired portfolio and a matured portfolio
column1087: in a matured portfolio that build would be offset by LLR releases for loans that actually paid off. However
column1088: if the acquired loans don\u2019t have an LLR
column1089: there\u2019s no offsetting releases as they pay down. So that means that your rate of build to a
column1090: let\u2019s call it normalized LLR for an acquired portfolio is actually depended on how fast the new loans are created
column1091:
as well as how fast the old loans pay down.

"
column1092:
"

So if the pay down rate really has the predominant driver of the pace of the LLR build
column1093: as the portfolio gets replenished with new spend on existing cards. So since Costco has a high pay down rate
column1094:
the LLR build on the Costco portfolio is going to be more front-loaded than with the case with Best Buy. So I actually think that what you\u2019re going to see in the third quarter could very well be the highest quarterly LLR build that we will see as a result of acquiring the portfolio.

"

column1:
{"Citigroup's (C) CEO Mike Corbat on Q3 2016 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Citigroup Inc. (NYSE:C)

"
column16:
"

Erika Najarian - Bank of America

"
column19:
"

Matt Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column25: and welcome to Citi's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Review with Chief Executive Officer
column26: Mike Corbat and Chief Financial Officer
column27: John Gerspach. Today's call will be hosted by Susan Kendall
column28: Head of Citi Investor Relations. [Operator Instructions] Also
column30: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column36: Brian. Good morning and thank you all for joining us. On our call today
column41: will take you through the earnings presentation
column42: which is available for download on our website
column43: citigroup.com. Afterwards
column44:
we'll be happy to take questions.

"
column45:
"

Before we get started
column46: I would like to remind you that today's presentation may contain forward-looking statements
column47: which are based on management's current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results in capital and other financial condition may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors
column48: including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today and those included in our SEC filings
column49: including
column50: without limitation
column51:
the Risk Factors section of our 2015 Form 10-K.

"
column52:
"

With that said
column53:
let me turn it over to Mike.

"
column57: and good morning
column58: everyone. Earlier today
column59: we reported earnings of $3.8 billion for the third quarter of 2016 or $1.24 per share. I have to say that I'm very encouraged by the underlying momentum across our franchise
column60:
notably in several areas where we've been investing.

"
column61:
"

In our Global Consumer Bank
column62: we saw revenue increases in every business line and geography
column63: excluding the impact of a one-time gain last year in Mexico. In the U.S.
column64: we realized the benefit of our first full quarter of the Costco portfolio
column65:
which is exceeding our expectations in every key metric. The remainder of our branded cards portfolio as well as retail services also delivered modest revenue growth as did our more focused retail branch network.

"
column66:
"

In our institutional businesses
column67: revenues increased 2%
column68: as meaningful improvement in nearly every banking and markets product was partially offset by a swing in the mark-to-market value of loan hedges. Our Fixed Income franchise continued to benefit from strong client engagement across both our corporate and investor client base. And the backbone of our global network
column69: Treasury and Trade Solutions
column70: generated year-over-year revenue growth for the 11th consecutive quarter despite the low rate environment. In both our consumer and institutional businesses
column71:
we continued to grow both loans and deposits.

"
column72:
"

Consistent with our strategy
column73: we continue to shift our resources to where they can generate the best returns for our investors. This can mean investments like Costco or divestments of certain businesses. For example
column74: this month
column75: we announced agreements to sell our retail banking operations in Argentina and Brazil and plans for significant investment in Mexico. As a sign of our commitment to Mexico
column76: a market where we have real scale and confidence in its growth prospects
column77: we're integrating the local brand with Citi's
column78:
and the franchise will be known as Citibanamex.

"
column79:
"

Turning toward our dwindling non-core assets. For the ninth quarter in a row
column80: Citi Holdings was profitable
column81: and its $74 million in net income was less than 2% of Citigroup's total earnings for the quarter. Assets in Citi Holdings are now only 3% of our balance sheet and down 48% from one year ago. As you know
column82:
the next quarter will be the last that we report holdings results separately.

"
column83:
"

We remain intensely focused on shareholder returns. This was the first quarter we began implementing our new capital plan. During the quarter
column84:
we reduced our outstanding common shares by 56 million. The amount of outstanding is 2% lower from the prior quarter and 4% down from one year ago. That acceleration in the reduction of the amount of outstanding shares is due to the increased amount of buybacks under the capital plan.

"
column85:
"

In the past two years
column86: we've lowered the amount of outstanding common shares by 180 million or 6%. Our tangible book value per share increased to $64.71 in the quarter
column87: which is an 8% increase from one year ago
column88: reflecting the impact of the stock repurchases and our efforts to deliver quality and consistent earnings. Even so
column89: our Common Equity Tier 1 ratio increased to 12.6%
column90:
and we're committed to continue increasing the capital we return to our shareholders in order to improve our returns.

"
column91:
"

Looking forward
column92: while we expect growth both in the developed and emerging markets to pick up next year
column93: the uncertainties that color the current economic environment haven't retreated. Brexit
column94: hard
column95: soft or scrambled
column96: is still an open question and is likely to remain so for the near future. Here in the U.S.
column97: thankfully
column98: we're only a few weeks away from the presidential election
column99: and there seems to be growing consensus for interest rate increases
column100: but the Fed has clearly been dovish up to this point. Economic projections have improved somewhat recently
column101: particularly in places like Brazil and Russia
column102:
which may soon return to positive growth.

"
column103:
"

John will now go through our presentation
column104:
and then we'd be happy to take your questions. John?

"
column105:
"

John Gerspach

"
column106:
"

Thank you
column107: Mike and good morning
column108: everyone. Starting on slide three
column109: we show total Citigroup results. Revenues of $17.8 billion declined 4% from last year
column110: and expenses decreased 2%
column111: each driven primarily by the continued wind-down of Citi Holdings as well as the impact of foreign exchange translations. And credit costs improved
column112: reflecting a reduction in the provision for benefits and claims due to asset sales in Citi Holdings as well as lower net credit losses
column113:
partially offset by a net reserve build this quarter as compared to a small release in the prior year.

"
column114:
"

Net income of $3.8 billion declined 8% from last year
column115: mostly driven by mark-to-market loan hedges and the absence of one-time gains in the prior period. However
column116: we were able to offset some of this impact through underlying business growth. We also benefited from share buybacks
column117: which drove a 4% decline in our average diluted shares outstanding. In constant dollars
column118: Citigroup end of period loans grew 3% year-over-year to $638 billion and 7% growth in Citicorp was partially offset by the continued wind-down of Citi Holdings
column119:
and deposits grew 4% to $940 billion.

"
column120:
"

On slide four
column121: we show the split between Citicorp and Citi Holdings. Citicorp was again the predominant driver of profitability in the third quarter
column122: contributing 98% of total net income. Pre-tax earnings of $5.6 billion in Citicorp declined by roughly $300 million year-over-year. However
column123: this comparison includes losses on mark-to-market loan hedges this quarter as compared to gains in the prior year as well as certain previously disclosed one-time items that benefited the third quarter of 2015
column124:
including a gain on the sale of our merchant-acquiring business in Mexico and the reversal of valuation adjustment in our equities business.

"
column125:
"

Together
column126: these items drove a roughly $900 million negative variance in the year-over-year EBIT comparison
column127: all of which was reflected in revenues. Excluding these items
column128: Citicorp revenues would have grown 6% year-over-year
column129: with broad-based growth across our institutional and consumer businesses
column130:
partially offset by lower revenues in Corp/Other.

"
column131:
"

Citicorp expenses grew 3%
column132: mostly reflecting volume growth as well as continued investments in the franchise
column133: partially offset by efficiency savings. And cost of credit grew 8% from the third quarter of last year
column134: driven by a larger reserve build. Most of the reserve build related to our U.S. Cards franchise
column135: driven by the Costco portfolio acquisition
column136: volume growth and the estimated impact of newly proposed regulatory guidelines on third-party collections
column137: which I'll describe more in a moment. Credit quality remained broadly favorable across the franchise
column138:
with stable to improving loss rates in every region.

"
column139:
"

Turning to Citi Holdings. Both revenues and expenses declined significantly year-over-year as we continue to wind down the portfolio. We reduced Citi Holdings assets by nearly half over the past year
column140: ending the third quarter with $61 billion of assets
column141:
and we have signed agreements in place to reduce this amount by an additional $10 billion.

"
column142:
"

Turning now to each business. Slide five shows the results for North America Consumer Banking. Total revenues grew 7% year-over-year. Retail banking revenues of $1.4 billion grew 2% from last year on continued growth in average loans and checking deposits of 9% and 10%
column143: respectively. We generated this volume growth even as our branch footprint continued to shrink. We have spent the last several years reshaping our branch network
column144: upgrading technology and deepening our focus on our core six markets
column145:
enabling us to grow revenues while reducing expenses and significantly improving the profitability of our retail bank.

"
column146:
"

And now with the right footprint and infrastructure in place
column147: we are beginning to invest for additional growth by enhancing our segmentation strategy focused on the Citigold wealth management platform
column148:
improving our digital and mobile banking capabilities and continuing to upgrade the network with smart branches and dedicated Citigold centers.

"
column149:
"

Turning to branded cards. Revenues of $2.2 billion grew 15%
column150: reflecting the first full quarter of contribution from the Costco portfolio as well as modest organic growth. Excluding Costco
column151:
we generated 1% underlying revenue growth as we are beginning to lap the investment program we started last year and a portion of the new balances are maturing to full rate.

"
column152:
"

Turning to Costco. The early results continue to be very encouraging. New account acquisitions have far exceeded our expectations at nearly 800
column153: 000 to date. Purchase sales have totaled roughly $28 billion to date
column154: with over 70% being out of store
column155:
indicating that customers are using this card first for their everyday purchases. And the loan portfolio had grown to over $14 billion as of the end of the third quarter.

"
column156:
"

Finally
column157: retail service revenues of $1.6 billion improved 1% from last year. We saw better-than-expected average loan growth in retail services this quarter
column158: up 2% sequentially
column159:
which offset the absence of two portfolios we sold in the first quarter as well as the impact of renewing and extending several partnerships.

"
column160:
"

Total expenses for North America consumer were $2.6 billion
column161: up 12% from last year
column162: mostly reflecting the Costco portfolio acquisition
column163:
volume growth and continued marketing investments. Costco-related expenses were somewhat elevated this quarter as we addressed higher-than-anticipated service volumes in the weeks following the conversion.

"
column164:
"

And finally
column165: credit costs in North America increased significantly from last year. Net credit losses increased 6% to $929 million
column166: driven by volume growth. And we\u2019ve built over $400 million of net loan loss reserves during the quarter
column167:
including nearly $450 million in branded cards and retail services. Roughly a third of this amount was related to the acquisition of the Costco portfolio as we previously described. Another third was related to volume growth in normal seasoning in the portfolios. And the remaining third predominantly reflected the estimated impact of newly proposed regulatory guidelines on third-party collections.

"
column168:
"

In branded cards
column169: the NCL rate declined to 225 basis points this quarter
column170: reflecting the addition of the Costco portfolio
column171: which did not incur any losses during the quarter as we had generally excluded late-stage delinquencies from the acquired loans. Excluding Costco
column172: the NCL rate in branded cards has been in the range of roughly 280 basis points year-to-date. We expect the loss rate on Costco to be lower than the existing portfolio
column173:
but this benefit will likely be offset by the impact of seasoning as well as the estimated impact of the proposed regulatory guidelines I just mentioned. So we expect the NCL rate to remain in the range of around 280 basis points next year with some quarterly variability.

"
column174:
"

In retail services
column175: the loss rate has been in the range of around 410 basis points year-to-date
column176: and we expect it to increase to around 435 basis points next year
column177: again
column178: primarily reflecting the impact of seasoning and the proposed regulatory guidelines. Importantly
column179: these NCL rates are consistent with our return goals for each business
column180:
with branded cards targeting at least 225 basis points of ROA and retail services in the range of around 250 basis points.

"
column181:
"

On slide six
column182: we show results for International Consumer Banking in constant dollars. In total
column183: excluding the impact of a one-time gain on the sale of our merchant-acquiring business in Mexico last year
column184: revenues grew 4% and expenses were flat to last year. In Latin America
column185: excluding the prior year gain
column186: consumer revenues were up 5% as continued growth in retail banking
column187: which grew 11% year-over-year
column188: was offset by a decline in cards. These retail banking results reflect strong volume growth
column189: with average loans and deposits increasing 8% and 12% respectively. Latin America cards revenues declined from last year. However
column190: we continue to see signs of recovery in that business this quarter
column191:
which I'll cover more in a moment.

"
column192:
"

And finally
column193: expenses were flat year-over-year in Latin America
column194: resulting in significant positive operating leverage. As Mike mentioned earlier
column195: we are continuing to invest in our Mexico consumer franchise to drive sustainable growth
column196: with initiatives to enhance our branch network
column197: digital capabilities and service offerings. We expect to maintain positive operating leverage next quarter and each year throughout the investment period
column198:
driven by revenue growth as well as cost savings from upgrading and standardizing our technology platforms.

"
column199:
"

Turning to Asia. Consumer revenues grew 3% year-over-year
column200: driven by improvement in Wealth Management and cards
column201: partially offset by the continued repositioning of our retail loan portfolio. Wealth Management revenues grew 11% from last year on improving investor sentiment and continued positive AUM inflows. And cards turned positive as well with revenues up 4%
column202: driven by modest volume growth
column203: a continued improvement in yields and abating regulatory headwinds. Retail lending revenues remained under pressure as we continued to shift our portfolio away from lower-return mortgage loans this quarter. While this shift drove a modest decline in average retail loans and lending revenues
column204: our goal is to build a higher-return
column205:
more balanced portfolio over time.

"
column206:
"

And finally
column207: total credit costs grew 13% in our international consumer franchise
column208: reflecting a modest reserve build this quarter compared to our release in the prior year
column209:
while loss rates remained favorable.

"
column210:
"

On slide seven
column211: we show some key performance indicators for our global branded cards franchise
column212: including year-over-year growth in purchase sales
column213: average card loans and revenues. In North America
column214: as you can see
column215: these trends show a significant positive impact from the Costco portfolio acquisition. But even excluding that transaction
column216: we continue to show progress in our existing franchise with organic growth in purchase sales
column217: average loans and revenues this quarter. As I just noted
column218: in Asia
column219: we have also achieved revenue growth year-over-year
column220:
which we expect to continue going forward.

"
column221:
"

And finally
column222: in Latin America
column223: we achieved growth in both purchase sales and average loans this quarter
column224:
but revenues remained down 6% versus last year. This year-over-year comparison was affected by certain episodic fee revenues in the prior period.

"
column225:
"

On a comparable basis
column226: card revenues in Latin America would have been down 3% versus last year
column227: reflecting the continued impact of higher payment rates. With continued growth in purchase sales and average loans
column228:
we expect Latin America card revenues to return to sustainable growth in the second half of next year.

"
column229:
"

Slide eight shows our global consumer credit trends in more detail across both cards and retail banking. Credit remained broadly favorable again this quarter in every region. The decline in the NCL rate in North America mostly reflects the impact of the Costco portfolio
column230: which
column231: as I mentioned earlier
column232: did not incur any losses this quarter. Excluding Costco
column233: the NCL rate would have been flat to the prior year at 2.2%. And the NCL rate in Latin America showed particular improvement as well. However
column234: as our loan portfolio continues to grow in season
column235:
we still expect this NCL rate to run closer to 4.5% as we go into next year.

"
column236:
"

On slide nine
column237: we show the year-over-year EBIT walk for consumer for the third quarter. When we presented this slide last quarter
column238: our first half EBIT comparison was affected by several factors
column239: including the comparison to much stronger prior year periods in wealth management
column240: the early stage of our organic cards investments
column241:
the expenses we were absorbing on Costco before we had the full benefit of the revenues on that portfolio and the impact of significant repositioning charges in the first quarter of this year.

"
column242:
"

Now in the third quarter
column243:
you can see that we're beginning to build momentum again. We generated business growth in areas like Asia and North America cards as well as the retail and commercial businesses in both North America and Latin America. We are beginning to lap the impact of our branded cards investments on rebate and rewards costs and saw a full-quarter benefit from the acquisition of the Costco portfolio. And Wealth Management revenues continue to recover with improving investor sentiment.

"
column244:
"

In total
column245: we generated 5% underlying revenue growth in our consumer franchise this quarter. And while expenses were up as well by 7%
column246: we still grew our operating margin by roughly $150 million year-over-year
column247:
and we believe we can operate closer to flat operating leverage in the fourth quarter.

"
column248:
"

Of course
column249: we faced credit headwind this quarter as we built loan loss reserves compared to our release in the prior year. However
column250: some of the current quarter reserve builds were related to Costco and the proposed regulatory guidelines I mentioned earlier and shouldn't recur at these levels. So overall
column251: while we still face some headwinds
column252:
we feel good about the direction of the consumer franchise.

"
column253:
"

Turning now to the Institutional Clients Group on slide 10. Revenues of $8.6 billion in the third quarter grew 2% from last year
column254: driven by Fixed Income
column255: Investment Banking and Treasury and Trade Solutions. Total banking revenues of $4.3 billion grew 7% from last year. Treasury and Trade Solutions revenues of $2 billion grew 8% in constant dollars
column256: driven by continued growth in transaction volumes with new and existing clients. The TTS business remains core to our institutional strategy
column257:
delivering integrated solutions to our multinational clients and deepening our operating relationships with them across multiple products and markets.

"
column258:
"

Investment Banking revenues of $1.1 billion grew 15% from last year on strong debt underwriting activity
column259: partially offset by lower equity underwriting revenues. Private Bank revenues of $746 million were up 4% year-over-year
column260: driven by loan growth
column261: improved spreads and higher managed investment revenues. And Corporate Lending revenues of $450 million also grew 4%
column262:
mostly reflecting higher average loans. Total Markets and Securities Services revenues of $4.5 billion grew 11% from last year.

"
column263:
"

Fixed Income revenues of $3.5 billion were up 35%
column264: with both rates and currencies and spread products contributing to revenue growth. Rates and currencies grew over 30% year-over-year
column265: with particular strength in G10 Rates
column266:
reflecting strong client activity in a more favorable environment. And spread product revenues grew over 40% as credit and securitized markets continued to recover from the depressed levels we saw in late 2015.

"
column267:
"

Turning to equities. Excluding a positive valuation adjustment in the prior year of approximately $140 million
column268: our revenues were down 23% year-over-year
column269: driven by lower client activity and a less favorable environment
column270:
particularly in derivatives as well as the comparison to a strong quarter in Asia last year.

"
column271:
"

Finally
column272: in Securities Services
column273: revenues grew 4% year-over-year as increased client activity
column274: higher deposit volumes and improved spreads more than offset the impact of divestitures. Total operating expenses of $4.7 billion were down 1% year-over-year
column275: driven by efficiency savings
column276: lower legal costs and a benefit from FX translation. On a trailing 12-month basis
column277: excluding the impact of severance
column278: our comp ratio remained at 27%. Cost of credit was a benefit of $90 million in the third quarter as net credit losses were largely offset by previously existing reserves and we also saw a net benefit from ratings upgrades
column279:
reductions in exposures and improved valuations.

"
column281: we show the year-over-year EBIT walk for ICG on a year-to-date basis
column282: which shows continued significant improvement from the start of the year. Given the strong revenue performance this quarter
column283: we're now showing 2% growth on a year-to-date basis in our accrual and transaction services businesses as well as markets and banking. And we were able to achieve this growth while maintaining our operating discipline
column284: with expenses up just 1% even while we continue to invest in the franchise. The most significant year-over-year drag comes from other revenue items
column285: including the impact of the Venezuela devaluation in the first quarter as well as mark-to-mark losses on loan hedges
column286:
driven by spread movements.

"
column287:
"

As part of our ongoing risk management efforts
column288: we use loan hedges to manage our credit risk concentrations using predominately single main CDS positions against specific exposures in our portfolio. While these positions provide an economic hedge and help us manage concentrations to any particular client
column289: sector or region
column290: they are accounted for on a mark-to-market basis. And this year
column291: we've seen consistent spread tightening in these positions driving mark-to-market losses in comparison to the spread widening we experienced last year
column292:
which drove significant gains.

"
column293:
"

Slide 12 shows the results for Corporate/Other. Revenues decreased year-over-year largely due to the absence of the contribution from our equity stake in China Guangfa Bank
column294: which we sold this quarter. And expenses increased
column295:
mostly reflecting our sponsorship of the U.S. Olympic team this year as well as higher consulting cost related to the timing of the resolution plan submissions.

"
column296:
"

On Slide 13
column297: we show Citigroup's net interest revenue and margin trends. The bars represent net interest revenue per day for each quarter in constant dollars
column298: showing consistent growth year-over-year in Citicorp while Citi Holdings has continued to shrink. Our net interest margin was 286 basis points this quarter
column299: lower than our previous outlook of around 290 basis points as the benefit from Costco and other loan growth was offset by lower trading NIM and higher-than-anticipated cash balances during the quarter as we supported client activity. Looking to the fourth quarter
column300:
we expect NIM to remain relatively flat to this level.

"
column301:
"

On Slide 14
column302: we show our key capital metrics. During the quarter
column303: our CET1 capital ratio increased to 12.6%. Our supplementary leverage ratio was 7.4%
column304: and our tangible book value per share grew by 8% year-over-year to $64.71
column305:
in part driven by a 4% reduction in our shares outstanding.

"
column306:
"

Before I turn it over to questions
column307: let me make a few comments on our outlook for the fourth quarter. In consumer
column308: we expect to continue to generate year-over-year revenue growth in constant dollars across North America
column309: Asia and Latin America
column310: although
column311: sequentially
column312: mortgage activity could be seasonally slower versus the third quarter. In the institutional franchise
column313: we expect markets to reflect a normal seasonal decline from the third quarter
column314: but revenues still should improve year-over-year. And Investment Banking revenue should be broadly stable sequentially
column315: assuming that market conditions remain favorable. In Corporate/Other
column316:
revenue should continue to run close to 0.

"
column317:
"

Turning to expenses. We expect core expenses in Citicorp to be down modestly from the third quarter
column318: reflecting the absence of certain episodic costs
column319: lower compensation expense and other efficiency savings
column320: partially offset by seasonally higher marketing expenses and ongoing investment spend. And cost of credit in Citicorp should be higher than the third quarter
column321: assuming that credit costs in ICG normalize versus the benefit we saw this quarter. In consumer
column322: the LLR build should be lower in the fourth quarter. However
column323: we also expect NCLs to be higher as the Costco portfolio begins to incur losses and we continue to see the impact of volume growth. Finally
column324:
we expect Citi Holdings to operate around breakeven.

"
column325:
"

And with that
column326:
Mike and I are happy to take any questions.

"
column327:
"

Question-and-Answer Session

"
column328:
"

Operator

"
column329:
"

[Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Glenn Schorr with Evercore ISI. Please go ahead.

"
column330:
"

Glenn Schorr

"
column331:
"

Hi. Thanks very much. First and foremost
column332: a big-picture question. I think you showed a lot of progress in turning around growth in both international consumer and cards
column333: keeping expenses flat
column334: credits fine
column335: shrinking the share count
column336: all the good stuff. So when I look at slide 19
column337: I want help in your words interpreting it. At Citigroup
column338: the return on tangible is not where you want it to be
column339: not earnings
column340: the cost of capital. Excluding the disallowed DTA
column341: it's a lot closer at 9.2%. When you look at GCB and ICG
column342: they're even better. So I guess
column343: I'm curious on how you evaluate where profitability is and where it should be. Not sure you're ready to roll out goals for next year yet
column344:
but just any guidance there would be great.

"
column345:
"

John Gerspach

"
column346:
"

So
column347: I mean
column348: Glenn
column349: this is a perfectly fair question. What you see in Corp/Other
column350: I think we laid this out in some of the slides we used at the Financial Services Conference early in September. We recognized that we've got a lot of capital sitting there in Corp/Other. Some of it is capital we're holding above what we would say is our target capital. And again
column351: we're waiting to see where the whole CCAR process and the various rules as far as Basel III enhanced or Basel IV come out
column352:
but we recognize our debt capital there. And that's also where you got the DTA capital that we backed out at the bottom.

"
column353:
"

So there is improvement clearly that we intend to drive in GCB. We still have the target there of 20%. ICG is closer to where we had set the longer-term goal of 14%
column354: and we still have a ways to go in getting that 9.2% up to that overall target of 14% that we set out. A good piece of that will come from continued business growth and continued expense efficiencies. A small bit will come as we continue to wind down holdings
column355:
and the rest of it will come as we continue to increase the amount of capital that we're able to return to our shareholders.

"
column357:
"

Fair enough. Two small ones to follow up. Specifically
