et cetera. Is that getting it up to speed with what you've been doing globally? Or is there something else? I know that's moving it forward. Is that going to be at the cutting-edge of what you're doing globally? Maybe you could speak to also how you're tying together the network between the U.S. and Mexico as well.

"
column749:
"

Mike Corbat

"
column750:
"

Sure
column751: I'll start. So if you look at our footprint in Mexico
column752: we've got about 1
column753: 500 branches in Mexico today
column754: and I'd say a lot of that investment spend
column755: if you went down there and looked
column757: is getting these branches up to where they should be from an appearance
column758: from a technology perspective. The other piece is today
column759: we\u2019ve got about 7
column760: 500 ATMs in Mexico. We want to do two things. We not only want to move towards smart ATMs as Mexico and Mexico banking move more towards digital. We also want to increase the number of ATMs. And what we've talked about is going from 7
column763:
"

And at the same time
column764: going to the earlier part of your question
column765: you'll see us continuing to employ our strategy around branch optimization. And the introduction of smart branches gives us that flexibility that you've seen us using in Asia
column766: in the U.S. and other parts of the world around that. And so it's kind of a combination of those. And the other piece we talked about is the technology piece
column767: and that technology piece really serves our ability to continue to bring the platforms of the historic Citi together with Banamex
column768: now Citibanamex
column769:
and trying to make sure we're offering the best of each to each.

"
column770:
"

Betsy Graseck

"
column771:
"

And that's within Mexico
column773: the Citi piece in Mexico and the Banamex piece in Mexico coming together
column774:
not Citi U.S. linked up with Mexico Banamex?

"
column775:
"

Mike Corbat

"
column777:
"

Betsy Graseck

"
column778:
"

Okay. And then Mexico's had real-time banking for a while. I know that here in the U.S.
column779:
we're beginning to launch that. I know you -- there's a press release I saw that you were going to be joining Clear Exchange. So maybe if you could speak a little bit to what your goals are there for real-time banking. And is there anything on money transfer in general between the two countries as well?

"
column780:
"

John Gerspach

"
column781:
"

Well
column783: I don't have the statistics in front of me. But when you look at branch transactions in Mexico and the way our customers like to bank
column784: they're very
column786: for lack of a better term
column787: branch-dependent or they really favor coming into the branches. And so the move towards digital is occurring certainly slower than the U.S. or parts of Asia. But we want to make sure we're there on the forefront in terms of having that technology in place and having to have the ability to convert as people care to do that. And we think that'll continue to happen over time
column788: although
column789: for right now
column790:
it feels like it's certainly occurring at a slower pace than the rest of the world.

"
column792:
"

Okay. And then just on
column793: like
column794:
is there anything there with money transfer between the two countries or not really?

"
column795:
"

John Gerspach

"
column796:
"

Well
column797: of course
column798: there's money transfer between the two countries. I don't know of anything and Clear Ex [ph] that necessarily promotes that. And obviously
column799: around money-management across that border
column800: you got to be smart about knowing your customer and your systems you have in place around KYC AML. And clearly
column801: we continue to make investments on that front. And as part of not just Mexico but who we are
column802: we are a large mover of money around the world
column803: and certainly
column804:
Mexico's one of those places where it's the same.

"
column805:
"

Betsy Graseck

"
column806:
"

Okay. I appreciate that. Thanks.

"
column808:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Matt O'Connor with Deutsche Bank. Please go ahead.

"
column809:
"

Matt O'Connor

"
column810:
"

I'm actually all set. Thank you.

"
column811:
"

Operator

"
column812:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Matt Burnell with Wells Fargo Securities.

"
column814:
"

Thanks for taking my call. Just a couple of quickies
column815: perhaps. John
column816: how are you all thinking about the potential for capital markets disruption from the beginning of the Brexit negotiations? There's been a lot of commentary about potential costs
column817: but I guess I'm just curious on the revenue side
column818:
how you are thinking about -- how that might play out over the next couple of quarters.

"
column819:
"

Mike Corbat

"
column820:
"

Matt
column821: it's Mike. From -- we don't have a lot of answers right now. And as the Prime Minister came out
column822: I guess
column823: it was last week or 1.5 weeks ago
column824: Article 50 won't be invoked until March of next year. That then starts to clock on a 2-year window. And I think it's our own belief
column825: based on a series of elections in Europe
column826: the combination of France and Germany
column827: that information is probably going to be more back-end loaded than front-end loaded. And so what we've been working for is making sure
column828: as that information comes out
column829: we're in a position to continue to service our clients really no matter what. And when you think about our franchise
column830: we not only have a sizable franchise in U.K.
column831:
we also operate in 20 of the 27 EU countries.

"
column832:
"

And so we've got flexibility. We've got our passport bank already established in Ireland. We've got the pipes connected
column834: certainly
column835: the larger countries within the EU. So we've got flexibility around that. And what we've said in the meetings that I've had with both U.K. and other European officials
column836: we're going to watch and see this unfold
column837: but our primary goal here is to make sure that in an undisrupted way
column838: we can continue to serve our clients. And we think our structure today gives us time and flexibility. And when the time is right
column839: we'll make a decision of ultimately what we're going to do. But we'd like to benefit as much information as possible before we make that decision
column840:
and we just don't have it today.

"
column842:
"

Okay
column843: that's helpful. Thank you. And just
column845: just a question on the card business and the investments you're making there. There have obviously been a couple of new products that have been either introduced or revamped in the U.S. market over the last quarter or so. I guess
column846:
I'm curious how you're thinking about the competitive landscape. And does that potentially put some greater pressure on you to increase investment relative to rewards in the card space? And does that have an effect on potential returns on that business over the next couple of years?

"
column847:
"

John Gerspach

"
column849: the cards business has always been competitive. So people introducing new products is nothing new. One of the new products that got introduced appears to be an answer -- an attempt to answer how our Prestige product
column850: which has been out there now for maybe 5 years or so
column851: and we still think that the Prestige card that we have is a mentally strong offering and should withstand the test. So we don't see anything there in some of these new issuance
column852:
these new introductions that would cause us to change our view as to where we can drive the cards business over time.

"
column853:
"

Matt Burnell

"
column854:
"

Okay. And then just finally for me
column855: in terms of the net interest margin
column856: you expect that to be stable in the fourth quarter? Last quarter
column857:
you had anticipated that Costco might have a modest benefit to the margin. Where is the change in the outlook there? Is it just cash balances or is it something else?

"
column858:
"

John Gerspach

"
column860: you hit it
column861: you hit it. When we -- on the second quarter NIM
column863: was 286 basis points. And the guidance we put out suggested that we thought third quarter NIM could grow to 290 basis points. And as we said
column864:
embedded in this assumption was that we'd get about a 3 basis point lift from Costco. And we thought an additional 3 basis point improvement by normalizing average cash balances. And we knew that we had a 2 basis point drag coming from the increase at a higher FDIC assessment that all the large banks got. So that's sort of how we got to the 290.

"
column865:
"

So then you ask
column866: okay
column867: so what actually happened? Well
column868: we got the 3 basis points from Costco. As a matter of fact
column869: our loan book actually contributed a 4 basis point improvement to NIM. We got the additional FDIC assessment so that did cost us too. But as we mentioned in some of our commentary
column870: we took on additional deposits to support client activity
column871: and therefore
column872: we just didn't get the improvement that we were seeking from lowering the average cash or HQLA. And then finally
column873: we had a 2 basis point hit with the lower NIM on our trading book. And the trading book NIM is always difficult to forecast. So 4 basis points up on loans
column874: 2 basis points down on trading
column875: 2 basis points down from FDIC
column876:
flat.

"
column877:
"

Matt Burnell

"
column878:
"

Okay. Thank you.

"
column879:
"

Operator

"
column880:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Brian Kleinhanzl with KBW. Please go ahead.

"
column881:
"

Brian Kleinhanzl

"
column882:
"

Hi. Good afternoon. I have a quick question on the Costco. You mentioned the new account openings. But can you give some color on the progression of those new account openings? Like
column883: are you at a run rate right now where you can say this is about
column884: on average
column885:
what we're opening per week or per month?

"
column888: I think we're still in the early days of this. Obviously
column889: as I mentioned a little bit earlier
column890: Costco had not been able to issue cards for 7 months or so. So there's been a large pent-up demand for these cards. So I certainly would have want to put the first 3.5 months and generating 800
column891: 000 new accounts as a new run rate. But it is -- it still is generating new accounts at a faster rate than we thought it was going to. And just like with everything else with the Costco portfolio
column892: I think we'll know more and be able to give you a better sense as to sustained run rates of growth
column894: over the course of the next two to three quarters. It's 1.5 quarters
column895: not even a quarter
column896: it's 4 months today
column897: just about since we took over the book. And it takes a while to get into the normal rhythm so you can actually have an understanding as to the way the portfolio is going to operate. And as we develop that level of comfort and understanding
column898:
we'll be happy to provide you with more color.

"
column900:
"

Okay. And then I had just one -- a different question on the -- you mentioned that there was an improvement in the yield in Asia. Can you maybe give some background on what's allowing you to have improved deal? Is it a change in geographies? Or is it just new loans coming out at higher yields?

"
column901:
"

John Gerspach

"
column904: we've been in the process of repositioning the cards portfolio in Asia. We got a lower amount of promotional balances now. So that's enabled us to -- some of that is because the promotional balances have run off
column905: but a lot of that is because these promotional balances now have converted into full rate loans. And that is really
column906: I'd say
column907:
the lion\u2019s share of the yield improvement that we're seeing in that portfolio.

"
column908:
"

Brian Kleinhanzl

"
column909:
"

Can you give what percentage is promotional over remaining balance?

"
column911:
"

No
column912:
I can't go that deep right now. I'm sorry.

"
column913:
"

Brian Kleinhanzl

"
column914:
"

Okay. Thanks.

"
column916:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Marty Mosby with Vining Sparks. Please go ahead.

"
column917:
"

Marty Mosby

"
column918:
"

Hi. I was checking in on the DTA. It didn't seem like we get much of a pull-down in that this quarter and just was curious why not.

"
column919:
"

John Gerspach

"
column920:
"

The underlying business has used about $300 million of DTA. And then given the movement in OCI
column921: as we saw a little bit of the impact of slightly higher rates but more important
column922: and equally as important
column923: the strengthening of the dollar against certain key currencies
column924: that wiped out the -- essentially wiped out the improvement that we got in DTA from the earnings. But again
column927: we're doing okay and we're in line with where we said we were going to be. And don't forget
column928: when it comes to utilizing the DTA
column930: it's really being focused on utilizing the FTCs
column931:
and we remain on track to utilizing substantial portion of the FTC this year.

"
column932:
"

Marty Mosby

"
column933:
"

CET1 kind of growth in the ratio
column934: to kind of roll back 18 months
column935: you were kind of increasing about 30 basis points per quarter. Last year
column936: it was really down to about 20 basis points per quarter. And then this quarter
column937: with the accelerated repurchase
column938: you're down to about 10 basis points per quarter. Is that just kind of a normal progression? And as you kind of think about that
column939:
you kind of round out at around 13% and then you start to kind of stabilize. And is that just kind of a maybe just a top looking down kind of approach of kind of how you kind of seeing yourself kind of landing in that ratio?

"
column940:
"

John Gerspach

"
column941:
"

Yes
column942: I'd say
column943: Marty
column944: that what you're seeing is exactly what we want to achieve over time
column945: which is to be able to return the capital that we're generating to our shareholders. And so over time
column946: we'd like to be able to continue to see that
column947: again
column948: that CET1 ratio
column949: either staying where it is or perhaps as we get more insight into some of the CCAR rules and some of the scenarios
column950:
even have a somewhat lower CET1 ratio. I think that's consistent with our view towards increasing the amount of capital return.

"
column951:
"

Marty Mosby

"
column952:
"

And then just lastly
column953: real quick question
column954: on the loan loss build
column955: loan loss reserve build in the consumer bank
column956:
you allocate most of that to Costco and to the regulatory guideline change. Could you give us a more specific number just for that? Because that really is kind of a setup in a sense of a change or unusual build that wouldn't recur as you move forward.

"
column959: I'd say we kind of -- we try to break that 450 build in cards out into thirds. One third was Costco. Another third was seasoning and volume growth. And then the last third was predominantly due to the impact of those regulatory guidelines. So it's something less than the 150 of the other third. If you want to think about that as being something in the 120
column961:
I'm not going to argue with you.

"
column963:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Gerard Cassidy with RBC.

"
column966: guys. Can you guys share with us -- clearly
column967: the oil markets have stabilized dramatically from the first quarter. Are you guys seeing any opportunities to grow the energy business at this point? Or how do you feel about your energy business
column968:
understanding that the credit has stabilized and is trying to improve in many areas?

"
column973: we do see some opportunities. Clearly
column974: as oil has stabilized and stabilized somewhere around the $50 area
column975: we've seen the combination of M&A conversations to combination of financing
column976: refinancing conversations and overall activity and people starting to engage coming back. Again
column978: our customer or client base remains consistent to. We are largely a multinational
column979: global-type client energy player throughout the vertical. And we're going to remain consistent to that. We think there's some opportunity for us to go back and you look historically
column980:
we've had a strong energy franchise.

"
column982:
"

Great. And then onto deposits. You guys saw some very good deposit growth in the ICG business in the quarter on a sequential basis. Did the change in the money market mutual funds have any impact on that growth?

"
column984:
"

Not that we can see.

"
column988: you pointed out that the trading markets
column990: are seasonal in the fourth quarter. Last year
column994: it was down about just under 20%. The year before that
column995: those numbers declined 30% sequentially. Do you have any sense on what this year is shaping up? Well
column996: you recognize they will be down
column999:
"

No. I think if you look historically
column1000: you run the last two years
column1001: you'd be looking at something in the low 20% range as being kind of the norm as to whether or not this year
column1002: we're going to get that type of reduction. I don't know. But December usually is a pretty light month
column1003: and there's certainly nothing to indicate right now that
column1004:
that's going to change. So I still think that you need to expect some seasonal reduction in fourth quarter trading revenues.

"
column1006:
"

Great. Appreciate the help. Thank you.

"
column1008:
"

Your final question comes from the line of Mike Mayo with CLSA. Please go ahead.

"
column1010:
"

Hi. I was just looking for a clarification. You had mentioned there wouldn't be positive operating leverage until 2018
column1011:
but I think you're referring to a specific area as opposed to the firm.

"
column1014: that's exactly right. The question was had to do with North America consumer and whether or not it was more likely that we'd have positive operating leverage in '18 versus '17
column1020:
we have no further questions in the queue at this time.

"
column1022:
"

Great. Thank you all for joining us today. That's been a busy morning. If you have any follow-up questions
column1023:
please feel free to reach out to Investor Relations. Thank you.

"
column1025:
"

Thank you. This concludes today's conference call. You may now disconnect.

column1:
{"Citigroup's (C) CEO Mike Corbat on Q4 2016 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Citigroup
column15:
"

Erika Najarian - Bank of America

"
column22:
"

Matt Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column26: and welcome to Citi's Fourth Quarter 2016 Earnings Review with Chief Executive Officer
column27: Mike Corbat; and Chief Financial Officer
column28: John Gerspach. Today's call will be hosted by Susan Kendall
column29: Head of Citi Investor Relations. We ask that you please hold all questions until the completion of the formal remarks at which time you'll be given instructions for the question-and-answer session. Also
column30: as a reminder
column31: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column32: please disconnect at this time. Ms. Kendall
column36: Geena. Good morning and thank you all for joining us. On our call today
column38: Mike Corbat will speak first. Then John Gerspach
column40: will take you through the earnings presentation
column41: which is available for download on our website
column42: citigroup.com. Afterwards
column43:
we'll be happy to take questions.

"
column44:
"

Before we get started
column45: I would like to remind you that today's presentation may contain forward-looking statements
column46: which are based on management's current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results in capital and other financial condition may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today and those included in our SEC filings
column47: including without limitation
column48:
the Risk Factors section of our 2015 Form 10-K.

"
column49:
"

With that said
column50:
let me turn it over to Mike.

"
column52:
"

Thank you
column56: we reported earnings of $3.6 billion for the fourth quarter of 2016 or $1.14 per share. For the full-year
column57:
we generated nearly $15 billion in net income or $4.72 a share. We finished the year strongly; and we carried that momentum into 2017.

"
column58:
"

We drove revenue growth in our businesses and demonstrated strong expense discipline across the firm. We achieved a full-year Citicorp efficiency ratio of 58% as we targeted while again increasing our loans and deposits.

"
column59:
"

We had excellent performance across our institutional businesses
column60: especially in fixed income and equities
column61:
with revenue up 31% for the quarter and 10% for the entire year despite the difficult start in the first quarter.

"
column62:
"

Treasury and Trade Solutions generated year-over-year revenue
column63: margin growth for the 12th consecutive quarter. We successfully navigated the volatility in the energy sector
column64:
earlier in the year resulting in solid credit performance consistent with our target client strategy.

"
column65:
"

In Global Consumer
column66: our U.S. branded cards business continues to see the early benefits from the Costco portfolio and our other cards products also delivered revenue growth. Internationally
column67: we again generated revenue growth and positive operating leverage in both Asia and Mexico. And we continued our investment in Mexico
column68: where we had scale
column69: a strong brand position
column70:
and the opportunity to drive improved wallet share and returns.

"
column71:
"

2016 was a very important year for Citi in several respects. This marks the last time
column72: we'll report the results of Citi Holdings separately. We will end this chapter much differently than we began. At its peak
column73: it had over $800 billion in assets generating sometimes multibillion dollar losses in a single quarter. Today Holdings $54 billion of assets are only 3% of Citigroup's balance sheet and for the 10th quarter in a row
column74:
Holdings was profitable with $87 million of net income. The results of Citigroup today are driven by the core franchise and we no longer need to distinguish between core and non-core.

"
column75:
"

In short
column76: the restructuring is over
column77: Citi is a unique and resilient franchise and after a lot of hard work
column78: we will focus on further optimizing its performance to the benefit of our shareholders. We won't take our eye off the ball on expenses and are committed to investing only in areas where we're going to drive improved returns. And in fact
column79:
we're beginning to produce the capital returns our investors expect and deserve.

"
column80:
"

In 2016
column81: we returned nearly $11 billion in capital to our shareholders. This reflected the impact of our original capital plan as well as the incremental increase we announced in November. That raises the total return to $12.2 billion for the 2016 CCAR cycle. And you're seeing the results
column82: buybacks of common stock
column83: a core element of the plan drove down the common shares outstanding by 181 million shares or 6% during the year and our tangible book value increased to $64.57
column84:
up 7% for the year.

"
column85:
"

Even with this capital return
column86: we ended the year with a common equity Tier 1 ratio of 12.5%
column87: 40 basis points higher than we started the year. And as you can see
column88:
the capability of this franchise to both generate and return very significant amounts of capital is quite powerful.

"
column89:
"

We move closer to our aspiration to be an indisputably strong and stable institution. The feedback we received from the FED and the FDIC in our resolution plan was another significant milestone for our firm during the year. And we are committed to improving not just our return of
column90: but our return on capital. Excluding the capital supporting disallowed DTA
column91: we generated a 9% return on our tangible common equity in 2016 and given our trajectory
column92:
we expect to reach at least 10% return on our TCE excluding disallowed DTA in 2018.

"
column93:
"

Looking forward
column94: economic sentiment is clearly become more positive since the U.S. election. In general
column95: the benefit from pro-growth policies as well as our clients. In addition
column96: we see a path for more consistent interest rate increases and revenue opportunities in areas such as infrastructure investment. And while corporate tax reform may lead to a writing down of a proportion of our deferred tax assets
column97:
it should also result in higher net income and improved returns.

"
column98:
"

At this point
column99:
no one actually knows what would become U.S. policy. But I believe that there are pent up and capital investment opportunities which corporates are poised to act on given the right circumstances. This could boost GDP growth in the U.S. and beyond given the significance of our economy globally.

"
column100:
"

So we enter the year with a healthy amount of optimism about the prospects of growth strengthening. John will go through our presentation and then we'll be happy to answer your questions.

"
column101:
"

John Gerspach

"
column102:
"

Thank you
column103: Mike
column104: and good morning everyone. Starting on Slide 3

column106: as well as the impact of foreign exchange translation. In our core Citicorp franchise revenues grew 6% year-over-year
column107:
while expenses declined 2% and in constant dollars revenues grew 8% versus 1% growth in expenses.

column108:
"

Citigroup credit costs improved significantly driven by improvement in both ICG and Citi Holdings
column109:
partially offset by higher credit costs in consumer reflecting the loan growth as well as the shift from reserve releases last year to reserve builds in North America cards.

"

Net income of $3.6 billion in the fourth quarter grew 4% from last year and earnings per share of $1.14 grew 8% including the benefit of share buybacks

which drove 5% decline in our average diluted shares outstanding.

"
column112:
"

On a full-year basis
column113:
we earn nearly $15 billion or $4.72 per share with a drag from higher preferred dividends in 2016 more than offset by lower shares outstanding. And our full-year return on tangible common equity was 7.6% on a reported basis or 9% excluding the TCE supporting disallowed DTA.

"
column114:
"

In constant dollars
column115:
Citigroup end of period loans grew 3% year-over-year to $624 billion as 6% growth in Citicorp was partially offset by the continued wind down of Citi Holdings and deposits grew 4% to $929 billion.

column116:
"

On Slide 4
column117: we showed a split between Citicorp and Citi Holdings. Citicorp was again the predominant driver of profitability in the fourth quarter contributing $3.5 billion or 98% of total net income. Pre-tax earnings of $5.1 billion in Citicorp grew by over $1.3 billion year-over-year mostly driven by higher revenues and lower credit costs in our institutional franchise. And on a full-year basis
column118: despite the difficult first quarter
column119:
we were able to deliver an efficiency ratio in Citicorp of 58% in line with our revised goal for the year.

"
column120:
"

Turning to Citi Holdings. We earned a small pre-tax profit in the fourth quarter with revenues
column121: expenses
column122: and cost of credit each declining significantly as we continue to wind down the portfolio. We reduced Citi Holdings to $54 billion of assets at year-end or 3% of total Citigroup and we have signed agreements in place to reduce this amount by an additional $9 billion. On a full-year basis
column123: Citi Holdings contributed $600 million of net income
column124:
which we do not expect to recur in 2017.

"
column125:
"

On Slide 5
column126: we show the full-year 2016 EBIT walk for Citigroup. In total EBIT declined by over $3 billion from 2015 to 2016. Roughly half of which was attributable to lower gains on asset sales in Citi Holdings and a modest impact from FX translation. The remaining EBIT decline occurred in the core Citicorp franchise. However this comparison includes losses on mark-to-market loan hedges in 2016 as compared to gains in the prior year
column127: as well as certain previously disclosed one-time items that also affect the variance
column128: including a gain on the sale of our merchant acquiring business in Mexico in 2015 and the write-down of our investment in Venezuela in the first quarter of 2016. Together
column129:
these items drove a nearly $1.3 billion negative variance in the full-year EBIT comparison all of which was reflected in revenues.

"
column130:
"

Excluding these items
column131: Citicorp revenue increased 3% year-over-year in constant dollars or over $1.7 billion driven by growth in fixed income markets
column132: Treasury and Trade Solutions
column133: North America Card
column134: and Mexico Consumer revenues. And our operating margin grew by nearly $400 million including the impact of significant investments in our North America cards franchise that have not yet fully matured. Of course credit cost also increased in 2016 as we grew loans in our target segments
column135: including the acquisition of the Costco portfolio. However
column136:
most of the year-over-year variance of roughly $700 million in 2016 reflects the absence of nearly $400 million of reserve releases that occurred in 2015 as credit normalized in North America cards.

"
column137:
"

Turning now to each business
column138:
Slide 6 shows the results for North America Consumer banking. Total revenues grew 5% year-over-year in the fourth quarter. Retail banking revenues of $1.3 billion declined 4% from last year reflecting lower mortgage revenues as well as the impact of certain consumer incentives offered in coordination with the launch of our enhanced retail segmentation strategy.

"
column139:
"

During the quarter
column140: we launched our enhanced Citigold integrated wealth management offering for the Affluent segment in the U.S. We also launched Citi Priority for the emerging Affluent segment and we executed significant enhancements to our mobile banking platform across all our consumer segments. We continue to rationalize our physical footprint down 7% to 723 branches at year-end
column141:
while doubling our free ATM access and we continue to grow volumes with average loans and checking deposits up 6% and 9% respectively.

"
column142:
"

Turning to branded cards
column143: revenues of $2.2 billion grew 15% reflecting the impact of the Costco portfolio acquisition as well as modest organic growth. Excluding Costco
column144:
we generated 2% revenue growth as we have largely absorbed the impact of higher acquisition and reward costs and are beginning to benefit from organic volume growth.

"
column145:
"

Turning to Costco
column146: the results continue to be very encouraging. To-date
column147: we have generated over 1 million new Costco card accounts and over $52 billion of purchase sales and loans continue to grow in the fourth quarter ending the year at nearly $17 billion. In total
column148: we grew end of period branded card loans by 11% or over $8 billion in the second half of 2016 across our proprietary products
column149: Costco
column150:
and other co-brand portfolios.

"
column151:
"

This reflects strong engagement with our existing cardholders as well as significant new account balance growth. New accounts typically feature promotional rates for a period of time. So we would expect revenue growth to follow once these balances mature and begin to accrue at full rate.

"
column152:
"

Finally
column153: Retail Services revenues of $1.6 billion were roughly flat to last year as loan growth offset the absence of two portfolios we sold in the first quarter as well as the impact of renewing and extending several partnerships. Total expenses for North America consumer were $2.5 billion
column154: up 6% from last year mostly reflecting the Costco portfolio acquisition
column155: volume growth
column156: and continued marketing investments
column157:
partially offset by efficiency savings.

"
column158:
"

And finally
column159: credit costs of $1.2 billion were down sequentially but increased $370 million from last year. Net credit losses increased to $1.1 billion mostly driven by Costco
column160: organic volume growth and seasoning
column161:
and the impact of regulatory changes on collections and cards and we've built a $113 million of net loan loss reserves during the quarter compared to a release in the prior year driven by the ongoing impact of the Costco portfolio acquisition as well as organic volume growth. We continue to expect the full-year NCL rate to be in the range of around 280 basis points in branded cards and 435 basis points in Retail Services for 2017 with some variability by quarter.

"
column162:
"

On Slide 7
column163: we show results for international consumer banking in constant dollars. Net income grew significantly from last year on higher revenues
column164: lower operating expenses and stable cost of credit. In total
column165: revenues grew 5% and expenses were down 1% versus last year. In Latin America
column166:
total consumer revenues grew 8% driven by continued momentum in retail banking with average loans and deposits increasing 7% and 13% respectively. Cards revenues declined slightly from last year.

"
column167:
"

However we saw ongoing strength in account acquisitions
column168: purchase sales
column169:
and average loan growth which should translate to sustainable revenue growth by the second half of 2017.

"
column170:
"

And finally
column171: expenses declined 5% year-over-year in Latin America as ongoing investment spending was more than offset by efficiency savings as well as the impact of one-time items in the prior year period. We continue to execute on our investment plans this quarter in Mexico
column172: modernizing our branches and ATMs
column173: enhancing our digital capabilities
column174:
and upgrading our core operating platforms. These infrastructure investments should improve operating efficiency and returns over time. And we still expect to maintain positive operating leverage each year throughout the investment period.

"
column175:
"

Turning to Asia
column176: consumer revenues grew 4% year-over-year driven by improvement in wealth management and cards. Wealth management revenues grew 18% from last year reflecting better investor sentiment and continued positive AUM influence. And cards remain positive as well with revenues up 4% driven by a continued improvement in yields and abating regulatory headwinds. Expenses in Asia grew 2% from last year
column177: driven by investment spending
column178:
partially offset by efficiency savings.

"
column179:
"

On Slide 8
column180: we show more detail on our Asia consumer portfolios. Starting with retail loans
column181: as we've discussed previously
column182: we have been working to optimize the returns on this portfolio by shifting away from lower yielding mortgage loans and derisking the commercial portfolio
column183: while growing higher return personal loans. Over the past year we have increased net interest revenue as a percentage of average loans in the retail portfolio by 13 basis points
column184:
largely offsetting the revenue impact from a 7% decline in average loans driven by mortgages and the runoff of certain non-core products.

"
column185:
"

As you can see on the slide
column186: personal loan balances have stabilized in recent quarters as underlying growth in certain markets has been offset by regulatory headwinds in others. These headwinds are abating and therefore
column187: we believe
column188: we can drive modest growth in total retail loans from this new base in 2017
column189:
while continuing to improve the yield on the portfolio.

"
column190:
"

And turning to cards
column191: while average card loans were flat year-over-year
column192: we have improved net interest revenue as a percentage of average loans by roughly 40 basis points
column193: as we have shifted a larger portion of our balances to higher yielding revolving loans. We also expect to generate loan growth in cards going forward as we invest to drive higher account acquisition and usage. We expect these initiatives
column194:
along with our continued focus on wealth management to drive sustained growth in Asia in 2017 and beyond.

"
column195:
"

Slide 9 shows our global consumer credit trends in more detail
column196: across both cards and retail banking. Credit remained broadly favorable again this quarter. The increase in the NCL rate in North America mostly reflects the impact of the Costco portfolio
column197: seasonality
column198:
and the impact of regulatory changes on collections and cards. Credit trends in Asia consumer remains stable this quarter and the NCL rate in Latin America remained favorable at 415 basis points.

"
column199:
"

While we continue to believe the NCL rate in Latin America should settle closer to 4.5% as the portfolio seasons
column200: it will likely remain below this level for the first half of 2017
column201:
reflecting strong credit quality and continued loan delinquency rates.

"
column202:
"

On Slide 10
column203: we showed a year-over-year EBIT walk for consumer for the second half of the year. As we noted last quarter
column204: the first half of 2016 was affected by several factors including the comparison to much stronger prior year periods in Wealth Management. The early stage of our organic cards investments
column205: the expenses we were absorbing on Costco before we had the full benefit of the revenues on that portfolio
column206:
and the impact of significant repositioning charges in the first quarter of the year.

"
column207:
"

As we moved into the third quarter you could see momentum building again in our consumer business and this continued through year-end. In total
column208: we generated 6% underlying revenue growth with a 5% increase in expenses in the second half of 2016
column209: driving growth in our operating margin of over $450 million year-over-year. Of course
column210: credit costs also increased
column211:
reflecting volume growth and the absence of prior period reserve releases. But overall we feel good about the trajectory of our consumer business based on our performance in the second half of the year.

"
column212:
"

Turning now to the institutional clients group on Slide 11. Net income of $2.5 billion in the fourth quarter grew substantially from last year on higher revenues
column213: lower operating expenses
column214:
and lower cost of credit. Revenues of $8.3 billion grew 11% from last year reflecting solid progress across the franchise.

"
column215:
"

Total banking revenues of $4.4 billion grew 3% from last year. Treasury and Trade Solutions revenues of $2.1 billion grew 6% in constant dollars driven by continued momentum with new and existing clients. We saw strong fee growth
column216: higher volumes
column217: and improved spreads in certain geographies
column218:
resulting in the 12th consecutive quarter of revenue and margin growth in TTS.

"
column219:
"

Investment Banking revenues of $1.1 billion were flat to last year and higher debt underwriting revenues offset declines in equity underwriting and M&A. Private Bank revenues of $731 million were up 6% year-over-year
column220: mostly driven by loan growth and improved spreads and corporate lending revenues of $462 million grew 7%
column221:
mostly reflecting the impact of loan sale activity in the prior year period.

"
column222:
"

Total markets and security services revenues of $4.1 billion
column223: grew 24% from last year. Fixed income revenues of $3 billion were up 36% with both rates and currencies and spread products contributing to revenue growth. Rates and currencies grew roughly 30% year-over-year
column224:
reflecting strong client activity and a more favorable environment continuing on the positive momentum that begin to build in the second quarter and spread product revenues grew nearly 40% this quarter also reflecting strong client engagement.

"
column225:
"

Turning to equities
column226: revenues grew 15% year-over-year driven by an improvement in derivatives along with improved trading activity overall
column227:
particularly post the U.S. election.

"
column228:
"

Finally
column229: in security services
column230: revenues grew 3% year-over-year as increased client activity
column231: higher deposit volumes
column232:
and improved spreads more than offset the impact of divestitures.

"
column233:
"

Total operating expenses of $4.6 billion
column234: were down 5% year-over-year driven by efficiency savings
column235: lower repositioning costs
column236:
and a benefit from FX translation.

"
column237:
"

For full-year 2016 excluding the impact of severance our comp ratio was 26% and cost of credit was substantially lower year-over-year reflecting stabilization in commodities as oil prices continue to recover from record lows.

"
column238:
"

On a full-year basis our institutional business earned nearly $10 billion with solid progress in our network-driven businesses. TTS grew 8% for the full-year in constant dollars. Security services grew 6% on the same basis excluding the impact of business divestitures
column239: and rates and currencies grew 22% in 2016 accelerating from the 5% growth we generated in 2015. We maintained our expense discipline absorbing higher volumes without significant incremental cost. And we managed effectively through the volatility in oil prices and other factors this year
column240:
resulting in favorable credit performance consistent with our high quality target client segments.

"
column241:
"

On Slide 12
column242: we show the year-over-year EBIT walk for ICG demonstrating the strong momentum we have generated since the difficult start of the year. We saw broad-based growth this year across our accrual and transaction services businesses. And in market-sensitive franchises our strength in fixed income more than offset the lower market activity in both investment banking and equities. The most significant year-over-year drag comes from other revenue items
column243:
including the impact of the Venezuela write-downs in the first quarter as well as the mark-to-market losses on loan hedges driven by spread movements.

"
column244:
"

Slide 13 shows the results for Corporate/Other. Revenue decreased year-over-year due to the absence of both the contribution from our equity stake in China Guangfa Bank
column245: which we sold last quarter as well as gains on asset sales in the prior year. And expenses decreased
column246: mostly reflecting lower repositioning cost
column247:
partially offset by higher regulatory spend.

"
column248:
"

On Slide 14 we show Citigroup's net interest revenue and margin trends. With net interest revenue continuing to grow year-over-year in Citicorp while Citi Holdings declined with the reduction in assets. Citicorp net interest revenues grew 4% in the fourth quarter and 5% for the full-year in constant dollars
column249:
driven by loan growth as well as the net impact of higher short-term rates.

"
column250:
"

Looking forward
column251:
we believe Citicorp net interest revenue will continue to grow in 2017 with a roughly $500 million impact from the December 2016 rate hike and a $900 million benefit from loan growth and mix including the impact of our card investments maturing in the second half of 2017. However this upside should be partially offset by an increase in funding costs of roughly $100 million as we absorb the full-year impact of our TLAC related benchmark debt issuance as well as a roughly $100 million impact from lower day count.

"
column252:
"

Turning to Citi Holdings. We would expect the net interest revenue of $2 billion in 2016 to decline again by roughly half in 2017. But this decline should be neutral to earnings as we continue to expect this portfolio to operate at around breakeven. Of course
column253: we could see some fluctuations from FX translation but these are the underlying trends we expect
column254:
going into 2017.

"
column255:
"

Turning to NIM
column256: our net interest margin of 279 basis points in the fourth quarter declined by roughly 7 basis points sequentially
column257: driven mostly by lower trading NIM
column258: higher funding costs
column259: and the higher mix of promotional rate balances in cards. And looking to next year
column260:
we expect the net interest margin to remain roughly flat to the full-year of 286 basis points as improvement in the core franchise offsets the continued decline in the Legacy Holdings portfolio.

"
column261:
"

On Slide 15 we show our key capital metrics. During the quarter our CET1 capital ratio declined slightly to 12.5% driven by OCI movements and $4.7 billion of capital return during the quarter
column262: partially offset by earnings and a decline in risk-weighted assets. Our supplementary leverage ratio was 7.2% and our tangible book value per share grew by 7% year-over-year to $64.57 per share despite the OCI pressure this quarter
column263:
in part driven by a 6% reduction in our shares outstanding.

"
column264:
"

To conclude
column265: I'd like to spend some time on our outlook. As a reminder
column266:
we are holding Citi Holdings into Corp/Other starting this quarter. So I'll reference total Citigroup results going forward.

"
column267:
"

Starting with our assumptions around the environment. We ended 2016 with a far more favorable backdrop than we started the year
column268: in terms of client engagement
column269: capital markets activity
column270: and commodity prices and we expect the environment to remain broadly favorable going forward. But our base case does not assume any additional rate hikes in 2017. At a high level
column271: we expect to deliver modest revenue growth and an improved efficiency ratio for total Citigroup
column272:
even as we continue to invest in the franchise and wind down the non-core assets that will now be reported in Corp/Other.

"
column273:
"

In consumer
column274: we expect continued revenue growth and positive operating leverage on a full-year basis in constant dollars in both Asia and Mexico even as we execute on our investment plans for each region. And in North America
column275:
we expect the revenue growth as well.

"
column276:
"

In the first half of 2017 this growth should mostly reflect the impact of the Costco portfolio acquisition. In the second half we expect growth to be driven organically as our branded cards investments mature and more loans begin to accrue at full rate. However mortgage revenues will likely continue to be a drag on year-over-year results in a higher rate environment.

"
column277:
"

In our institutional business
column278:
we expect continued growth in our accrual and transaction services businesses. We feel good about the strength of our franchises in fixed income and Investment Banking where clients remain engaged and our results will reflect overall market environment. And we remain focused on improved execution and wallet share gains in equities where we continue to see a significant revenue opportunity over time.

"
column279:
"

We believe we can drive an improvement in the efficiency ratio from 59% for total Citigroup in 2016 to roughly 58% in 2017 as we continue to automate processes and enhance our digital capabilities. Our original target of achieving an efficiency ratio in the mid-50 range for Citicorp remains in place now for total Citigroup and we believe we could operate within that range as early as 2018.

"
column280:
"

Citigroup cost of credit should be somewhat higher in 2017 driven by loan growth and seasoning and our tax rate should be in the range of around 31%. We also expect continued significant EPS benefits from our share buybacks during the year. As Mike described earlier
column281:
we believe we're on the right path to improve our return on tangible common equity excluding the capital supporting disallowed DTA from 9% in 2016 to at least 10% in 2018 and we should demonstrate progress towards that goal this year as we continue to drive efficiencies across the franchise and begin to see the full benefit of our cards investments in the second half of the year.

"
column282:
"

We continue to believe that we are capable of producing a return on tangible common equity of roughly 14% over time as we previously disclosed. And an important milestone on that path will be achieving at least a 10% ROTCE on the full amount of our tangible common equity
column283:
which we believe we could achieve as early as 2019 depending on the rate environment as well as the outcome of tax reform.

"
column284:
"

With that Mike and I will be happy to take any questions.

column333:

So let me just update only because numbers have changed a little bit since when I spoke at that conference back in November
column334: I think it was. But at that point
column335: what I would say right now is again just to reiterate we end the year with about $47 billion of deferred tax assets. And within that there's about $40 billion that are really U.S. federal DTAs
column336:
within that $40 billion there is about $3 billion of NOLs which you got 20-year life and there's $14 billion now of foreign tax credits that again you generally have a 10-year life. So that leaves $23 billion that really comes about as a result of timing differences and therefore have no specific time use or limitation.

column337:
"

So those are the -- that's just the
column338: I want to give you the context on some of the updated numbers. Everything you said when I spoke at that conference again
column339: I went through a whole series of things including how you might calculate rate impact saying that the largest impact would be on timing differences and just to again update some of the things that I talked about if we now dropped to a 25% tax rate with the territorial system
column340: we end up with still no reduction to our territory -- to our I'm sorry we end over combined with a territory system the P&L hit would be about $12 billion
column341:
which I think is consistent with what I quoted back in November.

column342:
"

And that $12 billion would probably have about $3 billion reduction would amount to a $3 billion reduction in our regulatory capital and the change from the $4 billion that I talked about back in November just reflects subsequent changes due to allowable
column343: disallowable DTA mostly coming out of the OCI. So again as I said those are all very
column344: very raw estimates. Within that again
column345: our belief is that we continue to expect FTC carryforwards to continue to exist post-tax reform. And under the law
column346: FTC carryforwards can be used because there is a provision in the law that allows 50% of domestic income to be treated as foreign income. So that's in the law and we don't think

column706: as we've demonstrated our ability to do this

column1:
{"Citigroup's CEO Discusses Q1 2014 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Citigroup
column3:
"

Q1 2014 Results Earnings Conference Call

"
column22:
"

Eric Wasserstrom - SunTrust Robinson Humphrey

"
column23:
"

Matt Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column27: and welcome to Citi\u2019s first quarter 2014 earnings review with Chief Executive Officer Mike Corbat and Chief Financial Officer John Gerspach. Today\u2019s call will be hosted by Susan Kendall
column28:
head of Citi Investor Relations.

"
column29:
"

We ask that you please hold all questions until the completion of the formal remarks
column30: at which time you will be given instructions for the question-and-answer session. Also
column32: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column39: and thank you all for joining us. On our call today
column41: Mike Corbat
column42: will speak first. Then John Gerspach
column43: our CFO
column44: will take you through the earnings presentation
column45: which is available for download on our website
column46: citigroup.com. Afterwards
column47:
we\u2019ll be happy to take questions.

"
column48:
"

Before we get started
column49: I would like to remind you that today\u2019s presentation may contain forward-looking statements
column50: which are based on management\u2019s current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results in capital and other financial condition may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors
column51: including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today and those included in our SEC filings
column52: including
column54:
the Risk Factors section of our 2013 Form 10-K.

"
column56:
let me turn it over to Mike.

"
column57:
"

"
column58:
"

Mike Corbat

"
column59:
"

Thank you
column60: Susan. Good morning everyone. Earlier today
column61: we reported earnings of $3.9 billion for the first quarter and excluding CVA
column62: DVA
column63: and a tax item
column64: net income was $4.1 billion
column65: a 4% increase over last year
column66: translating to $1.30 per share. I\u2019ll discuss these results and then turn to two other significant items in the quarter
column67: the Fed\u2019s objection to our capital plan
column68:
and the discovery of the fraud in Mexico.

"
column69:
"

During the first quarter
column70: our institutional business performed well across our products and geographies. While lower on a year on year basis
column71:
market revenues rebounded from the fourth quarter and our equities business grew its revenues and continued to make progress. Higher volumes in treasury and trade solutions led to revenue growth despite the ongoing low rate environment.

"
column72:
"

Our consumer bank again posted growth internationally
column73: generating positive operating leverage year on year. Revenues in Asia grew
column74: and while we continue to execute our repositioning plans in Korea
column75:
we believe revenues in that market have now largely stabilized.

"
column76:
"

In the U.S.
column77: lower mortgage refinancing activity continued to impact our retail banking business while retail services revenues strengthened year over year
column78:
showing the positive impact of the Best Buy portfolio acquisition.

"
column79:
"

In a challenging revenue environment
column80: we made progress toward several key priorities during the quarter. Overall
column81: we grew both loans and deposits while focusing on improving our efficiency. We continue to optimize our branch network
column82: reduce our real estate footprint
column83: and simplify our product offerings. We reduced our headcount by about 3
column84: 000 people
column85: to 248
column87:
which helped lower our expenses by over $250 million year on year.

"
column88:
"

While assets in Citi Holdings declined at a slower pace in the first quarter as expected
column89: we did bring the portfolio closer to breakeven. We\u2019ll continue to take advantage of more opportunistic sales as they present themselves
column90:
and we also resolved a significant legacy issue last week with the $1.1 billion settlement regarding certain private label mortgage securitizations.

"
column91:
"

The narrower loss in Citi Holdings helped drive continued progress with our deferred tax asset. After reducing our DTA by $2.5 billion in 2013
column92: we reduced the DTA by an additional $1.1 billion during the first quarter. While our capital levels were amongst the highest in the industry
column93:
we share your deep disappointment over the objection of our capital plan.

"
column94:
"

Let me tell you what we\u2019re doing in response. First
column95: we\u2019re engaged with the Fed
column96:
so we can fully understand their concern. We\u2019re committed to bringing our capital planning process in line with the highest standards befitting an institution of our global reach.

"
column97:
"

Let me now share with you some preliminary takeaways based on what we\u2019ve learned so far. To begin with
column98:
we don\u2019t believe this is an issue with our business model or our strategy. It also isn\u2019t an issue with our levels of capital or capability to generate capital.

"
column99:
"

As the quantitative tests showed
column100: we exceeded the Fed\u2019s requirements with 150 basis points cushion in the severely stressed scenario. And after generating over $20 billion of regulatory capital last year
column101:
we generated an additional $6 billion in the first quarter of 2014.

"
column102:
"

We now have an estimated tier one common ratio of 10.4% on a Basel III basis
column103: and at 5.6% we already surpass the supplementary leverage ratio requirement. While we clearly have a good amount of work to do to bring our capital planning process in line with the Fed\u2019s requirements
column104:
we believe we can fix what needs to be fixed in our CCAR process so we can pass the qualitative side as well.

"
column105:
"

So let me be clear. Whatever the gaps are between the Fed\u2019s expectations and our CCAR process
column106: we\u2019ll close it. We\u2019ll devote whatever resources and make whatever changes are necessary to accomplish this critical goal. We\u2019re moving as quickly as possible while mindful of the fact that it has to be done the right way. I want and I know our shareholders deserve an industrial strength
column107:
permanent solution that paves the way for sustainable capital return over time.

"
column108:
"

We\u2019ve already begun to make changes we believe will strengthen our process. As you know
column109: I\u2019ve asked Gene McQuade to delay his retirement and run our CCAR process. I\u2019ve fully empowered him to do whatever needs to be done as we prepare our next submission. It will require investment in new talent
column110: acceleration of spend on certain system
column111: and changes to the way we build
column112: validate
column113:
and test our scenarios.

"
column114:
"

While not insignificant
column115: we believe the required investments can be funded through our productivity initiatives
column116: consistent with other investments we\u2019ve made and continue to make in our safety and soundness
column117: including risk management
column118: compliance
column119:
and AML.

"
column120:
"

In light of this
column121: I believe the right decision is to focus our full attention on preparing for the 2015 CCAR process
column122: which begins in the fall. Among other things
column123:
this delay in increasing our capital return means it\u2019s hard to see a scenario where we\u2019ll be able to meet our intermediate target of a 10% return on tangible common equity in 2015.

"
column124:
"

However
column125: our 2015 return on asset and efficiency targets remain in place and we\u2019re committed to achieving them. I should also say that although we understand our shareholders desire for more information on CCAR
column126: we aren\u2019t able to go into further detail
column127: as our supervisory communications with the Fed are confidential. I hope people won\u2019t misread the absence of information as an absence of action. I assure you
column128:
we\u2019re addressing this issue with absolute urgency.

"
column129:
"

Regarding the fraud in Mexico
column130: we\u2019re progressing along several fronts. First
column131: we\u2019ve completed our rapid review and have not identified similar issues with any other account receivables program globally other than with the PEMEX supplier program. We reviewed over 1
column132:
100 facilities with over $14 billion of receivable financings.

"
column133:
"

Second
column134: working closely with the Attorney General in Mexico
column135: we\u2019re continuing our rigorous investigation into how the fraud was committed and how our controls were breached. At this point
column136:
we\u2019ve terminated one employee who we believe was criminally involved in the fraud and anyone else we find to have been criminally involved will be fired as well as referred to the Attorney General.

"
column137:
"

In addition
column138:
we expect to take action against others whose negligence or lack of compliance with our code of conduct allowed this fraud to be committed. Those responsible will be held accountable for their actions and inactions.

"
column139:
"

We also continue to pursue the recovery of any misappropriated funds. And finally
column140: we\u2019re reviewing all of our controls and processes in Mexico and will strengthen any area we think falls short of our global standards and best practices. While we\u2019d all like a quick resolution of this issue
column141:
we\u2019re doing a lot of work and it\u2019s just going to take some time to get it done.

"
column142:
"

In closing
column143: Citi has a unique global platform
column144: one which as the quarter shows
column145: is very capable of generating the returns our shareholders expect and reserve. We\u2019ll remain focused on serving our clients and taking our franchise to the next level. John will go through the deck
column146:
and then we\u2019d be happy to take your questions. John?

"
column147:
"

John Gerspach

"
column148:
"

Thank you
column149: Mike
column150: and good morning everyone. To start
column151: I\u2019d like to highlight two items which affect the comparability of this quarter\u2019s results to last year. First
column152: CVA and DVA had a small impact this quarter at $7 million
column153:
compared to a negative $319 million in pretax or $0.06 per share after tax in the first quarter of last year.

"
column154:
"

And second
column155: this quarter we took a $210 million tax charge related to corporate tax reforms enacted in two states. These reforms lowered marginal tax rates
column156:
resulting in a reduction in our state deferred tax asset for a negative impact on EPS of $0.07 per share.

"
column157:
"

Adjusting for CVA/DVA and the tax item
column158: we earned $1.30 per share in the recent quarter compared to $1.29 per share in the first quarter of last year. This quarter\u2019s results also included roughly $165 million of incremental credit costs related to the Pemex supplier program in Mexico
column159:
including direct exposure to two suppliers.

"
column160:
"

The vast majority of these credit costs were associated with our direct exposure to OSA and uncertainty around Pemex\u2019s obligation to pay us for a portion of the accounts receivable we\u2019ve validated with them as of year-end. The remainder was associated with one other supplier to Pemex that was found to have similar issues. We have not adjusted our results for these additional credit costs.

"
column161:
"

On slide four
column162: we show total Citigroup results. We earned $4.1 billion in the first quarter
column163: up 4% from last year
column164: as lower operating expenses and lower credit costs were partially offset by a decline in revenue. Our return on assets improved year over year as well
column165:
to 89 basis points.

"
column166:
"

Citigroup end of period loans grew 3% year over year to $664 billion
column167: as 7% growth in Citicorp was partially offset by the continued decline in Citi Holdings
column168:
and deposits also grew 3% to $966 billion.

"
column169:
"

On slide five
column170: we show more detail on expenses. Our expenses declined in total versus last year
column171: even as we incurred higher legal and repositioning costs. Legal and related costs were $945 million in the first quarter
column172:
and repositioning costs were over $200 million.

"
column173:
"

Excluding these two items
column174: core operating expenses of $11 billion in the first quarter declined by over $400 million year over year. In constant dollars
column175: expenses declined by over $260 million
column176: driven by continued cost reduction initiatives and the decline in Citi Holdings assets
column177: partially offset by higher regulatory and compliance costs as well as the impact of business growth
column178:
including the Best Buy portfolio acquisition.

"
column179:
"

Sequentially
column180: core expenses were up versus last year
column181: mostly reflecting higher incentive compensation
column182: resulting from improved performance. On slide six
column183: we show the split between Citicorp and Citi Holdings. In Citicorp
column184:
earnings declined 8% year over year as lower revenues were partially offset by lower operating expenses and an improvement in credit.

"
column185:
"

The revenue decline was mostly driven by lower revenues in fixed income markets and North America mortgage origination
column186:
partially offset by growth in both equities and international consumer.

"
column187:
"

In Citi Holdings
column188: the net loss improved significantly from roughly $800 million a year ago to just under $300 million
column189: driven by a number of factors
column190: including credit improvement in North America mortgages
column191: the absence of rep and warranty reserve builds in the recent quarter
column192: higher levels of mark-to-market gains
column193: lower funding costs
column194: and a one-time gain on a debt transaction. Citi Holdings assets declined by 23% year over year
column195:
to $114 billion or 6% of total Citigroup assets.

"
column196:
"

Turning to Citicorp
column197: on slide seven
column198: we show results for international consumer banking in constant dollars. Revenues grew 3% year over year in the first quarter while expenses increased by 2%. International consumer revenues continued to reflect spread compression
column199: as well as the impact of regulatory changes and the repositioning of our franchise in certain markets
column200:
particularly in Korea.

"
column201:
"

However
column202: most key drivers remain positive
column203: with average loans up 7% and card purchase sales up 4% from last year. In addition
column204:
we began to see the benefits this quarter of our exclusive distribution agreement with AIA to provide insurance products in 11 of our Asia markets.

"
column205:
"

Korea remained a headwind. However
column206: while we continue repositioning this franchise
column207: we believe revenues in this market have largely stabilized and credit has remained favorable. We will continue to restructure our cost base in Korea to reflect the lower revenue. International credit costs grew 12% year over year
column208: mostly reflecting portfolio growth and seasoning
column209:
while the net credit loss rate remains fairly stable at 200 basis points.

"
column210:
"

Slide eight shows the results for North America consumer banking. Total revenues were down 6% year over year and 2% sequentially. Retail banking revenues of $1.1 billion declined by 28% from last year
column211: mostly reflecting lower mortgage refinancing activity
column212: and were up 5% sequentially
column213:
driven by a gain on a sale leaseback transaction.

"
column214:
"

Branded card revenues of $2 billion were flat versus last year
column215: as higher purchase sales and improved spread were offset by lower average loans. Retail services revenues grew 8% from last year
column216:
driven by the Best Buy portfolio acquisition. And revenues were down sequentially in both card businesses on seasonally lower purchase sales and loan balances versus the fourth quarter.

"
column217:
"

Total operating expenses of $2.4 billion were down 3% year over year
column218: reflecting ongoing cost reduction initiatives
column219: partially offset by the impact of the Best Buy portfolio acquisition. We have significantly resized our mortgage operations over the last year to reflect the change in market volumes
column220:
and we continue to rationalize our branch footprint in North America by reducing the number and size of our branches while concentrating our presence in major urban areas and enhancing our digital channel.

"
column221:
"

Even as we have reduced branches
column222: we have continued to grow our average deposits and retail loans
column223: each up 4% year over year. And
column224:
we\u2019ve shifted a greater amount of our mortgage originations and card acquisitions to the retail channel.

"
column225:
"

Slide nine shows our global consumer credit trends in more detail. In North America
column226: credit remained favorable in the first quarter
column227: and we continue to anticipate the full year NCL rate to be in the range of 3%. Asia remained stable as well. And
column228: in Latin America
column229:
we saw an uptick in both NCL and delinquency rates.

"
column230:
"

The higher NCL rate in the first quarter was primarily driven by Mexico card
column231: as that portfolio continued to season. We have also seen a greater than anticipated impact on consumer behavior from the fiscal reforms enacted in Mexico last year
column232:
which included higher income and other taxes. This appears to have dampened card purchase activity and is resulting in increased card delinquencies across the industry.

"
column233:
"

Given these changes
column234: in combination with the generally slower pace of economic recovery in Mexico
column235:
we currently expect the full year NCL rate in Latin America to be roughly in line with the 4.6% we experienced in the first quarter.

"
column236:
"

The increase in the delinquency rate over the prior two quarters was mostly driven by our exposure to home builders in Mexico
column237: for which we have established loan loss reserves. Any losses from these home builders may increase our NCL rate in the coming quarter. However
column238: we would expect these losses to be charged against our reserve
column239:
and therefore they should be neutral to the overall cost of credit.

"
column240:
"

Slide 10 shows the efficiency ratio for global consumer banking on a trailing 12-month basis. Total franchise results are shown on the light blue line
column241: while the dark blue bars represent the efficiency ratio excluding North America mortgage and Korea. As I mentioned earlier
column242: revenues have declined in both North America mortgage and Korea over the past year
column243:
and this resulted in a significant drag on our reported operating efficiency.

"
column244:
"

Outside of these businesses
column245: we have made steady progress reducing our efficiency ratio from nearly 56% a year ago to just over 54% today
column246: as we have exited underperforming markets and simplified our operations
column247:
all while continuing to invest in those markets where we see growth opportunities.

"
column248:
"

While we now believe the revenues in both North America mortgage and Korea have largely stabilized
column249:
we will continue to take actions to reduce our cost base and improve efficiency in these businesses.

"
column250:
"

Slide 11 shows our total consumer expenses over the past five quarters
column251: split between core operating expenses and legal and repositioning costs. Core expenses had declined to just over $5.1 billion by the third quarter of last year
column252:
and then increased in the fourth quarter as a result of the Best Buy portfolio acquisition.

"
column253:
"

In the most recent quarter
column254: core operating expenses have been reduced again to just over $5.1 billion
column255: and we currently expect to deliver modest reductions in each of the subsequent quarters this year. This improvement is expected to come from a variety of actions
column256:
including those examples shown on the right side of the slide.

"
column257:
"

As you can see
column258: we have made significant progress since the end of 2012 in reducing headcount
column259: the number of card products
column260: retail branches
column261: and support sites
column262:
and we expect to make further progress by year-end.

"
column263:
"

Turning now to the institutional clients group
column264: on slide 12
column265: revenues of $9.2 billion declined 7% from last year
column266: but were up 28% sequentially. Total banking revenues of $4.1 billion were roughly flat versus prior period. Treasury and trade solutions revenues of $1.9 billion were up 1% versus prior periods on a reported basis and
column267: in constant dollars
column268: revenues grew 4% year over year and 2% sequentially
column269:
as growth in fees and volumes were partially offset by spread compression.

"
column270:
"

Investment banking revenues of $1.1 billion were down 10% from the prior year on lower debt underwriting activity
column271: as well as lower M&A revenue
column272: partially offset by growth in equity underwriting. And
column273: on a sequential basis
column274: revenues were down 8%
column275: mostly due to a pull forward of M&A transactions into the prior quarter
column276:
while underwriting revenues were roughly flat.

"
column277:
"

Private bank revenues of $668 million increased from prior periods
column278: driven by growth in investments and capital markets products. And

column280: excluding the impact of gains and losses on hedges related to accrual loans
column281: were $415 million
column282: up from prior periods
column283:
as higher loan balances and lower funding costs were partially offset by lower loan yields.

"
column284:
"

Total markets and securities services revenues of $5.2 billion declined 12% year over year
column285: but were up nearly 60% sequentially. Year over year
column286: fixed income revenues of $3.9 billion declined 18%
column287: reflecting the more muted environment in the first quarter of 2014
column288: as well as our strong performance last year
column289:
in both securitized products and local markets rates and currencies.

"
column290:
"

Sequentially
column291: fixed income was up over 60% on a rebound in spread product and local markets revenue
column292: as well as growth in commodity. Equities revenues of $883 million were up 13% from last year
column293: and over 80% from the prior quarter
column294: mostly reflecting improved performance in derivatives. And

column296:
as lower net interest revenue was offset by an increase in assets under custody and overall client activity.

column297:
"

Total operating expenses of $5 billion were down 2% versus the prior year

column299: partially offset by higher regulatory and compliance costs
column300: legal and related expenses
column301: and repositioning charges in the recent quarter. On a sequential basis
column302: expenses increased by roughly $100 million
column303: mostly reflecting higher incentive compensation
column304:
partially offset by the impact of reduced headcount.

"
column305:
"

On slide 13

column307: we have lowered our operating expenses every quarter for over two years
column308: driving the full year efficiency ratio from 67% two years ago to 59% as of the first quarter. Our comp ratio for the most recent 12 months was 29%
column309:
consistent with full year 2013.

column310:
"

Slide 14 shows the results for corporate other. Revenues increased year over year
column311: driven mainly by higher investment revenues and hedging activities
column312: while expenses also grew
column313: mainly reflecting higher legal and related costs. Assets of $323 billion included approximately $111 billion of cash and cash equivalents and $156 billion of liquid
column314:
available for sale securities.

"
column315:
"

Slide 15 shows Citi Holdings assets
column316: which totaled $114 billion at quarter end

column318:
mostly driven by net paydowns.

column319:
"

On slide 16

column321: primarily driven by the absence of rep and warranty reserve builds in the recent quarter
column322: as well as higher levels of mark-to-market gains versus prior period
column323: lower funding costs
column324: and a one-time gain on a debt transaction. Citi Holdings expenses increased slightly year over year to $1.5 billion
column325:
driven by higher leg and related costs.

column326:
"

Net credit losses continued to improve year over year

column328: the vast majority of which was related to North America mortgages. Looking at the past five quarters of Citi Holdings results on slide 17
column329: excluding legal and related expenses

column331: driven in part by the higher one-time and mark-to-market gains I just referred to
column332:
while credit costs were roughly flat.

"
column333:
"

The pretax loss in Citi Holdings was just over $400 million
column334: driven by nearly $800 million of legal and related expenses. Legal expenses were somewhat higher than in prior periods
column335:
including roughly $100 million of incremental accruals to cover the recently announced $1.1 billion settlement to resolve certain private label securitization repurchase claims.

"
column336:
"

This represented a significant step in resolving our legacy issues
column337: and we remain hopeful we will have better clarity on the remaining mortgage and securitization related issues in Citi Holdings
column338:
sometime this year.

"
column339:
"

On slide 18
column340: we show North America mortgage trends in Citi Holdings
column341: which continued to improve through the first quarter. We ended the quarter with $71 billion of North America mortgages
column342: down 18% from a year ago
column343: while net credit losses declined by nearly 50%
column344: and the loss rate improved by nearly 100 basis points. We had $4.6 billion of loan loss reserves allocated to North America mortgages in Citi Holdings
column345:
or 42 months of NCL coverage.
