column346:
"

On slide 19
column347: we show Citigroup\u2019s net interest revenue and margin trends. Net interest revenue was $11.8 billion in the first quarter
column348: up from last year on slightly higher interest earning assets and an improvement in net interest margin
column349: and down sequentially
column350: driven by a lower day count. Our net interest margin grew to 290 basis points in the first quarter
column351: mainly reflecting lower funding costs. As we look to the second quarter
column352: we expect our net interest margin to decline by several basis points
column353:
likely followed by a modest increase in the back half of the year.

"
column354:
"

On slide 20
column355: we show our key capital metrics. As of the fourth quarter
column356: we reported an estimated Basel III tier one common ratio of 10.6%. Subsequently
column357: we announced that we would be required to add roughly $56 billion of operational risk RWA to our total risk-weighted assets
column358:
related to our transition to the Basel III advanced approaches.

"
column359:
"

This additional RWA resulted in a pro forma Basel III tier one common ratio of 10.1% as of the fourth quarter
column360: and we grew our estimated Basel III tier one common ratio to 10.4% in the first quarter. Our estimated Basel III supplementary leverage ratio was unaffected by the change in operational risk RWA
column361: and improved from 5.4% to 5.6% in the first quarter. We continue to evaluate the impact of the newly released NPR for the U.S. SLR rules
column362: and based on our limited review to date
column363:
we believe the impact should be flat to a slight improvement.

"
column364:
"

In summary
column365: our performance in the first quarter demonstrated continued progress on several fronts. Markets revenues rebounded from the fourth quarter
column366: and while fixed income revenues were less robust than last year
column367: we partially offset this decline with growth in equities
column368: corporate lending
column369:
and the private bank.

"
column370:
"

Our international consumer business continued to grow
column371: with positive operating leverage year over year
column372: and we continued to see growth in purchase sales across our card portfolio. We also maintained our expense discipline
column373: and credit remained broadly favorable. We significantly reduced the drag from Citi Holdings again this quarter
column374:
and we ended the period with a strong capital position.

"
column375:
"

Looking to the rest of the year
column376: our goal is to grow our core franchise while improving our operating efficiency and reducing the drag from Citi Holdings. In global consumer banking
column377: we expect revenues to be somewhat flat going into the second quarter with sequential growth in the back half of the year
column378:
while core operating expenses should continue to decline each quarter.

"
column379:
"

In our institutional business
column380: revenues will likely continue to reflect the overall market environment
column381: with a goal of steadily gaining wallet share while maintaining our expense discipline. And
column382: in Citi Holdings
column383:
we remain focused on resolving our legacy mortgage and securitization related issues in order to further drive the business closer to breakeven.

"
column384:
"

In the first quarter
column385: we saw higher levels of one-time and mark-to-market revenues
column386: which are not likely to recur. But we still expect to achieve a small positive operating margin
column387:
excluding legal expenses.

"
column388:
"

For full year 2014
column389: in Citicorp
column390: we expect our core operating expenses to come in at or somewhat below the level of 2013
column391: as continued repositioning and other efficiency savings should offset the impact of business growth
column392: investment
column393: and a continued increase in regulatory related expenses. And in Citi Holdings
column394: core operating expenses should continue to decline
column395:
as we wind down those assets.

"
column396:
"

Over the past six quarters
column397: we have incurred roughly $1.7 billion of repositioning charges in Citicorp
column398: including the actions we announced in December 2012. We expect to achieve approximately $2.2 billion of annual savings from these initiatives. Roughly $1.8 billion of these benefits are already included in our expense base on an annualized basis
column399:
and we have achieved an additional $1 billion of annual savings through our ongoing effort to simplify and streamline our organization as well as improve our productivity.

"
column400:
"

Of these $2.8 billion in annualized savings
column401: approximately 40% has been reinvested in regulatory
column402: control
column403: and compliance initiatives. Another 40% went to fund higher volume related expenses
column404: cover the cost of inflation
column406: including the Best Buy portfolio acquisition
column407:
and 20% has fallen to the bottom line to benefit earnings.

"
column408:
"

In the second quarter
column409: we expect total legal and repositioning charges to be roughly in line with the first quarter although the mix should change to reflect an increase in repositioning charges
column410: due in part to the acceleration of our restructuring effort in Korea. For the second half of the year
column411:
repositioning charges should decline while legal expenses are likely to remain somewhat elevated.

"

"

With that

Mike and I are happy to take any questions.

column1350: but I guess I was surprised you didn\u2019t push any of the $56 billion of incremental operational RWA into the divisions. Is that just a timing issue
column1351:
sort of adjusting your models? Or is that corporate center going to have $124 billion of risk-weighted assets going forward?

"
column1353:
"

As we exited from parallel
column1354: and you can maybe go back to some of the disclosures that we\u2019ve made on this
column1355: with the level of operational risk-weighted assets
column1356: the $288 billion of RWA that is an amount that we agreed with the Fed on. We don\u2019t have the models in place today to apportion that last $56 billion out into the business units. So it\u2019s very much model-related more than anything else. I don\u2019t envision that $56 billion staying in corporate forever
column1357: but until we get an agreed upon model approach
column1358:
it\u2019s going to be difficult to apportion it out.

"
column1360:
"

Thank you. We have no further questions in the queue at this time.

"
column1363: operator. Thank you all for joining us here this morning. If you have any follow up questions
column1364:
please reach out to the investor relations team. Thank you.

"

{"Citigroup's (C) CEO Mike Corbat on Q2 2014 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Citigroup Inc. (NYSE:C)

"
column20:
"

Gerard Cassidy - RBC Capital Market

"
column22:

Eric Wasserstrom - SunTrust Robinson Humphrey

"
column34: and welcome to Citi\u2019s second quarter 2014 earnings review with Chief Executive Officer
column35: Mike Corbat and Chief Financial Officer
column36: John Gerspach. Today\u2019s call will be hosted by Susan Kendall
column38:
"

We ask that you please hold all questions until the completion of the formal remarks
column39: at which time you will be given instruction for the question-and-answer session. Also
column41: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column42: please disconnect at this time. Ms. Kendall
column43:
you may begin.

"
column44:
"

Susan Kendall

"
column45:
"

Thank you
column46: Regina. Good morning
column47: and thank you all for joining us. On our call today
column48: our CEO
column49: Mike Corbat
column50: will speak first
column52: our CFO will take you through the earnings presentation
column53: which is available for download on our website
column55:
we\u2019ll be happy to take questions.

"
column57: I would like to remind you that today\u2019s presentation may contain forward-looking statements
column58: which are based on management\u2019s current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results
column59: and capital and other financial condition may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors
column60: including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today and those included in our SEC filings
column61: including
column62: without limitation
column63:
the Risk Factors section of our 2013 Form 10-K.

"
column64:
"

With that said
column65:
let me turn it over to Mike.

"
column66:
"

Mike Corbat

"
column67:
"

Susan
column68: thank you; and good morning everyone. Earlier today
column69: we reported earnings of $181 million for the second quarter of 2014. Excluding the impact of the legacy mortgage settlement CVA and DVA
column70: net income was $3.9 billion
column71:
up slightly from last year or $1.24 per share.

"
column72:
"

Before I get into our operating performance I want to discuss our legacy mortgage settlement. The comprehensive settlement announced today with the U.S. Department of Justice
column73: the State AGs and the FDIC resolves all pending civil investigations related to our legacy RMBS and CDO underwriting
column74:
structuring and issuance activities. We also have now resolved substantially all of our legacy RMBS and CDO litigation. We believe that this settlement is in the best interest of our shareholders and allows us to move forward and to focus on the future in serving our clients.

"
column75:
"

During this quarter
column76: our institutional businesses performed well outside of markets where macro uncertainty and historically low volatility reduced client activity clearly impacting our fixed income and equities revenues. Corporate investment banking revenues strengthened
column77:
led by strong equity and debt underwriting and our treasury and trade solutions businesses again saw underlying revenue growth as volumes continued to increase.

"
column78:
"

In consumer banking
column79:
year-over-year comparisons continue to be affected by lower mortgage refinancing activity and our repositioning efforts in Korea. But we believe these businesses have now stabilized and we're better positioned for growth in the second half of the year. We grow our consumer loans despite the uneven economic environment and saw continued signs of progress in our U.S. cards business.

"
column80:
"

Excluding the settlement announced today
column81: Citi Holdings turned to profit for the first time since its formation and we announced agreements to sell our consumer businesses in Greece and Spain which will further reduce holdings assets in the third quarter. The holdings profit actually helped drive DTA consumption which totaled $1.1 billion in the quarter and $2.2 billion for the first half of 2014. And despite the impact of the legacy mortgage settlement on our net income
column82:
our capital position strengthened to a Tier 1 common ratio of 10.6% on a Basel III basis and our tangible book value also increased.

"
column83:
"

During the first half of this year we generated $10 billion in capital despite today\u2019s settlement. Throughout the organization we're focused on strengthening our capital planning process
column84: improving our execution and increasing our efficiency; we're engaged in a firm-wide effort that includes improving our target client model
column85: streamlining our structure
column86:
processes and technology platforms and optimizing our real estate footprint.

"
column87:
"

These actions create a capability to make investments in our business
column88:
regulatory and compliance activities and strength in our capital planning process. They also allow us to reduce our operating expenses both quarter-on-quarter and year-on-year.

"
column89:
"

"
column90:
"

While this effort is on-going
column91: we are already making some good headway. For example
column92: during the second quarter
column93: we\u2019ve reduced our headcount by 3
column94: 500 people to 244
column95: 000 and it is now down nearly 7
column96: 000 for the first half of 2014 and 15
column97: 000 people since the fourth quarter of 2012. We continue to simplify our product offerings and we further rationalized our footprint
column98:
shrinking retail branches by nearly 140 while reducing consumer support sides by another 31 locations.

"
column99:
"

"
column100:
"

Looking ahead
column101: for the second half of this year
column102: I feel good about how we're positioned and I believe we should see an improved revenue picture. On the consumer side
column103: the U.S. economy is gaining strength as job creation and consumer spending increases. Internationally
column104:
our franchise is performing well and we believe the headwinds facing our retail business in Korea are abated.

"
column105:
"

"
column106:
"

In our institutional business
column107: while client activity has been lower in markets
column108: business such as investment banking and trade finance are showing momentum. We\u2019ve also demonstrated the ability to reduce the drag of Citi Holdings and utilize DTA
column109:
both of which will contribute to the strengthening of our capital positions going forward.

"
column110:
"

"
column111:
"

John will now go through the deck and then we will be happy to take your questions. John?

"
column112:
"

"
column113:
"

John Gerspach

"
column114:
"

"
column115:
"

Okay
column116: thank you
column117: Mike and good morning everyone. To start
column118: I\u2019d like to highlight two items which affect the comparability of this quarter\u2019s results to last year. First as Mike described
column119: this quarter
column120: we took a $3.7 billion after-tax charge related to the mortgage settlement for a negative impact on EPS of a $1.21 per share; and second
column121:
CVA and DVA was a negative $33 million pre-tax this quarter or $0.01 per share after tax compared to a positive 477 million pre-tax or $0.09 per share in the second quarter of last year.

"
column122:
"

"
column123:
"

Adjusting for CVA
column124: DVA and the impact of the settlement
column125: we earned $1.24 per share in the recent quarter
column126: compared to $1.25 per share in the second quarter of last year. Throughout today\u2019s presentation
column127:
I\u2019ll be discussing our results excluding these two items to provide comparability to prior periods.

"
column128:
"

"
column129:
"

On slide four
column130: we show total Citigroup results. We are in $3.9 billion in the second quarter and $8.1 billion for the first half of 2014
column131:
both up slightly from prior periods as lower revenues were offset by lower operating expenses and a decline in credit cost. Citigroup end-of-period loans grew 4% year-over-year to $668 billion as 8% growth in Citicorp was partially offset by the continued decline in Citi Holdings and deposits grew 3% to $966 billion.

"
column132:
"

"
column133:
"

On slide five
column134: we show more detail on expenses. Legal and related costs were roughly $400 million in the second quarter
column135: mostly incurred in Citicorp. Repositioning costs were also around $400 million
column136:
including approximately $270 million of repositioning costs related to our consumer franchise in Korea.

"
column137:
"

"
column138:
"

Excluding these items
column139: core operating expenses of nearly $11 billion in the second quarter declined by over $225 million in constant dollars
column140: driven by continued cost reduction initiatives and the decline in Citi Holdings\u2019 assets
column141: partially offset by higher regulatory and compliance costs as well as the impact of business growth. Sequentially
column142: core expenses were down versus last quarter
column143: reflecting lower incentive compensation and continued efficiency efforts
column144:
again partially offset by higher regulatory and compliance cost.

"
column145:
"

"
column146:
"

On slide six
column147: we show the split between Citicorp and Citi Holdings. In Citicorp
column148: earnings declined 18% year-over-year as lower revenues and higher legal and repositioning costs were partially offset by lower core operating expenses and an improvement in credit. In Citi Holdings
column149: we earned over $240 million this quarter
column150:
compared to a loss of nearly $600 million last year.

"
column151:
"

"
column152:
"

Citi Holdings revenues increased significantly from last year driven by the absence of rep and warranty reserve builds in the recent quarter
column153:
higher gains on asset sales and lower funding costs. Core expenses continue to decline in line with a 15% year-over-year reduction in assets. Citi Holdings ended the quarter with $111 billion of assets or 6% of Citi Group assets.

"
column154:
"

"
column155:
"

Turning to Citi Corp on slide seven
column156: we show results for international consumer banking in constant dollars. Revenues grew 1% year-over-year in the second quarter. Core operating expenses
column157: excluding legal and repositioning cost also increased 1% from the prior year
column158: driven by business growth and higher regulatory and compliance costs
column159: partially offset by on-going efficiency savings. Including legal and repositioning cost
column160: total operating expenses increased 12% from the prior year
column161:
mostly due to the repositioning charges in Korea.

"
column162:
"

"
column163:
"

International consumer revenues continued to reflect spread compression as well as the impact of regulatory changes and the repositioning of certain markets. Korea remained a headwind year-over-year
column164:
however the franchise was broadly stable quarter-over-quarter and we believe we should begin to see sequential revenue growth in Korea as we go into the second half of the year.

"
column165:
"

Aside from Korea
column166: the most significant challenge for Asia consumer revenue this quarter was a decline in investment sales revenues both year-over-year and sequentially. While this business has grown over time
column167:
quarterly investment sales revenues tend to reflect the overall capital markets environment and in the second quarter we saw a weaker investor sentiment.

"
column168:
"

We provide more details on Asia consumer revenues on appendix slide 25. Despite these headwinds most underlying drivers remain positive with average loans up 7% and average deposits up 3% from last year. International credit cost grew 10% year-over-year mostly reflecting portfolio growth and seasoning in Latin America while the net credit loss rate remained broadly favorable at below 200 basis points.

"
column169:
"

Slide eight shows the results for North America consumer banking. Total revenues were down 5% year-over-year and flat sequentially. Retail banking revenues of $1.2 billion declined by 26% from last year mostly reflecting lower mortgage refinancing activity
column170:
and were up 3% sequentially as higher mortgage revenues and improved deposit spreads offset the absence of a onetime $70 million gain in the prior quarter.

"
column171:
"

Branded cards revenues of 2 billion were up 3% versus last year
column172: as we grew purchase sales and lower average loans were partially offset by an improvement in spreads driven by a reduction in promotional rate balances. And retail services revenues grew 7% from last year
column173:
driven by the Best Buy portfolio acquisition. On-going cost reduction initiatives drove total operating expenses down by 4% year-over-year to 2.3 billion even after absorbing the impact of the Best Buy portfolio acquisition.

"
column174:
"

We continue to resize our North America retail banking business in the second quarter
column175: taking cost out of our mortgage operations and rationalizing the branch footprint all while continuing to grow our franchise. Over the past 12 months
column176: we have sold or closed over 70 branches in North America. During the same period
column177:
we grew average retail loans by 11% and average deposits by 4% including 11% growth in checking account balances.

"
column178:
"

In branded cards
column179: we also saw momentum while total average loans have continued to decline modestly
column180: this mostly reflects the runoff of promotional rate balances. Full rate balances have growth year-over-year for five consecutive quarters
column181:
reflecting account growth and increased card usage primarily in our proprietary rewards and travel co-brand products including American advantage where new account growth for our executive card has exceeded our expectations.

"
column182:
"

Credit remained favorable in the second quarter with net credit losses and delinquencies both improving more than what we had anticipated in branded cards and retail services contributing to a loan loss reserve release of nearly $400 million. At quarter end
column183:
our loan loss reverses in North America cards represented roughly 16 months of concurrent NCL coverage.

"
column184:
"

Slide nine shows our global consumer credit trends in more detail. Overall
column185: global consumer credit trends remained favorable in the second quarter with net credit losses and delinquencies both improving as a percentage of loans. In North America
column186: the strong credit trends I just mentioned drove an improvement in our outlook and we now anticipate the full year NCL rate to be roughly in line with first half results or slightly better than our previous estimate of around 3%. Asia remained stable
column187: and in Latin America
column188:
we saw a modest uptick in both NCL and delinquency rates.

"
column189:
"

These trends were driven primarily by Mexico cards as that portfolio continued to season and consumers continued to adjust to fiscal reforms as well as the impact of slower economic growth. We continue to expect the full year NCL rate in Latin America to be roughly in line with first half levels. This rate could be higher of course if we incur any losses related to our exposure to homebuilders in Mexico; however
column190:
we would expect these losses to be charged against our reserves and therefore they should be neutral to the overall cost of credit.

"
column191:
"

Slide 10 shows the efficiency ratio for global consumer banking on a trailing 12-month basis. Total franchise results are shown on the light blue line
column192: while the dark blue bars represent the efficiency ratio excluding North America mortgage and Korea. As I\u2019ve mentioned before
column193: revenues have declined in both North America mortgage and Korea over the past year
column194:
in addition we encouraged significant repositioning charges in Korea in the second quarter creating a drag on our reported operating efficiency.

"
column195:
"

Outside of these businesses
column196: we have made steady progress reducing our efficiency ratio to just under 54% as we have exited underperforming markets and simplified our operations. Slide 11
column197: shows our total consumer expenses over the past five quarters
column198: split between core operating expenses and legal and repositioning costs. Legal and repositioning costs were elevated in the second quarter driven by Korea
column199: while core operating expenses continued to decline. We expect to make further progress in reducing core expenses in the second half of the year as we remain on track to achieve or exceed our year-end goals for headcount reduction
column200:
card product simplification and branch and support side rationalization.

"
column201:
"

Turning now to the institutional clients\u2019 group on slide 12; revenues of $8.5 billion declined 7% from last year and 8% sequentially. Total banking revenues of $4.5 billion grew 6% from last year and 9% from the prior quarter. Excluding the one-time $50 million gain in the prior year
column202: treasury and trade solutions revenues of $2 billion were up 3%
column203:
both year-over-year and sequentially as growth in fees and volumes were partially offset by spread compression.

"
column204:
"

Investment banking revenues of $1.3 billion were up 16% from last year and 27% from the prior quarter
column205:
driven by particularly strong debt and equity underwriting activity. M&A revenues improved from the prior quarter and we continue to increase our share of announced M&A volumes in a growing market. Private bank revenues of $656 million grew 2% from last year as growth in client volumes was partially offset by the impact of spread compression and were down 2% sequentially on lower capital markets activity.

"
column206:
"

Core lending revenues were $454 million
column207: up from prior periods mostly due to higher average loans. Total markets and security services revenues of $4.1 billion declined 16% year-over-year and 21% sequentially. Fixed income revenues of $3 billion declined 12% from last year as historically low volatility and continued macro uncertainty dampened investor client flows particularly in rates and currencies. In addition
column208:
the prior year period benefited from gains as we paired back risk positions given increased volatility in emerging markets.

"
column209:
"

Sequentially
column210: fixed income revenues declined 22% reflecting seasonal trends. Equities revenues of $659 million were down 26% year-over-year and 25% sequentially reflecting lower client activity
column211:
as well as weak trading performance in EMEA in part driven by macro and geopolitical uncertainties in the region.

"
column212:
"

In securities services revenues were roughly flat versus last year as increased client activity was offset by a reduction in high margin deposits and up 7% sequentially due to increased client balances and higher activity from new accounts.

"
column213:
"

Total operating expenses of $4.9 billion were down 2% versus the prior year driven by lower incentive compensation partially offset by higher regulatory and compliance cost and legal and related expenses in the recent quarter. On a sequential basis
column214:
expenses decreased by over a $100 million mostly reflecting lower incentive compensation.

"
column215:
"

On slide 13
column216: we show expense and efficiency trends for the institutional business. On a trailing 12 month basis we have lowered our operating expenses every quarter for over two years
column217: driving the full year efficiency ratio from 66% two years ago to 60% as of the second quarter
column218:
even as the revenue environment has remained challenging. Our comp ratio for the most recent 12 months was 29% consistent with the full year of 2013.

"
column219:
"

Slide 14 shows the results for corporate other. Revenues declined year-over-year driven mainly by hedging activities
column220: while expenses increased on higher
column221: legal and related expenses
column222:
as well as higher regulatory and compliance cost. Assets of $326 billion included approximately $104 billion of cash and cash equivalents and a $167 billion of liquid investment securities.

"
column223:
"

On slide 15 shows Citi Holdings\u2019 assets which totalled $111 billion at quarter-end
column224: with roughly 60% in North America mortgages. Total assets declined $3 billion during the quarter mostly driven by net pay downs. Roughly $3.8 billion of asset sales were in process during the quarter
column225: but not yet closed as of June 30. These include $2.7 billion of assets from the announced sale of our retail operations in Spain and Greece
column226: as well as nearly $1 billion of mortgage loans
column227:
each of which should close in the third quarter.

"
column228:
"

On slide 16
column229: we show Citi Holdings\u2019 financial results for the quarter. Total revenues of $1.5 billion were up year-over-year primarily driven by the absence of rep and warranty reserve bills in the recent quarter
column230: higher gains on asset sales and lower funding costs. Citi Holdings\u2019 expenses decreased significantly with core operating expenses down 15% in line with the reduction in assets. Net credit losses continued to improve and we released $254 million of loan loss reserves
column231:
the vast majority of which was related to North America mortgages.

"
column232:
"

Looking at the past five quarters of Citi Holdings results on Slide 17; the operating margin in Citi Holdings remained at roughly $700 million this quarter driven in part by gains on asset sales. Credit remained fairly stable and on an adjusted basis
column233:
legal cost declined significantly driving Citi Holdings to a profit in the second quarter.

"
column234:
"

On Slide 18
column235: we show Citigroup\u2019s net interest revenue and margin trends. Net interest revenue was $11.9 billion in the second quarter
column236:
up from last year on higher interest earning assets and an improvement in net interest margin and up sequentially driven by day count. Our net interest margin declined sequentially to 287 basis points in the second quarter driven by lower loan and investment yields partially offset by lower cost of funds. We currently believe our net interest margin should remain roughly flat to second quarter levels for the remainder of the year.

"
column237:
"

On Slide 19
column238:
we show our key capital metrics. Despite the impact of the settlement our Basel III tier one common ratio grew to 10.6% as we benefited from DTA utilization during the quarter. Our supplementary leverage ratio also improved to 5.7% and our tangible book value grew to $56.89 per share.

"
column239:
"

So in summary our results in the second quarter demonstrated further progress on several fronts
column240: while markets revenues reflected the challenging environment
column241:
we showed continued momentum in our investment banking franchise and Treasury and Trade solutions continued to grow all while we continued to reduce our total expense base in ICG.

"
column242:
"

On the consumer side we continued to grow loans
column243: deposits and card purchase sales while reducing our core operating expenses and maintaining overall favorable credit performance. And in Citi Holdings excluding the impact of the settlement we achieved our first profitable quarter and we believe Citi Holdings should remain profitable for the remainder of this year
column244:
although with some variability quarter-to-quarter.

"
column245:
"

Looking to the second half of the year
column246: in markets our results will likely reflect the overall environment. Although we would certainly anticipate that market conditions should be somewhat more favorable than in the second half of 2013. In investment banking revenues will also reflect the overall market
column247:
but we feel good about the quality and momentum of our franchise as demonstrated by our performance not only in the second quarter but over the past year. And in Treasury and Trade solutions we believe we can continue growing our revenues in the second half of the year driven by continued volume growth and abating spread headwinds.

"
column248:
"

Turning to consumer banking; in North America we believe revenue should grow in the second half of the year
column249:
both versus the first half of 2014 as well as year-over-year with positive operating leverage. And in international consumer revenue should also grow in the second half of the year. As we move past our repositioning efforts in Korea and the underlying growth of the remaining franchise becomes more apparent.

"
column250:
"

Turning to expenses; in Citicorp our core operating expenses should continue to decline
column251: although we expect to face on going higher regulatory and compliance costs. Repositioning expenses in the second half of the year should be roughly in line with the first half levels and legal cost will likely remain somewhat elevated and episodic in nature. We continue to have an overall favorable outlook with regard to our credit performance
column252: while we saw an increase in loan loss reserve releases in our North America cards business this quarter
column253:
driven better by better than anticipated credit performance. We do expect the reserve releases to be lower in the second half of the year and nominal credit costs in Citicorp could increase as we continue to grow our loan portfolios.

"
column254:
"

And finally we expect our tax rate for the remainder of the year to be broadly in line with the first half in the range of 32%. And with that Mike and I would be happy to take any questions.

"
column255:
"

Question-and-Answer Session

"
column256:
"

Operator

"
column257:
"

(Operator Instructions). Our first question will come from the line of John McDonald with Sanford Bernstein.

"

"

column259:
"

"

John a few questions

legal expenses in Citicorp that they are going to remain somewhat elevated and episodic in nature. I wouldn\u2019t expect anything significant.

"
column269:
"

John McDonald - Sanford Bernstein

"
column270:
"

And this quarter you had about 400 million in Citicorp in which you characterize that as still elevated to $400 million?

"
column271:
"

John Gerspach

"
column272:
"

"
column273:
"

I would say that\u2019s elevated versus what would expect in a normal environment
column274:
so we will see where we will go at the second half of the year.

"
column275:
"

John McDonald - Sanford Bernstein

"
column276:
"

"
column277:
"

Okay. And then I thought the repositioning expenses will be coming down in the second half of the year after the elevated charge this quarter for Korea. I thought you might have said that last quarter that they will be coming down after this. So
column278:
I thought you just said now that they would stay at the first half levels. What would be keeping the repositioning cost so high?

"
column279:
"

John Gerspach

"
column281:
"

Well John

column283: we actually used the slide that showed that we had improved our efficiency ratio by over -- I think it was 300 basis points in those markets during 2013 and we generated further improvements during 2014 through a combination of efforts of branch closures
column284: product rationalization

consolidation of operation and headcount reductions. And we're just going to continue that focus during the balance of this year and given that continued focus we just think it\u2019s more likely that the repositioning reserves for the second half are going to be much more in line with what we had in the first.

"
column286:
"

John McDonald - Sanford Bernstein

"
column287:
"

Okay. And you mentioned North America consumer expenses likely to improve some more
column288:
overall expenses on the core expense face of about 11 billion this quarter companywide. Do you hope to improve from there going forward?

"
column289:
"

John Gerspach

"
column290:
"

"
column291:
"

We expect the core expenses to decline sequentially in each of the next two quarters. Obviously
column292:
some -- we won\u2019t get as much I think as everybody would like just because of the higher legal and regulatory cost that we're facing but we do anticipate continued sequential decline in the core operating expenses.

"
column293:
"

John McDonald - Sanford Bernstein

"

"

Okay. And just shifting gears to the DTA utilization. That was a big number this quarter
column295: John and better than expected. The big settlement didn\u2019t seem to have an impact

column1020: I believe that if you look at the reserve release as a percentage of the NCL that we have took in mortgages
column1021: it\u2019s roughly equivalent to where we have been. I think that the reserve release was equal to about 86% of the net credit losses that we had in the Holdings\u2019 mortgage book and we have been running somewhere between 85% and 90% in any of the last several quarters. So
column1022:
that reserve release is likely going to again somewhere in that 85% to 90% range of the NCLs that we ultimately charge off in mortgages.

"
column1024:
"

Okay and then quick question on the asset yield. So
column1025: you mentioned that the NIM should be pretty stable from here
column1026: deposit cost look sort of flattened. So
column1027:
can you talk to us about incremental loan yields and incremental securities purchases and then ability to continue to just grow overall balance sheet in terms of NII dollars?

"
column1030:
"

Our expectation is that loans will continue to grow. I mean we still have loan growth in
column1031: again focused on the Citicorp business. Citicorp loans grew 8% year-over-year and we anticipate again still getting good healthy loan growth in our Citicorp businesses. Those loan growth
column1032: even if spreads comedown a little bit on loans that still gives you a nice healthy contribution to your near and your NIM. I think you are right as far as deposit cost
column1033: I think that\u2019s probably going to be somewhat flattish from here on out may be a slight uptick but not much. But we still have the ability to lower our overall cost of funds as we continue to issue
column1034:
rollover the long-term debt at more favorable spreads then what we were issuing several years ago.

"
column1036:
"

Okay and then last question on that last point
column1037:
John. As far as the long-term debt and then also more importantly the continued preferred issuance and I think you guys are still around 70 basis points of B3 RWAs. Can you give us an understanding of just how much of that long-term debt is for roll and then also your general issuance plans on how much of that preferred bucket you want to continue to get on?

"
column1040:
"

As far as long-term debt
column1041: I think we are pretty much at the level certainly of the long-term debt held at the holding company we are pretty much at the level that we think we need to be on a full year basis. And so there will continue to be issuance. We will give you an update on those issuance plans when we do our fixed income conference towards the end of this week but I think it\u2019s pretty much in line with the guidance that we gave out at the end of the first quarter. And we will continue to be an issuer of preferred stock; we recognize that we\u2019ve got some preferred stock issuance to do over the next three to five years
column1042:
so we will be issuing preferred stock but in a somewhat paced approach.

"
column1045:
"

Your next question will come from the line of Matt Burnell with Wells Fargo Security.

"
column1047:
"

Matt Burnell - Wells Fargo Security

column1050: just a follow up on John

column1052: you feel you\u2019re gaining share across the different geographies
column1054:
Europe and the US in both those businesses.

"
column1057:
"

I\u2019d say it\u2019s fairly widespread
column1058: obviously it\u2019s going to be a little bit heavier in some geographies than other and I don\u2019t want to get into you know a geography-by-geography commentary. But again it\u2019s a wide spread you know improvement in the second quarter certainly in the wallet share and again as we look to
column1059:
as the wallet share that we\u2019re capturing in the announced M&A again that\u2019s fairly broad based.

"
column1061:
"

Matt Burnell - Wells Fargo Security

"
column1062:
"

Okay and then just returning to slide 24

column1065:
is that going to stay at a roughly similar amount to the total Citigroup capital or could that be moved down into some of the operating units over time.

column1068:
"

Well when we set up the amount equal to corp other there we laid out the rationale for how we got there
column1069: it\u2019s a little bit of the operations that we have in corp other
column1070: importantly it\u2019s where we hold the capital associated with the DTA
column1071: it\u2019s where we hold some of the operator\u2019s capital that we can\u2019t quite allocate to other businesses and importantly as we continue to generate capital
column1073: far in excess of our ability to distribute capital

column1075: so we\u2019ll do an annual you know re-appropriation based upon what the level of capital that we think is appropriate for each business
column1076:
but as long as we continue to be net generators of TCE you\u2019re going to see more of that in the corp other number.

"
column1078:
"

Matt Burnell - Wells Fargo Security

column1079:
"

And then just finally from me

your investment portfolio is up about 8% year-over-year or 4% quarter-over-quarter. Can you update on what the estimated reduction in your tangible common equity would be from a 100 basis point higher rate environment.

"
column1086: we\u2019ll put this all out next
column1087: probably when we do the fixed income conference
column1088:
but my recollection is that it goes to about $3.4 billion.

column1091:
"

Your next question will come from the line of Derek De Vries with UBS.

column1095: I have a couple of questions on Latin America
column1096: I guess starting with last week the Mexican Anti Trust Authority published recommendations on reform
column1097:
I was hoping you could give us some of those key recommendations and maybe talk a little bit about the impact they could have on dynamics.

column1100:
"

I have to tell you we don\u2019t view what was published last week as having any significant near term impact on dynamics
column1101:
I say that the industry\u2019s still sorting through what was published and it\u2019s still in the early stages of analysis.

"
column1104:
"

Maybe a little more concrete
column1105: the provisions in Latin America ticked up
column1106: and I take on board your comments about portfolio growth and seasoning
column1107: but if there\u2019s nothing sort of one off in nature there
column1108:
is this a level we should sort of expect going forward from Latin America or is there some one-off things in there.

"
column1112: but again most of the performance and the credit performance in Latin America consumer really is being driven by Mexico cards
column1113: and the consumer in Mexico is still absorbing a little bit of the fiscal reform actions that they have gone through and clearly as the Mexico economy continues to struggle to really regain the momentum that everyone thought that it would have
column1114: consumer spending has not been robust
column1116: it\u2019s what he said that the NCO rate will remain relatively high through the end of this year
column1117: that\u2019s why we said that Latin America NCO rate will probably stay at around the first half levels but you know
column1118: we do believe that once that gets behind us there should be improvement in those NCO rates
column1119: as we go into next year
column1120:
so still feel very good about the overall the underlying credit quality in our Mexico cards portfolio.

"
column1123:
"

And then I guess one last question just touching on it
column1124: I think you\u2019ve had talked about a lot today. The last quarter you said that when you made your 2015 targets you build in about 200 basis points in your efficiency ratio for litigation
column1125: so obviously going off a lot from this year
column1126: I am just wondering with three months further along
column1128:
you\u2019ll get enough of litigation stuff behind you this year at the 200 basis points for litigations. So a good gap as to where you\u2019ll come out next year?

"
column1131: I believe that what I said was that the 200 basis points would cover to both
column1132: repositioning as well as legal and related costs. So we\u2019ll have to see as we get closer to the yearend we\u2019ll take a look
column1134:
we still believe based upon what we look at today that we should be able to achieve the efficiency targets that we set out for 2015.

column1137:
"

Your next question will come from the line of Andrew Marquardt with Evercore.

"
column1139:
"

Just back on the balance sheet dynamics in a potentially changing rate environment at some point ended deposit velocity question that Guy was getting to earlier. Can you just help us understand if you do have certain level that you baked into your modeling

column1141: so it\u2019s still a relatively good contribution total deposits. How you do think about maybe isolating that component that could be at risk in terms of reversal
column1144:
"

Yes. Actually we don\u2019t view that component as being at risk because
column1146: I won\u2019t say there wasn\u2019t $1 of deposit but it is at risk but the overall deposit level
column1147: we don\u2019t view as being at risk
column1152: because they really represent for the most part operating account balances. And so those are the funds that businesses need to have in order just to conduct their ongoing operations. So again
column1153: we feel relatively good about it
column1154: now if the FED tapering or if the FED comes in and does something to try to drain liquidity out of the system that could impact future deposit growth
column1155:
but it\u2019s not likely to impact the absolute level of deposit that we currently have in those businesses.

"
column1157:
"

And do you have any updated LCR reach it at this point or is that something we should refer not a fixed income call question maybe?

"

That calculation is still ongoing and we\u2019ll give that to you when we do the fixed income call. It still is a very strong ratio. I just don\u2019t have it in front of me right now.

column1161:
"

The last quarter was about 120-ish
column1164:
"

Yes. It\u2019s going to be just around that maybe even slightly higher
column1165:
when we publish at this week.

column1167:
"

Got it. And then just lastly
column1168: I know there\u2019s been a lot of questions of interest ratios and goals
column1169: but can you just help us understand maybe just to come it down like

column1171: if the revenue environment is stagnant here

column1173: if the revenue environment today seems as it is for another six quarter or so
column1174: is that possible is there enough room on what you have already or would it drive -- you generally think maybe point another something like to draw
column1177:
"

Let\u2019s think about the revenue environment that you refer to
column1178: all right. We have ongoing revenue growth and has had ongoing revenue growth in Latin America even as Mexico has slowed down. So the revenue environment for Latin America still seems to be in growth mode and we feel very good about the way our franchises position there. When you take a look at Asia
column1179: we now have got the Korea repositioning behind us. And we have had underlying growth in each of our franchises in Asia over the last several quarter
column1180: but that has been offset in many ways by the reduction in revenues in Korea so we actually are quite constructive as far as the revenue environment today in Asia
column1181: Asia consumer has producing growth both sequentially and year-over-year in the second half of the year. So we feel really good about the performance of our Asia consumer franchise going forward. In North America
column1182: we\u2019ve got the mortgage repositioning out of the way
column1183: so our mortgage revenues stabilized in the first quarter they actually grew in the second quarter
column1184: we\u2019ve got that business now positioned properly we think for the way the market should move forward. And again we\u2019re not looking to constantly gain
column1185: we don\u2019t look to be number one or number two in that business we just want to be able to serve our customers through our retail branches within appropriate mix of correspondence business. So again we\u2019re very constructive on what we\u2019ve been able to do with the mortgage business. Branded cards I mentioned we\u2019ve got purchase sales growth
column1186: we\u2019ve got good underlying momentum in the full rate loans in that business and importantly in the products where we have actually been investing. When you take a look at branded cards
column1187:
branded cards I think the year-over-year sales growth purchase sales growth was about 5% but if you look at the portfolios where we\u2019ve actually been investing the sales growth there year-over-year is upwards of 8%. So again we feel really good about the momentum and the revenue prospects for branded card. So in our consumer franchises from a revenue momentum point of view we feel good about the revenue momentum.

"
column1188:
"

And then when you move over to the ICG
column1189: we look at the banking franchise and again with the past investments that we\u2019ve made in investment banking we\u2019re doing very well as far as being able to maintain or actually grow wallet share. We\u2019ve had several quarters in a row now of 1 billion or a $1 billion plus revenue quarters. So again we feel good about the revenue momentum in that business. We feel very good about the revenue momentum that we\u2019ve got in transaction services in TTS. 10 quarter
column1191:
we struggled with spread compression overwhelming the volume growth because of the contribution of volume growth. Now that we see the impact of the spread compression beginning to abate the impact of the volume growth now actually is able to overcome the spread compression. And so we feel really good about the revenue prospects for that business going forward.

"
column1192:
"

So then that leaves you with markets. And I think we spend an awful lot of time focused on what\u2019s going on in markets but markets while it\u2019s an important part of our business it is not the largest contributor to our overall revenue picture or our overall profitability. And so I think that there are some legitimate questions going forward as far as markets but the rest of the business I\u2019d say we feel pretty good about the revenue prospects.

"
column1195:
thanks for that summary. And then in terms of in markets and maybe it\u2019s summarized in the ICG when you referenced your I think comp ratio this last quarter was 29% in line with last year. Should we expected that should remain or could it tick higher just because as one referenced earlier as well still trying to figure out how much is cyclical versus secular?

"
column1197:
"

The 29% that I referenced is actually the comp ratio over a trailing 12 month basis. So that\u2019s 29% both for full year 2013 and 29% for the last 12 months as measured as of the end of this quarter.

"
column1200:
"

And should we expect that for the full year or is that?

"
column1202:
"

I am not going to forecast where comp ratio is going to be but you can see that we\u2019ve been holding in fairly constant.

"
column1204:
"

Your next question will come from the line of Steven Chubak with Nomura.

"
column1206:
"

So one of your competitors provided some helpful disclosure on the advanced approach framework under CCAR specifically which reflected an additional 100 basis point decline in the Firm\u2019s Tier 1 common under stress due to the stressed RWA inflation under the Basel III advanced framework. And since the advanced framework appears to be your binding capital constraint at the moment
column1207:
I was wondering whether you\u2019ve conducted a similar assessment internally and if so if you could provide some guidance as to how the advanced approach framework could further impact future risk based capital ratios under CCAR?

"
column1209:
"

I got to tell you
column1210: I have not spent any time looking at what our peer institution put out there
column1213:
"

Have you done the work yourselves though?

"
column1215:
"

I am not sure what they did
column1216:
so I don\u2019t know what they did so I can\u2019t comment as to whether or not we did something similar.

"
column1219: fair enough. And then switching gears and as a follow up to Betsy\u2019s question on operational risk capital your comments indicated that 56 billion true-up proposed by the Fed or imposed by the Fed late last year
column1220:
contemplate some buffer for litigation matters not yet resolved. And I was just wondering what the process is for the Fed providing guidance on op risk capital level so is the feedback given quarterly or is it nearly evaluated as part of the advanced model submissions which from what I recall is actually an annual process?

"
column1223:
it\u2019s something that is under discussion periodically. But obviously goes through a much fuller exam on an annual basis.

"
column1225:
"

Okay. And then just one more from me on capital allocations
column1226:
as part of your enhanced segment disclosure on slide 24 the amount of capital allocated exclusive of DTA to support the operations in Corp and Holdings and focusing I guess or excluding the corporate other segment was a combined 126 billion or so which implies on current RWA levels about a 10% Tier 1 common target. And I was wondering if we should think about that 10% Tier 1 common ratio as an appropriate through the cycle target for Citigroup at this juncture or is it simply still too early to make such a determination?

"
column1228:
"

Again when you take a look at the underlying franchises in Citi right now. We clearly think that the Citicorp businesses are capable of producing mid-teens ROTCE
column1229:
and again that\u2019s going to be -- so the overall firm\u2019s contribution to ROTCE is going to be dependent upon our ability to return capital at some point in time.

"
column1231:
"

Actually there is one more quick question regarding the DTA disclosure. Can you update us on the level of U.S. foreign tax credits that are subject to expiry by 2018? I know it was about 9.9 billion at the end of the year
column1232:
but obviously you\u2019ve made some progress over the last two quarters.

"
column1235:
we update those disclosures on an annual basis. There is just too much movement during individual quarters that actually come up with something that is relevant. So we will update you at the end of this year as to the progress that we have been making.

"
column1237:
"

You have no further questions at this time.

"
column1239:
"

Thank you Regina and thank you all for joining us today. If you have any follow up questions

please reach out to the investor relations team. Thanks.
