column1:
{"Citigroup's (C) CEO Michael Corbat on Q3 2014 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Citigroup Inc. (NYSE:C)

"
column7:
"

Mike Corbat \u2013 Chief Executive Officer

"
column8:
"

John Gerspach \u2013 Chief Financial Officer

"
column10:
"

Susan Kendall - Head of Investor Relations

"
column22:
"

Gerard Cassidy \u2013 RBC Capital Markets

"
column24:
"

Erika Najarian \u2013 Bank of America

"
column26:
"

Matt Burnell \u2013 Wells Fargo Securities

"
column28:
"

[Brian Klein-Hansel] \u2013 KBW

"
column30:
"

"
column34: and welcome to Citi\u2019s Q3 2014 Earnings Review with Chief Executive Officer Mike Corbat and Chief Financial Officer John Gerspach. Today\u2019s call will be hosted by Susan Kendall
column35: Head of Citi Investor Relations. (Operator instructions.) Also this call is being recorded today. If you have any objections please disconnect at this time. Ms. Kendall
column39: Brett. Good morning and thank you all for joining us. On our call today our CEO Mike Corbat will speak first
column41: our CFO
column42: will take you through the earnings presentation which is available for download on our website
column43:
www.citigroup.com. Afterwards we\u2019ll be happy to take questions.

"
column44:
"

Before we get started I would like to remind you that today\u2019s presentation may contain forward-looking statements which are based on management\u2019s current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results in capital and other financial condition may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today and those included in our SEC filings
column45:
including without limitation the \u201cRisk Factors\u201d section of our 2013 Form 10(k).

"
column46:
"

With that said let me turn it over to Mike.

"
column47:
"

Mike Corbat

"
column48:
"

Thank you
column49: Susan. Good morning
column50:
everyone. Earlier today we reported earnings of $3.4 billion for Q3 2014. Excluding the impact of CVA/DVA net income was $3.7 billion or $1.15 per share.

"
column51:
"

Before I address the quarter I\u2019d like to discuss the actions we announced regarding Global Consumer Banking. As you know
column52: we\u2019re committed to simplifying our company and allocating our finite resources to the business where we can generate the best returns for our shareholders. Consistent with these priorities we intend to exit our consumer businesses in eleven markets \u2013 among them Japan
column53:
Egypt and Peru. We\u2019ll continue to serve our institutional clients in these markets which remain important to our global network.

"
column54:
"

While these consumer franchise have real value we didn\u2019t see a path for meaningful return. We believe our Consumer business will achieve stronger performance by focusing on the countries where our scale and network provide a competitive advantage. Sales processes are already underway in most of these markets and I expect these actions to be substantially completed by the end of 2015. At that point we\u2019ll have reduced our Consumer footprint by 19 markets since 2012 and Global Consumer Banking will be serving 57 million clients across 24 markets.

"
column55:
"

I\u2019d also like to address the announcement we issued earlier this morning regarding a legacy Banamex unit which provided personal security and protective services. While the fraud is not financially material
column56: in light of the conduct we found in the interest of transparency we thought it was best to inform you. As you know we\u2019ve been reviewing our franchise in Mexico and have already made meaningful changes to strengthen our processes and controls
column57:
and will continue to take whatever steps are necessary to make sure that every part of our global franchise lives up to the standards all of us rightfully expect.

"
column58:
"

Now turning to the quarter: we achieved solid performance across our Institutional businesses. Both Banking and Markets saw improved revenue from prior-year period assisted by a better trading environment and a strong M&A pipeline. Treasury and Trade Solution revenues increased slightly despite spread compression.

"
column59:
"

Global Consumer Banking had a strong quarter as well and saw loan growth throughout the regions. In North America we had revenue improvement in each of our businesses both quarter-on-quarter and year-on-year while we continued to optimize our branch network. Internationally we saw revenue improvements across every region compared to Q3 last year.

"
column60:
"

Overall these results show solid business performance which has helped increase Citigroup net income by 5% year-to-date over 2013. We also continue to be focused on reducing the drag on earnings caused by Citi Holdings and consuming DTA. These have been execution priorities and we again made progress on both fronts.

"
column61:
"

In Citi Holdings we closed the sales of our Consumer businesses in Greece and Spain which helped reduce assets during the quarter by 7% to $103 billion. Holdings assets now constitute only 5% of Citigroup\u2019s balance sheet.

"
column62:
"

The Holdings profit of $272 million again helped drive DTA consumption. We utilized $700 million of DTA in the quarter
column63:
bringing the total to over $5 billion for the last seven quarters. This contributed to our generating nearly $4 billion of regulatory capital this quarter and growing our Tier One common ratio to 10.7%. Our tangible booked value also increased to $57.73.

"
column64:
"

While we\u2019re pleased with our ability to generate capital we\u2019re equally focused on our ability to return it to our shareholders. During the quarter we continued to make progress on our efforts to strengthen our capital planning process.

"
column65:
"

Most important our capital planning process is being fully embedded in the way we run the firm. This must impact everything
column66:
from increased business engagement and enhancements to our forecasting models and scenario design processes \u2013 all of which lead to an improved approach to risk and controls. This work will continue as we get closer to receiving the 2015 stress test scenario from The Fed at which point we\u2019ll prepare a strong submission which reflects the work that has been done.

"
column67:
"

As we finish out 2014 we\u2019re very mindful of the challenging macro environment. Geopolitical tensions
column68: uneven growth and concerns over the timing of interest rate increases have increased volatility. While the economy in the US seems to be slowly gaining strength
column69:
the Eurozone is not yet in growth mode and emerging market growth has slowed.

"
column70:
"

While our expense reduction efforts have been productive we continue to face pressure related to legal costs and the need to invest in regulatory and compliance
column71:
as well as the critical need to protect our network from cybercrime. We\u2019ll remain vigilant along each of these fronts to ensure the safety and soundness of our institution.

"
column72:
"

John will now go through the deck and then we\u2019d be happy to take your questions. Thank you. John?

"
column73:
"

John Gerspach

"
column74:
"

Okay
column75: thank you
column76: Mike
column77:
and good morning everyone. Let me briefly review the results of the quarter and then I\u2019ll go into more detail on the strategic actions we announced earlier today.

"
column78:
"

To start
column79: I\u2019d like to highlight two items that affect the comparability of this quarter\u2019s results to prior periods. First
column80: CVA/DVA was a negative $371 million pre-tax
column81: or $228 million after-tax this quarter including a $474 million one-time charge due to the implementation of funding valuation adjustments related to certain derivatives. Together these charges had a negative impact on EPS of $0.08 per share this quarter
column82:
similar to the CVA/DVA charge last year.

"
column83:
"

And secondly
column84: last year we recorded a tax benefit of $176 million or $0.06 per share related to the resolution of certain tax audit items. Adjusting for these items
column85:
we earned $1.15 per share in the recent quarter compared to $1.02 per share in Q3 last year. Throughout today\u2019s presentation I will be discussing our results excluding these items to provide comparability to prior periods.

"
column86:
"

On Slide 4 we show total Citigroup results. We earned $3.7 billion in Q3
column87: a 13% increase from last year. Pre-tax earnings of $5.9 billion grew 28% driven by revenue growth and lower credit costs
column88: partially offset by an increase in operating expenses mostly driven by higher legal and repositioning charges. However
column89: our tax rate was higher this quarter at 36%
column90:
reflecting a higher level of non-tax deductible legal accruals versus last year as well as higher tax costs related to the sales of our Consumer operations in both Greece and Spain.

"
column91:
"

On a year-to-date basis
column92: we generated positive operating leverage with modest revenue growth and flat expenses
column93: and our return on assets improved to 83 basis points. In constant dollars
column94: Citigroup end-of-period loans grew slightly year-over-year
column95: to $654 billion
column96:
as 4% growth in Citicorp was partially offset by the continued decline in Citi Holdings. And deposits were flat at $943 billion.

"
column97:
"

On Slide 5 we show more detail on expenses. Legal and related and repositioning costs totaled over $1.3 billion in Q3
column98: mostly incurred in Citicorp. We also incurred $59 million of operating expenses related to the sales of our Consumer operations in Greece and Spain this quarter. Excluding these items core operating expenses of nearly $11 billion in Q3 increased by roughly $100 million versus prior periods
column99:
primarily reflecting an adjustment to incentive compensation expense driven by better-than-anticipated performance year-to-date in our Institutional franchise.

"
column100:
"

Higher regulatory and compliance costs
column101:
including those related to CECCAR and the impact of business growth were more than offset by continued cost reduction initiatives as well as the decline in Citi Holdings assets.

"
column102:
"

We expect to incur an incremental $150 million to $175 million of costs in full-year 2014 as we work to enhance our capital planning process. We estimate that about one-third of that amount will be non-recurring. In 2014
column103:
the incremental CECCAR-related costs will be more heavily weighted to the back half of the year. In Q3 we spent an incremental $60 million related to the CECCAR process and we expect this amount to increase further in Q4.

"
column104:
"

On Slide 6 we show the split between Citicorp and Citi Holdings. Citicorp\u2019s pre-tax earnings grew 13% as higher revenues across the franchise and lower credit costs were partially offset by an increase in operating expenses. Citicorp expense growth was mostly driven by higher legal and repositioning costs
column105: the adjustment to incentive compensation and ICG
column106:
and higher regulatory and compliance costs partially offset by efficiency savings.

"
column107:
"

In Citi Holdings we were profitable again this quarter with over $270 million in net income compared to a loss of over $100 million last year
column108:
driven primarily by lower legal and related expenses. Citi Holdings ended the quarter with $103 billion of assets or 5% of total Citigroup assets.

"
column109:
"

Before I go into more detail on Citicorp I\u2019d like to cover the strategic actions Mike discussed earlier which will streamline and simplify our Consumer operations. We are exiting our Consumer operations in eleven markets plus our Consumer Finance business in Korea. As you can see on Slide 7 these actions include markets across Latin America
column110:
Asia and AMEA.

"
column111:
"

Substantially all of these operations were previously classified as \u201coptimized markets\u201d in our country bucketing framework
column112:
and while we have made steady progress in many of these businesses we ultimately determined that our scale did not provide for meaningful returns.

"
column113:
"

We already have active sales processes underway for over half of the businesses and we currently expect the strategic actions to be substantially completed by the end of 2015. We expect to report these Consumer operations as part of Citi Holdings as of Q1. We will continue to serve our Institutional clients in these countries which remain important to our global network.

"
column114:
"

On Slide 8 we provide details on the financial impact of these actions
column115:
showing Citicorp on the left and Global Consumer Banking on the right. Over the last twelve months these businesses contributed over $1.6 billion of revenues and $34 million of net income. Total assets were $29 billion as of the end of Q3 including $7 billion of consumer loans; and total deposits were $26 billion.

"
column116:
"

As shown on the far right
column117:
on a pro forma basis our Global Consumer Banking business would continue to capture more than 95% of our existing revenue base while further simplifying our operations and improving our performance.

"
column118:
"

Now
column119: turning back to Q3
column120: on Slide 9 we show actual results for International Consumer Banking in constant dollars. Net income grew 22% year-over-year in Q3 driven by higher revenues and lower credit costs
column121:
partially offset by higher legal and repositioning charges. Revenues grew 5% year-over-year in Q3 driven by continued volume growth across the franchise with average loans up 5% and average deposits up 3%; a rebound in investment sales revenues in Asia; and a reduced impact from our repositioning efforts in Korea.

"
column122:
"

Core operating expenses excluding legal and repositioning costs were roughly flat as ongoing efficiency savings offset the impact of business growth as well as higher regulatory and compliance costs. International credit costs declined 13% year-over-year driven by a net loan loss reserve release in the current quarter
column123:
while the net credit loss rate remained broadly favorable at just under 200 basis points.

"
column124:
"

Slide 10 shows the results for North America Consumer Banking. Net income grew 33% year-over-year this quarter driven by higher revenues
column125: lower operating expenses
column126:
and continued favorable credit trends. Total revenues were up 5% year-over-year.

"
column127:
"

Retail Banking revenues of $1.2 billion grew 9% from last year
column128:
reflecting continued volume growth and abating spread headwinds as well as a mortgage repurchase reserve release of roughly $50 million this quarter.

"
column129:
"

Branded cards revenues of $2.1 billion were up 1% versus last year as we grew purchase sales and an improvement in spreads mostly offset the impact of lower average loans. And Retail Services revenues grew 8% from last year
column130:
mostly driven by the BestBuy portfolio acquisition.

"
column131:
"

Ongoing cost reduction initiatives drove total operating expenses down slightly year-over-year to $2.4 billion even after absorbing the impact of the BestBuy portfolio acquisition and higher legal and repositioning expenses. We continued to resize our North America Retail Banking business in Q3
column132: taking costs out of our mortgage operations and rationalizing the branch footprint
column133:
all while continuing to grow our franchise.

"
column134:
"

Over the past twelve months we have sold or closed nearly 90 branches in North America. During this same period we grew average retail loans by 9% and average deposits by 2% including 10% growth in checking account balances. We also continued to see momentum in branded cards. While total average loans have continued to decline modestly this mostly reflects the runoff of promotional rate balances.

"
column135:
"

Full rate balances have grown year-over-year for six consecutive quarters and we continue to see strong growth in accounts and purchase sales in our proprietary Rewards and Travel co-brand products. We also launched our Double Cash card this quarter
column136:
which rounds out our product portfolio in the important cash-back segment.

"
column137:
"

Slide 11 shows our Global Consumer Credit trends in more detail. Overall Global Consumer Credit trends remained favorable in Q3
column138: with net credit losses and delinquencies both improving as a percentage of loans. In North America the NCL rate continued to improve while 90+ day delinquency rates were flat. Asia remained stable
column139:
and in Latin America we saw a modest uptick in the NCL rate while the delinquency rate improved slightly.

"
column140:
"

Net credit losses grew broadly in line with our expectations in Q3 driven by portfolio growth and continued seasoning in the Mexico cards portfolio as well as the impact of both slower economic growth and fiscal reforms in that market. However
column141:
our overall loan growth was slower than anticipated which had a negative impact on the NCL rate for the quarter. This slower loan growth reflected the overall economic environment as well as a higher level of prepayments in our mortgage portfolio. Looking to Q4 we expect the dollar amount of net credit losses in Latin America to be more or less stable.

"
column142:
"

Slide 12 shows the expense and efficiency trends for Global Consumer Banking on a trailing twelve-month basis. While annual expenses increased in late 2012 and early 2013
column143: driven in part by higher North America mortgage activity
column144: we have driven down the core expense base over the last five quarters even as we have absorbed the impact of higher expenses associated with the BestBuy portfolio acquisition. Including roughly $800 million of legal and repositioning charges over the last year
column145:
our total efficiency ratio for Global Consumer Banking was 56%.

"
column146:
"

Slide 13 shows our total Consumer expenses over the past five quarters split between core operating expenses and legal and repositioning costs. Core expenses continued to decline on a sequential basis in Q3 as we made further progress towards our year-end goals for headcount reduction
column147: card product simplification
column148:
and branch and support site rationalization.

"
column149:
"

Turning now to the Institutional Clients Group on Slide 14
column150:
net income grew 29% year-over-year driven by higher revenues partially offset by higher operating expenses. Revenues of $8.7 billion grew 13% from last year and 2% sequentially. Total Banking revenues of $4.3 billion grew 11% from last year and were down 3% from the prior quarter.

"
column151:
"

Treasury and Trade Solutions revenues of $2 billion were up 1% year-over-year as growth in fees and volumes was partially offset by spread compression. Sequentially
column152:
revenues declined by 2% driven by lower trade assets and spreads.

"
column153:
"

Investment Banking revenues of $1.2 billion were up 32% from last year driven by strong M&A and equity underwriting activity
column154:
and down 7% from the prior quarter as continued momentum in M&A was more than offset by seasonally lower underwriting volumes. Private Bank revenues of $663 million grew 8% from last year as growth in client volumes was partially offset by the impact of spread compression.

"
column155:
"

Corporate Lending revenues were $442 million
column156:
up 17% from last year reflecting growth in average loans and improved funding costs partially offset by lower loan yields and down 3% from last quarter on lower gains from asset sales. Total Markets and Securities Services revenues of $4.3 billion grew 8% year-over-year and 5% sequentially.

"
column157:
"

Fixed Income revenues of $3 billion grew 5% from last year driven by strength in securitized products as well as an increase in foreign exchange volatility and volumes which benefited our Rates and Currencies business in the month of September. Sequentially
column158:
Fixed Income revenues were down slightly as a seasonal decline in spread product revenues was mostly offset by strength in rates and currencies.

"
column159:
"

Equities revenues of $763 million grew 14% year-over-year driven by improved client activity in derivatives
column160:
and were up 16% sequentially on better trading performance. In Securities Services revenues grew 8% year-over-year driven by an increase in client balances and activity.

"
column161:
"

Total operating expenses of $5 billion grew 3% over prior periods
column162: driven by the compensation adjustment
column163: higher regulatory and compliance costs
column164:
and higher repositioning charges partially offset by ongoing efficiency savings.

"
column165:
"

On Slide 15 we show expense and efficiency trends for the Institutional business. On a trailing twelve-month basis
column166: the efficiency ratio declined to 59% this quarter despite continued elevated legal and repositioning charges. And our comp ratio for the last twelve months was 28%
column167:
down from 29% last quarter.

"
column168:
"

Slide 16 shows the results for Corp. Other. Revenues declined year-over-year driven mainly by hedging activities while expenses increased on higher legal and related expenses as well as higher regulatory and compliance costs
column169:
including those related to the CECCAR process. Assets of $332 billion included approximately $97 billion of cash and cash equivalents and $180 billion of liquid investment securities.

"
column170:
"

Slide 17 shows Citi Holdings assets
column171:
which totaled $103 billion at quarter-end with over 60% in North America mortgages. Total assets declined $8 billion during the quarter driven by net pay downs and divestitures including the sales of our Consumer operations in both Greece and Spain.

"
column172:
"

On Slide 18 we show Citi Holdings financial results for the quarter. Total revenues of $1.6 billion were up year-over-year
column173: primarily driven on gains on the sales of our Consumer operations in both Greece and Spain and lower funding costs
column174:
partially offset by losses on the redemption of debt used to fund Holdings assets.

"
column175:
"

Citi Holdings expenses decreased significantly
column176: driven by the lower level of assets as well as lower legal and related costs partially offset by $59 million of episodic expenses related to the sales of our Consumer operations in Greece and Spain. Net Credit losses continued to improve
column177: down 45% year-over-year
column178:
driven by North America mortgages.

"
column179:
"

And we offset all of the mortgage net Credit losses with loan loss reserve releases. The net loan loss reserve release of $144 million includes the impact of roughly $75million of losses on assets moved to held for sale this quarter. Excluding these losses
column180:
the reserve release would have been close to $220 million.

"
column181:
"

On Slide 19 we show Citigroup\u2019s net interest revenue and margin trends. Our net interest margin improved to 291 basis points in Q3 reflecting lower cost of funds. Looking to Q4
column182:
given the sale of Consumer loans with attractive margins in Greece and Spain we could see our net interest margin decline by a basis point or two.

"
column183:
"

On Slide 20 we show our key capital metrics. During the quarter our Basil-3 Tier One common ratio grew to 10.7%
column184: driven by net earnings and continued DTA utilization. Our supplementary leverage ratio also improved to 6.0%
column185:
with about half of the sequential increase due to the impact of the revised final US Rules. And our tangible book value grew to $57.73 per share.

"
column186:
"

In summary
column187: our results in Q3 demonstrated momentum across the firm. In Consumer Banking we grew revenues
column188: loans and deposits in every region resulting in positive operating leverage and strong income growth over last year. And in our Institutional franchise we saw broad revenue growth across Markets
column189: Investment Banking and Treasury and Trade Solutions
column190:
also resulting in positive operating leverage and significant growth in net income.

"
column191:
"

In Citi Holdings we were profitable again this quarter while continuing to wind down the remaining assets in an economically rational manner. And we continued to grow our book and regulatory capital.

"
column192:
"

Looking to Q4
column193: in Consumer Banking we expect to continue growing our revenues while maintaining positive operating leverage year-over-year. In Markets our results will likely reflect the overall environment as well as normal seasonal trends. In Investment Banking
column194:
revenues should also reflect the overall market but we feel good about the quality and momentum of our franchise as demonstrated by our performance. And in Treasury and Trade Solutions we believe we can continue growing our revenues year-over-year in Q4 driven by continued volume growth and abating spread headwinds.

"
column195:
"

Turning to expenses
column196: in Citicorp our core operating expenses should be relatively flat to Q3 levels as we expect to continue to face ongoing higher regulatory and compliance costs
column197: including those related to our enhanced capital planning process. Repositioning expenses should be more or less in line with the roughly $400 million we incurred in Q3
column198:
and legal costs will likely remain elevated and episodic in nature.

"
column199:
"

We continue to have an overall favorable outlook with regard to our Credit performance. And finally
column200:
we expect our tax rate for Q4 to be broadly in line with the first half of the year in the range of 32%.

"
column201:
"

With that Mike and I would be happy to take any questions.

But from a TLAC point of view right now

we would put our loss absorbent capital at just over 20% of our risk-weighted assets.

"

column522: yeah
column523: it would definitely have an impact. You have to be highly cognizant now of your SLR ratio and you\u2019ve got to manage through both the SLR and the LCR. So depending upon what deposits you take in
column524: those deposits could have a high liquidity value or they could have zero liquidity value. If a deposit has zero liquidity value then you can\u2019t do anything with it other than invest it overnight
column525:
which means you\u2019re holding either cash or overnight Treasury securities. Now that drives up the asset side of your balance sheet and now you\u2019ve got to be worried about your SLR constraints because all of a sudden now you\u2019ve got to put capital against that.

"
column526:

But those savings in Q4 are likely going to be reinvested then as we continue to enhance our capital planning process
column658:
CECCAR.

column659:
"

Betsy Graseck \u2013 Morgan Stanley

"
column660:
"

Right
column661:
I get it. Thanks a lot.

column663:
"

Not a problem.

Your next question comes from the line of Gerard Cassidy with RBC. Please go ahead with your question.

column666:

Gerard Cassidy \u2013 RBC Capital Markets

column668: good afternoon. Can you share with us
column669: in your last (q) I think you put in there that a 100-basis point shift in the yield curve would contribute an additional $1.9 billion or so to revenue. If the yield curve flattens and The Fed does move rates up next year
column670:
but as you notice the ten-year today is down to about 2.2% - if we don\u2019t get the parallel shift how much of the benefit would you likely see with the front end going up but the long end remaining anchored where it is today?

"
column672:
"

If the front end went up but the long end dropped
column673: there is a scenario we\u2019ve laid out for you which has a 100 basis point increase in short-term and a relatively flat long-term. I think what you see in that type of environment
column674:
we capture the lion\u2019s share of the $1.9 billion. I don\u2019t have that number in my head but it\u2019s a substantial portion of the $1.9 billion.

column675:
"

Gerard Cassidy \u2013 RBC Capital Markets

"
column676:
"

Great. The second question is can you remind us

column678: your Tier One Common ratio for example

column680:
but are you looking to maintain a 50- or 100-basispoint number over whatever the final target becomes?

column681:

John Gerspach

"
column683:
as you say it\u2019s a little hard right now because we don\u2019t know where the final rules are going to come out. So give us a chance to take a look at the final rule and then we\u2019ll be happy to tell you what kind of buffer we think we need. There\u2019s still a bit of rulemaking yet to be laid down. We\u2019ve got the promise of another G-SIFI surcharge. We\u2019ve got OLA that still needs to be finalized. So when these things begin to settle down we\u2019ll be happy to come back to you then with a more informed target.

column684:
"

Gerard Cassidy \u2013 RBC Capital Markets

column685:
"

Okay

column687:
I know that this may not be the case a year from now.

column688:

John Gerspach

column689:
"

Well let\u2019s see \u2013 on October 14th I\u2019d say it\u2019s Tier One
column690: Basil-3
column692: Tier One Common. But check back with me by November 14<sup>th</sup> and I may have a slightly different answer. And I\u2019m not trying to be cute \u2013 it\u2019s just that as the rules begin to change and they intersect you\u2019re constantly battling one against the other. If you had asked me a year ago I would have said SLR was going to be the binding constraint. Six months ago I was really worried that Standardized RWA
column693: the standardized approach was going to be the binding constraint. Today I feel like it\u2019s Basil-3 Tier One Common
column694:
and then of course there\u2019s always the ultimate is of course the CECCAR submission itself. So we need to keep our eye on all four of those and it doesn\u2019t do you any good to just manage one.

column695:

Gerard Cassidy \u2013 RBC Capital Markets

Do you guys have any color on that or what do you guys think about that? Are you concerned about that if they bring it into the CECCAR process the way everybody underwrites leveraged lending?

Mike Corbat

You know
column702: Gerard. We haven\u2019t heard anything on that formally so obviously this has been a big area of focus for The Fed and the OCC

Gerard Cassidy \u2013 RBC Capital Markets

Thank you

guys.

But the entire net impact really is the result of enhancements to our risk models
column718: primarily credit models
column719:
and as well as our interpretation of the final B-3 rules. So we\u2019ve been enhancing our models and that\u2019s caused us then to increase the amount of risk-weighted assets that are required.

John Gerspach

our regulators still continue their reviews so there still may be additional enhancements required going forward.

the AOCI losses were actually quite substantial and presumably should only increase as the number of Basil-3 deductions are recognized within the transitional horizon. column736: and therefore how that impacts the numerator in our regulatory capital. So again

column738:
we don\u2019t want to overweight towards hold to maturity. But we would look at it right now and say perhaps we\u2019re a little underweight where we are.

"

column768: specifically Mexico. So you do have certain market-by-market where you can see the impact

column776: we\u2019re doing fine and I think that we\u2019re managing to keep pace within the economies in which we operate. We have seen spread pressure hit us in the trade product \u2013 that\u2019s certainly something that hit us this quarter. When you take a look at the revenue growth in TTS
column777:
the revenue growth in TTS was impacted both year-over-year and quarter-over-quarter by a roughly $40 million decline in Trade product revenues. And while the spreads in the cash management business were largely stable overall trade spreads have been declining now for several quarters.

column778:
"

So we\u2019ve seen that impact but we are maintaining our market share in that product
column779: but we\u2019re doing that by shifting to an originate for sale type of approach. So we\u2019re maintaining market share but instead of originating for balance sheet we\u2019re originating to sell \u2013 that means that we forego net interest revenue in return for an upfront fee but as a result the trade revenue assets have declined
column780:
so have our trade assets. But we\u2019ve preserved and in some cases have improved our returns. So there\u2019s different ways of managing through lower spread environments.

And obviously in preparation for the sale process you do a lot of those things that are requisite in the filing anyway. So it was I think convenient to be able to do that. So again
column826:
move towards the sale process and we\u2019ll always have the option to do an IPO if we want to use it.

"

"

Chris Kotowski \u2013 Oppenheimer & Co.

Great

Mike Corbat

Great

thanks Chris.

column1:
{"Citigroup's (C) CEO Mike Corbat on Q4 2014 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Citigroup Inc. (NYSE:C)

"
column19:
"

Gerard Cassidy - RBC Capital Markets

"
column21:
"

Matt Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column22:
"

Erika Najarian - Bank of America

"
column25: and welcome to Citi's Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Review
column27: Mike Corbat and John Gerspach. Today's call will be hosted by Susan Kendall
column28: Head of Citi Investor Relations. We ask that you please hold all questions until the completion of the formal remarks at which time you will be given instructions for the question-and-answer session. Also
column30: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column36: Brent. Good morning and thank you all for joining us. On our call today
column39: will speak first. Then John Gerspach
column41: will take you through the earnings presentation
column42: which is available for download on our Web site
column43: Citigroup.com. Afterwards
column44:
we will be happy to take questions.

"
column45:
"

Before we get started
column46: I would like to remind you that today's presentation may contain forward-looking statements
column47: which are based on management's current expectation and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results and capital and other financial conditions may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors
column48: including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today
column49: and those included in our SEC filings
column50: including
column52:
the risk factor section of our 2013 Form 10-K.

"
column54:
let me turn it over to Mike.

"
column57: Susan. Good morning
column58: everyone. Earlier today
column59: we reported earnings of $350 million for the fourth quarter of 2014
column60: or $0.06 a share. These results include the impact of $3.5 billion in legal reserves and repositioning costs
column61: which we had disclosed in December. While these charges had the biggest impact on our results
column62: we also saw a challenging end to the year
column63: with macro uncertainties and falling oil prices resulting in a more difficult market environment than we had expected
column64:
particularly in the last few weeks of December.

"
column65:
"

At the same time
column66: our institutional banking franchise continued to show solid revenue growth. In consumer banking
column67: our U.S. franchise performed well and we showed modest growth in international consumer
column68: even as the global economic growth remained uneven. In Citi Holdings
column69: we were profitable again this quarter and reduced assets to below $100 billion for the first time
column70:
driven by ongoing runoff in asset sales.

"
column71:
"

While the overall results for 2014 fell short of our expectations
column72: we did make significant progress towards our priorities
column73: and while some of the steps we took were painful
column74: I believe they allowed us to put our franchise in a position to have a successful 2015. We're doing everything we can to maximize the benefits of our repositioning costs and throughout 2014 we worked hard to improve our efficiency and reduce our cost base. We reduced our head count by almost 10
column75: 000 people
column76: closed 95 operation sites
column77: shrunk our branch network by over 10% while increasing digital uptake by consumers
column78: simplified our product offerings
column79:
and increased customer satisfaction as measured by net promoter scores.

"
column80:
"

We sold our consumer businesses in Spain and Greece and took important steps towards the exit of One Main. And in October
column81:
we announced plans to exit 11 consumer markets and have already signed two agreements regarding the sales of our Japanese retail business and our consumer business in Peru. These steps are part of our process to build one global consumer bank from a confederation of local banks.

"
column82:
"

Our institutional banking business performed well throughout the year
column83: as we focused on serving our core clients. In investment banking
column84: we gained share with our target clients across most regions
column85: generating strong revenue growth
column86: and despite the low interest rate environment
column87: treasury and trade solutions grew revenues as well
column88:
as did our private bank.

"
column89:
"

While our markets businesses were impacted by volatility towards the end of the year
column90: we'll continue to take steps to make sure that they are sized correctly for the environment we see going forward. After reviewing certain institutional businesses
column91:
we have decided to exit several non-core transactions businesses in order to further decrease our expense base and improve net income. These businesses will be reported out of Citi Holdings going forward.

"
column92:
"

For the first time since its establishment
column93: Citi Holdings was profitable for the full year and we reduced its assets by 16%. By utilizing $3.1 billion in DTA
column94: we exceeded 2013's utilization by $600 million and have now utilized $5.6 billion in the last two years. Despite significant legal challenges
column95: we were still able to generate $11 billion in regulatory capital in 2014
column96:
bringing the total to $31 billion over the last two years.

"
column97:
"

During the year
column98: we managed our balance sheet carefully. We grew our loan book in Citicorp and improved both our net interest revenue and margin from 2013 levels. We made Citi a safer and stronger institution in several ways. We invested in our risk
column99: audit and compliant functions. We reduced our risk to asset profile by asset sales in business exits and we maintained a highly liquid balance sheet while improving the quality of our deposits. Our capital
column100:
leverage and liquidity ratios each increased over the course of the year.

"
column101:
"

Returning capital to our shareholders remains a critical priority. During the year
column102: we invested in and strengthened our capital planning process by focusing on risk identification and scenario design
column103: improved our models
column104:
and we fostered a deeper engagement with our businesses.

"
column105:
"

Last week
column106: we submitted our capital plan to the Federal Reserve and we believe the submission reflects the progress we have made. We're fully committed to sustaining and building on these gains. As recent events have shown
column107: there's no reason to think that the environment in 2015 will be any less challenging than the one we faced in 2014. While the recovery in the U.S. is gaining momentum
column108: aided by lower energy costs
column109: Europe is a continuing area of concern
column110: with Russia and Greece facing the most immediate pressure. And while most emerging markets continue to grow
column111:
their economies remain the most vulnerable to external factors.

"
column112:
"

That being said
column113:
we feel good about how we're positioned and to meet the challenges. This is an important year for our firm and we're committed to reaching our efficiency and return on asset targets.

column362: including a mid-50s efficiency ratio in Citicorp and a return on assets of at least 90 basis points for Citigroup. We believe we can reach these targets through a combination of several drivers. First

column376: as we progressed through the year

column380: which account for over three quarters of Citicorp revenues. And in markets

column382:

column388: we believe we can drive a meaningful reduction in total operating expenses as a result of continued expense discipline to offset higher regulatory and compliance costs
column389: the full realization of cost savings from the actions we took in 2014

column512:

column513:

column515: or as we think of the potential winners and losers and how that impacts our business
column516: I would probably break the world into \u2013 or countries into one of three buckets. Those where there's a clear benefit from the reduction in terms of oil prices
column517: those where there's a clear detriment or headwind that comes as a function of lower oil or energy prices
column518: and then there's a bucket in the middle where it probably becomes a bit more complex. And that is where you've got different combinations of where economies overall benefit
column519:
yet you have governments that are quite dependent on oil export for revenue generation against their budgets.

column582: our expense line and our cost of credit line. However

column586:

column587:

When it comes to capital
column588: we do hedge our capital that's invested in foreign currencies
column589: but we hedge it with a view towards protecting our CET 1 ratio. And that's why
column590: when you look at how foreign exchange movements occur they not only impact your capital invested
column591: they will impact your assets. And they will also impact some of the assets that you have
column592: such as the intangibles that serve
column593: then
column594:
as direct deductions against your regulatory capital base.

"
column595:
"

So we factor all of that into a hedging program that
column596: gives us fairly good results. And this quarter
column597: with all the movement we had
column598: the combination of our hedging program and then the natural hedges that we have resulted in a zero impact on our CET 1 ratio. However
column599: because we do not hedge every dollar of capital
column600: you will then have an impact through OCI on tangible book. But
column601: if I'm going to run the company with an eye towards where do I have exposure
column602:
I want to protect my CET 1 ratio. I don't want to run an FX position through that ratio.

"
column603:
"

And so in a quarter where the dollar strengthens
column604: we may take a reduction on tangible book. But I've protected the ratio. If I go the other way
column605: if the dollar weakens
column606: and we have had quarters where the dollar is weakened
column607: then I may really enjoy the impact that it has on my tangible book
column608: but it's going to destroy my CET 1 ratio. And as you know
column609: that is one of the key measures of regulatory strength that we have. So we think that it's really important that through our hedging program
column610:
we focus on that CET 1 ratio.

looks like you guys have a bit more bigger market share there. Is there any reason why that wouldn't be a bit of a headwind for your DCM business here if we assume that there's a slowdown in energy-related issuance?

"
column901:
"

Some of these things will certainly have impact. I would say that global energy has certainly been a robust area for the last four years and clearly
column904: has seen significant growth in episodic business as a result from that sector. And you're going to have some impact for lower
column905: lower commodity prices and lower equity valuations. That is certainly going to have an impact on equity offerings and IPOs. But energy
column906: energy is a broad business
column907: and some sectors are going to be impacted more than others. And so we continue to see bust activity in some sectors where we're a leader
column908:
and I think you'll see the upstream in the energy services sector certainly see significantly less activity. So we'll just see how the whole mix continues.

"
column909:
"

Brennan Hawken

"
column911: thanks. And then shifting gears to Mexico

column913:
color in the market on Banamex and the fact that there would be a bunch of bidders for it and such. Is that \u2013 is the reason for that noise because you all were having dialogue? Or is this just from companies hoping to bid for an asset if it happens to come on the market?

column914:
"

Mike Corbat

"
column915:
"

We rarely comment on things. And in that case
column916:
we felt compelled to go out and comment and say that we are not a seller of Banamex. And I don't think we can be any more clear about that on these calls and in the forums. I've spoken directly to it and the importance of the franchise and why we're so constructive on our position in Mexico and why we think Banamex is the right way to express that in Mexico. So we have a terrific franchise. We're committed to it. And we think there's very good things ahead coming out of that business.

column917:
"

Brennan Hawken

"
column918:
"

That's clear. Thanks. And then in equities

column921: more broadly

column923:
whether it's derivatives or in this case EMEA or what have you. How do you feel about it currently and where do you want to take it in the next couple years?

column924:
"

John Gerspach

"
column925:
"

We're committed to the equities business. And this has been a business that we have spent a lot of time working on. And I think the \u2013 outside of EMEA
column926: this quarter we've actually got performance that shows the progress that we've made. As I mentioned in my prepared remarks
column927: excluding the performance in EMEA
column930: in every other region
column932: Latin America
column933: Asia all saw double-digit growth. It's not that there's just one region that's driving the action here. This is a good franchise. We have an issue with our equities franchise in one region. And we have certainly begun to take actions there. We've made management changes
column934:
beginning in the late second half of 2014 and we do expect that region to be a much better performer in 2015.

"
column935:
"

Brennan Hawken

"
column936:
"

And given the fact that it was so strong in other regions
column937: were there some sort of risk management or facilitation losses there

or was it purely just volume-driven?

column939:
"

John Gerspach

"
column940:
"

No
column941: it's a combination. We had volumes
column942: and we had strong performance in some of our equity derivatives business. Asia had a very good performance in equity derivatives this year for one in the quarter. So did Latin America. So it was pretty broad-based good performance. Again
column943:
the one difference would be \u2013 the one exception to that would be in EMEA.

"
column945:
"

Okay. And then last one for me
column946: you gave some helpful color on the fact that ICG expenses
column947: you took down the incentive comp. But there was an offsetting assumption to the deferral
column948:
deferred comp piece. Could you maybe give us a little bit more color on those changes? Was that tied to repositioning that you guys are planning? Or is it a change in the timing of the deferral schedule? Are you shifting to more cash oriented comp? What's driving that?

column949:
"

John Gerspach

"
column950:
"

No. It's a combination of factors
column951: as so many other things are. And as you go through the year
column952: you make assumptions both on the absolute
column953: the dollar level of deferred comp that you're going to have. And don't forget
column954: every country has got some slightly different rules. We also need to make assumptions based upon the level of forfeiture that we'll have coming out of deferred comp as people leave. And
column955: we've got \u2013 we had slightly less turnover this year
column956: in the non \u2013 outside of the actions
column959:
"

So we had to change the view that we had towards the forfeiture percentages and as well as the absolute amount of deferred comp that we were going to have. And so all of that we cleaned up in the fourth quarter.

"
column961:
"

Got it. Thanks for the color.

"
column965:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Gerard Cassidy with RBC Capital Markets. Please go ahead with your question.

"
column968: everyone. This is actually Steven Duong in for Gerard. Just starting out on the credit
column969:
where do you guys see your net charge-offs going in 2015? And what would be the drivers of that?

"
column971:
"

I don't want to get into any individual line item forecasts. Obviously
column972: what we said in the prepared remarks is that the cost of credit is likely to increase. That's going to come from a combination of both. We're likely to have slightly higher NCLs. I can't tell you \u2013 just as we continue to grow the book
column973:
it's not because we see credit quality weakening anywhere. And we continue to benefit this year from loan loss reserve releases and that is certainly likely to lessen next year. So the combination of those two items will largely cause an increase in our actual reported costs of credit. But we don't see any diminution in the credit quality of the portfolio.

"
column976: great. Thank you. And just switching over to Volcker Rule on trading. Volcker Rule's been here since July. Are you guys seeing your traders maybe being a little more cautious so that they are not doing any prop trading? And just a follow-up to that
column977:
where do you see the Volcker Rule impacting liquidity in the fixed income markets?

"
column979:
"

I think Steven \u2013 it's Mike. We haven't been a proprietary skewed institution for a long time. And so I would say no
column980: that we really haven't seen those impacts
column981: that ours is predominantly a client-facing organization. I think ways that you're going to see \u2013 I think we've already seen it manifesting itself probably comes in the form of liquidity
column982: that there's just things we're not in or there's types of trades we're not going to do
column983: and in times of market disruption
column984:
I think the buy side finds it quite difficult to find liquidity in certain types of assets or in certain asset classes.

"
column985:
"

And I think that's a reality of some of those changes. And so again
column986: we've talked a bit about that we're probably going to see heightened periods of volatility as a result of that. I think you're going to see more price fluctuations around certain types of asset classes as I think bank and broker balance sheets have become more refined and defined in terms of what they do
column987:
and I think that just manifests itself in just less liquidity.

"
column990: thank you. And just last question

column992:

column994:
"

column998: great. And just looking back at \u2013 in 2014

have you guys seen any \u2013 what the early credit metrics have been on home equity book?

column1003:
"

You mean as far as the home equity loans that that have gone to full amortization or just in general?

column1008:
"

Just the full amortization portion. They have been fairly consistent with the results that we've gotten for that over the last couple of years. Slightly higher levels of delinquencies
column1009:
slightly higher NCL rate. Everything is either on track with or slightly better than the assumptions that we have built into our loan loss reserve model.

"
column1012:
that's all our questions. Thank you again.

"

"

column1031: at least what I think I said in the prepared remarks was that our trading markets will perform in line with the market. And so

we had basically flat revenues on those businesses in the second half of this year compared to the second half of last year. We'll see how 2015 goes.

column1036:
"

Okay. And then just one thing in the North America cards. You've mentioned for a couple years ago that the runoff of promotional balances has been a headwind. Is there any way you can size what that promotional balance as a percentage of the total or may be say that when you expect to actually what quarter kind of the headwind will be?

column1038:
"

No. We haven't talked to that publicly. And I quite frankly

column1040:
but I just don't have it. Sorry.

"

Your next question comes from the line of Steven Chubak with Nomura. Please go ahead with your question.

"
column1049:
I just wanted to clarify something that you had mentioned relating to the efficiency target of 55%. One of the things that --

"
column1062: okay. I suppose after applying all the adjustments that you had talked about relating to the strategic actions on a pro forma basis

column1066: is that off of the reported revenue base from this past year
column1067: is it a pro forma revenue base
column1068:
which should include some revenue attrition as you exit some of those non-core businesses?

"
column1070:
"

It would be a low single-digit growth off of where we performed in 2014. You can pro forma \u2013 I'm not going to go into every \u2013 I can't help you with your model
column1073:
"

I guess the low single digits seems reasonably conservative
column1074: but if you have all the pro forma actions that are taken to drive that improvement in the efficiency target
column1075:
it feels as though the revenue growth actually needs to be a little bit better than that. I just wanted to confirm whether that was the appropriate way to think about it or not.

column1080:
"

Okay. Then just one more for me on a topic that's garnered some attention in the press relating to the growth in your derivatives book
column1081: at least through the first nine months of 2014. I actually wanted to just inquire as to whether you're managing that \u2013 how \u2013 I guess how much more growth you can support or whether one of the important considerations we should have is the potential risk that the growth and derivatives book over the last nine months could potentially move you into a higher adjacent bucket
column1082:
based on the inputs that have just come out from the fed.

"
column1084:
"

Yes. All very good questions
column1086: let's start with the fact that what everyone's been focused on is not the growth in our book
column1087: but the growth in notionals. And notionals
column1089: really are not any sort of measure really of risk or necessarily of counter party engagement
column1090:
net counter party engagement. It's a reference sum on which then other things are calculated. So we have been working to compress the trades and what you'll see when we publish results at the end of the fourth quarter is a reduction in the reported amount of gross notionals. Those are the notionals that we had at the end of the third quarter I believe were about 65 trillion of notionals. And that's being reduced now to 60.

"
column1093:
that's really helpful. Thank you for taking my questions.

"
column1095:
"

Not a problem at all.

"
column1097:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Matt Burnell with Wells Fargo Securities. Please go ahead with your question.

"
column1099:
"

Good afternoon. Thanks for taking my question. Just one follow-up and then I'll jump offline. But John
column1100: I just wanted to confirm some of the numbers you were saying before in terms of the cost reductions that are currently in the fourth quarter run rate from the repositioning exercise
column1101: were 700 million. That's not 700 million of incremental cost benefit. That's what's currently in the run rate right now
column1102:
with another 150 to come over the next year-plus. Is that how we should be thinking about it?

"
column1107:
"

Okay. Thanks very much. I'll jump offline for my other questions.

"
column1111:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Erika Najarian with Bank of America. Please go ahead with your question.

"
column1113:
"

Yes. Just one quick one for me. As the full CCAR process is now behind you

column1115:
was it more robust and specific this year versus last year's process?

"
column1120: I would say that the CCAR process is never behind you
column1122: that the CCAR process is just part of what we do and how we run the firm. So we in essence put a submission in
column1123: but the process continues and obviously us wanting to continue to improve and continue to embed. I would say that we had terrific engagement from the fed at every level

from our onsite team to the horizontal work teams to Washington and so I think that the communication was quite good.

"
column1127: at the end of the day

column1130: we felt like that we've accomplished what it was we set out to do
column1131: but more to do as we go into the future and I think as I said in my opening remarks
column1132:
I feel good about our submission.

"
column1136:
"

Your next question is a follow-up from the line of John McDonald with Sanford Bernstein. Please go ahead with your question.

"
column1138:
"

I'm all set. Asked and answered. Thanks.

"

And we have no further questions at this time.

Great. Thank you all for joining us. If you have any follow-up questions
