column1:
{"Citigroup's (C) Q4 2014 Results - Fixed Income Investor Review Conference Transcript": ["

Citigroup Inc. (NYSE:C)

"
column2:
"

Q4 2014 Fixed Income Investor Review Conference Call

"
column6:
"

John Gerspach - Chief Financial Officer

"
column12:
"

David Knutson - Legal and General

"
column18:
"

Mark Kehoe - Goldman Sachs Asset Management

"
column19:
"

Hima Inguva - Bank of America Merrill Lynch

"
column26:
"

Hello and welcome to Citi\u2019s Fixed Income Investor Review with Chief Financial Officer
column28: Eric Aboaf. Today\u2019s call will be hosted by Peter Kapp
column29: Head of Fixed Income Investor Relations. We ask that you please hold all questions until the completion of the formal remarks at which time you will be given instructions for the question-and-answer session. Also as a reminder
column30: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column31: please disconnect at this time. Mr. Kapp
column35: Brent. Good morning and thank you all for joining us. On our call today
column38: will speak first; then Eric Aboaf
column40: will take you through the Fixed Income Investor Review materials
column41: which are available for download on our website
column42: citigroup.com. Afterwards
column43:
we will be happy to take questions.

"
column44:
"

Before we get started
column45: I would like to remind you that today\u2019s presentation may contain forward-looking statements which are based on management\u2019s current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results and capital and other financial conditions may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors
column46: including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today and those included in our SEC filings including
column47:
without limitation the Risk Factors section of our 2013 Form 10-K.

"
column48:
"

With that said
column49:
let me turn it over to John.

"
column50:
"

John Gerspach

"
column52: thank you
column54: everyone. We are pleased to be hosting our Fixed Income Investor Review this quarter. Eric Aboaf
column55: our Treasurer will review our balance sheet
column56: liquidity profile and capital position and we will provide guidance on our current funding plans for 2015. Before I turn it over to Eric
column57: however
column58:
I would like to highlight some key points from our fourth quarter and full year results on Slide 2.

"
column59:
"

Last week
column60: we reported earnings of roughly $350 million for the fourth quarter of 2014
column61: including the impact of $3.5 billion in legal and repositioning costs
column62: which we had previously disclosed. On a full year basis
column63: revenues grew slightly
column64: while core operating expenses and credit costs declined. However
column65: higher legal and repositioning costs drove a decline in net earnings to $11.5 billion. While these legal and repositioning charges had a significant impact on our results for the year
column66: we believe we took important steps to resize our operations and address our legal issues. As we said in December
column67: we believe we put a significant portion of our outstanding legal matters behind us. Although of course nothing is certain until the matters are resolved. At the same time during 2014
column68:
we continued to make progress on our key execution priorities. In consumer banking our U.S. franchise performed well and we showed modest growth in international consumer even as global economic growth remained uneven.

"
column69:
"

Our institutional businesses performed well throughout the year as we focused on serving core clients. We generated solid revenue growth in banking driven by investment banking
column70:
treasury and trade solutions and the private bank. Our markets businesses were impacted by volatility towards the end of the year and we will continue to take steps to make sure that they are sized correctly for the environment we see going forward. For the first time since its establishment Citi Holdings was profitable for the full year and we reduced its assets by 16% to below $100 billion. And we utilized $3.1 billion of deferred tax assets. During the year we managed our balance sheet carefully. Grew our loan book in Citicorp and improved both our net interest revenue and margin from 2013 levels. We continued to reduce funding costs by increasing the quality of our deposits and optimizing our debt outstanding. And our capital leverage and liquidity ratios each increased over the course of the year.

"
column71:
"

On Slide 3
column72: we show total Citigroup results adjusted for the items noted on the slide. We earned $346 million in the fourth quarter as our results were impacted by significant legal charges and repositioning costs. Revenues declined by 1% year-over-year as shown on the slide
column73: but increased 2% on a constant dollar basis
column74: while credit costs continued to fall. For full year 2014
column75: we earned $11.5 billion. Looking ahead to 2015
column76: we remain committed to delivering on our financial targets including a mid-50s efficiency ratio in Citicorp and a return on assets of at least 90 basis points for Citigroup. We believe these targets can be delivered through a combination of modest revenue growth in our core business
column77:
maintaining expense discipline to offset higher regulatory and compliance costs and realizing the cost savings from the actions we took in 2014.

"
column78:
"

And with that I will turn it over to Eric.

"
column79:
"

Eric Aboaf

"
column80:
"

Thank you
column81: John. Let me start on Slide 4 with a review of how we are managing our balance sheet to drive profitability and returns and adapt to both current and expected regulations. On a reported basis
column82: our total assets declined by $40 billion in the quarter mainly as a result of the dollar\u2019s continued appreciation against foreign currencies especially the euro
column83: yen and peso. Therefore to provide more meaningful insights into the trends of our underlying business
column84: we presented this slide in several others in today\u2019s presentation on a constant dollar basis. On this basis we have held our balance sheet roughly flat below $1.9 trillion over the past five quarters
column85:
while continuing to optimize both our assets and liabilities and supporting our client activity.

"
column86:
"

On the assets side of our balance sheet cash and investments were 27% of our assets
column87:
consistent with recent quarters as we have maintained liquid balance sheet. Net loans were unchanged year-over-year as 3% growth in Citicorp was offset by continued runoff in Citi Holdings\u2019 loans. Trading assets and liabilities increased during the second half of 2014 as increased market volatility particularly in rates and currencies increased the carrying value of our existing derivative positions. We expect these values to decline in the coming months as the shorter tenor positions runoff.

"
column88:
"

On the liabilities side
column89: we maintain a diversified stable and low-cost funding profile. Including the Japan retail bank deposits which were reclassified to held for sale during the quarter due to our announced sale agreement
column90:
deposits declined 2% as we carefully managed the quality of our deposit base under the LCR including actively reducing zero value deposits. Repo decreased 10% from last year as we strengthen our liquidity position and trading liabilities increased consistent with trading assets.

"
column91:
"

At the bottom of the page average assets grew $35 billion sequentially and were greater than ending assets
column92: mostly due to the elevated trading assets that I just mentioned. We expect average assets to decline going into 2015 though foreign exchange rates may influence the balance. Overall
column93:
we continue to actively manage the return profile of our balance sheet allocating from lower return assets to higher return opportunities while serving our clients.

"
column94:
"

Now
column95: turning to Slide 5
column96: let me discuss our loan portfolio. In constant dollars
column97: total Citigroup loans increased 1% year-over-year as 3% growth in Citicorp was offset by continued reductions in Citi Holdings loans. Consumer loans grew 2% year-over-year driven by 4% growth internationally. Corporate loans grew 4% year-over-year. Traditional corporate lending balances grew 4% with strong growth in North America as we supported transaction activity among our core clients. Trade loans decreased 8% as we maintain trade loan origination volumes
column98:
while reducing lower spread assets and increasing asset sales to optimize returns. And private banking and markets loans increased 16% led by growth in the North America private bank contributing to revenue growth in that business. Citi Holdings loans decreased 20% year-over-year mainly due to continued runoff in asset sales in North America mortgages as well as the sale of our consumer banking operations in Greece and Spain.

"
column99:
"

As John mentioned in our earnings call last week
column100: on Page 28 of the appendix
column101: we have provided information on our corporate credit portfolio
column102: including additional detail on our $60 billion of energy exposures covering both funded loans and unfunded commitments. Approximately 70% of our exposures are in the U.S.
column103:
UK and Canada. Funded loans to the energy industry amount to approximately $22 billion or roughly 3% of Citigroup\u2019s total loans. And roughly 80% of our energy exposures are rated investment grade consistent with our target market strategy and our overall corporate credit exposures. We actively manage this risk in several ways. Loan underwriting decisions are calibrated to a through the cycle perspective on commodity prices. Industry limits control our aggregate exposure to the energy industry and we actively monitor performance and manage net exposures in the event of any credit quality changes.

"
column104:
"

On Slide 6
column105: I\u2019d like to review the credit trends in Citicorp\u2019s consumer and corporate loan portfolios. On the top half of the page illustrates net credit losses in Citicorp\u2019s consumer credit portfolio across four regions. In the fourth quarter
column106: global consumer credit trends remained favorable
column107: with net credit losses of 2.33% in North America
column108: the NCL rate continued to improve to 255 basis points. Asia remains stable with net credit losses of 80 basis points. And in Latin America
column109: we have recorded roughly $70 million charge-off related to our homebuilder exposure in Mexico
column110: which was entirely offset by related loan loss reserve release. Excluding this charge-off
column111:
the NCL rate in Latin America would have improved to 467 basis points.

"
column112:
"

Although not shown on this page
column113:
credit quality in Citi Holdings also continues to improve with NCLs in the North America mortgage book declining to 130 basis points this quarter. All the losses in that portfolio were offset by reserve releases. The bottom half of the page highlights the high quality of our corporate portfolio. Non-accrual loans as a percentage of corporate loans improved slightly to 41 basis points as a charge-off of an exposure in Latin America in the quarter drove a reduction in the non-accrual loans in that region.

"
column114:
"

Now
column115: turning to Slide 7
column116: let me discuss changes in our deposit base
column117: which continues to serve as the primary source of funding for the lending activities in our banks
column118: including the Japan retail bank deposits. On a constant dollar basis
column119: total deposits declined 2% year-over-year. Consumer deposits increased 2%. North America consumer deposits increased 1% with a continued focus in growing checking account balances and despite selling or closing over 130 branches in the past year. And international consumer deposits
column120: including the Japan deposits
column121:
grew 3%. Corporate deposits increased 1% year-over-year as we saw continued strong deposit growth in North America while we actively reduced lower quality deposits. Citi Holdings and other deposits have declined year-over-year due to the transfer of MSSB deposits.

"
column122:
"

On Slide 8
column123:
we highlight the quality of our deposit franchise by carefully managing our deposit base to prioritize higher quality deposits and reduced lower value deposits. We have improved the liquidity value under the LCR and compressed the size of the balance sheet. Our deposit base is geographically diversified with approximately 55% of our deposits outside the U.S. as you can see in the left column.

"
column124:
"

The right side of the page demonstrates the improvement in the liquidity value of our deposit base under the final U.S. LCR rules. Under the LCR deposits are assigned liquidity values based on their stability and the type of clients served
column125: generally 90% to 97% for retail deposits
column126:
60% to 75% for corporate deposits and zero to 75% for financial institutions deposits. Our consumer deposits including retail and commercial banking deposits provided approximately 87% liquidity value consistently over the past year. Our institutional deposits have a 66% liquidity value and have improved steadily as we have reduced the 100% runoff deposits by nearly $30 billion over the past year. At the bottom of the page you can see that our total deposits had LCR liquidity value of 73% trending upwards driven by the reductions in the low LCR value deposits. We will continue to actively manage the quality of our deposit base.

"
column127:
"

On Slide 9
column128: we show the evolution of our net interest revenue and margin. Net interest revenue in constant dollars has continued to increase steadily. Our net interest margin improved to 292 basis points in the fourth quarter reflecting two primary factors. First
column129: we have issued long-term debt at tighter spreads in maturing our repurchase debt. This contributed to a 70 basis point improvement in our cost of long-term debt over the past year. And second
column130:
we have driven the cost of deposits down by reducing customer rates paid on deposits mindful of both the regulatory value of the deposits and local market conditions.

"
column131:
"

Looking to the first half of 2015
column132: we expect our net interest margin to remain more or less flat to full year 2014 levels. As you can see in our appendix Slide 36
column133:
we continue to expect the NIM benefit from a rising rate environment. We estimate that 100 basis point parallel rate shock would increase our net interest revenue by $1.8 billion over the first year for a NIM benefit of 11 basis points similar to recent quarters. Our exposures remains concentrated in the shorter end of the curve so that we would not expect material impact from the continued decline in long-term rates that we have recently seen.

"
column134:
"

On Slide 10
column135: let me cover our long-term debt which is the primary source of funding for our parent company and our broker-dealers and is a valuable liquidity management and supplementary funding tool for our banking subsidiaries. During 2014
column136: our total long-term debt was broadly stable. As we worked to optimize our liquidity position
column137: manage funding cost and position for current regulatory requirements
column138: we increased our bank level debt to strengthen our liquidity position and comply with the U.S. LCR rules. We continued to securitize credit card receivables and we increased our long-term FHLB advances to extend the term structure of the bank level funding at attractive funding costs. Parent company debt decreased slightly during the year. And we continued to refinance high-cost debt with new issuances at lower coupon. In 2015
column139:
we expect parent company debt to increase slightly and bank level debt to decline as we position for likely TLAC requirements.

"
column140:
"

Moving to Slide 11
column141: we cover the bank\u2019s recent securitizations activity and our issuance plans for 2015. Our securitization activity has helped us diversify the bank\u2019s funding sources and optimize the firm\u2019s liquidity position at cost-effective pricing levels. In 2014
column142:
we issued $14 billion of securitizations primarily backed by Citi branded credit cards. In 2015 we expect to issue $5 billion to $10 billion in the securitization markets continuing to support this important funding program while also considering the impact of TLAC requirements on our funding strategy which I will come to in a moment.

"
column143:
"

Slide 12 details our debt issuance and liability management activity at our parent company. During 2014 we issued $21 billion of benchmark debt and $11 billion of structured notes. Maturities for the year were $29 billion and we redeemed $10 billion of debt through tenders and other early redemptions resulting in net redemptions of $3 billion. Our issuance during 2014 was diversified as we maintain an active benchmark curve in dollars and we expanded our non-dollar debt to nearly a third of total issuance across a range of tenders. Our $10 billion of liability management activity in 2014 helped us to maintain liquid and efficiently priced benchmark curves while managing our overall funding costs.

"
column144:
"

For 2015
column145: we expect maturities of $17 billion. We also expect to continue to opportunistically repurchase outstanding debt consistent with past practice of approximately $11 billion for the year. And we expect to issue $20 billion to $25 billion of benchmark debt in 2015 and approximately $10 billion of customer related debt
column146:
resulting in net issuance in the range of zero to $5 billion for the year.

"
column147:
"

Shown on the bottom of this page
column148: in 2014 we issued approximate $4 billion of preferred stock consistent with 2013 issuance levels
column149:
bringing our additional Tier 1 capital to approximately 90 basis points of risk-weighted assets. We expect to issue approximately $4 billion of preferred stock again in 2015 as we continue to prepare for full implementation of capital requirements in 2019.

"
column150:
"

In November
column151: the FSB released a consultative document for total loss-absorbing capacity or TLAC. While the document helps to resolve some questions
column152: many uncertainties remain and we are awaiting formal U.S. guidance. On Slide 13
column153: we updated our estimate of total loss-absorbing capacity
column154: which totals $264 billion. The discussion around total loss-absorbing capacity continues to focus on a few questions
column155: what qualifies as loss-absorbing; how much loss absorbing capacity will be required; against what denominator; risk-weighted assets; total leverage assets or something else
column156:
is it measured and which entities are subject to bail-in requirement.

"
column157:
"

Consistent with our prior estimate under the FSB\u2019s proposal
column158: the primary components of TLAC include Common Equity Tier 1 capital
column159: preferred stock
column160: unsecured parent issued senior
column161: and subordinated debt with at least a year remaining until maturity and a small portion of our customer related debt. By contrast
column162: debt issued by operating subsidiaries and secured debt will likely not qualify as TLAC. Additionally
column163: certain structural features of structured notes are viewed unfavorably. We are working with industry groups to evaluate ways of improving the eligibility of these instruments. As of quarter end
column164: we estimate Citigroup\u2019s loss-absorbing capacity to be $264 billion or bit more than 20% of our risk-weighted assets
column165:
and 10.6% of our total leverage exposure. All of our estimates and expectations at this point are just that given that we do not yet have a formal proposal from the U.S. regulators.

"
column166:
"

On Slide 14
column167: we provided some context for a loss-absorbing capacity relative to the potential FSB requirements. Our estimated TLAC of $264 billion represents just over 20% of risk-weighted assets as compared to the FSB\u2019s potential requirement of 20.5% to 24.5%. This range is based on the FSB\u2019s requirement of 16% to 20%
column168:
to which we add the capital conservation buffer of 2.5% and our international GSIB surcharge of 2%.

"
column169:
"

As TLAC rules become clearer
column170: we expect to meet our requirements through an optimization of our regulatory capital position and our funding strategy. First
column171: between now and 2019
column172: we will continue to issue preferred stock and subordinated debt to satisfy our regulatory capital needs
column173: providing roughly $15 billion to $20 billion of additional TLAC over the next four years
column174: as we have previously communicated. Second
column175: as certain aspects of the rules are clarified
column176: we may also be able to adjust the terms of our structured note issuance
column177:
allowing us to continue to serve our customers needs without increasing our net issuance or funding cost with as much as $20 billion of benefit over the next four years.

"
column178:
"

And third
column179: if we need additional loss-absorbing capacity
column180: we can increase our issuance of TLAC eligible senior debt and reduce our outstanding securitizations FHLB advances and repo. The incremental cost of this issuance is marginal
column181: driven by the spread differential between our parent company senior debt and the funding we replace
column182: not the full cost of the debt issued. As a result
column183:
we believe that we have a number of avenues to manage the cost of meeting potential TLAC requirements. The Fed released an NPR for the U.S. version of the GSIB surcharge in December.

"
column184:
"

On Slide 15
column185: we highlighted the key features of the proposal and the drivers of the surcharge calculation. The U.S. NPR builds upon the international GSIB framework
column186: but includes several features that make it more stringent than those standards. Most notably
column187: the Fed\u2019s method to proposal retains four of the five systemic indicator scores under the international approach
column188: but doubles them to determine the surcharge. It then adds a short-term wholesale funding indicator
column189:
which is unique to the U.S. proposal. This last indicator was expected to increase capital requirements for firms heavily reliant on repo financing to reduce systemic risk from fire sales. Instead however it heavily penalizes non-operating deposits and is relatively lenient towards repo funding.

"
column190:
"

Under the LCR rules
column191: these non-operating deposits are effectively placed as cash at the Fed today
column192: therefore presenting no fire sale risk to either the institution or the financial system. The obvious question is how much can banks manage their GSIB surcharge
column193: which relates to some 64 individual line items across the five broad indicators? Some elements of the NPR are well-coordinated with other regulations. So
column194: our ongoing efforts to actually manage our LCR and SLR drivers
column195: for example
column196: should complement our responses to the GSIB rules. For example
column197: non-operating deposits are discouraged under the LCR and the SLR already encourages a smaller balance sheet
column198: incentives consistent with lower scores under the size and interconnectedness indicators. However
column199:
other elements of the proposal are incompatible with current regulations and therefore harder to manage. The interconnectedness indicator as an example includes the long-term debt we use to safely fund the firm.

"
column200:
"

While we believe the GSIB surcharge was intended to provide incentives to reduce size and complexity
column201: it is difficult for a bank to impact directly the surcharge calculation
column202: because there are additional factors outside management\u2019s control. The proportionality of the calculation means that the impact of any one institution\u2019s actions on its surcharge also depends on the collective actions of the other 74 GSIBs. Furthermore
column203: since the aggregate market indicators are denominated in euros
column204: U.S. institutions are disadvantaged when the dollar strengthens as their dollar denominated balance sheet translates into a larger relative proportion of the other 74 GSIBs. In light of the recent strength of the dollar
column205:
we would currently expect a 4% GSIB surcharge under these proposed U.S. rules.

"
column206:
"

Turning to Slide 16
column207: let me summarize our capital position
column208: which remains among the strongest in the industry. During the quarter
column209: our common equity Tier 1 capital ratio declined approximately 20 basis points to 10.5% driven by a pension-related reduction in OCI and an increase in operational risk
column210: RWA. Foreign exchange movement had virtually no impact on our common equity Tier 1 ratio during the quarter. Under the standardized approach
column211:
our common equity Tier 1 ratio remained stable at 11.1%. And our supplementary leverage ratio and total leverage exposure were both flat to the prior quarter. Citigroup\u2019s SLR was 6% and Citibank\u2019s estimated SLR remained in excess of 6% as well.

"
column212:
"

Turning to Slide 17
column213: I\u2019d like to update you on our liquidity profile. We currently estimate that our LCR under the U.S. rules was 112% in excess of the 100% minimum requirement and up 1 percentage point from last quarter primarily driven by deposit flows and improvements in the quality of our deposit base. Factored into the 112% LCR
column214: we have $413 billion of HQLA predominantly consisting of cash and sovereign debt with only 14% of HQLA categorized as Level 2 assets. In addition to the LCR
column215: we continue to assess the impact of the Basel committee standards regarding the net stable funding ratio
column216: the NSFR
column217: which measures our liquidity under a 12-month stress scenario. The Basel committee released its final rules in the fourth quarter
column218: which better aligned the NSFR and the LCR rules in several important ways. Based on what we know today
column219:
we believe we are in compliance with the international NSFR. We expect a proposed rule from the U.S. regulators in 2015.

"
column220:
"

Moving to our last slide let me summarize four major points. First
column221:
we saw momentum across our businesses in 2014 notwithstanding a challenging macroeconomic and market environment. We saw continued progress on a number of our execution priorities including continued utilization of our DTA and a profitable year for Citi Holdings as well as further repositioning and strategic actions to streamline our franchise.

"
column222:
"

Second
column223: we actively managed our balance sheet maintaining total assets below $1.9 trillion and optimizing our assets and liabilities to support client needs and improve returns. Credit trends remained favorable across both our consumer and corporate credit portfolios. Third
column224: our deposit base remains a key strength as we continue to prioritize our high quality deposits. Our 2015 issuance plans are designed to support our operations and position us to adapt the regulatory changes. And lastly
column225: we have continued to actually manage our balance sheet
column226:
our capital and liquidity remained strong.

"
column227:
"

This concludes our fixed income review. John and I will be happy to take your questions.

"

Let me take that from the end of the question that you asked Scott. The rating agencies have actually to their credit been in front of this question of bail-in debt at the parent versus operating company debt this \u2013 they have evolved their rating systems. I think everyone of the three agencies have cut over to a process where they think about debt as open to bail-in. They have tiered their ratings accordingly. They have been quite public in that. And so I think there isn\u2019t much more to come from there that is going to impact investors from the rating agencies. I think the rating agencies have actually been leaders in this area and they have properly sensed the evolution of the government and regulatory practices here. So I think there isn\u2019t that much on that front that will change the equation. And as such the real question will be how the U.S. begins to develop a set of rules for TLAC. They are clearly going to put a set of rules out there. We expect in the first half of the year. So there will be proposed rules open for comments. So clearly we are giving them some through the industry association the industry is providing some initial feedback on the FSB rules to the Fed and our other supervisors in the U.S. And again post the proposed rule we will do that again

column741: but would that be an incorrect assumption
column742:
are you going to be using some of those?

alright. Thanks.

column754:
"

Louise Pitt-Goldman Sachs

"
column756: good morning guys. Thanks very much for call and for the additional it is very helpful. I know I am going to beat a dead horse on the question on TRAC
column757: but there is nothing in your deductions for other GSIBs TLAC debt holdings
column758:
is that just because you don\u2019t have enough information right now because you don\u2019t have any?

"
column759:
"

Eric Aboaf

"
column760:
"

Louise
column761: it\u2019s Eric
column762: fair question. We have been working through the deductions and obviously the FSB paper is quite broad-based. I think as you have mentioned there is a deduction that they referenced for the cross holdings of debt and equity of other GSIBs. For us that would be worth potentially 0.5 point it\u2019s doing that calculation
column763: is it a daily calculation
column764:
is it in the period calculation where it could be done in different ways. I think the reason we haven\u2019t explicitly reduced these amounts by that is really for two reasons.

"
column765:
"

First
column766: if there is an active deduction for that it\u2019s one of the easiest things on the balance sheet to manage down and actually to reduce our holdings. And you can imagine like for other activities we will intervene to a reasonable amount because that might be a costly deduction. The other is that in discussions that the industry groups have begun to have with some of our regulators
column767:
they seem to have an openness to potentially thinking about a quarter or a certain amount that is allowable for these holdings of in inventory of debt or equity of other firms.

"
column768:
"

And the reason is that obviously when we market make in the debt or equity of another firm
column769: we are helping create liquidity and transparency in the marketplace that has some benefits for many investors and for the Fed as they oversee the financial system. And so we could see a way where it is possible
column770: but again it\u2019s highly uncertain
column771:
at this point we don\u2019t have any real rules. We can see where it\u2019s possible that there is a certain reasonable amount that as along as it\u2019s diversified potentially across counterparties that we hold that might be allowable.

"
column773:
"

That\u2019s really helpful. Thank you. In terms of the securities that will be TLAC eligible obviously you have excluded anything with less than one year to maturity
column774: but in thinking that they will still be at hold co and while they may not be TLAC eligible they would be bail-in of all under the tons of the regulators\u2019 view of those securities
column775:
they will still be outstanding in parity pursue at the time of any resolution. So is there any move to actually require all securities with maturities of less then one year to not actually be at the hold cos so that there is no cross default and therefore fund everything in less than one year at an operating company?

"
column777:
"

I think we have seen some \u2013 a bit of chatter on that question
column778: but it seems pretty straightforward for us that if you have debt that was issued at 10 years and 9 years later is rolling down to under a year that\u2019s debt that you have outstanding. And whether regulators think of it as TLAC eligible
column779: it\u2019s up to their discretion. As it goes below the 1-year basis
column780: will it still get bailed in? I am guessing probably
column781: but they obviously don\u2019t want to count on it. So
column783: but we don\u2019t see any particular reason why having debt that either rolls down or other small amounts of short-term liabilities that may exist in the parent would create an issue
column784: although maybe there is \u2013 we don\u2019t see a particular reason there. So
column787:
"

So
column788:
you don\u2019t see a move to issue sort of 10 non-call 9 securities or 11 non-call 10 to give you the option and forecast?

"
column789:
"

Eric Aboaf

"
column790:
"

Louise
column791: that would be a little premature at this point given we have an FSB kind of whitepaper
column792: that\u2019s what it feels like. And we don\u2019t even have a proposed U.S. rule
column793:
so not at this point.

"
column794:
"

Louise Pitt-Goldman Sachs

"
column795:
"

Okay. Just a couple of other questions. On your opportunistic redemptions that you have listed there in the past
column796:
it potentially hasn\u2019t just been a coupon or clearly visible to the investor base rationale as to why certain securities have been in any LME transactions? Is there anymore additional color you can give us in terms of what might drive those opportunistic redemptions?

column797:

Eric Aboaf

column798:
"

Yes
column799: Louise
column800: it\u2019s Eric again. I think you are referring to the redemptions and the liability management that you see on Page 12. There are really two drivers for the bonds that we tend to choose. The first is that we tend to find that we have bonds over time that trade outside of the natural credit curve. Sometimes that\u2019s rolled down. Sometimes that\u2019s debt that may have \u2013 may have smaller outstandings or where you don\u2019t see much secondary market activity
column801: but what we routinely do and for those who are interested in understanding or even guessing at what we might buyback
column802: what we routinely do is ask the question across all the outstanding debt that exists across the credit curve what might be trading north of the \u2013 of what would be that average or perhaps the top quartile credit curve that you could draw through that mix. So
column803:
that\u2019s the first one and you will see that we have been \u2013 we routinely tend to retire that debt.

"
column804:
"

The second factor is the basis. And this one I think tends to be a little more volatile and a little harder to predict. But as we look at the currency basis between dollars and euros or dollars and yen or where we may have issued that also gives us an ability to retire debt and then reissue right out on a less expensive level. And so to the extent that I described the first bit of analysis we do is a credit curve
column805: we do a merit set of that analysis on a basis adjusted credit curve and we find that there is debt that we could buyback and then reissue at more normalized levels. So
column806: those are the two drivers and we are happy to show you how some of our practices are pretty
column807:
pretty straightforward. I think that might give you some guidance.

"
column808:
"

Louise Pitt-Goldman Sachs

column809:
"

Okay

that\u2019s really helpful. Thanks again guys.

You are welcome.

column828:
plus the 2% which gets you to the 9%. And then we are planning to run at 9.5% with the 50 basis point buffer. And that\u2019s all I can tell you right now.

column829:

Pri de Silva-CreditSights

Eric Aboaf

so I just want to make sure are you still planning to operate at the 150 basis points or what\u2019s driving that small diversions from kind of 7 versus 8 to 10?

column845:
"

Brian I think it\u2019s just a little bit of rounding

But I don\u2019t think that\u2019s particularly significant as we have started more recently they should perhaps. But I think you are in the right range 7
column850:
10 it is somewhere in that area I think is fair to model.

"
column851:
"

Brian Monteleone-Barclays

"
column852:
"

Okay. We should assume that 150 basis points is the target and that the Citi ends will remain part of that?

column853:

Eric Aboaf

column854:
"

That\u2019s correct.

column855:

Okay. And the second question just around energy

column860: can you talk about what you are see in your stress tests maybe that the pockets where you do have some concerns

column862:
your ability to take collateral things like that that gave you comfort and kind of how you expect things to play out?

column864:
"

Brian
column865: it\u2019s Eric. I think there is obviously intense focus you are at Citi. But I think every bank as we consider oil and you can imagine we are stressing oil from we stressed it first on the 50s and to 40 I am sure we are working on stressing it to 30
column866: 20 and 10 right for operating purposes. And then we are going to stress it when it goes back up
column867: right because that\u2019s going to create dislocations not just happiness on the energy industry or in the stock market. So I think first you should imagine we do a lot of stress testing a lot of different ways across various parts of the energy supply chain as we talked about earlier and around the world because it can have different impacts on different economies
column868: I don\u2019t want to get into great detail because it\u2019s a long
column869:
long conversation.

"
column870:
"

I think at the same time we actively risk manage these books. And I think we would try to give you a little bit of that taste in the sense that our underwriting considers not just spot rates of pricing in oil but a range. John mentioned some of the collateral that we revalue so that we have the right amounts of protection and can either call loans or have them adjusted. We clearly have limit structures not just for aggregate energy but multiple levels down across different sectors of energy or different quality types of energy companies. And then obviously we have an ability as we see any concerns or changes we can certainly have an ability to sell certain portions of loans. We have done that before.

"
column871:
"

You have seen us talk about that as we have adjusted our books
column872: we could buy protection in the CDS markets. We could enter into a series of different actions to adjust our position. So there is I think on one hand significant amount of stress testing that you can imagine goes all the way up to the Board and even our supervisors are interested
column873: but we ourselves as bankers are first and foremost interested in how our books will perform. So
column874: you could imagine there is a significant amount of work in that front in multiple different ways of the imaginable and the unimaginable on one hand. And on the other
column875:
there is a very active risk management process that we have lot of experience in and we will continue to be active in.

"
column876:
"

Brian Monteleone-Barclays

"
column877:
"

Thanks. Thanks.

"
column878:
"

Eric Aboaf

"
column879:
"

Thank you
column880:
Brian.

"
column881:
"

Operator

"
column882:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Rob Nuccio with Income Research. Please go ahead with your question.

"
column883:
"

Rob Nuccio-Income Research

"
column884:
"

Hi
column885: thanks for taking my call. And I will just come out and say I will beat the dead horse one more time
column886:
but just when you consider your needs of debt issuance and trying to do $1 billion to $1.5 billion to keep things manageable for investors. Has that changed your shift and how much you would ultimately want to issue in U.S. dollars versus other currencies?

"
column888:
"

Rob
column889: it\u2019s Eric. No
column890: the discussion of dollar versus non-dollar is really driven by investor appetite on one hand around the world that we find it quite broad-based. We have always been a global issuer. It\u2019s driven by the credit demands
column891: the credit spreads you see in those individual markets
column892: which tends to be a little different. And so we take advantage of that. And then the foreign exchange basis
column893: because we naturally will swap most of the dead back to dollars and insulated for many currency swings. And as the basis moves in favor of one currency or another
column894: we will issue that currency. What we do like to do is to have the diversified set of issuance across multiple currencies
column895: multiple investor groups
column896: multiple geographies
column897: multiple tenors and you will see us continue to do that
column898:
because that\u2019s an optimization on one hand for the economics and it gives us a diversification of funding opportunities from a liquidity standpoint on the other.

"
column901:
great. Thanks. That\u2019s all I had.

"
column903:
"

Thank you. We have no further questions in the queue at this time.

"

"

Peter Kapp

Right. Thank you all for joining us today. If you have further questions
column906:
please reach out to us in IR.

column1:
{"Citigroup's (C) CEO Mike Corbat on Q1 2015 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Citigroup Inc. (NYSE:C)

"
column20:
"

Matt Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column21:
"

Erika Najarian - Bank of America

"
column24:
"

Chris Kotowski - Oppenheimer and Company

"
column28: and welcome to Citi's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Review with Chief Executive Officer
column29: Mike Corbat; and Chief Financial Officer
column30: John Gerspach. Today's call will be hosted by Susan Kendall
column32:
"

We ask that you please hold all questions until the completion of the formal remarks at which time you will be given instructions for the question-and-answer session. Also
column34: this conference is being recorded today. If you have any objections
column40: Brent. Good morning and thank you all for joining us. On our call today
column41: our CEO
column42: Mike Corbat will speak first. Then John Gerspach
column43: our CFO will take you through the earnings presentation
column44: which is available for download on our Web site
column45: citigroup.com. Afterwards
column46:
we will be happy to take questions.

"
column47:
"

Before we get started
column48: I would like to remind you that today's presentation may contain forward-looking statements
column49: which are based on management's current expectation
column50: and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results and capital and other financial condition may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors
column51: including the precautionary statements referenced in our discussion today
column52: and those included in our SEC filings
column55:
the risk factor section of our 2014 Form 10-K.

"
column57:
let me turn it over to Mike.

"
column58:
"

Mike Corbat

"
column59:
"

Susan
column60: thank you. Good morning
column61: everyone. Earlier today
column62: we reported earnings of $4.8 billion for the first quarter of 2015
column63: or $1.52 per share
column64: excluding the impact of CVA and DVA. It was a strong quarter overall
column65: and we accomplished a great deal by executing against our top strategic priorities. We tightly managed our expenses
column66: helping to achieve positive operating leverage in Citicorp
column67:
and we're on track to hit our financial targets for the year.

"
column68:
"

Citi Holdings was profitable again
column69: earning a $149 million. We also announced the sales of the largest business remaining in holdings
column70: OneMain
column71: as well as our credit cards business in Japan
column72: and our consumer business in Nicaragua. We have now signed deals to divest over $30 billion of the remaining assets in Citi Holdings
column73:
which were already reduced 19% over the last four quarters.

"
column74:
"

After utilizing $3.3 billion of our deferred tax asset during 2014
column75: we utilized another $1.2 billion of DTA during the first quarter. This helped Citi generate $5.3 billion in regulator capital during the quarter
column76: helping increase our common equity Tier 1 ratio to 11% on a fully implemented Basel III basis
column77:
and increase our supplementary leverage ratio to 6.4%.

"
column78:
"

The Fed did not object to our capital plan
column79: so we can now begin meaningful capital return to our shareholders. This reflects the improvements we made in our capital planning process
column80:
as we build a safer and stronger institution.

"
column81:
"

We continued the transformation of our credit cards business
column82: setting us up for growth in the U.S. with the Costco announcement
column83: and solidifying an important global relationship with MasterCard. We've simplified our products
column84: improved our technology
column85: brought in new talent
column86:
and have built a solid foundation to invest in.

"
column87:
"

While some businesses
column88: such as markets in international consumer faced revenue headwinds
column89: we had solid overall performance from our core business during the quarter. We grew loans and deposits in our core businesses
column90:
and gained wallet share among our target clients.

"
column91:
"

In ICG
column92: our banking business had a very good quarter
column93: led by investment banking in the private bank
column94:
and treasury and trade solutions revenues were up as well in constant dollars.

"
column95:
"

In markets
column96: as we previously disclosed
column97: we saw a slow start to the year in parts of fixed income
column98: including credit
column99: but our rates and currencies franchise continued to see strong client activity
column100:
and equities was roughly flat to last year.

"
column101:
"

Our U.S. consumer business posted good performance
column102: driven by growth in retail banking
column103: and international consumer revenues were flat
column104: but loans
column105: deposits
column106: and purchase sales all continued to grow
column107:
and some of the headwinds in that business should abate as we go through the year.

"
column108:
"

While I'm pleased with our first quarter accomplishments
column109: the environment
column110: both macro-economically and legally remains very challenging. Interest rates remain low
column111: economic growth is uneven
column112: and market sentiment lacks conviction. That highlights the need for us to continue simplifying our company by focusing on our target clients and markets
column113:
while driving our finite resources to where they can generate the best risk adjusted returns.

"
column114:
"

Regarding our capital planning
column115: we're committed to building on our progress to ensure we have a sustainable process that satisfies the expectations we place on our institution; a bank with unique global reach. We recognize the need to keep strengthening the CCAR process
column116: and are continuing to invest in our compliance and regulatory functions. Overall
column117: we expect to reach a headcount of 30
column118: 000 people in these functions by year end
column119: and as an example
column120: we're very focused on resolution planning
column121:
and have 600 people dedicated to it.

"
column122:
"

We're maintaining discipline across our company
column123: whether it pertains to our balance sheet
column124: risk management
column125: and expenses in light of the environment. I believe we have the right people in the right jobs to meet these challenges and our targets. As you may know
column126: Steven Bird will succeed Manuel Medina-Mora as Head of Global Consumer Bank. Francisco Aristeguieta will follow him as CEO of Asia
column127: and Jane Fraser will replace him as CEO of Latin America
column128: including Mexico. Between them
column129: these three Citi veterans have been in our company for nearly 50 years
column130:
and reflect our deep bench talent.

"
column131:
"

I also want to acknowledge the contributions of Brian Leach
column132: who is retiring from Citi at the end of the month. He's worked practically non-stop for the firm over the past nine years
column133:
and I know we would not be where we are today without him.

"
column134:
"

John will now go through the deck
column135:
and then we'll be happy to take your questions. John?

"
column136:
"

John Gerspach

"
column137:
"

Thank you
column138: Mike
column139: and good morning
column140: everyone. Starting on Slide 3
column141: I'd like to highlight a couple of items; CVA/DVA
column142: and a prior period tax change that affect the comparability of our results to last year. Excluding these items
column143: we earned $1.52 per share in the recent quarter
column144:
compared to $1.30 in the first quarter of 2014.

"
column145:
"

On Slide 4
column146: we show total Citigroup results. In the first quarter
column147: we earned $4.8 billion
column148: generating a return on assets of 105 basis points
column149: and a return on tangible common equity of 11%. Net income grew by over $660 million year-over-year
column150: with about one-third coming from our core improvement in Citicorp
column151:
and two-thirds attributable to lower legal and related expenses in Citi Holdings.

"
column152:
"

Revenues declined on a reported basis to $19.8 billion
column153: but increased slightly year-over-year in constant dollars
column154: driven by modest growth in Citicorp. Expenses declined 10% year-over-year
column155: mostly reflecting the lower legal and repositioning charges
column156: as well as a benefit from FX translation. And net credit losses improved
column157:
offset by a lower net loan loss reserve release.

"
column158:
"

In constant dollars
column159: Citigroup end-of-period loans declined 3% year-over-year to $621 billion
column160: as growth in Citicorp was more than offset by the continued wind down of Citi Holdings. Deposits also decreased 3%
column161: driven by Citi Holdings
column162:
including the reclassification of $21 billion of Japan retail deposits to held-for-sale in the fourth quarter of last year.

"
column163:
"

On Slide 5
column164: we provide more detail on first quarter revenues in constant dollars. Citicorp revenues were up 2% year-over-year
column165: driven by North America retail banking
column166: and continued strength in our institutional banking franchise
column167: partially offset by lower markets revenues. This growth in Citicorp was partially offset by lower revenues in Citi Holdings
column168:
mostly reflecting continued asset reductions.

"
column169:
"

On Slide 6
column170: we show more detail on expenses. In total
column171: Citigroup expenses declined 6% year-over-year in constant dollars
column172:
driven by a significant decline in legal and related costs in Citi Holdings. Citicorp expenses grew 1% year-over-year as growth related expenses and higher regulatory and compliance costs were partially offset by efficiency savings.

"
column173:
"

On Slide 7
column174: we show the split between Citicorp and Citi Holdings. Citicorp net income grew 5% year-over-year in the first quarter. As I just described
column175: we generated positive operating leverage in Citicorp
column176: with 2% growth in revenues
column177: and 1% growth in expense in constant dollars
column178:
and we achieved an operating efficiency ratio of 54%.

"
column179:
"

Turning to Citi Holdings; we were profitable again this quarter
column180: with nearly $150 million in net income
column181: compared to a loss of roughly $290 million last year
column182: driven mostly by the lower legal and related expenses. Citi Holdings ended the quarter with $122 billion of assets
column183:
or 7% of total Citigroup assets.

"
column184:
"

On Slide 8
column185: we show results for international consumer banking in constant dollars; revenues were roughly flat year-over-year in the first quarter
column186: reflecting modest volume growth
column187: offset by spread compression
column188: ongoing regulatory headwinds in certain markets
column189:
and the impact of prior period asset sales.

"
column190:
"

In Latin America
column191: we grew revenues in Mexico on higher loan and deposit balances
column192: as well as a rebound in card purchase sales. However
column193: this growth was offset by the impact of prior period divestitures in other markets. In Asia
column194: we saw modest growth in our retail banking franchise
column195: and wealth management revenues were stable year-over-year. However
column196: card revenues declined as higher volumes were more than offset by lower spreads. In total
column197: average loans grew 3% from last year. Card purchase sales grew 7%
column198:
and average deposits grew 5%.

"
column199:
"

Operating expenses grew 2%
column200: as the impact of volume growth and higher regulatory and compliance costs were mostly offset by ongoing efficiency savings. Credit costs declined from last year
column201:
driven by a modest net reserve release.

"
column202:
"

Slide 9
column203: shows the results for North America Consumer Banking. Net income grew 12% year-over-year
column204: on higher revenues
column205: lower operating expenses
column206: and a continued decline in net credit losses
column207: partially offset by a lower net reserve release
column208: and the impact of a tax benefit in the prior year period. Pretax earnings grew 21% from last year. Total revenues were up 4%. Retail banking revenues of $1.3 billion grew 18% from last year
column209: reflecting continued loan and deposit growth
column210: higher mortgage origination activity
column211:
and improved deposit spreads.

"
column212:
"

This quarter's results include a gain of roughly $110 million on the sale of our Texas branches
column213: as compared to a gain of $70 million last year
column214: on a sale/leaseback transaction. Branded Cards revenues of $2 billion were down slightly from last year as growth in purchase sales and improved spreads were more than offset by the impact of lower average loans
column215: mostly driven by the runoff of promotional rate balances
column216: and higher payment rates. Retail Service revenues grew slightly from last year on higher average loans
column217: and improved spreads
column218:
partially offset by contractual partner payments.

"
column219:
"

Total expenses declined 6%
column220: driven by ongoing efficiency savings
column221: as well as lower legal and repositioning costs. We continue to resize our North America retail banking business in the first quarter
column222: while also growing our average deposits
column223: loans
column224: and assets under management. Since the beginning of 2014
column225:
we have sold or closed nearly 200 branches in North America. We are focused on deepening relationships with our target clients in urban areas.

"
column226:
"

Today
column227: roughly 90% of our footprint is concentrated around seven key markets. While average deposits grew 1% year-over-year in the first quarter
column228: checking account balances grew 10%
column229: and assets under management grew 7%. Today
column230: our average deposit balance per branch is roughly $218 million
column231:
up over 20% from a year ago.

"
column232:
"

Slide 10 shows our global consumer credit trends in more detail. Overall
column233: credit remained favourable in the first quarter. In North America and Asia
column234: trends remained stable to improving; and in Latin America
column235: the NCL rate increased somewhat from last quarter on a normalized basis
column236: however
column237: the delinquency rate continue to improve
column238:
which we expect to result in lower NCL rates later in the year.

"
column239:
"

Slide 11 shows the expense trends for global consumer banking. Over the last 12 months
column240: our consumer efficiency ratio was 55%
column241: including over 200 basis points attributable to legal and repositioning charges. In the first quarter
column242: these charges were minimal
column243: and the total efficiency ratio for global consumer banking was 52.6%
column244:
down from nearly 55% in the first quarter of last year. We currently expect to improve the total consumer efficiency ratio to 52% or below for the full year of 2015.

"
column245:
"

Turning now to the institutional clients group on Slide 12; revenues of $9.1 billion in the first quarter were down slightly from last year and up 27% sequentially. Total banking revenues of $4.2 billion grew 4% from last year
column246:
and 3% from the prior quarter. Treasury and trade solution revenues of $1.9 billion were down 2% versus prior period on a reported basis.

"
column247:
"

In constant dollars
column248: TTS revenues grew 4% from last year
column249: as growth in deposit balances and spreads more than offset a decline in trade revenues. Investment banking revenues of $1.2 billion were up 14% from last year
column250: and 12% sequentially
column251:
driven by strong M&A and debt underwriting activity partially offset by lower equity underwriting revenues.

"
column252:
"

Private bank revenues of $708 million grew 6% year-over-year
column253: driven by higher client volumes and growth in capital markets products
column254: and corporate lending revenues were $445 million
column255:
up 7% from last year on higher average loans and improved fair value marks.

"
column256:
"

Total markets and security services revenues of $4.8 billion declined 6% year-over-year and grew 62% sequentially. Fixed income revenues of $3.5 billion were down 11% from last year
column257:
primarily driven by spread products partially offset by growth in rates and currencies.

"
column258:
"

As we previously disclosed
column259: we saw a slow start in spread products this year as compared to a strong first quarter last year
column260: with lower activity levels across distressed credit
column261: non-investment grades CLOs
column262: and municipals. We did see strong client activity in investment grade credit; however
column263:
these flows tend to come at lower spreads.

"
column264:
"

Turning to rates and currencies
column265: client flows were very strong this quarter in both G10 and local markets
column266: driven in part by Central Bank actions and a pickup in FX volatility. Excluding the modest loss we incurred on the Swiss franc revaluation
column267:
rates and currencies revenues would have improved by greater than 20% from last year.

"
column268:
"

Equities revenues of $873 million declined 1% year-over-year
column269: as growth in prime finance was offset by lower cash equity revenues. Sequentially
column270:
revenues grew 86% on seasonally higher activity and improved trading performance in EMEA.

"
column271:
"

In security services
column272: revenues were up 12% year-over-year and 7% sequentially
column273: reflecting increased activity and higher client balances. Total operating expenses of $4.6 billion declined 5%
column274: driven by FX translations
column275: lower legal and repositioning expenses
column276: and ongoing efficiency savings
column277:
partially offset by higher regulatory and compliance costs.

"
column278:
"

On Slide 13
column279: we show expense and efficiency trends for the institutional business. Over the last 12 months
column281:
including roughly a 140 basis points attributable to legal and repositioning charges; and our comp ratio was 28%. Currently expect to achieve a total ICG efficiency ratio closer to the midpoint of the 53% to 57% target range for the full year 2015.

"
column282:
"

Slide 14 shows the results for corporate other. Revenues were down slightly year-over-year
column283: while total operating expenses increased
column284: driven by higher legal and repositioning charges. On a sequential basis
column285: revenues improved
column286:
driven by hedging activities as well as the absence of losses from the sale of available-for-sale securities. And expenses were down as more regulatory and compliance costs were absorbed directly by the businesses.

"
column287:
"

Slide 15 shows Citi Holdings' assets
column288: which totaled $122 billion at quarter end
column289: including $31 billion of assets
column290: which had been reported in Citicorp until this quarter. Over the past few months we've made great progress in divesting these and other assets in Citi Holdings
column291: including the announced sales of our consumer businesses in Japan
column292: Peru
column293: and Nicaragua
column294: as well as OneMain Financial. We expect these sales to close this year
column295: totaling roughly $32 billion of assets
column296:
and we have several other active sales processes underway.

"
column297:
"

On Slide 16
column298: we show Citi Holdings' financial results for the quarter. A significant reduction in legal and related expenses drove most of the earnings improvement year-over-year. Total revenues of $1.8 billion were down 7%
column299: while core operating expenses fell by 13%
column300:
reflecting the continued wind down of the portfolio. And credit cards improved as lower net credit losses were partially offset by a lower net reserve release.

"
column301:
"

On Slide 17
column302: we show Citigroup's net interest revenue and margin trends. The bars represent net interest revenue per day for each quarter in constant dollars
column303:
showing a consistent growth trend year-over-year even as the contribution from Citi Holdings has begun to shrink.

"
column304:
"

Our net interest margin remained flat sequentially at 292 basis points in the first quarter
column305: and was up slightly from a year ago on improved funding costs. In the second quarter
column306:
we expect our net interest margin to decline perhaps by two to three basis points similar to the trend we've seen in prior years.

"
column307:
"

Looking to the second half of the year
column308: our results will depend in part on the timing of divestitures
column309: including OneMain and our Japanese retail business. We estimate that without these businesses on a combined basis
column310:
our net interest margin would be lower by roughly seven to eight basis points before using any part of the associated gains to redeem high cost debt.

"
column311:
"

On Slide 18
column312: we show our key capital metrics on a fully implemented Basel III basis. During the quarter
column313: our CET 1 capital ratio improved to 11%
column314: driven by retained earnings
column315: and approximately $1.2 billion of DTA utilization. Our supplementary leverage ratio improved to 6.4%
column316:
and our tangible book value grew to $57.66 per share.

"
column317:
"

In summary
column318: we delivered solid results in the first quarter with modest revenue growth and positive operating leverage in Citicorp
column319: significantly lowered legal and repositioning expenses and continued favorable credit trends. We continue to wind down Citi Holdings in an economically rational manner including several announced divestitures that we expect to close by year end. And we also strengthened our capital position
column320: ending the quarter with a CET 1 ratio of 11%
column321:
and a supplementary leverage ratio of 6.4%.

"
column322:
"

On a full year basis
column323: we remain committed to delivering our financial targets
column324: including a Citicorp efficiency ratio in the mid-50s
column325:
and as Citigroup return on assets of at least 90 basis points.

"
column326:
"

In Citicorp
column327: we continue to expect modest revenue growth in 2015. In consumer
column328: we saw healthy growth in North America retail banking this quarter
column329: as volumes continued to grow and deposit spreads improved. However
column330: international consumer revenues were flat year-over-year. This trend should improve somewhat as we progress through the year
column331: driven by continued volume growth
column332:
as we expect the pace of regulatory change and spread headwinds to abate in certain markets.

"
column333:
"

Turning to our institutional franchise
column334: we saw good momentum this quarter across corporate lending
column335: investment banking
column336: treasury and trade solutions
column337: security services and the private bank. Together
column338: these businesses represent over half of our institutional revenues
column339: and should continue to grow this year with some quarterly fluctuations. And in markets
column340:
we expect our performance in 2015 to reflect the overall environment with a goal of continuing to gain wallet share with our target clients.

"
column341:
"

In Citi Holdings
column342: we remain focused on winding down the portfolio
column343: while staying above breakeven on a full year basis. Overall
column344: we continue to expect credit cards to increase in 2015
column345: driven by loan growth as well as lower loan loss reserve releases. And we expect to keep balance sheet discipline
column346:
staying at or below our current size.

"
column347:
"

Our first quarter results provide a solid start to 2015
column348:
better demonstrating our underlying earnings power and the impact of the actions we've taken to simplify and streamline our operations.

"
column349:
"

And with that
column350:
Mike and I are happy to take any questions.

column1218: if hypothetically you sell a business for $1 billion in proceeds and you have a $100 million gain
column1219: can you buyback a $100 million of debt or a billion or is the constraining factor
column1220:
that is got to be -- the redemption cost have to be less than 100 million?

column1223: the constraining factor is the cost of the redemption. So if I've got a $100 million dollar gain
column1224: I should be able to retire debt that would generate a $100 million loss that would cancel out the gain and the loss
column1225: producing a zero impact on net income
column1226: and we would have the ongoing benefit of the debt being retired
column1227:
therefore lessening interest charges in the future periods.
